The film and its visuals developed from a deep collaboration with his college friend, screenwriter and director Barry Jenkins, that date back to when they met 17 years ago at Florida State University. Since that time the duo developed a very personal aesthetic their work inspired by fine art photography and indie cinema. Laxton, who says he first started talking about this movie with Jenkins years ago, breaks down the anatomy of the film&#8217;s pivotal scenes and reveals the who inspired the distinct look of Moonlight. data-reactid="231"><p class="column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2  _10M0Ygc4" data-reactid="232"><!-- react-text: 233 -->This weekend at the Oscars, cinematographer James Laxton is up for his first Academy Award for his work on the drama <!-- /react-text --><em data-reactid="234">Moonlight. </em><!-- react-text: 235 -->The film and its visuals developed from a deep collaboration with his college friend, screenwriter and director Barry Jenkins, that date back to when they met 17 years ago at Florida State University. Since that time the duo developed a very personal aesthetic their work inspired by fine art photography and indie cinema.<!-- /react-text --></p><p class="column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2  _10M0Ygc4" data-reactid="236"><!-- react-text: 237 -->Laxton, who says he first started talking about this movie with Jenkins years ago, breaks down the anatomy of the film&#x27;s pivotal scenes and reveals the who inspired the distinct look of <!-- /react-text --><em data-reactid="238">Moonlight</em><!-- react-text: 239 -->.<!-- /react-text --></p><p class="column small-12 The film and its visuals developed from a deep collaboration with his college friend, screenwriter and director Barry Jenkins, that date back to when they met 17 years ago at Florida State University. Since that time the duo developed a very personal aesthetic their work inspired by fine art photography and indie cinema. Laxton, who says he first started talking about this movie with Jenkins years ago, breaks down the anatomy of the film&#8217;s pivotal scenes and reveals the who inspired the distinct look of Moonlight. Go behind the scenes with James Laxton here."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThis weekend at the Oscars, cinematographer James Laxton is up for his first Academy Award for his work on the drama Moonlight. According to statistics released by the country&#8217;s national police, cited by Rappler and Human Rights Watch, more than 2,500 of those slain in the offensive were suspected drug dealers and users; another 3,600-plus were killed by unidentified vigilantes. As the nightly warfare has intensified, so has the haunting coverage by local photographers. TIME asked 12 of them&mdash;working independently or for the various wire agencies&mdash;to mine their archives, select a picture that particularly impacted them and detail its significance. African American Photographers You Should Follow Right Now"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor Black History Month, LightBox gathered a panel of experts&mdash;from major artists such as Carrie Mae Weems to curators such as Azu Nwagbogu and educators like John Edwin Mason&mdash;and asked them to each nominate one under-the-radar, exciting African American photographer. By no means a definitive list of panelists or nominees (for that, check out TIME&rsquo;s &ldquo;\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002F100photos.time.com\u002F\"\u003E100 Photos\u003C\u002Fa\u003E&rdquo; project), this is instead a personal and subjective tribute to the thriving field of contemporary African American photography.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile some artists such as Joshua Rashaad McFadden make use of archival material, others like Jasmine Murrell incorporate sculpture, while Gerald Cyrus&rsquo; work is firmly documentary in nature and Shamayim&rsquo;s is clearly fashion-based.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe nominators include Awol Erizku, artist; Azu Nwagbogu, director African Artists&rsquo; Foundation; Carrie Mae Weems, artist; Deborah Willis, chair of the Department of Photography &amp; Imaging at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; Derrick Adams, artist; Jamel Shabazz, artist; John Edwin Mason, Associate Professor at University of Virginia; Rujeko Hockley, Assistant Curator of Contemporary Art at Brooklyn Museum; Kalia Brooks, Adjunct Professor in the Photography and Imaging Department in the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; and the staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For Black History Month, LightBox gathered a panel of expertsfrom major artists such as Carrie Mae Weems to curators such as Azu Nwagbogu and educators like John Edwin Masonand asked them to each nominate one under-the-radar, exciting African American photographer. By no means a definitive list of panelists or nominees (for that, check out TIMEs ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002F100photos.time.com\u002F"},"content":["100 Photos"]}," project), this is instead a personal and subjective tribute to the thriving field of contemporary African American photography."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["While some artists such as Joshua Rashaad McFadden make use of archival material, others like Jasmine Murrell incorporate sculpture, while Gerald Cyrus work is firmly documentary in nature and Shamayims is clearly fashion-based."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The nominators include Awol Erizku, artist; Azu Nwagbogu, director African Artists Foundation; Carrie Mae Weems, artist; Deborah Willis, chair of the Department of Photography &amp; Imaging at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; Derrick Adams, artist; Jamel Shabazz, artist; John Edwin Mason, Associate Professor at University of Virginia; Rujeko Hockley, Assistant Curator of Contemporary Art at Brooklyn Museum; Kalia Brooks, Adjunct Professor in the Photography and Imaging Department in the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; and the staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem."]}],"plain":"For Black History Month, LightBox gathered a panel of experts&mdash;from major artists such as Carrie Mae Weems to curators such as Azu Nwagbogu and educators like John Edwin Mason&mdash;and asked them to each nominate one under-the-radar, exciting African American photographer. By no means a definitive list of panelists or nominees (for that, check out TIME&rsquo;s &ldquo;100 Photos&rdquo; project), this is instead a personal and subjective tribute to the thriving field of contemporary African American photography. While some artists such as Joshua Rashaad McFadden make use of archival material, others like Jasmine Murrell incorporate sculpture, while Gerald Cyrus&rsquo; work is firmly documentary in nature and Shamayim&rsquo;s is clearly fashion-based. The nominators include Awol Erizku, artist; Azu Nwagbogu, director African Artists&rsquo; Foundation; Carrie Mae Weems, artist; Deborah Willis, chair of the Department of Photography &amp; Imaging at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; Derrick Adams, artist; Jamel Shabazz, artist; John Edwin Mason, Associate Professor at University of Virginia; Rujeko Hockley, Assistant Curator of Contemporary Art at Brooklyn Museum; Kalia Brooks, Adjunct Professor in the Photography and Imaging Department in the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University; and the staff of The Studio Museum in Harlem."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EArtists, photographers and editors nominated under-the-radar, exciting African American These 6 Instagram Photographers Got a Million Followers"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWith more than 600 million monthly active users, Instagram offers great opportunities for photographers to build an audience of dedicated fans. But convincing a million of those people to follow you is a feat generally reserved for superstars, brands and a handful of influencers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EYet, with a few well-employed tricks and excellent photography skills, these five photographers have managed to approach and even exceed that mark.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHere is how they did it and what they have learned along the way.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["With more than 600 million monthly active users, Instagram offers great opportunities for photographers to build an audience of dedicated fans. Sometimes, it&#8217;s just not worth the risk of disappointing your audience. That state of mind works against Instagram&#8217;s growth targets &mdash; and that&#8217;s why the image-sharing app has introduced new features over the past year that move away from curated photography in favor of instant visual communication. The trend started with Instagram Stories, those Snapchat-like visual diaries that disappear after 24 hours. Now, Instagram is introducing another of its most requested features: the photo album. InstagramBlue dots below each post let you know there are more photos to see Starting today, users will be able to share up to 10 photos and videos in a single post. While captions and location tags will apply to the entire set of images, filters and edits can be applied to individual photographs or all at once. You can also tap and hold on the photos and videos to change their order within your sequence. &#8220;In feed, you&#8217;ll see blue dots at the bottom of these posts to let you know you can swipe to see more,&#8221; says Instagram in a blog post. Advertisers have had this feature since 2015, but everyday users are getting access for the first time. InstagramYou can select up to 10 photos and videos to share The new feature, which will roll out to all users in the coming weeks, comes after Instagram recently added the ability to bookmark posts from other users, turn off comments and remove followers from private accounts."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EYou can now share multiple images or videos in a single news, reviews, how-to's and analysis of smartphones, tablets, computers, apps, video games, streaming media, innovation, social networks and more","parent":0,"count":7975,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","tech"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4677598,"date":"2017-02-22T07:00:11","date_gmt":"2017-02-22T12:00:11","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4677598"},"modified":"2017-02-22T07:00:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-22T12:00:00","slug":"arrival-oscar-cinematography","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677598\u002Farrival-oscar-cinematography\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Inside the Cinematography of the Oscar-Nominated Movie \u003Ci\u003EArrival\u003C\u002Fi\u003E"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;Cautious, yet mystified, Louise takes another bold action: She steps for the boundary. The light from that mist on the other side of that glass illuminates her face, showing her wonderment.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn the surprise hit movie \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4565975\u002Famy-adams-arrival\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EArrival\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which is nominated for eight Academy Awards, linguistics professor Louise Banks (played by Amy Adams), is tasked with interpreting the language of a race of visiting aliens. In a dark, cavernous chamber aboard their spaceship, Louise moves from the shadows to the light &ndash; a dance that&rsquo;s mirrored throughout the movie as the character slowly comes to terms with the true lessons the arrival brings.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;I think that journey from darkness to light is her journey,&rdquo; says \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fbradfordyoung.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EBradford Young\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,\u003Cem\u003E Arrival\u003C\u002Fem\u003E&rsquo;s cinematographer. Born in Louisville, Ky., Young has made his reputation with like \u003Cem\u003EA Most Violent Year\u003C\u002Fem\u003E and \u003Cem\u003ESelma\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, in which his mastery of available light helped convey the stories&rsquo; intimate natures. And that&rsquo;s what \u003Cem\u003EArrival\u003C\u002Fem\u003E&rsquo;s director Denis Villeneuve was looking for when he embarked on his first science-fiction film.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;I was looking for a cinematographer with a very precise sensibility towards natural light,&rdquo; Villeneuve tells TIME. &ldquo;I wanted the movie to have strong roots in realism. I wanted a cinematographer who would not be afraid to deal with intimacy. It&rsquo;s a very specific sensibility that I felt in Bradford&rsquo;s previous work.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENowhere else is this play on light more apparent then aboard the spaceship, in the gloomy chamber where Louise spends much of her time. Villeneuve says that the set was specifically designed to be ominous and dark, a place where light is absorbed rather than reflected, a place that subliminally represents death. &ldquo;The main character is in a relationship with death,&rdquo; says Villeneuve. &ldquo;The more she learns about the Heptapod [alien] culture, the more it changes her perception of life, death and time.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4678276\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677598\u002Farrival-oscar-cinematography\u002Farrival-3\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Farrival-cinematography-oscars-97.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,1600\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"3.5\",\"credit\":\"Photo credit: Jan Thijs\",\"camera\":\"Canon EOS 5D Mark III\",\"caption\":\"A scene from the film ARRIVAL by Paramount Pictures\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1437790058\",\"copyright\":\"Photo credit: Jan Thijs\",\"focal_length\":\"28\",\"iso\":\"3200\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.0125\",\"title\":\"ARRIVAL\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"ARRIVAL\" data-image-description=\"pA scene inside the spaceships chamber from the film Arrival by Paramount Pictures\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Farrival-cinematography-oscars-97.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Farrival-cinematography-oscars-97.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Farrival-cinematography-oscars-97.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=350\" alt=\"A scene inside the spaceship's chamber from the film \"Arrival\" by Paramount Pictures\" height=\"350\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EJan Thijs\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EA scene inside the spaceship&#8217;s chamber from the film &#8220;Arrival&#8221; by Paramount Pictures\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat&rsquo;s where \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.kmreps.net\u002Fpatrice_vermette.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EPatrice Vermette\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, the film&rsquo;s production designer, comes in. &ldquo;With any movies I do, my process is very similar,&rdquo; Vermette tells TIME. &ldquo;I start by creating mood boards and collections of images that are only emotional reactions to the script. It could be colors, lights, marbles, rocks.&rdquo; Then, he and the director work out where to go with that inspiration. In this case, both men were deeply influenced by the artist \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fjamesturrell.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJames Turrell\u003C\u002Fa\u003E&rsquo;s Shallow Space Constructions, a series of artworks that use light and space to question the nature of human perception. &ldquo;When I saw hundreds of people being hypnotized by James Turrell&rsquo;s light, I had an epiphany,&rdquo; says Villeneuve.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe cavernous chamber was born out of that experience. It is designed like a dark temple where the film&rsquo;s characters come to see the light &ndash; in this case, the aliens who remain semi-hidden behind a blinding rectangular white screen. Instead of using green screens, Vermette and his team actually built the ship&rsquo;s chamber. The physical space was humbling and also helped the director and cinematographer set up their shots, Villeneuve days, but the chamber&#8217;s bright screen was a challenge for Young.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5331998482001\" data-video-id=\"5331998482001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;We had to be fearless,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;We had to accept the fact that when Louise&rsquo;s very far from the screen she would be quite dark, and when she&rsquo;s right up on the screen, we would, for lack of a better term, overexpose her.&rdquo; But that was the point, he adds. &ldquo;This movie is about Louise&rsquo;s personal enlightenment. So you just submit to what the light offers and let that tell the story. It gave us the opportunity to let the lighting of the film mirror the journey of the character.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat concept is replicated in two other locations throughout the movie. In Louise&rsquo;s home, a large wall-to-wall window opens up to a blinding, yet hazy, lake, contrasting with the deliberate darkness of her living room. And inside the brutalist, fortress-like architecture of Louise&rsquo;s university, she faces a rectangular white board that opens up to a television announcing the aliens&rsquo; arrival. Again, light and darkness are at play, informing Louise&rsquo;s journey.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;The structure of all these places work together,&rdquo; says Young. &ldquo;Those places make the spaceship that much more important and the spaceship makes those places that much more important. They are in a conversation with one another. They remind us of where Louise came from and where she&rsquo;s headed.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOutside of the spaceship, Young was inspired by the work of photographer \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.martinahooglandivanow.com\u002Fwork\u002Fspeedway\u002Findex.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMartina Hoogland Ivanow\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to create a sense of dread and chaos in direct opposition to the Zen-like nature of Louise&rsquo;s safe and sacred zones. In her book, \u003Cem\u003ESpeedway\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, Ivanow creates gloomy, ominous images from mundane situations: a simple landscape becomes a Twin Peaks-like world where the unknown could be lurking in the dark; a motorcycle pilot is transformed into a shadowy, threatening figure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4678278\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677598\u002Farrival-oscar-cinematography\u002Fmhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2000,1614\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"EskoScan F14\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"mhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm\" data-image-description=\"pFrom the series Speedway\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmhi_speedway_nr01___h30cm.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=452\" alt=\"Martina Hoogland Ivanow\" height=\"452\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EMartina Hoogland Ivanow\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EFrom the series &#8220;Speedway&#8221;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn \u003Cem\u003EArrival\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, this is in play when we enter the military&rsquo;s compound set up near the spaceship. &ldquo;The calmness of the ship&rsquo;s chamber is in contrast with the interior of the tents,&rdquo; says Vermette. &ldquo;We realize that it&rsquo;s the human beings that are disturbing the peace and we can&rsquo;t wait to get back inside the spaceship.&rdquo; Toward the light &ndash; the one controlled by the aliens and the one under Young&rsquo;s spell. &ldquo;A light that brings a lot of intimacy, sensuality, fragility and humanity to the project,&rdquo; says Villeneuve.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOlivier Laurent \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.wordpress.com\u002Fmentions\u002Folivierclaurent\u002F' class='mention'\u003E\u003Cspan class='mentions-prefix'\u003E@\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Eolivierclaurent\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Cautious, yet mystified, Louise takes another bold action: She steps for the boundary. A light that brings a lot of intimacy, sensuality, fragility and humanity to the project, says Villeneuve."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Olivier Laurent "]},"is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}," @olivierclaurent"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"&ldquo;Cautious, yet mystified, Louise takes another bold action: She steps for the boundary. The light from that mist on the other side of that glass illuminates her face, showing her wonderment.&rdquo; In the surprise hit movie Arrival, which is nominated for eight Academy Awards, linguistics professor Louise Banks (played by Amy Adams), is tasked with interpreting the language of a race of visiting aliens. In a dark, cavernous chamber aboard their spaceship, Louise moves from the shadows to the light &ndash; a dance that&rsquo;s mirrored throughout the movie as the character slowly comes to terms with the true lessons the arrival brings. &ldquo;I think that journey from darkness to light is her journey,&rdquo; says Bradford Young, Arrival&rsquo;s cinematographer. Born in Louisville, Ky., Young has made his reputation with like A Most Violent Year and Selma, in which his mastery of available light helped convey the stories&rsquo; intimate natures. And that&rsquo;s what Arrival&rsquo;s director Denis Villeneuve was looking for when he embarked on his first science-fiction film. &ldquo;I was looking for a cinematographer with a very precise sensibility towards natural light,&rdquo; Villeneuve tells TIME. &ldquo;I wanted the movie to have strong roots in realism. I wanted a cinematographer who would not be afraid to deal with intimacy. It&rsquo;s a very specific sensibility that I felt in Bradford&rsquo;s previous work.&rdquo; Nowhere else is this play on light more apparent then aboard the spaceship, in the gloomy chamber where Louise spends much of her time. Villeneuve says that the set was specifically designed to be ominous and dark, a place where light is absorbed rather than reflected, a place that subliminally represents death. &ldquo;The main character is in a relationship with death,&rdquo; says Villeneuve. &ldquo;The more she learns about the Heptapod [alien] culture, the more it changes her perception of life, death and time.&rdquo; Jan ThijsA scene inside the spaceship&#8217;s chamber from the film &#8220;Arrival&#8221; by Paramount Pictures That&rsquo;s where Patrice Vermette, the film&rsquo;s production designer, comes in. &ldquo;With any movies I do, my process is very similar,&rdquo; Vermette tells TIME. &ldquo;I start by creating mood boards and collections of images that are only emotional reactions to the script. It could be colors, lights, marbles, rocks.&rdquo; Then, he and the director work out where to go with that inspiration. In this case, both men were deeply influenced by the artist James Turrell&rsquo;s Shallow Space Constructions, a series of artworks that use light and space to question the nature of human perception. &ldquo;When I saw hundreds of people being hypnotized by James Turrell&rsquo;s light, I had an epiphany,&rdquo; says Villeneuve. The cavernous chamber was born out of that experience. It is designed like a dark temple where the film&rsquo;s characters come to see the light &ndash; in this case, the aliens who remain semi-hidden behind a blinding rectangular white screen. Instead of using green screens, Vermette and his team actually built the ship&rsquo;s chamber. The physical space was humbling and also helped the director and cinematographer set up their shots, Villeneuve days, but the chamber&#8217;s bright screen was a challenge for Young. &ldquo;We had to be fearless,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;We had to accept the fact that when Louise&rsquo;s very far from the screen she would be quite dark, and when she&rsquo;s right up on the screen, we would, for lack of a better term, overexpose her.&rdquo; But that was the point, he adds. &ldquo;This movie is about Louise&rsquo;s personal enlightenment. So you just submit to what the light offers and let that tell the story. It gave us the opportunity to let the lighting of the film mirror the journey of the character.&rdquo; That concept is replicated in two other locations throughout the movie. In Louise&rsquo;s home, a large wall-to-wall window opens up to a blinding, yet hazy, lake, contrasting with the deliberate darkness of her living room. And inside the brutalist, fortress-like architecture of Louise&rsquo;s university, she faces a rectangular white board that opens up to a television announcing the aliens&rsquo; arrival. Again, light and darkness are at play, informing Louise&rsquo;s journey. &ldquo;The structure of all these places work together,&rdquo; says Young. &ldquo;Those places make the spaceship that much more important and the spaceship makes those places that much more important. They are in a conversation with one another. They remind us of where Louise came from and where she&rsquo;s headed.&rdquo; Outside of the spaceship, Young was inspired by the work of photographer Martina Hoogland Ivanow to create a sense of dread and chaos in direct opposition to the Zen-like nature of Louise&rsquo;s safe and sacred zones. In her book, Speedway, Ivanow creates gloomy, ominous images from mundane situations: a simple landscape becomes a Twin Peaks-like world where the unknown could be lurking in the dark; a motorcycle pilot is transformed into a shadowy, threatening figure. Martina Hoogland IvanowFrom the series &#8220;Speedway&#8221; In Arrival, this is in play when we enter the military&rsquo;s compound set up near the spaceship. &ldquo;The calmness of the ship&rsquo;s chamber is in contrast with the interior of the tents,&rdquo; says Vermette. &ldquo;We realize that it&rsquo;s the human beings that are disturbing the peace and we can&rsquo;t wait to get back inside the spaceship.&rdquo; Toward the light &ndash; the one controlled by the aliens and the one under Young&rsquo;s spell. &ldquo;A light that brings a lot of intimacy, sensuality, fragility and humanity to the project,&rdquo; says Villeneuve. Olivier Laurent is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on Twitter and Instagram @olivierclaurent Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDirector Denis Villeneuve and cinematographer Bradford Young explain how they created the Arrival&#8217;s visual Your Smartphone Photos To Life With a Portable Printer"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ESmartphones have done generally wonderful things for photography. By putting a camera in millions of people&#8217;s pockets, they&#8217;ve greatly democratized the art form. In terms of photo quality, the latest flagship smartphones can go toe-to-toe with basic point-and-shoots any day of the week. And thanks to social media and data plans, it&#8217;s never been easier to share your creativity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut along the way to Instagram and Snapchat, we lost something special: Printed photos. There&#8217;s something magical about turning an image into a real, tangible thing you can hold and share. That&#8217;s not just me talking nonsense. We&#8217;re in the middle of a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4649188\u002Ffilm-photography-industry-comeback\u002F\"\u003Efilm photography renaissance\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as the cultural pendulum swings from the digital back to the analog. (It&#8217;s similar to what&#8217;s happening with \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2016\u002F04\u002F16\u002Fvinyl-sales-record-store-day\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Evinyl records\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThankfully, a handful of new gadgets can help you capture some of that film photography magic without the hassle of old-school cameras or darkrooms. These three portable printers connect to your smartphone over Wi-Fi or Bluetooth, then produce business card-sized prints that you can stick on the fridge or share with your friends.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHere&#8217;s what I liked and disliked about each after testing all of them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHP Sprocket (\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fgp\u002Fproduct\u002FB01LBWEMP4\u002Fref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=timetechphotoprinters-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B01LBWEMP4&amp;linkId=0b3397f99a3a3f9692a63cb2f00ddd9b\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E$130 at Amazon\u003C\u002Fa\u003E | \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fgp\u002Fproduct\u002FB01LW1AL6Y\u002Fref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?ie=UTF8&amp;tag=timetechphotoprinters-20&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325&amp;linkCode=as2&amp;creativeASIN=B01LW1AL6Y&amp;linkId=1e03e74ad78513102f7155f485a80ef4\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFilm $10 for 20 images\u003C\u002Fa\u003E)\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg Sprocket\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EWhat I liked: \u003C\u002Fem\u003EHP&#8217;s printer made some of the nicest prints of the bunch. It&#8217;s also tiny and light enough to stick into your bag and take to your next party or on your next trip. After you print a photo, you can choose to peel a layer off the back to turn it into a sticker, which is lots of fun. HP&#8217;s companion app, meanwhile, is dead simple to use.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EWhat I didn&#8217;t like:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E I noticed some vertical lines when examining my prints carefully, but this isn&#8217;t pro-level printing gear we&#8217;re talking about here. I also had to restart my phone to get the Sprocket to connect the first time, though it was solid thereafter.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EFujifilm Instax SHARE SP-2 (\u003Ca Like the HP Sprocket, it uses ZINK film that can turn into a sticker. Polaroid's app is straightforward enough."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["What I didn't like: "]},"The prints are oversaturated and have too much contrast for my tastes, but you may enjoy the effect. For some reason, the Polaroid app made me crop my photos. The HP didn't do that despite using the same type and size film."]}],"plain":"Smartphones have done generally wonderful things for photography. By putting a camera in millions of people&#8217;s pockets, they&#8217;ve greatly democratized the art form. In terms of photo quality, the latest flagship smartphones can go toe-to-toe with basic point-and-shoots any day of the week. And thanks to social media and data plans, it&#8217;s never been easier to share your creativity. But along the way to Instagram and Snapchat, we lost something special: Printed photos. There&#8217;s something magical about turning an image into a real, tangible thing you can hold and share. That&#8217;s not just me talking nonsense. We&#8217;re in the middle of a film photography renaissance as the cultural pendulum swings from the digital back to the analog. (It&#8217;s similar to what&#8217;s happening with vinyl records.) Thankfully, a handful of new gadgets can help you capture some of that film photography magic without the hassle of old-school cameras or darkrooms. These three portable printers connect to your smartphone over Wi-Fi or Bluetooth, then produce business card-sized prints that you can stick on the fridge or share with your friends. Here&#8217;s what I liked and disliked about each after testing all of them. HP Sprocket ($130 at Amazon | Film $10 for 20 images) HPHP Sprocket What I liked: HP&#8217;s printer made some of the nicest prints of the bunch. It&#8217;s also tiny and light enough to stick into your bag and take to your next party or on your next trip. After you print a photo, you can choose to peel a layer off the back to turn it into a sticker, which is lots of fun. HP&#8217;s companion app, meanwhile, is dead simple to use. What I didn&#8217;t like: I noticed some vertical lines when examining my prints carefully, but this isn&#8217;t pro-level printing gear we&#8217;re talking about here. I also had to restart my phone to get the Sprocket to connect the first time, though it was solid thereafter. Fujifilm Instax SHARE SP-2 ($162 at Amazon | Film $13 for 20 images) FujifilmFujifilm Instax Share SP-2 What I liked: Prints from Fuji&#8217;s SP-2 need a few minutes to develop, which gave me all sorts of Polaroid nostalgia &mdash; it&#8217;s incredible to watch nothingness become somethingness. The prints also have a Polaroid-style white border that I like. And if you have a Fuji camera (which I happen to love) with wireless connectivity, you can send photos directly to the SP-2, no smartphone necessary. What I didn&#8217;t like: The SP-2 is notably bulkier than the other two models listed here, though it&#8217;s definitely still portable. Fuji&#8217;s photos don&#8217;t turn into stickers, which is decidedly less fun. And Fuji&#8217;s app, while perfectly functional, badly needs a design refresh. Polaroid Zip ($127 at Amazon | Film $10 for 30 images) PolaroidPolaroid Zip What I liked: It&#8217;s the smallest of the bunch&mdash;about the size and shape of a sleek portable hard drive. Like the HP Sprocket, it uses ZINK film that can turn into a sticker. Polaroid&#8217;s app is straightforward enough. What I didn&#8217;t like: The prints are oversaturated and have too much contrast for my tastes, but you may enjoy the effect. For some reason, the Polaroid app made me crop my photos. The HP didn&#8217;t do that despite using the same type and size film."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThese are the best models out Haitian Refugees Are Stranded at the U.S.-Mexico Border"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe majority of the migrants who wound up in the refugee centers of Tijuana used to come from South and Central American countries &ndash; from Guatemala to Colombia and Nicaragua. But in recent months, that&#8217;s changed. Thousands of Haitian migrants are crowding the centers, hoping to cross the border into the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMost of them have come via Brazil, embarking on the same long and arduous journey that has been a mainstay of cross-American immigration for decades. Following the 7.0-magnitude earthquake that destroyed swaths of their island in 2010, thousands of Haitians had found \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fhaitian-migrants-turn-toward-brazil\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Erefuge\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in Brazil, benefiting from a growing economy in the years leading to the 2014 Soccer World Cup and 2016 Olympic Games. They worked on construction sites across Rio de Janeiro &mdash; building new stadiums, new transportation systems, new condominiums. Now, with the limelight gone, the jobs have disappeared.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThat&#8217;s when the U.S. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.latimes.com\u002Fworld\u002Fmexico-americas\u002Fla-fg-haiti-deportations-20161012-snap-story.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ethrew\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Haitians a lifeline. Following Hurricane Matthews, which \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4522707\u002Fhurricane-matthew-haiti\u002F\"\u003Ekilled\u003C\u002Fa\u003E more than 500 people and left 1.4 million homeless in Haiti in October, President Obama&#8217;s administration announced it would stop deporting Haitians. When the news spread, thousands crossed the Amazon into Peru, going on to cross Ecuador, Colombia, Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Guatemala and the whole of Mexico, ending in Tijuana. There, they either wait for an asylum appointment with the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency or attempt to cross the border on their own.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;When there are no more jobs, they go somewhere else,&#8221; says Magnum photographer Jerome Sessini, who spent eight days in January in Tijuana. &#8220;It&rsquo;s always the same, the exploitation of labor. It knows no color, no nationalities.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4675314\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674517\u002Fimmigration-haiti-mexico\u002Fmexico-tijuana-december-17-2016-the-border-cross-to-usa-in-tijuana\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-11.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"3000,2250\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.8\",\"credit\":\"Jerome Sessini\",\"camera\":\"E-M1\",\"caption\":\"MEXICO. Dec. 17, 2016.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, tens of thousands of Haitians wait for, they hope, a chance at a better life in the U.S. In one church near the border, more than 400 Haitians have found refuge. &#8220;They are well taken care off there,&#8221; Sessini tells TIME. &#8220;But you see the same things as anywhere else around the world: hundreds of refugees sleeping on the floor in crowded rooms.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn recent months, the U.S. has slowly admitted some women and children, says Sessini, but as a whole their future remains \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4652918\u002Fdonald-trump-immigration-ban-muslim-protests\u002F\"\u003Euncertain\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. With a new administration in power, most fear the door will close on them, forcing them to take to the road. Following Hurricane Matthews, which ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4522707\u002Fhurricane-matthew-haiti\u002F"},"content":["killed"]}," more than 500 people and left 1.4 million homeless in Haiti in October, President Obama's administration announced it would stop deporting Haitians. It knows no color, no nationalities.\""]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4675314","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-11.jpg?w=560","alt":"The border crossing between Mexico and the U.S. in Tijuana, Mexico. Dec. 17, 2016.","width":"560","height":"420"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["The border crossing between Mexico and the U.S. in Tijuana, Mexico. Dec. 17, 2016."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Jerome SessiniMagnum"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now, tens of thousands of Haitians wait for, they hope, a chance at a better life in the U.S. In one church near the border, more than 400 Haitians have found refuge. \"They are well taken care off there,\" Sessini tells TIME. \"But you see the same things as anywhere else around the world: hundreds of refugees sleeping on the floor in crowded rooms.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In recent months, the U.S. has slowly admitted some women and children, says Sessini, but as a whole their future remains ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4652918\u002Fdonald-trump-immigration-ban-muslim-protests\u002F"},"content":["uncertain"]},". Yet again."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Jerome Sessini"]}," is a photojournalist represented by Magnum Photos."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Olivier Laurent "]},"is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}," @olivierclaurent"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"The majority of the migrants who wound up in the refugee centers of Tijuana used to come from South and Central American countries &ndash; from Guatemala to Colombia and Nicaragua. But in recent months, that&#8217;s changed. Thousands of Haitian migrants are crowding the centers, hoping to cross the border into the U.S. Most of them have come via Brazil, embarking on the same long and arduous journey that has been a mainstay of cross-American immigration for decades. Following the 7.0-magnitude earthquake that destroyed swaths of their island in 2010, thousands of Haitians had found refuge in Brazil, benefiting from a growing economy in the years leading to the 2014 Soccer World Cup and 2016 Olympic Games. They worked on construction sites across Rio de Janeiro &mdash; building new stadiums, new transportation systems, new condominiums. Now, with the limelight gone, the jobs have disappeared. That&#8217;s when the U.S. threw Haitians a lifeline. Following Hurricane Matthews, which killed more than 500 people and left 1.4 million homeless in Haiti in October, President Obama&#8217;s administration announced it would stop deporting Haitians. When the news spread, thousands crossed the Amazon into Peru, going on to cross Ecuador, Colombia, Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Guatemala and the whole of Mexico, ending in Tijuana. There, they either wait for an asylum appointment with the U.S. Customs and Border Protection agency or attempt to cross the border on their own. &#8220;When there are no more jobs, they go somewhere else,&#8221; says Magnum photographer Jerome Sessini, who spent eight days in January in Tijuana. &#8220;It&rsquo;s always the same, the exploitation of labor. It knows no color, no nationalities.&#8221; Jerome Sessini&mdash;MagnumThe border crossing between Mexico and the U.S. in Tijuana, Mexico. Dec. 17, 2016. Now, tens of thousands of Haitians wait for, they hope, a chance at a better life in the U.S. In one church near the border, more than 400 Haitians have found refuge. &#8220;They are well taken care off there,&#8221; Sessini tells TIME. &#8220;But you see the same things as anywhere else around the world: hundreds of refugees sleeping on the floor in crowded rooms.&#8221; In recent months, the U.S. has slowly admitted some women and children, says Sessini, but as a whole their future remains uncertain. With a new administration in power, most fear the door will close on them, forcing them to take to the road. Yet again. Jerome Sessini is a photojournalist represented by Magnum Photos. Olivier Laurent is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on Twitter and Instagram @olivierclaurent Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMagnum photographer Jerome Sessini reports back from 2016.","width":3000,"height":2250,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674517\u002Fimmigration-haiti-mexico\u002Fphoto\u002Folympus-digital-camera-72\u002F","encoded_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674517\u002Fimmigration-haiti-mexico\u002Fphoto\u002Folympus-digital-camera-72\u002F","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"These+Haitian+Refugees+Are+Stranded+at+the+U.S.-Mexico+Border","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Folympus-digital-camera-72%2F","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Folympus-digital-camera-72%2F","email_title":"These%20Haitian%20Refugees%20Are%20Stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20Border","twitter_text":"These%20Haitian%20refugees%20are%20stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20border","fb_text":"These%20Haitian%20refugees%20are%20stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20border","email_body":"These%20Haitian%20Refugees%20Are%20Stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20Border%0A%0AMagnum%20photographer%20Jerome%20Sessini%20reports%20back%20from%20Tijuana%2C%20Mexico%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Folympus-digital-camera-72%2F","src":{"small":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=360","small_2x":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=720","landscape_large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=360","large_2x":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=745","square":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1","fullscreen_fhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=1440","fullscreen_qhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-08.jpg?quality=85&w=1920"}},{"id":4675312,"title":"Haitian quare":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-09.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1","fullscreen_fhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-09.jpg?quality=85&w=1440","fullscreen_qhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-09.jpg?quality=85&w=1920"}},{"id":4675313,"title":"MEXICO. Tijuana. December 18, 2016.Tijuana and the border fence seen from USA.","width":3000,"height":2250,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674517\u002Fimmigration-haiti-mexico\u002Fphoto\u002Fmexico-tijuana-december-18-2016-tijuana-and-the-border-fence-seen-from-usa\u002F","encoded_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674517\u002Fimmigration-haiti-mexico\u002Fphoto\u002Fmexico-tijuana-december-18-2016-tijuana-and-the-border-fence-seen-from-usa\u002F","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"These+Haitian+Refugees+Are+Stranded+at+the+U.S.-Mexico+Border","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Fmexico-tijuana-december-18-2016-tijuana-and-the-border-fence-seen-from-usa%2F","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Fmexico-tijuana-december-18-2016-tijuana-and-the-border-fence-seen-from-usa%2F","email_title":"These%20Haitian%20Refugees%20Are%20Stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20Border","twitter_text":"These%20Haitian%20refugees%20are%20stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20border","fb_text":"These%20Haitian%20refugees%20are%20stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20border","email_body":"These%20Haitian%20Refugees%20Are%20Stranded%20at%20the%20U.S.-Mexico%20Border%0A%0AMagnum%20photographer%20Jerome%20Sessini%20reports%20back%20from%20Tijuana%2C%20Mexico%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4674517%2Fimmigration-haiti-mexico%2Fphoto%2Fmexico-tijuana-december-18-2016-tijuana-and-the-border-fence-seen-from-usa%2F","src":{"small":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=360","small_2x":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=720","landscape_large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=360","large_2x":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=745","square":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=600&h=600&crop=1","fullscreen_fhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=1440","fullscreen_qhd":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmexico-wall-haiti-tijuana-jerome-sessini-10.jpg?quality=85&w=1920"}}]},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":114694,"name":"Refugees","slug":"refugees","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":1079,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":303,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","world"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4674482,"date":"2017-02-17T15:26:38","date_gmt":"2017-02-17T20:26:38","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4674482"},"modified":"2017-02-17T18:08:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-17T23:08:00","slug":"guatemala-boys-murder-school-funeral","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674482\u002Fguatemala-boys-murder-school-funeral\u002F","title":{"rendered":"In Guatemala, Even Walking to School Can Turn Deadly"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAs photojournalists we sometimes see people on the worst days of their lives. In Guatemala this week, I was with families whose sons had been kidnapped on their way to school, their hands and feet bound and their bodies thrown into sacks.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI first learned about the killings on social media, as both my driver and I were following the local Guatemalan news of what&#8217;s called the \u003Cem\u003Enota roja\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, usually spot news and mostly about crime. I lived in Mexico and Central America for about seven years earlier in my career, and I still have good friends&mdash;both writers and photojournalists&mdash;who work throughout that region, who I can count on to help me on the ground when news is breaking. Our profession, even globally, is small and the relationships we make along the way serve us for our entire careers.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI&#8217;ve been photographing immigration and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4537222\u002Fphotographs-usa-border-mexico\u002F\"\u003Eborder security\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as a staffer for Getty Images for most of the last decade, and I try to approach the issues broadly. I spend a lot of time on the southern U.S. border, both with the border agents, whose job it is to enforce the law, and with the immigrants in shelters, before and after they attempt to cross. I also reach out to immigrant support groups that aim to make their lives better and help them integrate easier into American society.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis 10-day trip to Guatemala, planned for months with my editor, was part of my effort to show the root causes of illegal immigration and to put a more human face on the issue. The funeral was on the last day.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe village, along an unpaved road on a steep hillside, is near the area of San Juan Sacatep&eacute;quez is more than an hour west of Guatemala City. The people are mostly indigenous Kaqchikel-speaking Mayans and they generally don&#8217;t want much media in their community. Yet this news was so horrific they were united in their grief and wanted to show their solidarity against such barbarism. Most people there also speak Spanish, so I was able to talk with them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe wake for the two boys&mdash;Carlos Daniel Xiquin, 10, and Oscar Armando Toc Cotzajay, 11&mdash;was held in Oscar&#8217;s home beginning the day before and straight through until the funeral. The two were neighbors and schoolmates. A crowd of people filled the street outside house.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI introduced myself to a family member who was greeting locals coming to view the bodies that were in glass-topped caskets, side by side. I photographed for a few minutes and then went back outside to give them privacy, as they prepared for a short Christian service. The sound system was playing the theme song to &#8220;The Young and the Restless&#8221; on loop.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOnce the procession started, it wound up the hill. About 2,000 people solemnly walked along, as pall bearers carried the coffins and a small brass band played. It took about an hour for them to reach the boys&#8217; elementary school, where the memorial service was held.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EI concentrated on the faces of the people who attended. That two children in their community could be kidnapped while walking to school and then so brutally killed was as terrifying to them as it would be to any of us in any neighborhood. After the service, the procession meandered another two hours to the cemetery on top of a mountain.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAlthough the boys were from different families, they were both interred in the tomb of Oscar&#8217;s family. The children died together and together they will remain. Two of my kids are about that age, so I found this funeral especially hard to cover. I hope that my photographs portrayed them with a sense of dignity, even in such an undignified time.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EJohn Moore\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is a special correspondent and senior staff photographer for Getty Images, based in New York. He often focuses on issues related to immigration. Follow him on Instagram \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Fjbmoorephoto\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E@jbmoorephoto\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAndrew Katz\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, who edited this photo essay, is TIME&#8217;s International Multimedia Editor. Follow him on Twitter \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fkatz\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E@katz\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimemagazinephoto\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As photojournalists we sometimes see people on the worst days of their lives. In Guatemala this week, I was with families whose sons had been kidnapped on their way to school, their hands and feet bound and their bodies thrown into sacks."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I first learned about the killings on social media, as both my driver and I were following the local Guatemalan news of what's called the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["nota roja"]},", usually spot news and mostly about crime. I lived in Mexico and Central America for about seven years earlier in my career, and I still have good friendsboth writers and photojournalistswho work throughout that region, who I can count on to help me on the ground when news is breaking. Our profession, even globally, is small and the relationships we make along the way serve us for our entire careers."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I've been photographing immigration and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4537222\u002Fphotographs-usa-border-mexico\u002F"},"content":["border security"]}," as a staffer for Getty Images for most of the last decade, and I try to approach the issues broadly. I spend a lot of time on the southern U.S. border, both with the border agents, whose job it is to enforce the law, and with the immigrants in shelters, before and after they attempt to cross. I also reach out to immigrant support groups that aim to make their lives better and help them integrate easier into American society."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This 10-day trip to Guatemala, planned for months with my editor, was part of my effort to show the root causes of illegal immigration and to put a more human face on the issue. The funeral was on the last day."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The village, along an unpaved road on a steep hillside, is near the area of San Juan Sacatepquez is more than an hour west of Guatemala City. The people are mostly indigenous Kaqchikel-speaking Mayans and they generally don't want much media in their community. Yet this news was so horrific they were united in their grief and wanted to show their solidarity against such barbarism. Most people there also speak Spanish, so I was able to talk with them."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The wake for the two boysCarlos Daniel Xiquin, 10, and Oscar Armando Toc Cotzajay, 11was held in Oscar's home beginning the day before and straight through until the funeral. The two were neighbors and schoolmates. A crowd of people filled the street outside house."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I introduced myself to a family member who was greeting locals coming to view the bodies that were in glass-topped caskets, side by side. I photographed for a few minutes and then went back outside to give them privacy, as they prepared for a short Christian service. The sound system was playing the theme song to \"The Young and the Restless\" on loop."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Once the procession started, it wound up the hill. About 2,000 people solemnly walked along, as pall bearers carried the coffins and a small brass band played. It took about an hour for them to reach the boys' elementary school, where the memorial service was held."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I concentrated on the faces of the people who attended. That two children in their community could be kidnapped while walking to school and then so brutally killed was as terrifying to them as it would be to any of us in any neighborhood. After the service, the procession meandered another two hours to the cemetery on top of a mountain."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Although the boys were from different families, they were both interred in the tomb of Oscar's family. The children died together and together they will remain. Two of my kids are about that age, so I found this funeral especially hard to cover. I hope that my photographs portrayed them with a sense of dignity, even in such an undignified time."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["John Moore"]}," is a special correspondent and senior staff photographer for Getty Images, based in New York. He often focuses on issues related to immigration. Follow him on Instagram ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Fjbmoorephoto\u002F"},"content":["@jbmoorephoto"]},"."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Andrew Katz"]},", who edited this photo essay, is TIME's International Multimedia Editor. Follow him on Twitter ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Fkatz"},"content":["@katz"]},"."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimemagazinephoto","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"As photojournalists we sometimes see people on the worst days of their lives. In Guatemala this week, I was with families whose sons had been kidnapped on their way to school, their hands and feet bound and their bodies thrown into sacks. I first learned about the killings on social media, as both my driver and I were following the local Guatemalan news of what&#8217;s called the nota roja, usually spot news and mostly about crime. I lived in Mexico and Central America for about seven years earlier in my career, and I still have good friends&mdash;both writers and photojournalists&mdash;who work throughout that region, who I can count on to help me on the ground when news is breaking. Our profession, even globally, is small and the relationships we make along the way serve us for our entire careers. I&#8217;ve been photographing immigration and border security as a staffer for Getty Images for most of the last decade, and I try to approach the issues broadly. I spend a lot of time on the southern U.S. border, both with the border agents, whose job it is to enforce the law, and with the immigrants in shelters, before and after they attempt to cross. I also reach out to immigrant support groups that aim to make their lives better and help them integrate easier into American society. This 10-day trip to Guatemala, planned for months with my editor, was part of my effort to show the root causes of illegal immigration and to put a more human face on the issue. The funeral was on the last day. The village, along an unpaved road on a steep hillside, is near the area of San Juan Sacatep&eacute;quez is more than an hour west of Guatemala City. The people are mostly indigenous Kaqchikel-speaking Mayans and they generally don&#8217;t want much media in their community. Yet this news was so horrific they were united in their grief and wanted to show their solidarity against such barbarism. Most people there also speak Spanish, so I was able to talk with them. The wake for the two boys&mdash;Carlos Daniel Xiquin, 10, and Oscar Armando Toc Cotzajay, 11&mdash;was held in Oscar&#8217;s home beginning the day before and straight through until the funeral. The two were neighbors and schoolmates. A crowd of people filled the street outside house. I introduced myself to a family member who was greeting locals coming to view the bodies that were in glass-topped caskets, side by side. I photographed for a few minutes and then went back outside to give them privacy, as they prepared for a short Christian service. The sound system was playing the theme song to &#8220;The Young and the Restless&#8221; on loop. Once the procession started, it wound up the hill. About 2,000 people solemnly walked along, as pall bearers carried the coffins and a small brass band played. It took about an hour for them to reach the boys&#8217; elementary school, where the memorial service was held. I concentrated on the faces of the people who attended. That two children in their community could be kidnapped while walking to school and then so brutally killed was as terrifying to them as it would be to any of us in any neighborhood. After the service, the procession meandered another two hours to the cemetery on top of a mountain. Although the boys were from different families, they were both interred in the tomb of Oscar&#8217;s family. The children died together and together they will remain. Two of my kids are about that age, so I found this funeral especially hard to cover. I hope that my photographs portrayed them with a sense of dignity, even in such an undignified time. John Moore is a special correspondent and senior staff photographer for Getty Images, based in New York. He often focuses on issues related to immigration. Follow him on Instagram @jbmoorephoto. Andrew Katz, who edited this photo essay, is TIME&#8217;s International Multimedia Editor. Follow him on Twitter @katz. Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The children died together and together they will Drone-Hunting Eagles Aren't Messing Around"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhen it comes to defending against pesky drones, the French military has gone to the birds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThese drone-hunting birds of prey are being trained at a French Air Force base in Southwestern France. They&#8217;re literally \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-france-drones-idUSKBN13D1Y9\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eborn on top of drones\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, and kept there during early stages of feeding. When they&#8217;re ready to fly, they&#8217;re brought to a field to intercept drones. In turn, they&#8217;re rewarded with meat.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;These eagles can spot the drones several thousand meters (yards) away and neutralize them,&#8221; Jean-Christophe Zimmerman, a French Air Force general, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-france-drones-idUSKBN13D1Y9\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Etold Reuters\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe idea is to offer a solution to sneaky smaller drones near military bases, airports and other sensitive sites. (They&#8217;re not meant to tangle with militarized Predator-style drones.) The eagles are seen as safer than other solutions, like shooting down drones or using nets to capture them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOther countries, including The Netherlands, are also \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.pbs.org\u002Fnewshour\u002Fbb\u002Fdutch-police-use-eagles-hunt-illegal-drones\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eusing eagles to capture drones\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When it comes to defending against pesky drones, the French military has gone to the birds."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["These drone-hunting birds of prey are being trained at a French Air Force base in Southwestern France. They're literally ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-france-drones-idUSKBN13D1Y9"},"content":["born on top of drones"]},", and kept there during early stages of feeding. When they're ready to fly, they're brought to a field to intercept drones. In turn, they're rewarded with meat."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"These eagles can spot the drones several thousand meters (yards) away and neutralize them,\" Jean-Christophe Zimmerman, a French Air Force general, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-france-drones-idUSKBN13D1Y9"},"content":["told Reuters"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The idea is to offer a solution to sneaky smaller drones near military bases, airports and other sensitive sites. (They're not meant to tangle with militarized Predator-style drones.) The eagles are seen as safer than other solutions, like shooting down drones or using nets to capture them."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Other countries, including The Netherlands, are also ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.pbs.org\u002Fnewshour\u002Fbb\u002Fdutch-police-use-eagles-hunt-illegal-drones\u002F"},"content":["using eagles to capture drones"]},"."]}],"plain":"When it comes to defending against pesky drones, the French military has gone to the birds. These drone-hunting birds of prey are being trained at a French Air Force base in Southwestern France. They&#8217;re literally born on top of drones, and kept there during early stages of feeding. When they&#8217;re ready to fly, they&#8217;re brought to a field to intercept drones. In turn, they&#8217;re rewarded with meat. &#8220;These eagles can spot the drones several thousand meters (yards) away and neutralize them,&#8221; Jean-Christophe Zimmerman, a French Air Force general, told Reuters. The idea is to offer a solution to sneaky smaller drones near military bases, airports and other sensitive sites. (They&#8217;re not meant to tangle with militarized Predator-style drones.) The eagles are seen as safer than other solutions, like shooting down drones or using nets to capture them. Other countries, including The Netherlands, are also using eagles to capture drones."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;These eagles can spot drones several thousand meters yards
