more","parent":0,"count":7975,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","tech","world"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4674934,"date":"2017-02-17T12:46:09","date_gmt":"2017-02-17T17:46:09","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4674934"},"modified":"2017-02-17T13:14:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-17T18:14:00","slug":"oroville-dam-photos","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4674934\u002Foroville-dam-photos\u002F","title":{"rendered":"In Oroville, Everyone Is Watching the Weather"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWith three \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672864\u002Fcalifornia-lake-oroville-dam-spillway-new-storm\u002F\"\u003Estorms\u003C\u002Fa\u003E making their way across California, the state&rsquo;s Department of Water Resources is racing against time, draining more than 100,000 cubic feet of water every second from Lake Oroville.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe reason why, at least for Sacramento-based photographer Max Whittaker, started in the early hours of Feb. 7. &ldquo;The San Francisco \u003Cem\u003EChronicle\u003C\u002Fem\u003E called and asked if I wanted to go up to Oroville to do a story on how California&rsquo;s reservoirs are full,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;I set out figuring that it would be a straightforward story.&rdquo; When he arrived, however, authorities had blocked the road leading to the spillway. When he tried to go to the top of the dam itself to look for other angles, they blocked his way again. Perplexed &mdash; who would object to him taking a picture of the water? &mdash; he then overheard officials at a roadblock talking about &ldquo;the incident.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter a back and forth with his editor and the authorities on the scene, a representative from the California Department of Water Resources let him follow along to see what was happening. &ldquo;We went close to the spillway and there was this huge hole in it,&#8221; he recalls.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAs he photographed the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671105\u002Foroville-dam-crisis-infrastructure\u002F\"\u003Edamage\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, the story was changing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4675116\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fweather0208_reservoirs-3\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmax-whittaker-oroville-dam.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,1414\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"5.6\",\"credit\":\"Max Whittaker\\\u002FPrime\",\"camera\":\"Canon EOS 5D Mark III\",\"caption\":\"A hole was torn in the spillway of the Oroville Dam while releasing approximately 60,000 cubic-feet-second of water in advance of more rain on February 7, 2017 in Oroville, California.\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1486478982\",\"copyright\":\"Max Whittaker\\\u002FPrime\",\"focal_length\":\"340\",\"iso\":\"400\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.0008\",\"title\":\"WEATHER0208_RESERVOIRS\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"WEATHER0208_RESERVOIRS\" data-image-description=\"pA hole was torn in the spillway of the Oroville Dam while releasing approximately 60,000 cubic-feet-second of water in advance of more rain on Feb. 7, 2017 in Oroville, California.\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmax-whittaker-oroville-dam.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmax-whittaker-oroville-dam.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmax-whittaker-oroville-dam.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=309\" alt=\"WEATHER0208_RESERVOIRS\" height=\"309\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EMax Whittaker&mdash;Prime\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EA hole was torn in the spillway of the Oroville Dam while releasing approximately 60,000 cubic-feet-second of water in advance of more rain on Feb. 7, 2017 in Oroville, Calif.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis was at the end of a very warm and wet storm that had hit northern California. &ldquo;It was raining up to 9,000 feet [in altitude] when typically, in the winter, it would snow from 2,000 to 5,000 feet,&rdquo; says Whittaker. &ldquo;All this water was running down quickly to the lake, even melting existing snow so there was tremendous inflow.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAuthorities realized they wouldn&rsquo;t be able to drain the water quickly enough to solve the problem, and an \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668690\u002Fcalifornia-oroville-dam-evacuations\"\u003Eevacuation\u003C\u002Fa\u003E order was issued for 200,000 people living downstream from the Oroville Dam, including some of Whittaker&rsquo;s friends and relatives.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;I saw people at the evacuation centers who literally brought nothing with them,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It was somewhat terrifying for people because the traffic jams were so massive and in areas that could be inundated if the dam had collapsed.&rdquo; While people were orderly, there was still a stressful vibe hanging over everyone, says Whittaker. &ldquo;But, as time went on [and the evacuation order was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671443\u002Fcalifornia-oroville-dam-evacuation-lifted\"\u003Elifted\u003C\u002Fa\u003E], it&rsquo;s been interesting to see the variety of emotions people have about it. Some felt they got evacuated for no reason, when others refused to return to their homes because the danger has not subsided.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, everyone is watching the weather. The Department of Water Resources says the situation is under control if the forecast stands, Whittaker reports. But when it comes to something so dependent on the weather, the future is hard to predict.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;Another storm just started,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s raining steadily today.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.primecollective.com\u002Fphotographers\u002Fwhittaker\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EMax Whittaker\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a photographer based in Sacramento. He&#8217;s represented by the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.primecollective.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EPrime\u003C\u002Fa\u003E collective.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EKim Bubello\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOlivier Laurent \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003Eis the editor of TIME LightBox. It was raining up to 9,000 feet [in altitude] when typically, in the winter, it would snow from 2,000 to 5,000 feet, says Whittaker. All this water was running down quickly to the lake, even melting existing snow so there was tremendous inflow."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Authorities realized they wouldnt be able to drain the water quickly enough to solve the problem, and an ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668690\u002Fcalifornia-oroville-dam-evacuations"},"content":["evacuation"]}," order was issued for 200,000 people living downstream from the Oroville Dam, including some of Whittakers friends and relatives."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I saw people at the evacuation centers who literally brought nothing with them, he says. But, as time went on [and the evacuation order was ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671443\u002Fcalifornia-oroville-dam-evacuation-lifted"},"content":["lifted"]},"], its been interesting to see the variety of emotions people have about it. Some felt they got evacuated for no reason, when others refused to return to their homes because the danger has not subsided."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now, everyone is watching the weather. But when it comes to something so dependent on the weather, the future is hard to predict."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Another storm just started, he says. Its raining steadily today.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.primecollective.com\u002Fphotographers\u002Fwhittaker\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Max Whittaker"]}]}," is a photographer based in Sacramento. He's represented by the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.primecollective.com\u002F"},"content":["Prime"]}," collective."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Kim Bubello"]},", who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Olivier Laurent "]},"is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}," @olivierclaurent"]}]}],"plain":"With three storms making their way across California, the state&rsquo;s Department of Water Resources is racing against time, draining more than 100,000 cubic feet of water every second from Lake Oroville. The reason why, at least for Sacramento-based photographer Max Whittaker, started in the early hours of Feb. 7. &ldquo;The San Francisco Chronicle called and asked if I wanted to go up to Oroville to do a story on how California&rsquo;s reservoirs are full,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;I set out figuring that it would be a straightforward story.&rdquo; When he arrived, however, authorities had blocked the road leading to the spillway. When he tried to go to the top of the dam itself to look for other angles, they blocked his way again. Perplexed &mdash; who would object to him taking a picture of the water? &mdash; he then overheard officials at a roadblock talking about &ldquo;the incident.&rdquo; After a back and forth with his editor and the authorities on the scene, a representative from the California Department of Water Resources let him follow along to see what was happening. &ldquo;We went close to the spillway and there was this huge hole in it,&#8221; he recalls. As he photographed the damage, the story was changing. Max Whittaker&mdash;PrimeA hole was torn in the spillway of the Oroville Dam while releasing approximately 60,000 cubic-feet-second of water in advance of more rain on Feb. 7, 2017 in Oroville, Calif. This was at the end of a very warm and wet storm that had hit northern California. &ldquo;It was raining up to 9,000 feet [in altitude] when typically, in the winter, it would snow from 2,000 to 5,000 feet,&rdquo; says Whittaker. &ldquo;All this water was running down quickly to the lake, even melting existing snow so there was tremendous inflow.&rdquo; Authorities realized they wouldn&rsquo;t be able to drain the water quickly enough to solve the problem, and an evacuation order was issued for 200,000 people living downstream from the Oroville Dam, including some of Whittaker&rsquo;s friends and relatives. &ldquo;I saw people at the evacuation centers who literally brought nothing with them,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It was somewhat terrifying for people because the traffic jams were so massive and in areas that could be inundated if the dam had collapsed.&rdquo; While people were orderly, there was still a stressful vibe hanging over everyone, says Whittaker. &ldquo;But, as time went on [and the evacuation order was lifted], it&rsquo;s been interesting to see the variety of emotions people have about it. Some felt they got evacuated for no reason, when others refused to return to their homes because the danger has not subsided.&rdquo; Now, everyone is watching the weather. The Department of Water Resources says the situation is under control if the forecast stands, Whittaker reports. But when it comes to something so dependent on the weather, the future is hard to predict. &ldquo;Another storm just started,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s raining steadily today.&#8221; Max Whittaker is a photographer based in Sacramento. He&#8217;s represented by the Prime collective. Kim Bubello, who edited this photo essay, is a freelance photo editor at TIME. Olivier Laurent is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on Twitter and Instagram @olivierclaurent"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMax Whittaker photographed the aftermath of the Oroville Dam","slug":"oroville-dam","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":101193,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":1,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","us"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4672686,"date":"2017-02-16T08:50:35","date_gmt":"2017-02-16T13:50:35","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4672686"},"modified":"2017-02-16T20:32:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-17T01:32:00","slug":"time-cover-trump-chaos","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672686\u002Ftime-cover-trump-chaos\u002F","title":{"rendered":"The Story Behind TIMEs Trump Chaos Cover"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor the Feb. 27 cover of TIME on the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fchaos\"\u003Echaos\u003C\u002Fa\u003E surrounding the initial days of the Trump administration we turned to Brooklyn-based artist Tim O&rsquo;Brien. A long-time TIME collaborator, O&#8217;Brien&#8217;s work has appeared on over two dozen TIME covers since 1989, with subjects ranging from Pope Benedict XVI to Osama Bin Laden. His imaginative style and gift for detail made him the right choice to create a portrait of disruption in the White House.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4672425\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672686\u002Ftime-cover-trump-chaos\u002Ftrump-cover-final-4\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump-cover-final-e1487295095347.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2000,1378\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"Donald Trump Nothing to See Here Time Magazine Cover 170227\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump-cover-final-e1487295095347.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump-cover-final-e1487295095347.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump-cover-final.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=747\" alt=\"Donald Trump Nothing to See Here Time Magazine Cover\" height=\"747\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EIllustration by Tim O&rsquo;Brien for TIME\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;Painting this cover was like imagining a movie,&rdquo; O&rsquo;Brien said. &#8220;I see it all in my head, the swirling rain, the wind blowing papers across the desk, the splats of the heavy raindrops on the desk. The e-mail from [TIME Creative Director] D.W. Pine asked if I could paint Trump in a storm. As soon as he asked I saw the image. A cartoonist might get the subject to react, to animate, hold on and grimace in the face of the wind. I saw it more as a dead pan look at us. In paintings, it is the contrast that creates the interest, in this case, the calm and the chaos.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-inline_small alignleft \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4672796\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672686\u002Ftime-cover-trump-chaos\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time1.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"1051,1369\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"clinton-dole-cover-time\" data-image-description=\"pBill Clinton and Bob Dole\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time1.jpg?quality=85&w=230\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time1.jpg?quality=85&w=461\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time1.jpg?w=190&#038;quality=85&#038;h=247\" alt=\"Painting by Tim O'Brien\" height=\"247\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EPainting by Tim O&#8217;Brien\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EBill Clinton and Bob Dole\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOutside of his 28-year relationship with TIME, O&rsquo;Brien&rsquo;s work has appeared in publications all over the world, including several U.S. postage stamps and book covers such as the popular \u003Cem\u003EHunger Games\u003C\u002Fem\u003E trilogy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETwo of his TIME magazine covers &ndash; one with Bill Clinton and Bob Dole and the other with the Grand Old Populists, both published in 1996 &ndash; reside in the National Portrait Gallery at the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWatch O&#8217;Brien work in virtual reality as part of a recent TIME story, \u003Cem\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fvr-is-for-artists\u002F\"\u003EVirtual Reality is For Artists\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For the Feb. 27 cover of TIME on the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fchaos"},"content":["chaos"]}," surrounding the initial days of the Trump administration we turned to Brooklyn-based artist Tim OBrien. A long-time TIME collaborator, O'Brien's work has appeared on over two dozen TIME covers since 1989, with subjects ranging from Pope Benedict XVI to Osama Bin Laden. His imaginative style and gift for detail made him the right choice to create a portrait of disruption in the White House."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4672425","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump-cover-final.jpg?w=560","alt":"Donald Trump Nothing to See Here Time Magazine Cover","width":"560","height":"747"},"content":[]}," ",{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Illustration by Tim OBrien for TIME"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Painting this cover was like imagining a movie, OBrien said. \"I see it all in my head, the swirling rain, the wind blowing papers across the desk, the splats of the heavy raindrops on the desk. The e-mail from [TIME Creative Director] D.W. Pine asked if I could paint Trump in a storm. As soon as he asked I saw the image. A cartoonist might get the subject to react, to animate, hold on and grimace in the face of the wind. I saw it more as a dead pan look at us. In paintings, it is the contrast that creates the interest, in this case, the calm and the chaos.\""]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4672796","align":"alignleft","width":"190"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fclinton-dole-cover-time1.jpg?w=190","alt":"Painting by Tim O&#039;Brien","width":"190","height":"247"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Bill Clinton and Bob Dole"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Painting by Tim O'Brien"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Outside of his 28-year relationship with TIME, OBriens work has appeared in publications all over the world, including several U.S. postage stamps and book covers such as the popular ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Hunger Games"]}," trilogy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Two of his TIME magazine covers  one with Bill Clinton and Bob Dole and the other with the Grand Old Populists, both published in 1996  reside in the National Portrait Gallery at the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Watch O'Brien work in virtual reality as part of a recent TIME story, ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fvr-is-for-artists\u002F"},"content":["Virtual Reality is For Artists"]}]},"."]}],"plain":"For the Feb. 27 cover of TIME on the chaos surrounding the initial days of the Trump administration we turned to Brooklyn-based artist Tim O&rsquo;Brien. A long-time TIME collaborator, O&#8217;Brien&#8217;s work has appeared on over two dozen TIME covers since 1989, with subjects ranging from Pope Benedict XVI to Osama Bin Laden. His imaginative style and gift for detail made him the right choice to create a portrait of disruption in the White House. Illustration by Tim O&rsquo;Brien for TIME &#8220;Painting this cover was like imagining a movie,&rdquo; O&rsquo;Brien said. &#8220;I see it all in my head, the swirling rain, the wind blowing papers across the desk, the splats of the heavy raindrops on the desk. The e-mail from [TIME Creative Director] D.W. Pine asked if I could paint Trump in a storm. As soon as he asked I saw the image. A cartoonist might get the subject to react, to animate, hold on and grimace in the face of the wind. I saw it more as a dead pan look at us. In paintings, it is the contrast that creates the interest, in this case, the calm and the chaos.&#8221; Painting by Tim O&#8217;BrienBill Clinton and Bob Dole Outside of his 28-year relationship with TIME, O&rsquo;Brien&rsquo;s work has appeared in publications all over the world, including several U.S. postage stamps and book covers such as the popular Hunger Games trilogy. Two of his TIME magazine covers &ndash; one with Bill Clinton and Bob Dole and the other with the Grand Old Populists, both published in 1996 &ndash; reside in the National Portrait Gallery at the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. Watch O&#8217;Brien work in virtual reality as part of a recent TIME story, Virtual Reality is For Artists."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EBrooklyn-based artist Tim OBrien painted Donald Trump for this week&#8217;s TIME cover\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":703985,"featured_media":4674291,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[10252575,10853,148,189091,436,27683,430952604,467532],"time_section":[326619029,204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937791],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4672686"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4672686"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4672686"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4672686\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002 cover","slug":"behind-the-cover","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F10252575"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=10252575"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=10252575"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":10853,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fcover\u002F","name":"Cover","slug":"cover","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F10853"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=10853"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=10853"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":148,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fdesign\u002F","name":"Design","slug":"design","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F148"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=148"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u0 2Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=27683"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":430952604,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Ftim-obrien\u002F","name":"Tim O'Brien","slug":"tim-obrien","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430952604"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430952604"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430952604"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":467532,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Ftrump\u002F","name":"trump","slug":"trump","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F467532"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=467532"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=467532"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No route was found matching the URL and request method","data":{"status":404}}],"wp:meta":[{"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Fti.me\u002F2lRW5Vx","negative_coverage":false,"mt_seo_keywords":"Behind the Cover, design, cover, Tim O'Brien, Donald Trump, Trump, president","mt_seo_google_news_meta":"Behind the Cover, design, cover, Tim O'Brien, Donald Trump, Trump, president","mt_seo_title":"Trump: The Story Behind TIMEs Trump Chaos Cover","mt_seo_description":"Brooklyn-based artist Tim OBrien painted Donald Trump for this week's TIME cover","og_title":"The Story Behind TIMEs Trump Chaos Cover","og_description":"Brooklyn-based artist Tim OBrien painted Donald Trump for this week's TIME cover","twitter_text":"The story behind TIMEs Trump chaos cover","short_title":"The Story Behind Our Trump Chaos Cover","home_deck":"\"Painting this cover was like imagining a movie, Brooklyn-based artist Tim OBrien said","permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672686\u002Ftime-cover-trump-chaos\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4672686\u002Ftime-cover-trump-chaos\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"video","visible":true,"image":{"id":4674291,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fscreen-shot-2017-02-17-at-9-34-00-am.png","alt":"","caption":"","credit":"","title":"screen-shot-2017-02-17-at-9-34-00-am"},"video":{"id":"5324675016001","markup":"\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5324675016001\" data-video-id=\"5324675016001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E","provider":"brightcove"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"controls":"1","videoid":"5324675016001"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":10252575,"name":"behind the cover","slug":"behind-the-cover","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":51461,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":11,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","politics"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4667825,"date":"2017-02-15T11:05:08","date_gmt":"2017-02-15T16:05:08","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4667825"},"modified":"2017-02-15T11:05:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-15T16:05:00","slug":"a-dystopian-vision-of-the-refugee-crisis","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4667825\u002Fa-dystopian-vision-of-the-refugee-crisis\u002F","title":{"rendered":"A Dystopian Vision of the Refugee Crisis"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe refugee crisis is becoming increasingly politicized; less about the safe guarding of human rights and more about the safe guarding of national borders. Though forced migration is nothing new, the numbers are unprecedented; 65.3 million people around the world are currently displaced by war or persecution, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.unhcr.org\u002Fen-us\u002Fnews\u002Flatest\u002F2016\u002F6\u002F5763b65a4\u002Fglobal-forced-displacement-hits-record-high.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eaccording to the UNHCR\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. It&#8217;s a modern problem of biblical proportions and as the figures rise, the individual refugee is increasingly regarded as little more than a troubling statistic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPhotographer Richard Mosse&rsquo;s latest project, \u003Cem\u003EHeat Maps\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, offers an unconventional take on a much-dissected subject. The work charts the refugee crisis unfolding across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East using a powerful military grade telephoto camera attached to a robotic arm which detects thermal radiation by scanning landscapes and interiors. The result is unsettling; human flesh is turned a translucent grey, eye sockets are blackened, bodies appear like avatars existing in a virtual dystopia.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe paradox is, life in these refugee camps can be just as hellish and dehumanizing as the photographs imply. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a camera that strips people of their identity. It turns them into a creature or a biological trace,&rdquo; Mosse tells TIME. &ldquo;I hope that the camera will reveal the way we in the West and our governments represent and therefore regard the refugee.&rdquo; Deliberately disconcerting, Mosse wants the viewer to feel an uneasy sense of their own complicity. &ldquo;The horrific conditions in those camps are created by our governments. And we vote those people in,&rdquo; he adds.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EHeat Maps\u003C\u002Fem\u003E isn&rsquo;t easily classified, perching as it does between factual surveillance, aesthetic ambiguity and the fantasy-world of a Ray Bradbury novel. But it&rsquo;s supposed to be polyvalent, ambivalent, open-ended. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s meant to force the viewer into a place where they have to decide what it is,&rdquo; says Mosse. &ldquo;Because with the refugee crisis, everyone has already made up their mind.&rdquo; Though the photos are revealing of the refugees&rsquo; situation, the individual characters technically remain indistinguishable. While Ai Weiwei was refused access photographing the interior of Berlin&rsquo;s Tempelhof Airport &ndash; now Germany&rsquo;s largest refugee camp &ndash; Mosse was admitted, because he could show how the camera left the subjects identities \u003Cstrong\u003Ein tact\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E. But taken at long range &#8211; as far away as 50 kilometers &ndash; there is still a degree of violation. &ldquo;You&rsquo;re not quite committing an invasion of privacy, yet you are,&rdquo; he says.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe photographs are impressive online but humbling in person; the large-scale panoramas take up most of a gallery wall. They evoke the detail of a Bruegel painting but the flatness of a Medieval tapestry; an array of miniature scenes impossibly arranged into one prevailing landscape. The large-scale pieces are technically &lsquo;photo-illustration&rsquo; and are constructed from a grid of almost a thousand smaller frames &ndash; each with their own vanishing point &ndash; painstakingly sewn together.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe work is a surveillance of the grim squalor of the camps but cannot be read as an exact reality. Amid the complex scenes, an occasional figure will stand dismembered &ndash; the result of a glitch in the camera&rsquo;s heat scanning that Mosse decided to leave in. &ldquo;Being a refugee strips you of the inalienable rights of man, which are subsumed into the idea of a citizen,&rdquo; Mosse says. &ldquo;Once you&rsquo;ve left your nation state due to persecution, conflict, climate change, you lose your human rights.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&nbsp;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4667942\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4667825\u002Fa-dystopian-vision-of-the-refugee-crisis\u002Fmosse_alexandra\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmosse_alexandra.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,1707\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"5.6\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"Canon EOS 5D Mark II\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1486146995\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"70\",\"iso\":\"400\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.016666666666667\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"mosse_alexandra\" data-image-description=\"pRichard Mosse stands in front of the work iHelliniko,\u002Fi 2016, at the Jack Shainman Gallery, West 20, NYC. \u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmosse_alexandra.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmosse_alexandra.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmosse_alexandra.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=373\" alt=\"Alexandra Genova\" height=\"373\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003ERichard Mosse stands in front of the work \u003Ci\u003EHelliniko,\u003C\u002Fi\u003E 2016, at the Jack Shainman Gallery, West 20, NYC. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe violent aesthetic of the images is not without context. Primarily designed for surveillance, the camera can also be connected to a weapons system to target the enemy. The misuse of its intended purpose is another deliberate attempt to subvert the common perception of the refugee. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m trying to use these sinister technologies against their original intended purpose,&rdquo; he says. This is ironic considering the call made by German far-right leader Frauke Petry to use firearms on illegal refugees &#8220;\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.independent.co.uk\u002Fnews\u002Fworld\u002Fgerman-police-should-shoot-refugees-says-german-party-leader-a6844611.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eif necessary.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E&#8221; Quoting the work of Allan Sekula, Mosse believes his role as an artist is to try to &ldquo;brush photography against the grain&rdquo;. It&rsquo;s a method he&rsquo;s adopted before with his \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3774918\u002Fphotojournalism-at-the-crossroads-3-richard-mosse-and-infrared-film\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EInfra\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E series; a psychedelic vision of the Democratic Republic of Congo conflict taken with a discontinued surveillance film originally used by the military. Both projects employ the Brechtian &#8216;Verfremdungseffekt&#8217; &ndash; or distancing effect &ndash; which serves to make the familiar strange. &ldquo;I put the viewer in a space where they have no cues, they don&rsquo;t understand the grammar of the language,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;So they have to actually engage with this on an unfamiliar level and as a result, it&rsquo;s fresh.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnlike the hyper-local \u003Cem\u003EInfra\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, Mosse worked across many, dislocated landscapes. &ldquo;These people are dispossessed, they&rsquo;re displaced,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;You can&rsquo;t really predict where the story will flash up next. You have to keep your ears to the ground. &rdquo; Complex logistics plagued the three-year project. Mosse built up a network of volunteers and fixers but access was often difficult, particularly in the Calais Jungle, which they eventually infiltrated right before it was dismantled. Outside Europe, attempting to cross borders was mired in deadlock. When Mosse and his team were trying to reach Timbuktu through Mali, they spent a month &ndash; without success &ndash; trying to permeate a Swedish battalion, hoping to make use of their convoys. But these stumbling blocks were part of the process and the constant challenges forced Mosse into a space of hyperawareness.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENavigating sticky border control ran parallel to navigating tricky equipment. Attached to the already complex telephoto camera was a tangle of wires and cables that connected to an X-Box controller, media recorder and several laptops. &ldquo;You really need to earn your chops with [the camera],&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;And you constantly feel slightly compromised by what you&rsquo;re doing. But I think that&rsquo;s always a good space to be in as an artist: feeling uncomfortable.&rdquo; Mosse witnessed some horrific scenes, impossible to express through the prism of art. But, he says, once you&rsquo;re looking through the ground glass of the camera you become a machine with a job to do. &ldquo;I cling to the idea that although &lsquo;art is useless&rsquo;, it can be iconic,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It can be culturally resonant without being politically committed.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERichard Mosse\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is an Irish conceptual documentary photographer. More of his work can be viewed \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.richardmosse.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EHeat Maps\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is on display at the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.jackshainman.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EJack Shainman Gallery\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on West 20th Street, NYC until March 11. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2 _10M0Ygc4\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAlexandra Genova \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ci\u003Eis a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2 end _10M0Ygc4\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The refugee crisis is becoming increasingly politicized; less about the safe guarding of human rights and more about the safe guarding of national borders. Though forced migration is nothing new, the numbers are unprecedented; 65.3 million people around the world are currently displaced by war or persecution, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.unhcr.org\u002Fen-us\u002Fnews\u002Flatest\u002F2016\u002F6\u002F5763b65a4\u002Fglobal-forced-displacement-hits-record-high.html"},"content":["according to the UNHCR"]},". It's a modern problem of biblical proportions and as the figures rise, the individual refugee is increasingly regarded as little more than a troubling statistic."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Photographer Richard Mosses latest project, ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Heat Maps"]},", offers an unconventional take on a much-dissected subject. The work charts the refugee crisis unfolding across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East using a powerful military grade telephoto camera attached to a robotic arm which detects thermal radiation by scanning landscapes and interiors. The result is unsettling; human flesh is turned a translucent grey, eye sockets are blackened, bodies appear like avatars existing in a virtual dystopia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The paradox is, life in these refugee camps can be just as hellish and dehumanizing as the photographs imply. Its a camera that strips people of their identity. It turns them into a creature or a biological trace, Mosse tells TIME. I hope that the camera will reveal the way we in the West and our governments represent and therefore regard the refugee. Deliberately disconcerting, Mosse wants the viewer to feel an uneasy sense of their own complicity. The horrific conditions in those camps are created by our governments. And we vote those people in, he adds."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Heat Maps"]}," isnt easily classified, perching as it does between factual surveillance, aesthetic ambiguity and the fantasy-world of a Ray Bradbury novel. But its supposed to be polyvalent, ambivalent, open-ended. Its meant to force the viewer into a place where they have to decide what it is, says Mosse. Because with the refugee crisis, everyone has already made up their mind. Though the photos are revealing of the refugees situation, the individual characters technically remain indistinguishable. While Ai Weiwei was refused access photographing the interior of Berlins Tempelhof Airport  now Germanys largest refugee camp  Mosse was admitted, because he could show how the camera left the subjects identities ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["in tact"]},". But taken at long range - as far away as 50 kilometers  there is still a degree of violation. Youre not quite committing an invasion of privacy, yet you are, he says."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The photographs are impressive online but humbling in person; the large-scale panoramas take up most of a gallery wall. They evoke the detail of a Bruegel painting but the flatness of a Medieval tapestry; an array of miniature scenes impossibly arranged into one prevailing landscape. The large-scale pieces are technically photo-illustration and are constructed from a grid of almost a thousand smaller frames  each with their own vanishing point  painstakingly sewn together."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The work is a surveillance of the grim squalor of the camps but cannot be read as an exact reality. Amid the complex scenes, an occasional figure will stand dismembered  the result of a glitch in the cameras heat scanning that Mosse decided to leave in. Being a refugee strips you of the inalienable rights of man, which are subsumed into the idea of a citizen, Mosse says. Once youve left your nation state due to persecution, conflict, climate change, you lose your human rights."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4667942","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fmosse_alexandra.jpg?w=560","alt":"Alexandra Genova","width":"560","height":"373"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Richard Mosse stands in front of the work ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Helliniko,"]}," 2016, at the Jack Shainman Gallery, West 20, NYC. "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The violent aesthetic of the images is not without context. Primarily designed for surveillance, the camera can also be connected to a weapons system to target the enemy. The misuse of its intended purpose is another deliberate attempt to subvert the common perception of the refugee. Im trying to use these sinister technologies against their original intended purpose, he says. This is ironic considering the call made by German far-right leader Frauke Petry to use firearms on illegal refugees \"",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.independent.co.uk\u002Fnews\u002Fworld\u002Fgerman-police-should-shoot-refugees-says-german-party-leader-a6844611.html"},"content":["if necessary."]},"\" Quoting the work of Allan Sekula, Mosse believes his role as an artist is to try to brush photography against the grain. Its a method hes adopted before with his ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3774918\u002Fphotojournalism-at-the-crossroads-3-richard-mosse-and-infrared-film\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Infra"]}]}," series; a psychedelic vision of the Democratic Republic of Congo conflict taken with a discontinued surveillance film originally used by the military. Both projects employ the Brechtian 'Verfremdungseffekt'  or distancing effect  which serves to make the familiar strange. I put the viewer in a space where they have no cues, they dont understand the grammar of the language, he says. So they have to actually engage with this on an unfamiliar level and as a result, its fresh."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Unlike the hyper-local ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Infra"]},", Mosse worked across many, dislocated landscapes. These people are dispossessed, theyre displaced, he says. You cant really predict where the story will flash up next. You have to keep your ears to the ground.  Complex logistics plagued the three-year project. Mosse built up a network of volunteers and fixers but access was often difficult, particularly in the Calais Jungle, which they eventually infiltrated right before it was dismantled. Outside Europe, attempting to cross borders was mired in deadlock. When Mosse and his team were trying to reach Timbuktu through Mali, they spent a month  without success  trying to permeate a Swedish battalion, hoping to make use of their convoys. But these stumbling blocks were part of the process and the constant challenges forced Mosse into a space of hyperawareness."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Navigating sticky border control ran parallel to navigating tricky equipment. Attached to the already complex telephoto camera was a tangle of wires and cables that connected to an X-Box controller, media recorder and several laptops. You really need to earn your chops with [the camera], he says. And you constantly feel slightly compromised by what youre doing. But I think thats always a good space to be in as an artist: feeling uncomfortable. Mosse witnessed some horrific scenes, impossible to express through the prism of art. But, he says, once youre looking through the ground glass of the camera you become a machine with a job to do. I cling to the idea that although art is useless, it can be iconic, he says. It can be culturally resonant without being politically committed.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Richard Mosse"]}," is an Irish conceptual documentary photographer. More of his work can be viewed ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.richardmosse.com\u002F"},"content":["here"]},". "]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Heat Maps"]}," is on display at the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.jackshainman.com\u002F"},"content":["Jack Shainman Gallery"]}," on West 20th Street, NYC until March 11. "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Alexandra Genova "]}]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Twitter"]}]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Instagram"]}]}]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}]}]}],"plain":"The refugee crisis is becoming increasingly politicized; less about the safe guarding of human rights and more about the safe guarding of national borders. Though forced migration is nothing new, the numbers are unprecedented; 65.3 million people around the world are currently displaced by war or persecution, according to the UNHCR. It&#8217;s a modern problem of biblical proportions and as the figures rise, the individual refugee is increasingly regarded as little more than a troubling statistic. Photographer Richard Mosse&rsquo;s latest project, Heat Maps, offers an unconventional take on a much-dissected subject. The work charts the refugee crisis unfolding across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East using a powerful military grade telephoto camera attached to a robotic arm which detects thermal radiation by scanning landscapes and interiors. The result is unsettling; human flesh is turned a translucent grey, eye sockets are blackened, bodies appear like avatars existing in a virtual dystopia. The paradox is, life in these refugee camps can be just as hellish and dehumanizing as the photographs imply. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a camera that strips people of their identity. It turns them into a creature or a biological trace,&rdquo; Mosse tells TIME. &ldquo;I hope that the camera will reveal the way we in the West and our governments represent and therefore regard the refugee.&rdquo; Deliberately disconcerting, Mosse wants the viewer to feel an uneasy sense of their own complicity. &ldquo;The horrific conditions in those camps are created by our governments. And we vote those people in,&rdquo; he adds. Heat Maps isn&rsquo;t easily classified, perching as it does between factual surveillance, aesthetic ambiguity and the fantasy-world of a Ray Bradbury novel. But it&rsquo;s supposed to be polyvalent, ambivalent, open-ended. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s meant to force the viewer into a place where they have to decide what it is,&rdquo; says Mosse. &ldquo;Because with the refugee crisis, everyone has already made up their mind.&rdquo; Though the photos are revealing of the refugees&rsquo; situation, the individual characters technically remain indistinguishable. While Ai Weiwei was refused access photographing the interior of Berlin&rsquo;s Tempelhof Airport &ndash; now Germany&rsquo;s largest refugee camp &ndash; Mosse was admitted, because he could show how the camera left the subjects identities in tact. But taken at long range &#8211; as far away as 50 kilometers &ndash; there is still a degree of violation. &ldquo;You&rsquo;re not quite committing an invasion of privacy, yet you are,&rdquo; he says. The photographs are impressive online but humbling in person; the large-scale panoramas take up most of a gallery wall. They evoke the detail of a Bruegel painting but the flatness of a Medieval tapestry; an array of miniature scenes impossibly arranged into one prevailing landscape. The large-scale pieces are technically &lsquo;photo-illustration&rsquo; and are constructed from a grid of almost a thousand smaller frames &ndash; each with their own vanishing point &ndash; painstakingly sewn together. The work is a surveillance of the grim squalor of the camps but cannot be read as an exact reality. Amid the complex scenes, an occasional figure will stand dismembered &ndash; the result of a glitch in the camera&rsquo;s heat scanning that Mosse decided to leave in. &ldquo;Being a refugee strips you of the inalienable rights of man, which are subsumed into the idea of a citizen,&rdquo; Mosse says. &ldquo;Once you&rsquo;ve left your nation state due to persecution, conflict, climate change, you lose your human rights.&rdquo; &nbsp; Richard Mosse stands in front of the work Helliniko, 2016, at the Jack Shainman Gallery, West 20, NYC. The violent aesthetic of the images is not without context. Primarily designed for surveillance, the camera can also be connected to a weapons system to target the enemy. The misuse of its intended purpose is another deliberate attempt to subvert the common perception of the refugee. &ldquo;I&rsquo;m trying to use these sinister technologies against their original intended purpose,&rdquo; he says. This is ironic considering the call made by German far-right leader Frauke Petry to use firearms on illegal refugees &#8220;if necessary.&#8221; Quoting the work of Allan Sekula, Mosse believes his role as an artist is to try to &ldquo;brush photography against the grain&rdquo;. It&rsquo;s a method he&rsquo;s adopted before with his Infra series; a psychedelic vision of the Democratic Republic of Congo conflict taken with a discontinued surveillance film originally used by the military. Both projects employ the Brechtian &#8216;Verfremdungseffekt&#8217; &ndash; or distancing effect &ndash; which serves to make the familiar strange. &ldquo;I put the viewer in a space where they have no cues, they don&rsquo;t understand the grammar of the language,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;So they have to actually engage with this on an unfamiliar level and as a result, it&rsquo;s fresh.&rdquo; Unlike the hyper-local Infra, Mosse worked across many, dislocated landscapes. &ldquo;These people are dispossessed, they&rsquo;re displaced,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;You can&rsquo;t really predict where the story will flash up next. You have to keep your ears to the ground. &rdquo; Complex logistics plagued the three-year project. Mosse built up a network of volunteers and fixers but access was often difficult, particularly in the Calais Jungle, which they eventually infiltrated right before it was dismantled. Outside Europe, attempting to cross borders was mired in deadlock. When Mosse and his team were trying to reach Timbuktu through Mali, they spent a month &ndash; without success &ndash; trying to permeate a Swedish battalion, hoping to make use of their convoys. But these stumbling blocks were part of the process and the constant challenges forced Mosse into a space of hyperawareness. Navigating sticky border control ran parallel to navigating tricky equipment. Attached to the already complex telephoto camera was a tangle of wires and cables that connected to an X-Box controller, media recorder and several laptops. &ldquo;You really need to earn your chops with [the camera],&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;And you constantly feel slightly compromised by what you&rsquo;re doing. But I think that&rsquo;s always a good space to be in as an artist: feeling uncomfortable.&rdquo; Mosse witnessed some horrific scenes, impossible to express through the prism of art. But, he says, once you&rsquo;re looking through the ground glass of the camera you become a machine with a job to do. &ldquo;I cling to the idea that although &lsquo;art is useless&rsquo;, it can be iconic,&rdquo; he says. &ldquo;It can be culturally resonant without being politically committed.&#8221; Richard Mosse is an Irish conceptual documentary photographer. More of his work can be viewed here. Heat Maps is on display at the Jack Shainman Gallery on West 20th Street, NYC until March 11. Alexandra Genova is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on Twitter and Instagram Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ERichard Mosse used thermal imagery to question our response to the refugee crisis\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":108650784,"featured_media":4667829,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[177,113545,4328,3263,430952309,430952310,458487,227019606,436,1823368,114694,11877487],"time_section":[326619029],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937791],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4667825"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4667825"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4667825"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4667825\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti- crisis","slug":"refugee-crisis","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":26605,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":63,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4658857,"date":"2017-02-15T08:30:15","date_gmt":"2017-02-15T13:30:15","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4658857"},"modified":"2017-02-15T08:30:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-15T13:30:00","slug":"america-black-and-white-zimmerman","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4658857\u002Famerica-black-and-white-zimmerman\u002F","title":{"rendered":"A Rare Look at the Early Photographs of John G. Zimmerman"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E&ldquo;There&rsquo;s no such thing as an impossible picture. If you can visualize a picture in your mind, you can make the camera do it.&rdquo; &ndash; John G. Zimmerman\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMany know the work of John G. Zimmerman in the context of his groundbreaking sports photography. He was the first photographer to place the camera above a basketball hoop and was known for using his equipment in new and innovative ways to get the shot he wanted. He was among the first staff photographers for \u003Cem\u003ESports Illustrated\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, photographing 10 Olympics and many covers for the famous \u003Cem\u003ESI\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Swimsuit Issue.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut, as the new book \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FAmerica-Black-White-Photographs-Zimmerman\u002Fdp\u002F9492081768\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAmerica in Black and White\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E illustrates, his archive goes much deeper than that. The book (like its companion \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.art2art.org\u002Fjohn-g-zimmerman.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eexhibit\u003C\u002Fa\u003E) offers a new look at Zimmerman&#8217;s early humanist photography, focusing on his career between 1950 and 1975, including famous pictures like the Mariner Church relocation (slide 7 above) as well as images shot for LIFE and \u003Cem\u003EEbony\u003C\u002Fem\u003E in their coverage of the Jim Crow South. Many of the images &mdash; which were selected by Belgian scholar Arne De Winde with the input of Zimmerman&#8217;s family &mdash; have never been seen or published before, and they show a thoughtful eye and attention to detail that would later inform his sports photos.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-medium alignleft \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4658865\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4658857\u002Famerica-black-and-white-zimmerman\u002F170202-john-zimmerman-book-cover\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F170202-john-zimmerman-book-cover.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,2375\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"John G. Zimmerman. Published by Hannibal.\" height=\"278\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:300px\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EJohn G. Zimmerman Archive\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EAmerica in Black and White: Selected Photographs of John G. Zimmerman. Published by Hannibal.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHis career in photography began at Freemont High School in California, where Hollywood cinematographer C.A. Bach led a photo program that produced no fewer than 8 LIFE staff photographers, including John Dominis, George Strock and Mark Kauffman. His professional career was jumpstarted when he happened to capture an attempted assassination of President Truman, the photos of which would be published in both TIME and LIFE in 1950.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne of the rarer stories in the book shows a shoeshine contest in Wilson, N.C., in 1952. Speaking with TIME, Zimmerman&rsquo;s daughter Linda recalled getting this set from the TIME-LIFE archives with little information on what she was seeing. Because the story had not been published, the magazine had not collected extensive caption issue. Intrigued by the subject matter, she worked with local librarians and archivists in North Carolina over the course of several years to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwunc.org\u002Fpost\u002Fbreathtaking-images-discovered-1950s-shoeshine-competition-north-carolina#stream\u002F0\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eidentify and locate \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ethe winner of the contest, Curtis Phillips.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EZimmerman&rsquo;s early assignments in the 1950s for \u003Cem\u003EEbony,\u003C\u002Fem\u003E photographing the segregated south, clearly influenced the way he would photograph in the years to come &mdash; and this look behind the scenes makes clear the pervasive reach of that time. For example, the fifth photograph above, showing a young African-American girl receiving polio treatment in Montgomery, Ala., was not published. But a similar Zimmerman photo of a young white girl \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fvault\u002Fissue\u002F1953-07-13\u002Fpage\u002F62\u002F\"\u003Eran in TIME magazine in 1953.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELinda Zimmerman notes that her father, who died in 2002, always worked in a linear fashion, always looking ahead, so the book&#8217;s focus on his early work is &#8220;a wonderful surprise&#8221; that contextualizes his entire career and offers a look at work rarely seen.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Theres no such thing as an impossible picture. For example, the fifth photograph above, showing a young African-American girl receiving polio treatment in Montgomery, Ala., was not published. But a similar Zimmerman photo of a young white girl ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fvault\u002Fissue\u002F1953-07-13\u002Fpage\u002F62\u002F"},"content":["ran in TIME magazine in 1953."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Linda Zimmerman notes that her father, who died in 2002, always worked in a linear fashion, always looking ahead, so the book's focus on his early work is \"a wonderful surprise\" that contextualizes his entire career and offers a look at work rarely seen."]}],"plain":"&ldquo;There&rsquo;s no such thing as an impossible picture. If you can visualize a picture in your mind, you can make the camera do it.&rdquo; &ndash; John G. Zimmerman Many know the work of John G. Zimmerman in the context of his groundbreaking sports photography. He was the first photographer to place the camera above a basketball hoop and was known for using his equipment in new and innovative ways to get the shot he wanted. He was among the first staff photographers for Sports Illustrated, photographing 10 Olympics and many covers for the famous SI Swimsuit Issue. But, as the new book America in Black and White illustrates, his archive goes much deeper than that. The book (like its companion exhibit) offers a new look at Zimmerman&#8217;s early humanist photography, focusing on his career between 1950 and 1975, including famous pictures like the Mariner Church relocation (slide 7 above) as well as images shot for LIFE and Ebony in their coverage of the Jim Crow South. Many of the images &mdash; which were selected by Belgian scholar Arne De Winde with the input of Zimmerman&#8217;s family &mdash; have never been seen or published before, and they show a thoughtful eye and attention to detail that would later inform his sports photos. John G. Zimmerman ArchiveAmerica in Black and White: Selected Photographs of John G. Zimmerman. Published by Hannibal. His career in photography began at Freemont High School in California, where Hollywood cinematographer C.A. Bach led a photo program that produced no fewer than 8 LIFE staff photographers, including John Dominis, George Strock and Mark Kauffman. His professional career was jumpstarted when he happened to capture an attempted assassination of President Truman, the photos of which would be published in both TIME and LIFE in 1950. One of the rarer stories in the book shows a shoeshine contest in Wilson, N.C., in 1952. Speaking with TIME, Zimmerman&rsquo;s daughter Linda recalled getting this set from the TIME-LIFE archives with little information on what she was seeing. Because the story had not been published, the magazine had not collected extensive caption issue. Intrigued by the subject matter, she worked with local librarians and archivists in North Carolina over the course of several years to identify and locate the winner of the contest, Curtis Phillips. Zimmerman&rsquo;s early assignments in the 1950s for Ebony, photographing the segregated south, clearly influenced the way he would photograph in the years to come &mdash; and this look behind the scenes makes clear the pervasive reach of that time. For example, the fifth photograph above, showing a young African-American girl receiving polio treatment in Montgomery, Ala., was not published. But a similar Zimmerman photo of a young white girl ran in TIME magazine in 1953. Linda Zimmerman notes that her father, who died in 2002, always worked in a linear fashion, always looking ahead, so the book&#8217;s focus on his early work is &#8220;a wonderful surprise&#8221; that contextualizes his entire career and offers a look at work rarely seen."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA new book showcases a different side of the noted sports photographer&#8217;s career\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":31476327,"featured_media":4661584,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[678,436],"time_section":[262754262,280055411,326619029],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937791],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4658857"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4658857"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4658857"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4658857\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4658857"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\
