Surprisingly Simple Technique Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Photographers Use"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4661664\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661515\u002Fsports-illustrated-swimsuit\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2227,1670\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.2\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"iPhone 6\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1470926264\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"4.15\",\"iso\":\"32\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.00050505050505051\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"si-swimsuit-2-crop\" data-image-description=\"pBarbara Palvin being photographed in ???\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=420\" alt=\"Janine Berey\" height=\"420\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EJanine Berey\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EBarbara Palvin being photographed in Curacao\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHigh-profile shoots rely on complex lighting setups, which in turn rely on a large team of assistants. For the \u003Cem\u003ESports Illustrated\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Swimsuit Issue, photographers tend not to use any lights at all. Instead they work with available light modifying it with strategically placed light modifiers such as a scrim and a bounce.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EA scrim is a large silk screen that resembles a giant fly swatter. It is placed between the sun and the model to soften sunlight. This reduces the sun a quarter-of-a-stop of light or a half-of-a-stop depending on the thickness of the material. \u003Cem\u003ESI\u003C\u002Fem\u003E photographer James Macari uses a scrim \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E&ldquo;if [the model] has recessed eyes and the sun is coming up to minimize the harshness of the light.&rdquo; At times scrims are essential to reducing shadows, but are also used for stylistic reasons. &ldquo;I like definition in the face,&#8221; says Macari. &#8220;But obviously flat light prints better. It&rsquo;s what sells in the commercial world. But with what we&rsquo;re selling they have to be fresh looking.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4661653\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661515\u002Fsports-illustrated-swimsuit\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2033,1518\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.2\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"iPhone 6\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1470581060\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"4.15\",\"iso\":\"32\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.0004040404040404\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"si-swimsuit-crop\" data-image-description=\"pAn assistant hold a skrimm above Barbara Palvin\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=418\" alt=\"Janine Berey\" height=\"418\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EJanine Berey\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EAn assistant hold a skrimm above Rose Bertram\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EScrims are quite large, generally 6&#215;4.5 or 8&#215;10 feet. They can be quite cumbersome to use and can turn into sails if turned in the wrong direction on a windy day, causing them to snap.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EAssistants and photographers should also be aware of the shadow scrim&rsquo;s can create.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E &#8220;You&rsquo;ve got to be careful with the shadow,&#8221; says \u003Cem\u003ESI\u003C\u002Fem\u003E photographer Ben Watts. &#8220;It creates a square shadow which you want to camouflage in with other shadows like palm leaves or retouch out.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EBut scrims are often only half of the battle. While scrims reduce the intensity of the light, reflectors can help add light and contrast into the shadows areas like the face and the eyes. There are a variety of bounce materials, each with different shine qualities. The most common are white, silver, and gold. Each photographer has their own preferences. For James Macari it&rsquo;s old silver reflectors. &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t use any gold. I prefer to use a silver bounce. I also use old bounces because they&rsquo;re weaker.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4661660\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661515\u002Fsports-illustrated-swimsuit\u002Fsi-swimsuit4\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit4.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"4032,3024\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.2\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"iPhone 6s\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1478632242\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"4.15\",\"iso\":\"25\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.008695652173913\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"si-swimsuit4\" data-image-description=\"pA reflector (on the right) bouncing gold light into model ???\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit4.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit4.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit4.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=420\" alt=\"si-swimsuit4\" height=\"420\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EA reflector (on the right) bouncing gold light into model Hannah Ferguson \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-inline_small alignleft \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4661517\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661515\u002Fsports-illustrated-swimsuit\u002Fashley-graham\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fashley-graham.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"432,590\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"0\",\"copyright\":\"\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"0\"}' data-image-title=\"ashley-graham\" data-image-description=\"\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fashley-graham.jpg?quality=85&w=220\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fashley-graham.jpg?quality=85&w=432\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fashley-graham.jpg?w=190&#038;quality=85&#038;h=259\" alt=\"James Macari&acirc;&#128;&#148;Sports Illustrated\" height=\"259\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EJames Macari&mdash;Sports Illustrated\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EIt is worth noting that beach shoots also provide quite a few natural reflectors. Sand and water can bounce a significant amount of light into the subjects. Macari prefers to shoot without any light modifiers at all when the light is perfect. That approach worked so well for his shoot with Ashley Graham it ended up on the cover of last year&rsquo;s issue.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUsing scrims and reflectors might be essential but the true trick is in the timing. On a typical \u003Cem\u003ESI\u003C\u002Fem\u003E shoot, James Macari wakes up at 3 AM, starts shooting around 6 AM until 10 AM. He then edits and quickly naps before shooting again at 7 PM to around 10 PM. The photographers and tireless photo staff lead by MJ Day maintain that breakneck schedule for ten to 18 days a few times a year. &ldquo;It is a dream job sure, but it sure can run you down,&#8221; says Macari.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4661664","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-2-crop.jpg?w=560","alt":"Janine Berey","width":"560","height":"420"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Barbara Palvin being photographed in Curacao"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Janine Berey"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["High-profile shoots rely on complex lighting setups, which in turn rely on a large team of assistants. For the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Sports Illustrated"]}," Swimsuit Issue, photographers tend not to use any lights at all. Instead they work with available light modifying it with strategically placed light modifiers such as a scrim and a bounce."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A scrim is a large silk screen that resembles a giant fly swatter. ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["SI"]}," photographer James Macari uses a scrim  if [the model] has recessed eyes and the sun is coming up to minimize the harshness of the light. At times scrims are essential to reducing shadows, but are also used for stylistic reasons. I like definition in the face,\" says Macari. \"But obviously flat light prints better. Its what sells in the commercial world. But with what were selling they have to be fresh looking."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4661653","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit-crop.jpg?w=560","alt":"Janine Berey","width":"560","height":"418"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["An assistant hold a skrimm above Rose Bertram"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Janine Berey"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Scrims are quite large, generally 6x4.5 or 8x10 feet. They can be quite cumbersome to use and can turn into sails if turned in the wrong direction on a windy day, causing them to snap."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Assistants and photographers should also be aware of the shadow scrims can create.  \"Youve got to be careful with the shadow,\" says ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["SI"]}," photographer Ben Watts. \"It creates a square shadow which you want to camouflage in with other shadows like palm leaves or retouch out."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But scrims are often only half of the battle. While scrims reduce the intensity of the light, reflectors can help add light and contrast into the shadows areas like the face and the eyes. There are a variety of bounce materials, each with different shine qualities. The most common are white, silver, and gold. Each photographer has their own preferences. For James Macari its old silver reflectors. I dont use any gold. I prefer to use a silver bounce. I also use old bounces because theyre weaker. "]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4661660","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fsi-swimsuit4.jpg?w=560","alt":"si-swimsuit4","width":"560","height":"420"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["A reflector (on the right) bouncing gold light into model Hannah Ferguson "]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4661517","align":"alignleft","width":"190"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fashley-graham.jpg?w=190","alt":"James MacariSports Illustrated","width":"190","height":"259"},"content":[]}," ",{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["James MacariSports Illustrated"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It is worth noting that beach shoots also provide quite a few natural reflectors. Sand and water can bounce a significant amount of light into the subjects. Macari prefers to shoot without any light modifiers at all when the light is perfect. That approach worked so well for his shoot with Ashley Graham it ended up on the cover of last years issue."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Using scrims and reflectors might be essential but the true trick is in the timing. On a typical ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["SI"]}," shoot, James Macari wakes up at 3 AM, starts shooting around 6 AM until 10 AM. He then edits and quickly naps before shooting again at 7 PM to around 10 PM. The photographers and tireless photo staff lead by MJ Day maintain that breakneck schedule for ten to 18 days a few times a year. It is a dream job sure, but it sure can run you down,\" says Macari."]}],"plain":"Janine BereyBarbara Palvin being photographed in Curacao High-profile shoots rely on complex lighting setups, which in turn rely on a large team of assistants. For the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue, photographers tend not to use any lights at all. Instead they work with available light modifying it with strategically placed light modifiers such as a scrim and a bounce. A scrim is a large silk screen that resembles a giant fly swatter. It is placed between the sun and the model to soften sunlight. This reduces the sun a quarter-of-a-stop of light or a half-of-a-stop depending on the thickness of the material. SI photographer James Macari uses a scrim &ldquo;if [the model] has recessed eyes and the sun is coming up to minimize the harshness of the light.&rdquo; At times scrims are essential to reducing shadows, but are also used for stylistic reasons. &ldquo;I like definition in the face,&#8221; says Macari. &#8220;But obviously flat light prints better. It&rsquo;s what sells in the commercial world. But with what we&rsquo;re selling they have to be fresh looking.&rdquo; Janine BereyAn assistant hold a skrimm above Rose Bertram Scrims are quite large, generally 6&#215;4.5 or 8&#215;10 feet. They can be quite cumbersome to use and can turn into sails if turned in the wrong direction on a windy day, causing them to snap. Assistants and photographers should also be aware of the shadow scrim&rsquo;s can create. &#8220;You&rsquo;ve got to be careful with the shadow,&#8221; says SI photographer Ben Watts. &#8220;It creates a square shadow which you want to camouflage in with other shadows like palm leaves or retouch out.&rdquo; But scrims are often only half of the battle. While scrims reduce the intensity of the light, reflectors can help add light and contrast into the shadows areas like the face and the eyes. There are a variety of bounce materials, each with different shine qualities. The most common are white, silver, and gold. Each photographer has their own preferences. For James Macari it&rsquo;s old silver reflectors. &ldquo;I don&rsquo;t use any gold. I prefer to use a silver bounce. I also use old bounces because they&rsquo;re weaker.&rdquo; A reflector (on the right) bouncing gold light into model Hannah Ferguson James Macari&mdash;Sports Illustrated It is worth noting that beach shoots also provide quite a few natural reflectors. Sand and water can bounce a significant amount of light into the subjects. Macari prefers to shoot without any light modifiers at all when the light is perfect. That approach worked so well for his shoot with Ashley Graham it ended up on the cover of last year&rsquo;s issue. Using scrims and reflectors might be essential but the true trick is in the timing. On a typical SI shoot, James Macari wakes up at 3 AM, starts shooting around 6 AM until 10 AM. He then edits and quickly naps before shooting again at 7 PM to around 10 PM. The photographers and tireless photo staff lead by MJ Day maintain that breakneck schedule for ten to 18 days a few times a year. &ldquo;It is a dream job sure, but it sure can run you down,&#8221; says Macari."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor Sports Illustrated&#8217;s Swimsuit issue, photographers always use this one Swimsuit","title":"swim161_tk1_00032-rawwmfinal1920"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":6,"name":"technology","slug":"technology","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":542,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":1236,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","sports"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4669974,"date":"2017-02-14T07:30:14","date_gmt":"2017-02-14T12:30:14","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4669974"},"modified":"2017-02-14T10:32:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-14T15:32:00","slug":"love-intimacy","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4669974\u002Flove-intimacy\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Lessons of Love and Intimacy"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENestled in the foothills of the Saugus Mountains, is a close-knit community where love is able to flourish without inhibition. Los Angeles Residential Community (LARC) Ranch is home to 100 developmentally disabled adults, many of whom have formed romantic relationships. There is casual dating, long-term commitments and even several marriages. It&rsquo;s a space where residents feel safe articulating who they are. This vulnerability and openness is what drew photographer Isadora Kosofsky to begin her project, \u003Cem\u003ELove the One You&rsquo;re With\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, an ongoing multi-disciplinary work that closely follows the complexity of relationships within an often-sidelined part of society.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKosofsky documented two couples over the course of three years. Barry, 59, and Debbie, 51, have been together for 31 years while Krysta, 24, and Nathanial, 28, were together three years before their break up last month. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a project about intimacy. And it was important for me to make them feel comfortable so that moments that anybody can identify with were revealed,&rdquo; Kosofsky tells TIME. &ldquo;For example the conflict between closeness and distance, the balance between togetherness and solitude are many of the fundamental paradoxes that come up between two people who are in love.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5322319225001\" data-video-id=\"5322319225001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EVideo directed and produced by Isadora Kosofsky, edited by Elissa Mirzaei, music by Josh Woodward. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBarry is a feminist and a hippie at heart, calling Debbie his &lsquo;Yoko Ono&rsquo;. He is very accepting of her and doesn&rsquo;t see her limitations as limitations. He once told Kosofsky: &ldquo;There&rsquo;s so much love in the world and also so much hate. But we need to counteract that with love.&rdquo; Kosofsky adds: &ldquo;When they say unconditional love, they really mean it. They honor each other.&rdquo; Their relationship began when they were both living at home with their families but when Barry moved to LARC when his mother was unable to take care of him, Debbie followed soon after. &ldquo;\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EWe are lovers but I don&#8217;t make love to her. When I put my arms around her that is making love to her\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E,&rdquo; Barry told Kosofsky.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKosofsky had been working with Debbie and Barry for a year before she decided to explore how young love manifests itself at LARC. She witnessed the love between Nathanial and Krista develop from its first blushes, when Nathanial gave Krista a rose he bought from the 99 Cents store. &ldquo;Nathanial would stand outside the workshop and mouth &lsquo;I love you Krista, I want you to be my wife,&rsquo; and practice saying it to her by himself,&rdquo; says Kosofsky. &ldquo;He would then repeat it so that when he spoke to her it would be clear for her to understand.&rdquo; They were together for three years and engaged for a time but broke up a month ago. Krista told Kosofsky they simply weren&rsquo;t happy anymore. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s important that people understand the complexity of their relationship,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;And that we can learn, as I have, lessons of love, intimacy, forgiveness, redemption and acceptance from them.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKosofsky believes most people in mainstream society don&rsquo;t think developmentally disabled people are capable of sustaining relationships. &ldquo;Their difference seems to strip them of their humanness in the public consciousness,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;So we assume that because they have different needs they therefore don&rsquo;t share ours.&rdquo; There is also a presumption that if they do experience romance it&rsquo;s superficial, without depth or complexity. &ldquo;In fact I believe that special-needs love, is how love is supposed to be,&rdquo; she says. The director at LARC, Kathy Starkey, encourages agency among the residents, whilst also having their needs met by those around them and the wider community.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKosofsky has been visiting the Ranch for three years and has developed an intimate bond with her subjects. &ldquo;I feel part of the community now in a way,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;For me the goal is to become an occupant when I&rsquo;m working. Of course being a witness and holding a journalistic distance is important. But for me holding an intimate relationship with the subjects is as tantamount as the image-making process.&rdquo; Kosofsky&rsquo;s goal, as with all her projects is for people to &ldquo;experience these lives, be brought into their world and be able to relate and identify with them.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignnone \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4670138\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4669974\u002Flove-intimacy\u002Fisadorakosofsky19-2\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky191.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,1708\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"NIKON D810\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1486704753\",\"copyright\":\"\\u2044\\u2044\\u2044copyright 2016 Isadora Kosofsky\",\"focal_length\":\"35\",\"iso\":\"320\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.033333333333333\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"isadorakosofsky19\" data-image-description=\"pDebbie, age 51, and Barry, age 59, sit together on Debbies bed. Eight years ago, when Barry&#128;&#153;s mother decided to place him at LARC Ranch, Debbie asked her family to let her live there in order to be with Barry. \u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky191.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky191.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky191.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=374\" alt=\"Isadora Kosofsky\" height=\"374\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EIsadora Kosofsky\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EDebbie, age 51, and Barry, age 59, sit together on Debbie&#8217;s bed. Eight years ago, when Barry&rsquo;s mother decided to place him at LARC Ranch, Debbie asked her family to let her live there in order to be with Barry. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x alignnone \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4670137\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4669974\u002Flove-intimacy\u002Fisadorakosofsky18-2\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky181.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,1707\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"2.8\",\"credit\":\"\",\"camera\":\"NIKON D810\",\"caption\":\"\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1486882071\",\"copyright\":\"\\u2044\\u2044\\u2044copyright 2016 Isadora Kosofsky\",\"focal_length\":\"35\",\"iso\":\"500\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0.05\",\"title\":\"\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"isadorakosofsky18\" data-image-description=\"pA photograph of Debbie, age 22, and Barry, age 30, taken shortly after they met 31 years ago at a workshop for developmentally disabled adults in San Fernando Valley, California. As young adults, they sat apart and passed notes to each other during work. In hindsight, Debbie describes, &#128;&#156;I had nobody. He had nobody.&#128;&#157; Debbie immediately liked Barry because her old boyfriend, Donald, held her too tightly, and Barry was gentler and didn&#128;&#153;t need to be told that she wanted to be held. Barry was attracted to Debbie because she was a new face that he wanted to know. When thinking back to his attraction, he says, &#128;&#156;Debbie went through some hard times when she was a young girl and that attracted me to her. I wanted to help her.&#128;&#157;\u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky181.jpg?quality=85&w=300\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky181.jpg?quality=85&w=600\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky181.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=373\" alt=\"Isadora Kosofsky\" height=\"373\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EIsadora Kosofsky\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EA photograph of Debbie, age 22, and Barry, age 30, taken shortly after they met 31 years ago at a workshop for developmentally disabled adults in San Fernando Valley, California. As young adults, they sat apart and passed notes to each other during work. In hindsight, Debbie describes, &ldquo;I had nobody. He had nobody.&rdquo; Debbie immediately liked Barry because her old boyfriend, Donald, held her too tightly, and Barry was gentler and didn&rsquo;t need to be told that she wanted to be held. Barry was attracted to Debbie because she was a new face that he wanted to know. When thinking back to his attraction, he says, &ldquo;Debbie went through some hard times when she was a young girl and that attracted me to her. I wanted to help her.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe honesty and vulnerability of these relationships particularly struck Kosofsky. &ldquo;They are so unmasked,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;It has been really wonderful to document and work with people who will readily show their emotions.&rdquo; The couples at LARC Ranch contend with the same highs and lows as any adult relationship; the joy of first dates, the celebration of milestones and later talk about marriage and children. This emotional honesty also manifests itself in introspection. &ldquo;They are aware of their own disenfranchisement,&rdquo; she says. But finding support in one another &ndash; as well as romantic attraction &ndash; is extremely empowering. Kosofsky credits the Ranch with providing a space for them to be safe articulating who they are.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPhotography aside, her time spent at LARC has taught Kosofsky a more authentic way to love. &ldquo;They have shown me a fearless love. They&rsquo;re able to extrapolate meaning I think in a much more authentic way,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;They&rsquo;ve shown me a love where you open your heart without hesitation and you give. And whatever happens, happens. But at least you tried.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIsadora Kosofsky\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E is a documentary photographer and filmmaker based in Los Angeles. You can view more of her work \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.isadorakosofsky.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ehere\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EOlivier Laurent\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E, who edited this photo essay, is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Ca href='https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.wordpress.com\u002Fmentions\u002Folivierclaurent\u002F' class='mention'\u003E\u003Cspan class='mentions-prefix'\u003E@\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Eolivierclaurent\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EAlexandra Genova \u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003E\u003Ci\u003Eis a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nestled in the foothills of the Saugus Mountains, is a close-knit community where love is able to flourish without inhibition. Kosofskys goal, as with all her projects is for people to experience these lives, be brought into their world and be able to relate and identify with them."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4670138","align":"alignnone","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky191.jpg?w=560","alt":"Isadora Kosofsky","width":"560","height":"374"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Debbie, age 51, and Barry, age 59, sit together on Debbie's bed. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Isadora Kosofsky"]}]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4670137","align":"alignnone","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fisadorakosofsky181.jpg?w=560","alt":"Isadora Kosofsky","width":"560","height":"373"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["A photograph of Debbie, age 22, and Barry, age 30, taken shortly after they met 31 years ago at a workshop for developmentally disabled adults in San Fernando Valley, California. As young adults, they sat apart and passed notes to each other during work. In hindsight, Debbie describes, I had nobody. He had nobody. Debbie immediately liked Barry because her old boyfriend, Donald, held her too tightly, and Barry was gentler and didnt need to be told that she wanted to be held. Barry was attracted to Debbie because she was a new face that he wanted to know. When thinking back to his attraction, he says, Debbie went through some hard times when she was a young girl and that attracted me to her. I wanted to help her."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["Isadora Kosofsky"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The honesty and vulnerability of these relationships particularly struck Kosofsky. They are so unmasked, she says. It has been really wonderful to document and work with people who will readily show their emotions. The couples at LARC Ranch contend with the same highs and lows as any adult relationship; the joy of first dates, the celebration of milestones and later talk about marriage and children. This emotional honesty also manifests itself in introspection. They are aware of their own disenfranchisement, she says. But finding support in one another  as well as romantic attraction  is extremely empowering. Kosofsky credits the Ranch with providing a space for them to be safe articulating who they are."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Photography aside, her time spent at LARC has taught Kosofsky a more authentic way to love. They have shown me a fearless love. Theyre able to extrapolate meaning I think in a much more authentic way, she says. Theyve shown me a love where you open your heart without hesitation and you give. And whatever happens, happens. But at least you tried."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Isadora Kosofsky"]}," is a documentary photographer and filmmaker based in Los Angeles. You can view more of her work ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.isadorakosofsky.com\u002F"},"content":["here"]},". "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Olivier Laurent"]},", who edited this photo essay, is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Folivierclaurent","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]}," @olivierclaurent."]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Alexandra Genova "]}]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FAlexandraaa_cg","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["Twitter"]}]}," and ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.instagram.com\u002Falexandraaaa_cg\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"Nestled in the foothills of the Saugus Mountains, is a close-knit community where love is able to flourish without inhibition. Los Angeles Residential Community (LARC) Ranch is home to 100 developmentally disabled adults, many of whom have formed romantic relationships. There is casual dating, long-term commitments and even several marriages. It&rsquo;s a space where residents feel safe articulating who they are. This vulnerability and openness is what drew photographer Isadora Kosofsky to begin her project, Love the One You&rsquo;re With, an ongoing multi-disciplinary work that closely follows the complexity of relationships within an often-sidelined part of society. Kosofsky documented two couples over the course of three years. Barry, 59, and Debbie, 51, have been together for 31 years while Krysta, 24, and Nathanial, 28, were together three years before their break up last month. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s a project about intimacy. And it was important for me to make them feel comfortable so that moments that anybody can identify with were revealed,&rdquo; Kosofsky tells TIME. &ldquo;For example the conflict between closeness and distance, the balance between togetherness and solitude are many of the fundamental paradoxes that come up between two people who are in love.&rdquo; Video directed and produced by Isadora Kosofsky, edited by Elissa Mirzaei, music by Josh Woodward. Barry is a feminist and a hippie at heart, calling Debbie his &lsquo;Yoko Ono&rsquo;. He is very accepting of her and doesn&rsquo;t see her limitations as limitations. He once told Kosofsky: &ldquo;There&rsquo;s so much love in the world and also so much hate. But we need to counteract that with love.&rdquo; Kosofsky adds: &ldquo;When they say unconditional love, they really mean it. They honor each other.&rdquo; Their relationship began when they were both living at home with their families but when Barry moved to LARC when his mother was unable to take care of him, Debbie followed soon after. &ldquo;We are lovers but I don&#8217;t make love to her. When I put my arms around her that is making love to her,&rdquo; Barry told Kosofsky. Kosofsky had been working with Debbie and Barry for a year before she decided to explore how young love manifests itself at LARC. She witnessed the love between Nathanial and Krista develop from its first blushes, when Nathanial gave Krista a rose he bought from the 99 Cents store. &ldquo;Nathanial would stand outside the workshop and mouth &lsquo;I love you Krista, I want you to be my wife,&rsquo; and practice saying it to her by himself,&rdquo; says Kosofsky. &ldquo;He would then repeat it so that when he spoke to her it would be clear for her to understand.&rdquo; They were together for three years and engaged for a time but broke up a month ago. Krista told Kosofsky they simply weren&rsquo;t happy anymore. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s important that people understand the complexity of their relationship,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;And that we can learn, as I have, lessons of love, intimacy, forgiveness, redemption and acceptance from them.&rdquo; Kosofsky believes most people in mainstream society don&rsquo;t think developmentally disabled people are capable of sustaining relationships. &ldquo;Their difference seems to strip them of their humanness in the public consciousness,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;So we assume that because they have different needs they therefore don&rsquo;t share ours.&rdquo; There is also a presumption that if they do experience romance it&rsquo;s superficial, without depth or complexity. &ldquo;In fact I believe that special-needs love, is how love is supposed to be,&rdquo; she says. The director at LARC, Kathy Starkey, encourages agency among the residents, whilst also having their needs met by those around them and the wider community. Kosofsky has been visiting the Ranch for three years and has developed an intimate bond with her subjects. &ldquo;I feel part of the community now in a way,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;For me the goal is to become an occupant when I&rsquo;m working. Of course being a witness and holding a journalistic distance is important. But for me holding an intimate relationship with the subjects is as tantamount as the image-making process.&rdquo; Kosofsky&rsquo;s goal, as with all her projects is for people to &ldquo;experience these lives, be brought into their world and be able to relate and identify with them.&rdquo; Isadora KosofskyDebbie, age 51, and Barry, age 59, sit together on Debbie&#8217;s bed. Eight years ago, when Barry&rsquo;s mother decided to place him at LARC Ranch, Debbie asked her family to let her live there in order to be with Barry. Isadora KosofskyA photograph of Debbie, age 22, and Barry, age 30, taken shortly after they met 31 years ago at a workshop for developmentally disabled adults in San Fernando Valley, California. As young adults, they sat apart and passed notes to each other during work. In hindsight, Debbie describes, &ldquo;I had nobody. He had nobody.&rdquo; Debbie immediately liked Barry because her old boyfriend, Donald, held her too tightly, and Barry was gentler and didn&rsquo;t need to be told that she wanted to be held. Barry was attracted to Debbie because she was a new face that he wanted to know. When thinking back to his attraction, he says, &ldquo;Debbie went through some hard times when she was a young girl and that attracted me to her. I wanted to help her.&rdquo; The honesty and vulnerability of these relationships particularly struck Kosofsky. &ldquo;They are so unmasked,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;It has been really wonderful to document and work with people who will readily show their emotions.&rdquo; The couples at LARC Ranch contend with the same highs and lows as any adult relationship; the joy of first dates, the celebration of milestones and later talk about marriage and children. This emotional honesty also manifests itself in introspection. &ldquo;They are aware of their own disenfranchisement,&rdquo; she says. But finding support in one another &ndash; as well as romantic attraction &ndash; is extremely empowering. Kosofsky credits the Ranch with providing a space for them to be safe articulating who they are. Photography aside, her time spent at LARC has taught Kosofsky a more authentic way to love. &ldquo;They have shown me a fearless love. They&rsquo;re able to extrapolate meaning I think in a much more authentic way,&rdquo; she says. &ldquo;They&rsquo;ve shown me a love where you open your heart without hesitation and you give. And whatever happens, happens. But at least you tried.&rdquo; Isadora Kosofsky is a documentary photographer and filmmaker based in Los Angeles. You can view more of her work here. Olivier Laurent, who edited this photo essay, is the editor of TIME LightBox. Follow him on Twitter and Instagram @olivierclaurent. Alexandra Genova is a writer and contributor for TIME LightBox. Follow her on Twitter and Instagram. Press Photo 2017: The Best News Images"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhen America erupted in protest after the shooting death of Alton Sterling, one image elegantly illustrated the power of peaceful defiance. The photograph shows demonstrator\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4403635\u002Fieshia-evans-jonathan-bachman-baton-rouge\u002F\"\u003E Ieshia Evans\u003C\u002Fa\u003E standing resolute as two heavily armored police approach her and came to represent what was happening in Baton Rouge &ndash; and the country &ndash; at that moment. The poignancy of this moment is reflected at this year&rsquo;s World Press Photo awards and the iconic image, taken by Jonathan Bachman, has won First Prize in the Singles category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAn Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EClashes between police and activists also marked the Anti-DAPL protests, which saw riot police use rubber bullets, pepper spray and tasers to clear marchers from the Standing Rock site. Amber Bracken&rsquo;s documentation of the struggle won First Prize in the Stories category. While Tomas Munita&rsquo;s haunting portrayal of Cuba in mourning for Fidel Castro was another notable series that made this year&#8217;s News Shortlist.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. The photograph shows demonstrator Ieshia Evans standing resolute as two heavily armored police approach her and came to represent what was happening in Baton Rouge &ndash; and the country &ndash; at that moment. The poignancy of this moment is reflected at this year&rsquo;s World Press Photo awards and the iconic image, taken by Jonathan Bachman, has won First Prize in the Singles category. An Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year Clashes between police and activists also marked the Anti-DAPL protests, which saw riot police use rubber bullets, pepper spray and tasers to clear marchers from the Standing Rock site. Amber Bracken&rsquo;s documentation of the struggle won First Prize in the Stories category. While Tomas Munita&rsquo;s haunting portrayal of Cuba in mourning for Fidel Castro was another notable series that made this year&#8217;s News Shortlist. The winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22. See the winning images in the Sports, Nature and People categories, as well as the World Press Photo of the Year. Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe jury selected these images as the best in A man is treated with milk of magnesia after being pepper sprayed at the police blockade on highway 1806 near Cannon Ball, North Dakota on Sunday, November 20, 2016. Many people were injured when, with temperatures below freezing, police deployed water canons, pepper spray, tear gas, rubber bullets and percussion grenades. The teepee is signed by camp supporters from all over North America and around the world.","credit":"Amber Bracken, Contemporary Issues - First Prize, Stories.","alt":"Oceti Sakowin - Oceti Sakowin, or the Seven Council Fires, is the true name of the great Sioux nation and refers to the coming together of the different factions of the tribe. Oglala, Cheyenne, Ut, Cree, Hopi and non-indigenous all are among the 200+ tribes represented in the camps and on the front lines. The last time there was a similar gathering was before the Battle of the Little Bighorn, 1876.Jesse Jaso, 12, enters the Unity Teepee, at the Sacred Stone Camp near Cannonball, ND on Saturday, September 10, 2016. The teepee is signed by camp supporters from all over North America and around the world. Amber Bracken for Buzzfeed First Prize, Singles","alt":"KABUL, AFGHANISTAN -MARCH 29, 2016: A the Emergency hospital Najiba holds her nephew Shabir, age 2, who was injured from a bomb blast which killed his sister in Kabul on March 29, 2016. Najiba had to stay with the children as their mother buried her daughter.In 2016 marked another milestone in its 15-year engagement in Afghanistan. Despite billions of dollars spent by the international community to stabilize the country, Afghanistan has seen little improvement in terms of overall stability and human security. The situation on the ground for Afghans continues to be grave. Security for the Afghan people has also deteriorated in large swaths of the country, further complicating humanitarian response. Afghan civilians are at greater risk today than at any time since Taliban rule. According to UN statistics, in the first half of 2016 at least 1,600 people had died, and more than 3,500 people were injured, a 4 per cent increase in overall civilian causalities compared to the same period last year. The upsurge in violence has had devastating consequences for civilians, with suicide bombings and targeted attacks by the Taliban and other insurgents causing 70 percent of all civilian casualties.","width":2560,"height":1707,"orientation":"square","url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668156\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-news\u002Fphoto\u002F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting\u002F","encoded_url":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668156\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-news\u002Fphoto\u002F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting\u002F","twitter_via":"","encoded_title":"World+Press+Photo+2017%3A+The+Best+News+Images","encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4668156%2Fworld-press-photo-2017-news%2Fphoto%2F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting%2F","twitter_encoded_shortlink":"http%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4668156%2Fworld-press-photo-2017-news%2Fphoto%2F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting%2F","email_title":"World%20Press%20Photo%202017%3A%20The%20Best%20News%20Images","twitter_text":"World%20Press%20Photo%202017%3A%20See%20the%20best%20news%20images","fb_text":"World%20Press%20Photo%202017%3A%20See%20the%20best%20news%20images","email_body":"World%20Press%20Photo%202017%3A%20The%20Best%20News%20Images%0A%0AThe%20jury%20selected%20these%20images%20as%20the%20best%20in%20photojournalism%0A%0Ahttp%3A%2F%2Ftime.com%2F4668156%2Fworld-press-photo-2017-news%2Fphoto%2F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting%2F","src":{"small":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting.jpg?quality=85&w=405","small_2x":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting.jpg?quality=85&w=810","landscape_large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F017_paula-bronstein_time-lightbox_pulitzer-center-for-crisis-reporting.jpg?quality=85&w=550&h=367&crop=1","large":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpr Press Photo 2017: The Best People Images"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ESometimes the innocence of a child&rsquo;s face can say more about a country&rsquo;s struggle than countless graphic images of blood and destruction. A haunting photograph of five-year-old Maha, whose family were forced to flee ISIS, does just that. The image, taken by Magnus Wennman, quietly reveals the suffering felt by so many Iraqis at the hands of terrorism and is the winner in the World Press Photo&#8217;s People Singles category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAn Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe quiet beauty of Robin Hammond&rsquo;s portrait of Helen, a woman living in a developing country with a mental illness, took second prize in same category. Michael Vince Kim&rsquo;s vignette of ethnic Koreans born in Mexico and Cuba as a result of migration won first prize in the People Stories category, while Antonio Gibotta took second prize for his lively portrayal of Spanish traditions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESee the winning images in the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668076\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-sports\u002F\"\u003ESports\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668076\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-nature\u002F\"\u003ENature\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668156\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-news\u002F\"\u003ENews\u003C\u002Fa\u003E categories, as well as the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F\"\u003EWorld Press Photo of the Year\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EFollow \u003Cstrong\u003ETIME LightBox\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E on \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EFacebook\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETwitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EInstagram\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Sometimes the innocence of a childs face can say more about a countrys struggle than countless graphic images of blood and destruction. A haunting photograph of five-year-old Maha, whose family were forced to flee ISIS, does just that. The image, taken by Magnus Wennman, quietly reveals the suffering felt by so many Iraqis at the hands of terrorism and is the winner in the World Press Photo's People Singles category."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["An Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The quiet beauty of Robin Hammonds portrait of Helen, a woman living in a developing country with a mental illness, took second prize in same category. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["See the winning images in the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668076\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-sports\u002F"},"content":["Sports"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668076\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-nature\u002F"},"content":["Nature"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668156\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-news\u002F"},"content":["News"]}," categories, as well as the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F"},"content":["World Press Photo of the Year"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Follow ",{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["TIME LightBox"]}," on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.facebook.com\u002Ftimelightbox","target":"_blank"},"content":["Facebook"]},", ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002Ftimepictures","target":"_blank"},"content":["Twitter"]}," and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Finstagram.com\u002Ftimelightbox\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Instagram"]},"."]}]}],"plain":"Sometimes the innocence of a child&rsquo;s face can say more about a country&rsquo;s struggle than countless graphic images of blood and destruction. A haunting photograph of five-year-old Maha, whose family were forced to flee ISIS, does just that. The image, taken by Magnus Wennman, quietly reveals the suffering felt by so many Iraqis at the hands of terrorism and is the winner in the World Press Photo&#8217;s People Singles category. An Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year The quiet beauty of Robin Hammond&rsquo;s portrait of Helen, a woman living in a developing country with a mental illness, took second prize in same category. Michael Vince Kim&rsquo;s vignette of ethnic Koreans born in Mexico and Cuba as a result of migration won first prize in the People Stories category, while Antonio Gibotta took second prize for his lively portrayal of Spanish traditions. The winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22. See the winning images in the Sports, Nature and News categories, as well as the World Press Photo of the Year. Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe jury selected these images as the best in Her illness developed later in life. In developing countries, over 80% of people living with mental health problems do not receive any treatment.","credit":"Robin HammondNoor for Witness Change, winner in the People - Second Prize, Singles category.","alt":"41 year old Hellen Alfred (right) with her daughter, 22 year old Gloria John Peter (left). Both mother and daughter live with a mental health problem, Hellens illness developed later in life and Gloria was born with a mental health problem. (+211954148800).  Handicap International (HI) launched a four year project funded by AFD (L'Agence Franaise de Dveloppement) in support of the Ministry of Health to strengthen their mental health activities in the Central Prison and Juba Teaching Hospital. The project aims to develop mental health policy in South Sudan and create evidence for international advocacy on social and civic participation of people living with mental health problems. Links have been established with the prison and hospital to support the growing needs of persons with psychosocial impairments currently detained within the prison. Training of prison and hospital staff on basic care, identification and treatment plans will be strengthened further by specialized advanced clinical training in association with various mental health actors and experts. To supplement HIs work within the institutions, HI seeks to establishing connections with local community actors such as NGOs and DPOs (Disabled Peoples Organisations) providing MHPSS services over the coming year in order to facilitate post-institutional care at a community level as well as to raise awareness in community through various measures (including peer support, advocacy, communication and educational activities). Juba, South Sudan. Photo Robin Hammond. 02 April Press Photo","slug":"world-press-photo","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":31949,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":48,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4668076,"date":"2017-02-13T05:30:34","date_gmt":"2017-02-13T10:30:34","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4668076"},"modified":"2017-02-13T05:30:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-13T10:30:00","slug":"world-press-photo-2017-sports","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668076\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-sports\u002F","title":{"rendered":"World Press Photo 2017: The Best Sports Images"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWith spectacular wins and even more spectacular falls, the Grand National is one of sport&rsquo;s most dramatic events. This is reflected in Tom Jenkins&rsquo; photograph of Jockey Nina Carberry&rsquo;s theatrical tumble at this year&rsquo;s race, which won First Prize in the Sports Singles category at the World Press Photo awards.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAn Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EKai Oliver Pfaffenbach&rsquo;s photograph of a grinning Usain Bolt clinching gold at the Men&rsquo;s 100m seemed to encapsulate the vitality and joy of the Olympic Games and won Third Place in the same category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EGiovanni Capriotti&rsquo;s unconventional portrayal of Rugby players, which throws macho stereotyping out the window, won First Prize for the Stories category. Meanwhile, the intensity and pleasure of competitive chess was thoughtfully drawn by Michael Hanke, whose series, which won Second Prize in the same category, shows that excitement can be found off the pitch too.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. This is reflected in Tom Jenkins&rsquo; photograph of Jockey Nina Carberry&rsquo;s theatrical tumble at this year&rsquo;s race, which won First Prize in the Sports Singles category at the World Press Photo awards. An Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year Kai Oliver Pfaffenbach&rsquo;s photograph of a grinning Usain Bolt clinching gold at the Men&rsquo;s 100m seemed to encapsulate the vitality and joy of the Olympic Games and won Third Place in the same category. Giovanni Capriotti&rsquo;s unconventional portrayal of Rugby players, which throws macho stereotyping out the window, won First Prize for the Stories category. Meanwhile, the intensity and pleasure of competitive chess was thoughtfully drawn by Michael Hanke, whose series, which won Second Prize in the same category, shows that excitement can be found off the pitch too. The winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22. See the winning images in the Nature, People and News categories, as well as the World Press Photo of the Year. Follow TIME LightBox on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWith spectacular wins and even more spectacular falls, the Grand National is one of sport&rsquo;s most dramatic events. Press Photo","slug":"world-press-photo","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":31949,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":48,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":326619029,"name":"LightBox","slug":"lightbox","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":32739,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"","parent":0,"count":2826,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["lightbox","sports"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4668109,"date":"2017-02-13T05:30:08","date_gmt":"2017-02-13T10:30:08","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4668109"},"modified":"2017-02-14T21:47:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-15T02:47:00","slug":"world-press-photo-2017-nature","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668109\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017-nature\u002F","title":{"rendered":"World Press Photo 2017: The Best Nature Images"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe human thirst for progress means animals&rsquo; natural habitats are increasingly under threat. Francis Perez&rsquo;s distressing image of a sea turtle entangled in fishnets perfectly captures this tension between nature and its artificial enemy and won First Prize in the World Press Nature Singles category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4668281\u002Fworld-press-photo-2017\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAn Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMeanwhile, as the endangered species Red List increased by 16,118 last year alone, Brent Stirton&rsquo;s documentation of rhino poaching in Africa serves as a painful reminder of man&rsquo;s complicity. The series was awarded first prize in the Stories category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We have to recognize that the way we treat animals is a mark of our humanity,&#8221; says Magnum photographer Stuart Franklin, the chair of this year&#8217;s jury. &#8220;It&rsquo;s as much about humanity as it is about nature. I respect hugely what Brent Stirton has tried to show.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAmi Vitale&rsquo;s playful depiction of giant pandas in captivity took second place and Bence M&aacute;t&eacute;&rsquo;s starry portraits of nature&rsquo;s majestic heavyweights took third place, both in the Stories category.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. Francis Perez&rsquo;s distressing image of a sea turtle entangled in fishnets perfectly captures this tension between nature and its artificial enemy and won First Prize in the World Press Nature Singles category. An Iconic Photograph of an Assassination Is the World Press Photo of the Year Meanwhile, as the endangered species Red List increased by 16,118 last year alone, Brent Stirton&rsquo;s documentation of rhino poaching in Africa serves as a painful reminder of man&rsquo;s complicity. The series was awarded first prize in the Stories category. &#8220;We have to recognize that the way we treat animals is a mark of our humanity,&#8221; says Magnum photographer Stuart Franklin, the chair of this year&#8217;s jury. &#8220;It&rsquo;s as much about humanity as it is about nature. I respect hugely what Brent Stirton has tried to show.&#8221; Ami Vitale&rsquo;s playful depiction of giant pandas in captivity took second place and Bence M&aacute;t&eacute;&rsquo;s starry portraits of nature&rsquo;s majestic heavyweights took third place, both in the Stories category. The winning photographs were selected from among 80,408 images submitted by 5,034 photographers from 125 different countries. In the end, 45 photographers from 25 countries made up the winning list. They will receive their awards at a ceremony in Amsterdam on April 22. See the winning images in the Sports, People and News categories, as well as the World Press Photo of the Year. Michoacn in Mexico on March 2015.On March 8th and 9th of 2016 a strong snow storm hit the mountains of Central Mexico creating havoc in the wintering colonies of Monarch Butterflies just when they were starting their migration back to U.S.A. and Canada.Monarch butterflies are surprisingly resilient and they can survive several days in below zero temperatures as long as they remain dry. Deforestation reduces the shelter for the butterflies making them more vulnerable to the weather elements. And although illegal logging has been curbed thanks to the conservation efforts in Mexico, climate change is creating an increase of these unusual weather events which represent one of the biggest challenges for these insects during their hibernation hours earlier at Hluhluwe Umfolozi Game Reserve, South Africa. It is suspected that the killers came from a local community approximately 5 kilometers away, entering the park illegally, shooting the rhino at a water hole with a high-powered, silenced hunting rifle. An autopsy and postmortem carried out by members of the KZN Ezemvelo ranger team later revealed that the large calibre bullet went straight through this rhino, causing massive tissue damage. It was noted that he did not die immediately but ran a short distance, fell to his knees and a coup de grace shot was administered to the head from close range. Black Rhino are one of the most endangered rhino species. HluHluwe Umfolozi is one of the last repositories for these animals, with less than 3000 left in the wild Groenewalt, South Africa's alleged Rhino horn kingpin and the subject of a six-year-old court case involving multiple charges related to illegal Rhino horn theft and money laundering amongst other charges. He is seen on his game farm in Polokwane where he breeds high-end game for sale and hunting purposes.","credit":"Brent StirtonGetty Images for National Geographic Magazine, winner in the Nature - First Prize, Stories category.","alt":"POLOKWANE, SOUTH AFRICA: Dawie Groenewalt, South Africa's alleged Rhino horn kingpin and the subject of a 6 year old court case involving multiple charges related to illegal Rhino horn theft and money laundering amongst other charges. He is seen on his game farm in Polokwane where he breeds high-end game for sale and hunting purposes. Groenewalt has also been charged and arrested in the USA on animal trophy charges. Groenwalt denies any wrong doing. He is one of the driving forces behind the court effort to legalize the rhino trade in South Africa. If horn was to be legalized, most of his charges would disapear and he would be in a prime position as a breeder to make significant money from rhino horn. He owns two large properties for breeding and hunting purposes and he hosts many international hunters on those properties. He states freely that he believes South Africa's recent decision not to apply to CITES for the legalization of trade in horn is a death knell for rhino in the wild in South Africa. He further alleges that Kruger National Park, the largest repository for Rhino in the world, vastly over-reports their rhino numbers. Kruger is Groenwalt's largest source for Rhino, he has won repeated tenders for rhino from the park. He is also connected to John Hume, the worlds largest Rhino breeder and one of three partners in Groenwalt's legal efforts to legalize Rhino horn for export to Asia. He claims to receive multiple calls from both Chinese and Vietnamese buyers on a monthly basis, all asking for horn. He speaks of taking representatives from both nations to John Hume's place to show them Hume's cache of horns from dehorning. This cache is allegedly worth in excess of 300 000 000 South African Rand, around 20-40 million dollars. He argues in favour of breeding and dehorning for export, stating that John Hume alone can supply over 1000 kilograms of horn every Trump Is Still Talking About Sweden"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EPresident \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672974\u002Fdonald-trump-white-house-chaos\u002F\"\u003EDonald country\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that never actually happened.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I took a lot of heat on Sweden,&#8221; the President said. &#8220;A day later I said has anybody
