And it turned out that they didn&rsquo;t, not too many of them. &#8230; The [Swedish] people understand I&rsquo;m right.&#8221; In his original remarks, Trump said an incident had occurred last Friday night in Sweden. He later clarified that he was talking about a Fox News segment that ran that night about immigration in Sweden which alleged there had been a surge in violence in the country. There is no data to suggest that refugees are responsible for more crime in Sweden than other groups and Sweden&#8217;s crime prevention council found that there was no significant increase in crimes between 2015 and 2016. And despite Trump&#8217;s insistence that the Swedish people &#8220;understand I&#8217;m right,&#8221; officials in the country have forcefully pushed back against his comments."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;The [Swedish] people understand Im right&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":66943548,"featured_media":4681970,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[785708,189091,430939235,430942547,7053],"time_section":[204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681963\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681963\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681963\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"video","visible":true,"image":{"id":4681970,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdonald-trump-cpac1.jpg?quality=85","alt":"President Trump Addresses Annual CPAC Event In National Harbor, Maryland","caption":"President Donald Trump delivers remarks to the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland on Feb. 24, 2017. ","credit":"Olivier DoulieryPool\u002FGetty Images","title":"President Trump Addresses Annual CPAC Event In National Harbor, Maryland"},"video":{"id":"5335880607001","markup":"\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5335880607001\" data-video-id=\"5335880607001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E","provider":"brightcove"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"controls":"1","videoid":"5335880607001"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":189091,"name":"Donald Trump","slug":"donald-trump","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":7101,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":3484,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":204777755,"name":"Politics","slug":"politics","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":17,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"Political insight from the Beltway and beyond. Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11775,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics"]}]}},{"id":4675860,"date":"2017-02-18T14:13:48","date_gmt":"2017-02-18T19:13:48","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4675860"},"modified":"2017-02-21T08:20:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-21T13:20:00","slug":"donald-trump-fake-news-attacks","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675860\u002Fdonald-trump-fake-news-attacks\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Don't Dismiss President Trump's Attacks on the Media as Mere Stupidity"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EBret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. Read the full text of his remarks below:\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EI&rsquo;m profoundly honored to have this opportunity to celebrate the legacy of Danny Pearl, my colleague at \u003Cem\u003EThe Wall Street Journal.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EMy topic this evening is intellectual integrity in the age of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672974\u002Fdonald-trump-white-house-chaos\u002F\"\u003EDonald Trump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWhen you work at \u003Cem\u003EThe Wall Street Journal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, the coins of the realm are truth and trust &mdash; the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the \u003Cem\u003EJournal\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ENot \u003Ci\u003Eprobably\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual. Not \u003Ci\u003Epartially\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual. Not \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4642689\u002Fkellyanne-conway-sean-spicer-donald-trump-alternative-facts\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003Ealternatively\u003C\u002Fi\u003E factual\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThis is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EIn the 15 years since Danny&rsquo;s death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EPaul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EZahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EJim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EFive journalists in Turkey. Twenty-six in Mexico. More than 100 in Iraq.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWhen we honor Danny, we honor them, too.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe do more than that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-portrait_small_2x aligncenter \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4676387\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675860\u002Fdonald-trump-fake-news-attacks\u002Fthis-is-an-undated-file-photo-of-wall-street-journ\u002F\" data-orig-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85\" data-orig-size=\"2560,2783\" data-comments-opened=\"1\" data-image-meta='{\"aperture\":\"0\",\"credit\":\"AFP\",\"camera\":\"\",\"caption\":\"JANUARY28:  This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl who disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi 23 January 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) agents arrived in Pakistan 28 January 2002 to join the search for Pearl, who they believed to have been kidnapped, police sources said. AFP PHOTO  (Photo credit should read AFP\\\u002FAFP\\\u002FGetty Images)\",\"created_timestamp\":\"1012204800\",\"copyright\":\"AFP\\\u002FGetty Images\",\"focal_length\":\"0\",\"iso\":\"0\",\"shutter_speed\":\"0\",\"title\":\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\",\"orientation\":\"1\"}' data-image-title=\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\" data-image-description=\"pWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi  on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. \u002Fp\n\" data-medium-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85&w=276\" data-large-file=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?quality=85&w=552\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?w=560&#038;quality=85&#038;h=609\" alt=\"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ\" height=\"609\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" \u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EAFP\u002FGetty Images\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"caption\" \u003EWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe honor the central idea of journalism &mdash; the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, &ldquo;that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EAnd we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ESo that&rsquo;s the business we&rsquo;re in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673707\u002Fdonald-trump-press-conference-news-media\u002F\"\u003E&ldquo;disgusting and corrupt media.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5325845908001\" data-video-id=\"5325845908001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ESome of you may have noticed that we&rsquo;re living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press &ldquo;the opposition party,&rdquo; ridicules news organizations it doesn&rsquo;t like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThis isn&rsquo;t unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos haven&rsquo;t been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EBut the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EIdeologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes &mdash; Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that he&rsquo;s trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EHis objection to, say, the New York\u003Cem\u003E Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, isn&rsquo;t that there&rsquo;s a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. He&rsquo;s perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt &mdash; so long as it&rsquo;s on his side.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EBut again, that&rsquo;s not all the president is doing.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EConsider this recent exchange he had with Bill O&rsquo;Reilly. O&rsquo;Reilly asks:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EIs there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you can&rsquo;t back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you don&rsquo;t have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that it&rsquo;s irresponsible for the President to say that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ETo which the president replies:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EMany people have come out and said I&rsquo;m right.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. &ldquo;Many people say&rdquo; is what&rsquo;s known as an \u003Ci\u003Eargumentum ad populum\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWe are not a nation of logicians.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI think it&rsquo;s important not to dismiss the president&rsquo;s reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that it&rsquo;s darkly brilliant &mdash; if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a \u003Ci\u003Eclaim of fact\u003C\u002Fi\u003E not by denying the \u003Ci\u003Efact\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EHe isn&rsquo;t telling O&rsquo;Reilly that he&rsquo;s got his facts wrong. He&rsquo;s saying that, as far as he is concerned, facts, as most people understand the term, don&rsquo;t matter: That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion; and that statements of fact needn&rsquo;t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them &mdash; or, in his case, both.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf some of you in this room are students of political philosophy, you know where this argument originates. This is a version of Thrasymachus&rsquo;s argument in Plato&rsquo;s Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice &ldquo;if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESubstitute the words &ldquo;truth&rdquo; and &ldquo;falsehood&rdquo; for &ldquo;justice&rdquo; and &ldquo;injustice,&rdquo; and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, it would be this: \u003Ci\u003ETruth is what you can get away with\u003C\u002Fi\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf you can sell condos by claiming your building is 90% occupied when it&rsquo;s only 20% occupied, well, then&mdash;it&rsquo;s 90% occupied. If you can convince a sufficient number of people that you really did win the popular vote, or that your inauguration crowds were the biggest&mdash;well then, what do the statistical data and aerial photographs matter?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow, we could have some interesting conversations about why this is happening&mdash;and why it seems to be happening all of a sudden.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EToday we have &ldquo;dis-intermediating&rdquo; technologies such as Twitter, which have cut out the media as the middleman between politicians and the public. Today, just 17% of adults aged 18-24 read a newspaper daily, down from 42% at the turn of the century. Today there are fewer than 33,000 full-time newsroom employees, a drop from 55,000 just 20 years ago.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhen Trump attacks the news media, he&rsquo;s kicking a wounded animal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut the most interesting conversation is not about why Donald Trump lies. Many public figures lie, and he&rsquo;s only a severe example of a common type.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe interesting conversation concerns how we come to accept those lies.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENearly 25 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the great scholar and Democratic Senator from New York, coined the phrase, &ldquo;defining deviancy down.&rdquo; His topic at the time was crime, and how American society had come to accept ever-increasing rates of violent crime as normal.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003E&ldquo;We have been re-defining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized, and also quietly raising the &lsquo;normal&rsquo; level in categories where behavior is now abnormal by any earlier standard,&rdquo; Moynihan wrote.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EYou can point to all sorts of ways in which this redefinition of deviancy has also been the story of our politics over the past 30 years, a story with a fully bipartisan set of villains.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI personally think we crossed a rubicon in the Clinton years, when three things happened: we decided that some types of presidential lies didn&rsquo;t matter; we concluded that &ldquo;character&rdquo; was an over-rated consideration when it came to judging a president; and we allowed the lines between political culture and celebrity culture to become hopelessly blurred.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut whatever else one might say about President Clinton, what we have now is the crack-cocaine version of that.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf a public figure tells a whopping lie once in his life, it&rsquo;ll haunt him into his grave. If he lies morning, noon and night, it will become almost impossible to remember any one particular lie. \u003Ci\u003EOutrage will fall victim to its own ubiquity\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. It&rsquo;s the same truth contained in Stalin&rsquo;s famous remark that the death of one man is a tragedy but the death of a million is a statistic.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOne of the most interesting phenomena during the presidential campaign was waiting for Trump to say that one thing that would surely break the back of his candidacy.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWould it be his slander against Mexican immigrants? Or his slur about John McCain&rsquo;s record as a POW? Or his lie about New Jersey Muslims celebrating 9\u002F11? Or his attacks on Megyn Kelly, on a disabled New York Times reporter, on a Mexican-American judge? Would it be him tweeting quotations from Benito Mussolini, or his sly overtures to David Duke and the alt-right? Would it be his unwavering praise of Vladimir Putin? Would it be his refusal to release his tax returns, or the sham that seems to been perpetrated on the saps who signed up for his Trump U courses? Would it be the tape of him with Billy Bush?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENone of this made the slightest difference. On the contrary, it helped him. Some people became desensitized by the never-ending assaults on what was once quaintly known as &ldquo;human decency.&rdquo; Others seemed to positively admire the comments as refreshing examples of personal authenticity and political incorrectness.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EShameless rhetoric will always find a receptive audience with shameless people. Donald Trump&rsquo;s was the greatest political strip-tease act in U.S. political history: the dirtier he got, the more skin he showed, the more his core supporters liked it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAbraham Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, called on Americans to summon &ldquo;the better angels of our nature.&rdquo; Donald Trump&rsquo;s candidacy, and so far his presidency, has been Lincoln&rsquo;s exhortation in reverse.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EHere&rsquo;s a simple truth about a politics of dishonesty, insult and scandal: It&rsquo;s entertaining. Politics as we&rsquo;ve had it for most of my life has, with just a few exceptions, been distant and dull.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ENow it&rsquo;s all we can talk about. If you like Trump, his presence in the White House is a daily extravaganza of sticking it to pompous elites and querulous reporters. If you hate Trump, you wake up every day with some fresh outrage to turn over in your head and text your friends about.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhichever way, it&rsquo;s exhilarating. Haven&rsquo;t all of us noticed that everything feels speeded up, more vivid, more intense and consequential? One of the benefits of an alternative-facts administration is that fiction can take you anywhere.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EEarlier today, at his press conference, the president claimed his administration is running like a &ldquo;fine-tuned machine.&rdquo; In actual fact, he just lost his Labor Secretary nominee, his National Security Adviser was forced out in disgrace, and the Intelligence Community is refusing to fully brief the president for fear he might compromise sources and methods.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut who cares? Since when in Washington has there been a presidential press conference like that? Since when has the denial of reality been taken to such a bald-faced extreme?\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAt some point, it becomes increasingly easy for people to mistake the reality of the performance for reality itself. If Trump can get through a press conference like that without showing a hint of embarrassment, remorse or misgiving&mdash;well, then, that becomes a new basis on which the president can now be judged.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ETo tell a lie is wrong. But to tell a lie with brass takes skill. Ultimately, Trump&rsquo;s press conference will be judged not on some kind of Olympic point system, but on whether he &ldquo;won&rdquo;&mdash;which is to say, whether he brazened his way through it. And the answer to that is almost certainly yes.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESo far, I&rsquo;ve offered you three ideas about how it is that we have come to accept the president&rsquo;s behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe first is that we normalize it, simply by becoming inured to constant repetition of the same bad behavior.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe second is that at some level it excites and entertains us. By putting aside our usual moral filters&mdash;the ones that tell us that truth matters, that upright conduct matters, that things ought to be done in a certain way&mdash;we have been given tickets to a spectacle, in which all you want to do is watch.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAnd the third is that we adopt new metrics of judgment, in which politics becomes more about perceptions than performance&mdash;of how a given action \u003Ci\u003Eis perceived as being perceived\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trump&rsquo;s press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ELet me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOne of the more fascinating aspects of last year&rsquo;s presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the &ldquo;TrumpXplainers.&rdquo; For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBut rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly \u003Ci\u003Emeant\u003C\u002Fi\u003E to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trump&rsquo;s mind.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIf Trump said he&rsquo;d get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have &ldquo;taken the oil,&rdquo; we&rsquo;d have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EA year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Times&rsquo;s David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didn&rsquo;t amount to a kind of &ldquo;America First policy&rdquo;&mdash;a reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And that&rsquo;s how we got the return of America First.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EMore recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: &ldquo;How Trump&rsquo;s &lsquo;disarray&rsquo; may be merely a strategy,&rdquo; by Wesley Pruden, the paper&rsquo;s former editor-in-chief. In his view, the president&rsquo;s first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincoln&rsquo;s cabinet of rivals. Sure.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EOverall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, he&rsquo;s giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, you&rsquo;re not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWatching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peers&mdash;precisely because I \u003Ci\u003Ehaven&rsquo;t\u003C\u002Fi\u003E changed my opinions about anything.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EBy contrast, I&rsquo;ve become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the right&mdash;again, because I&rsquo;ve stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called &ldquo;Trump Derangement Syndrome&rdquo; simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putin&rsquo;s Russia.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EIn his 1953 masterpiece, &ldquo;The Captive Mind,&rdquo; the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Poland&rsquo;s post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThey \u003Ci\u003Ewanted\u003C\u002Fi\u003E to believe. They were willing to \u003Ci\u003Eadapt\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didn&rsquo;t fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to one&rsquo;s beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldn&rsquo;t possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EI fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trump&rsquo;s &ldquo;pragmatism&rdquo; on the subject.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EAnd it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clinton&rsquo;s sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThe mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master aren&rsquo;t so different from Milosz&rsquo;s former colleagues.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThere&rsquo;s the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EThis is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that it&rsquo;s the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ESo, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhen Judea wrote me last summer to ask if I&rsquo;d be this year&rsquo;s speaker, I got my copy of Danny&rsquo;s collected writings, &ldquo;At Home in the World,&rdquo; and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Danny&rsquo;s memory isn&rsquo;t that he&rsquo;s a martyred journalist. It&rsquo;s that he was a great journalist.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003ELet me show you what I mean. Here&rsquo;s something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p2\" style=\"padding-left:30px;\"\u003EWhat is India&rsquo;s earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You can&rsquo;t imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if you&rsquo;ve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p3\"\u003EWhat stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasn&rsquo;t a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EGeorge Orwell wrote, &ldquo;To see what is in front of one&rsquo;s nose needs a constant struggle.&rdquo; Danny saw what was in front of his nose.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EWe each have our obligations to see what&rsquo;s in front of one&rsquo;s nose, whether we&rsquo;re reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ENot to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what we&rsquo;d like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that won&rsquo;t waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThe legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EThank you.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Bret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When you work at ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["The Wall Street Journal"]},", the coins of the realm are truth and trust  the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Journal"]},", you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Not ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["probably"]}," factual. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In the 15 years since Dannys death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Paul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Zahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Five journalists in Turkey. More than 100 in Iraq."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When we honor Danny, we honor them, too."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We do more than that."]},{"tag":"caption","attributes":{"id":"attachment_4676387","align":"aligncenter","width":"560"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fdaniel-pearl.jpg?w=560","alt":"This is an undated file photo of Wall Street Journ","width":"560","height":"609"},"content":[]},{"tag":"br","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcaption","attributes":[],"content":["Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[]},{"tag":"figcredit","attributes":[],"content":["AFP\u002FGetty Images"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We honor the central idea of journalism  the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So thats the business were in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673707\u002Fdonald-trump-press-conference-news-media\u002F"},"content":["disgusting and corrupt media."]}]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"autoplay":"1","controls":"1","videoid":"5325845908001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Some of you may have noticed that were living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press the opposition party, ridicules news organizations it doesnt like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This isnt unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos havent been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Ideologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes  Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that hes trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["His objection to, say, the New York",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" Times"]},", isnt that theres a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. Hes perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt  so long as its on his side."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But again, thats not all the president is doing."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Consider this recent exchange he had with Bill OReilly. OReilly asks:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["Is there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you cant back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you dont have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that its irresponsible for the President to say that."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["To which the president replies:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["Many people have come out and said Im right."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. Many people say is whats known as an ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["argumentum ad populum"]},". If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We are not a nation of logicians."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I think its important not to dismiss the presidents reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that its darkly brilliant  if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["claim of fact"]}," not by denying the ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["fact"]},", but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He isnt telling OReilly that hes got his facts wrong. This is a version of Thrasymachuss argument in Platos Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Substitute the words truth and falsehood for justice and injustice, and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trumps press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Let me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One of the more fascinating aspects of last years presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the TrumpXplainers. For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["meant"]}," to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trumps mind."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If Trump said hed get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have taken the oil, wed have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Timess David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didnt amount to a kind of America First policya reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And thats how we got the return of America First."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["More recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: How Trumps disarray may be merely a strategy, by Wesley Pruden, the papers former editor-in-chief. In his view, the presidents first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincolns cabinet of rivals. Sure."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Overall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, hes giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, youre not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Watching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peersprecisely because I ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["havent"]}," changed my opinions about anything."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["By contrast, Ive become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the rightagain, because Ive stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called Trump Derangement Syndrome simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putins Russia."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In his 1953 masterpiece, The Captive Mind, the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Polands post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["They ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["wanted"]}," to believe. They were willing to ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["adapt"]},". They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didnt fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to ones beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldnt possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trumps pragmatism on the subject."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["And it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clintons sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master arent so different from Miloszs former colleagues."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Theres the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that its the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["So, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When Judea wrote me last summer to ask if Id be this years speaker, I got my copy of Dannys collected writings, At Home in the World, and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Dannys memory isnt that hes a martyred journalist. Its that he was a great journalist."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Let me show you what I mean. Heres something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":{"style":"padding-left:30px;"},"content":["What is Indias earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You cant imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if youve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["What stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasnt a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["George Orwell wrote, To see what is in front of ones nose needs a constant struggle. Danny saw what was in front of his nose."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["We each have our obligations to see whats in front of ones nose, whether were reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Not to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what wed like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that wont waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Thank you."]}],"plain":"Bret Stephens delivered the Daniel Pearl Memorial Lecture this week at the University of California, Los Angeles. Read the full text of his remarks below: I&rsquo;m profoundly honored to have this opportunity to celebrate the legacy of Danny Pearl, my colleague at The Wall Street Journal. My topic this evening is intellectual integrity in the age of Donald Trump. I suspect this is a theme that would have resonated with Danny. When you work at The Wall Street Journal, the coins of the realm are truth and trust &mdash; the latter flowing exclusively from the former. When you read a story in the Journal, you do so with the assurance that immense reportorial and editorial effort has been expended to ensure that what you read is factual. Not probably factual. Not partially factual. Not alternatively factual. I mean fundamentally, comprehensively and exclusively factual. And therefore trustworthy. This is how we operate. This is how Danny operated. This is how he died, losing his life in an effort to nail down a story. In the 15 years since Danny&rsquo;s death, the list of murdered journalists has grown long. Paul Klebnikov and Anna Politkovskaya in Russia. Zahra Kazemi and Sattar Behesti in Iran. Jim Foley and Steve Sotloff in Syria. Five journalists in Turkey. Twenty-six in Mexico. More than 100 in Iraq. When we honor Danny, we honor them, too. We do more than that. AFP\u002FGetty ImagesWall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl disappeared in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Jan 23, 2002 after telling his wife he was going to interview an Islamic group leader. We honor the central idea of journalism &mdash; the conviction, as my old boss Peter Kann once said, &ldquo;that facts are facts; that they are ascertainable through honest, open-minded and diligent reporting; that truth is attainable by laying fact upon fact, much like the construction of a cathedral; and that truth is not merely in the eye of the beholder.&rdquo; And we honor the responsibility to separate truth from falsehood, which is never more important than when powerful people insist that falsehoods are truths, or that there is no such thing as truth to begin with. So that&rsquo;s the business we&rsquo;re in: the business of journalism. Or, as the 45th president of the United States likes to call us, the &ldquo;disgusting and corrupt media.&rdquo; Some of you may have noticed that we&rsquo;re living through a period in which the executive branch of government is engaged in a systematic effort to create a climate of opinion against the news business. The President routinely describes reporting he dislikes as FAKE NEWS. The Administration calls the press &ldquo;the opposition party,&rdquo; ridicules news organizations it doesn&rsquo;t like as business failures, and calls for journalists to be fired. Mr. Trump has called for rewriting libel laws in order to more easily sue the press. This isn&rsquo;t unprecedented in U.S. history, though you might have to go back to the Administration of John Adams to see something quite like it. And so far the rhetorical salvos haven&rsquo;t been matched by legal or regulatory action. Maybe they never will be. But the question of what Mr. Trump might yet do by political methods against the media matters a great deal less than what he is attempting to do by ideological and philosophical methods. Ideologically, the president is trying to depose so-called mainstream media in favor of the media he likes &mdash; Breitbart News and the rest. Another way of making this point is to say that he&rsquo;s trying to substitute news for propaganda, information for boosterism. His objection to, say, the New York Times, isn&rsquo;t that there&rsquo;s a liberal bias in the paper that gets in the way of its objectivity, which I think would be a fair criticism. His objection is to objectivity itself. He&rsquo;s perfectly happy for the media to be disgusting and corrupt &mdash; so long as it&rsquo;s on his side. But again, that&rsquo;s not all the president is doing. Consider this recent exchange he had with Bill O&rsquo;Reilly. O&rsquo;Reilly asks: Is there any validity to the criticism of you that you say things that you can&rsquo;t back up factually, and as the President you say there are three million illegal aliens who voted and you don&rsquo;t have the data to back that up, some people are going to say that it&rsquo;s irresponsible for the President to say that. To which the president replies: Many people have come out and said I&rsquo;m right. Now many people also say Jim Morrison faked his own death. Many people say Barack Obama was born in Kenya. &ldquo;Many people say&rdquo; is what&rsquo;s known as an argumentum ad populum. If we were a nation of logicians, we would dismiss the argument as dumb. We are not a nation of logicians. I think it&rsquo;s important not to dismiss the president&rsquo;s reply simply as dumb. We ought to assume that it&rsquo;s darkly brilliant &mdash; if not in intention then certainly in effect. The president is responding to a claim of fact not by denying the fact, but by denying the claim that facts are supposed to have on an argument. He isn&rsquo;t telling O&rsquo;Reilly that he&rsquo;s got his facts wrong. He&rsquo;s saying that, as far as he is concerned, facts, as most people understand the term, don&rsquo;t matter: That they are indistinguishable from, and interchangeable with, opinion; and that statements of fact needn&rsquo;t have any purchase against a man who is either sufficiently powerful to ignore them or sufficiently shameless to deny them &mdash; or, in his case, both. If some of you in this room are students of political philosophy, you know where this argument originates. This is a version of Thrasymachus&rsquo;s argument in Plato&rsquo;s Republic that justice is the advantage of the stronger and that injustice &ldquo;if it is on a large enough scale, is stronger, freer, and more masterly than justice.&rdquo; Substitute the words &ldquo;truth&rdquo; and &ldquo;falsehood&rdquo; for &ldquo;justice&rdquo; and &ldquo;injustice,&rdquo; and there you have the Trumpian view of the world. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, it would be this: Truth is what you can get away with. If you can sell condos by claiming your building is 90% occupied when it&rsquo;s only 20% occupied, well, then&mdash;it&rsquo;s 90% occupied. If you can convince a sufficient number of people that you really did win the popular vote, or that your inauguration crowds were the biggest&mdash;well then, what do the statistical data and aerial photographs matter? Now, we could have some interesting conversations about why this is happening&mdash;and why it seems to be happening all of a sudden. Today we have &ldquo;dis-intermediating&rdquo; technologies such as Twitter, which have cut out the media as the middleman between politicians and the public. Today, just 17% of adults aged 18-24 read a newspaper daily, down from 42% at the turn of the century. Today there are fewer than 33,000 full-time newsroom employees, a drop from 55,000 just 20 years ago. When Trump attacks the news media, he&rsquo;s kicking a wounded animal. But the most interesting conversation is not about why Donald Trump lies. Many public figures lie, and he&rsquo;s only a severe example of a common type. The interesting conversation concerns how we come to accept those lies. Nearly 25 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the great scholar and Democratic Senator from New York, coined the phrase, &ldquo;defining deviancy down.&rdquo; His topic at the time was crime, and how American society had come to accept ever-increasing rates of violent crime as normal. &ldquo;We have been re-defining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized, and also quietly raising the &lsquo;normal&rsquo; level in categories where behavior is now abnormal by any earlier standard,&rdquo; Moynihan wrote. You can point to all sorts of ways in which this redefinition of deviancy has also been the story of our politics over the past 30 years, a story with a fully bipartisan set of villains. I personally think we crossed a rubicon in the Clinton years, when three things happened: we decided that some types of presidential lies didn&rsquo;t matter; we concluded that &ldquo;character&rdquo; was an over-rated consideration when it came to judging a president; and we allowed the lines between political culture and celebrity culture to become hopelessly blurred. But whatever else one might say about President Clinton, what we have now is the crack-cocaine version of that. If a public figure tells a whopping lie once in his life, it&rsquo;ll haunt him into his grave. If he lies morning, noon and night, it will become almost impossible to remember any one particular lie. Outrage will fall victim to its own ubiquity. It&rsquo;s the same truth contained in Stalin&rsquo;s famous remark that the death of one man is a tragedy but the death of a million is a statistic. One of the most interesting phenomena during the presidential campaign was waiting for Trump to say that one thing that would surely break the back of his candidacy. Would it be his slander against Mexican immigrants? Or his slur about John McCain&rsquo;s record as a POW? Or his lie about New Jersey Muslims celebrating 9\u002F11? Or his attacks on Megyn Kelly, on a disabled New York Times reporter, on a Mexican-American judge? Would it be him tweeting quotations from Benito Mussolini, or his sly overtures to David Duke and the alt-right? Would it be his unwavering praise of Vladimir Putin? Would it be his refusal to release his tax returns, or the sham that seems to been perpetrated on the saps who signed up for his Trump U courses? Would it be the tape of him with Billy Bush? None of this made the slightest difference. On the contrary, it helped him. Some people became desensitized by the never-ending assaults on what was once quaintly known as &ldquo;human decency.&rdquo; Others seemed to positively admire the comments as refreshing examples of personal authenticity and political incorrectness. Shameless rhetoric will always find a receptive audience with shameless people. Donald Trump&rsquo;s was the greatest political strip-tease act in U.S. political history: the dirtier he got, the more skin he showed, the more his core supporters liked it. Abraham Lincoln, in his first inaugural address, called on Americans to summon &ldquo;the better angels of our nature.&rdquo; Donald Trump&rsquo;s candidacy, and so far his presidency, has been Lincoln&rsquo;s exhortation in reverse. Here&rsquo;s a simple truth about a politics of dishonesty, insult and scandal: It&rsquo;s entertaining. Politics as we&rsquo;ve had it for most of my life has, with just a few exceptions, been distant and dull. Now it&rsquo;s all we can talk about. If you like Trump, his presence in the White House is a daily extravaganza of sticking it to pompous elites and querulous reporters. If you hate Trump, you wake up every day with some fresh outrage to turn over in your head and text your friends about. Whichever way, it&rsquo;s exhilarating. Haven&rsquo;t all of us noticed that everything feels speeded up, more vivid, more intense and consequential? One of the benefits of an alternative-facts administration is that fiction can take you anywhere. Earlier today, at his press conference, the president claimed his administration is running like a &ldquo;fine-tuned machine.&rdquo; In actual fact, he just lost his Labor Secretary nominee, his National Security Adviser was forced out in disgrace, and the Intelligence Community is refusing to fully brief the president for fear he might compromise sources and methods. But who cares? Since when in Washington has there been a presidential press conference like that? Since when has the denial of reality been taken to such a bald-faced extreme? At some point, it becomes increasingly easy for people to mistake the reality of the performance for reality itself. If Trump can get through a press conference like that without showing a hint of embarrassment, remorse or misgiving&mdash;well, then, that becomes a new basis on which the president can now be judged. To tell a lie is wrong. But to tell a lie with brass takes skill. Ultimately, Trump&rsquo;s press conference will be judged not on some kind of Olympic point system, but on whether he &ldquo;won&rdquo;&mdash;which is to say, whether he brazened his way through it. And the answer to that is almost certainly yes. So far, I&rsquo;ve offered you three ideas about how it is that we have come to accept the president&rsquo;s behavior. The first is that we normalize it, simply by becoming inured to constant repetition of the same bad behavior. The second is that at some level it excites and entertains us. By putting aside our usual moral filters&mdash;the ones that tell us that truth matters, that upright conduct matters, that things ought to be done in a certain way&mdash;we have been given tickets to a spectacle, in which all you want to do is watch. And the third is that we adopt new metrics of judgment, in which politics becomes more about perceptions than performance&mdash;of how a given action is perceived as being perceived. If a reporter for the New York Times says that Trump&rsquo;s press conference probably plays well in Peoria, then that increases the chances that it will play well in Peoria. Let me add a fourth point here: our tendency to rationalize. One of the more fascinating aspects of last year&rsquo;s presidential campaign was the rise of a class of pundits I call the &ldquo;TrumpXplainers.&rdquo; For instance, Trump would give a speech or offer an answer in a debate that amounted to little more than a word jumble. But rather than quote Trump, or point out that what he had said was grammatically and logically nonsensical, the TrumpXplainers would tell us what he had allegedly meant to say. They became our political semioticians, ascribing pattern and meaning to the rune-stones of Trump&rsquo;s mind. If Trump said he&rsquo;d get Mexico to pay for his wall, you could count on someone to provide a complex tariff scheme to make good on the promise. If Trump said that we should not have gone into Iraq but that, once there, we should have &ldquo;taken the oil,&rdquo; we&rsquo;d have a similarly high-flown explanation as to how we could engineer this theft. A year ago, when he was trying to explain his idea of a foreign policy to the New York Times&rsquo;s David Sanger, the reporter asked him whether it didn&rsquo;t amount to a kind of &ldquo;America First policy&rdquo;&mdash;a reference to the isolationist and anti-Semitic America First Committee that tried to prevent U.S. entry into World War II. Trump clearly had never heard of the group, but he liked the phrase and made it his own. And that&rsquo;s how we got the return of America First. More recently, I came across this headline in the conservative Washington Times: &ldquo;How Trump&rsquo;s &lsquo;disarray&rsquo; may be merely a strategy,&rdquo; by Wesley Pruden, the paper&rsquo;s former editor-in-chief. In his view, the president&rsquo;s first disastrous month in office is, in fact, evidence of a refreshing openness to dissent, reminiscent of Washington and Lincoln&rsquo;s cabinet of rivals. Sure. Overall, the process is one in which explanation becomes rationalization, which in turn becomes justification. Trump says X. What he really means is Y. And while you might not like it, he&rsquo;s giving voice to the angers and anxieties of Z. Who, by the way, you&rsquo;re not allowed to question or criticize, because anxiety and anger are their own justifications these days. Watching this process unfold has been particularly painful for me as a conservative columnist. I find myself in the awkward position of having recently become popular among some of my liberal peers&mdash;precisely because I haven&rsquo;t changed my opinions about anything. By contrast, I&rsquo;ve become suddenly unpopular among some of my former fans on the right&mdash;again, because I&rsquo;ve stuck to my views. It is almost amusing to be accused of suffering from something called &ldquo;Trump Derangement Syndrome&rdquo; simply because I feel an obligation to raise my voice against, say, the president suggesting a moral equivalency between the U.S. and Vladimir Putin&rsquo;s Russia. The most painful aspect of this has been to watch people I previously considered thoughtful and principled conservatives give themselves over to a species of illiberal politics from which I once thought they were immune. In his 1953 masterpiece, &ldquo;The Captive Mind,&rdquo; the Polish poet and dissident Czeslaw Milosz analyzed the psychological and intellectual pathways through which some of his former colleagues in Poland&rsquo;s post-war Communist regime allowed themselves to be converted into ardent Stalinists. In none of the cases that Milosz analyzed was coercion the main reason for the conversion. They wanted to believe. They were willing to adapt. They thought they could do more good from the inside. They convinced themselves that their former principles didn&rsquo;t fit with the march of history, or that to hold fast to one&rsquo;s beliefs was a sign of priggishness and pig-headedness. They felt that to reject the new order of things was to relegate themselves to irrelevance and oblivion. They mocked their former friends who refused to join the new order as morally vain reactionaries. They convinced themselves that, brutal and capricious as Stalinism might be, it couldn&rsquo;t possibly be worse than the exploitative capitalism of the West. I fear we are witnessing a similar process unfold among many conservative intellectuals on the right. It has been stunning to watch a movement that once believed in the benefits of free trade and free enterprise merrily give itself over to a champion of protectionism whose economic instincts recall the corporatism of 1930s Italy or 1950s Argentina. It is no less stunning to watch people who once mocked Obama for being too soft on Russia suddenly discover the virtues of Trump&rsquo;s &ldquo;pragmatism&rdquo; on the subject. And it is nothing short of amazing to watch the party of onetime moral majoritarians, who spent a decade fulminating about Bill Clinton&rsquo;s sexual habits, suddenly find complete comfort with the idea that character and temperament are irrelevant qualifications for high office. The mental pathways by which the new Trumpian conservatives have made their peace with their new political master aren&rsquo;t so different from Milosz&rsquo;s former colleagues. There&rsquo;s the same desperate desire for political influence; the same belief that Trump represents a historical force to which they ought to belong; the same willingness to bend or discard principles they once considered sacred; the same fear of seeming out-of-touch with the mood of the public; the same tendency to look the other way at comments or actions that they cannot possibly justify; the same belief that you do more good by joining than by opposing; the same Manichean belief that, if Hillary Clinton had been elected, the United States would have all-but ended as a country. This is supposed to be the road of pragmatism, of turning lemons into lemonade. I would counter that it&rsquo;s the road of ignominy, of hitching a ride with a drunk driver. So, then, to the subject that brings me here today: Maintaining intellectual integrity in the age of Trump. When Judea wrote me last summer to ask if I&rsquo;d be this year&rsquo;s speaker, I got my copy of Danny&rsquo;s collected writings, &ldquo;At Home in the World,&rdquo; and began to read him all over again. It brought back to me the fact that, the reason we honor Danny&rsquo;s memory isn&rsquo;t that he&rsquo;s a martyred journalist. It&rsquo;s that he was a great journalist. Let me show you what I mean. Here&rsquo;s something Danny wrote in February 2001, almost exactly a year before his death, from the site of an earthquake disaster in the Indian town of Anjar. What is India&rsquo;s earthquake zone really like? It smells. It reeks. You can&rsquo;t imagine the odor of several hundred bodies decaying for five days as search teams pick away at slabs of crumbled buildings in this town. Even if you&rsquo;ve never smelled it before, the brain knows what it is, and orders you to get away. After a day, the nose gets stuffed up in self-defense. But the brain has registered the scent, and picks it up in innocent places: lip balm, sweet candy, stale breath, an airplane seat. What stands out for me in this passage is that it shows that Danny was a writer who observed with all his senses. He saw. He listened. He smelled. He bore down. He reflected. He understood that what the reader had to know about Anjar wasn&rsquo;t a collection of statistics; it was the visceral reality of a massive human tragedy. And he was able to express all this in language that was compact, unadorned, compelling and deeply true. George Orwell wrote, &ldquo;To see what is in front of one&rsquo;s nose needs a constant struggle.&rdquo; Danny saw what was in front of his nose. We each have our obligations to see what&rsquo;s in front of one&rsquo;s nose, whether we&rsquo;re reporters, columnists, or anything else. This is the essence of intellectual integrity. Not to look around, or beyond, or away from the facts, but to look straight at them, to recognize and call them for what they are, nothing more or less. To see things as they are before we re-interpret them into what we&rsquo;d like them to be. To believe in an epistemology that can distinguish between truth and falsity, facts and opinions, evidence and wishes. To defend habits of mind and institutions of society, above all a free press, which preserve that epistemology. To hold fast to a set of intellectual standards and moral convictions that won&rsquo;t waver amid changes of political fashion or tides of unfavorable opinion. To speak the truth irrespective of what it means for our popularity or influence. The legacy of Danny Pearl is that he died for this. We are being asked to do much less. We have no excuse not to do it. Thank you."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWe should assume they are darkly brilliant\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":53721627,"featured_media":4675870,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[292,430939235],"time_section":[272184451,204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937781],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":true,"_links":{"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4675860\u002Fprimary_section"}]},"_embedded":{"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":true,"image":{"id":4675870,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Ftrump8.jpg?quality=85","alt":"President Trump Holds Joint Press Conference With Japanese PM Shinzo Abe","caption":"President Trump stands during a joint press conference with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at the White House on Feb. 10, 2017 in Washington, DC.
