His movie, ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Moonlight"]},", could be the first film with a gay protagonist to win Best Picture. Ava DuVernay could become the first black woman to win Best Documentary, Denzel Washington could beat his own record for most awards by a black actor, and Meryl Streep could tie Katharine Hepburn for most acting awards ever (with four)male or female, lead or supporting. And on the young prodigy front, ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["La La Land"]},"'s Damien Chazelle, 32, could tie 1932 winner Norman Taurog for youngest Best Director winner, and ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Manchester by the Sea"]},"'s Lucas Hedges, 20, could tie 1981 winner Timothy Hutton for youngest Best Supporting Actor."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":["MORE "]},{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4662871\u002Fava-duvernay-13th-documentary-interview\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Ava DuVernay on Her Oscar-Nominated Documentary ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["13th"]}," and Resistance Through Art"]}]}],"plain":"It&#8217;s Oscars time again, and this year, Hollywood will not only be celebrating Hollywood, it will be celebrating a movie that celebrates Hollywood (that would be La La Land, of the 14 nominations). And while we don&#8217;t know who will win at the 89th Academy Awards, we can predict with some degree of confidence that there will be political speeches (see: Meryl Streep at the Golden Globes), there will be Jimmy Kimmel\u002FMatt Damon gags and records will be broken. Here&#8217;s everything you need to know before tuning in on Sunday, Feb. 26 at 8:30 p.m. ET on ABC. Who&rsquo;s hosting? Jimmy Kimmel will host the ceremony for the first time, taking on the duty performed in recent years by Chris Rock, Neil Patrick Harris and Ellen DeGeneres. His attitude toward the whole affair so far has been characteristically nonchalant&mdash;he joked on his show that the producers selected him for his physical proximity to the Dolby Theatre. The announcement also provided fuel for his long-running faux-feud with Matt Damon. Kimmel says he hopes Damon loses (he&rsquo;s nominated for Best Picture as a producer of Manchester by the Sea), while Damon told the Hollywood Reporter that he hopes Kimmel &ldquo;live[s] up to my extremely low expectations.&rdquo; MORE Here&rsquo;s How You Can Watch the 2017 Oscars Who&rsquo;s presenting? As is customary, last year&rsquo;s acting winners&mdash;Brie Larson, Leonardo DiCaprio, Alicia Vikander and Mark Rylance&mdash;will present awards to this year&rsquo;s honorees. Other presenters include past Oscar winners Halle Berry and Shirley MacLaine and nominees Hailee Steinfeld and Samuel L. Jackson. Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan will be there to make a TV-appropriate joke about BDSM, Chris Evans to continue repping good old Steve Rogers and Kate McKinnon to hopefully do something deliciously unhinged to wake us up should we happen to doze off during the speeches&mdash;er, commercials. Who&rsquo;s performing? All five numbers nominated for Best Original Song will be performed during the ceremony. Auli&rsquo;i Cravalho, who voices the title character in Moana, will join songwriter Lin-Manuel Miranda for the empowering &ldquo;How Far I&rsquo;ll Go.&rdquo; Sting will sing &ldquo;The Empty Chair&rdquo; from the documentary Jim: The James Foley Story. Justin Timberlake will perform &ldquo;Can&rsquo;t Stop the Feeling,&rdquo; from Trolls, also known as The Song That Will Probably Still Be Playing Constantly When You Are on Your Deathbed. And La La Land star John Legend will perform the movie&rsquo;s two nominated songs, sung in the movie by Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, presumably to allow the two nominees to direct their energies to nervously waiting to see if their lives are about to change forever. MORE Lin-Manuel Miranda: How to Be an Artist in the Donald Trump Era Who&rsquo;s expected to win? La La Land boasts an impressive 14 nominations, an honor shared only by Titanic and All About Eve, and one which puts within reach the prospect of breaking the record of 11 wins. In the acting categories, Emma Stone (La La Land), Casey Affleck (Manchester by the Sea), Viola Davis (Fences) and Mahershala Ali (Moonlight) all have the edge on their respective categories. La La Land also looks strong in the directing and music categories&mdash;but nothing is on lock, of course, and a surprise or two would jazz up (or jazz down, if it involves La La Land losing) the whole affair. (Read our full list of predictions.) Is there anything different about this year&rsquo;s ceremony? After two years with zero non-white acting nominees (and a very long history with disproportionately few), this year&rsquo;s nominations are much more inclusive: seven of the 20 nominees are people of color. But change, unsurprisingly, is slow, and we&rsquo;re still without any female directing nominees, and limited to no representation when it comes to Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, LGBT and gender-nonconforming people and people with disabilities. Any controversies to look out for? Two nominees are considered especially controversial this year: Best Actor nominee Casey Affleck&mdash;after two sexual harassment suits, which were settled in 2010, resurfaced in the news&mdash;and Best Director nominee Mel Gibson, whose nomination represents a Hollywood comeback after a domestic violence charge and a highly publicized anti-Semitic outburst. Any records to be broken? This year&rsquo;s ceremony could bring a slew of firsts. Barry Jenkins could be the first black filmmaker to win Best Director. His movie, Moonlight, could be the first film with a gay protagonist to win Best Picture. Ava DuVernay could become the first black woman to win Best Documentary, Denzel Washington could beat his own record for most awards by a black actor, and Meryl Streep could tie Katharine Hepburn for most acting awards ever (with four)&mdash;male or female, lead or supporting. And on the young prodigy front, La La Land&#8216;s Damien Chazelle, 32, could tie 1932 winner Norman Taurog for youngest Best Director winner, and Manchester by the Sea&#8216;s Lucas Hedges, 20, could tie 1981 winner Timothy Hutton for youngest Best Supporting Actor. MORE Ava DuVernay on Her Oscar-Nominated Documentary 13th and Resistance Through Art"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s Oscars time again, and this year, Hollywood will not only be celebrating Hollywood, it will be celebrating a movie that celebrates Hollywood (that would be La La Land, of the 14 nominations). And while we don&#8217;t know who will win at the 89th Academy Awards, we can predict with some degree of confidence style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4671727,"date":"2017-02-16T12:16:53","date_gmt":"2017-02-16T17:16:53","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4671727"},"modified":"2017-02-17T12:21:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-17T17:21:00","slug":"dev-patel-lion-oscars-interview","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4671727\u002Fdev-patel-lion-oscars-interview\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Dev Patel on \u003Ci\u003ELion\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, the Oscars and His Meatiest Role Since \u003Ci\u003ESlumdog Millionaire\u003C\u002Fi\u003E"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3730925\u002Fdev-patel-marigold-hotel-chappie\u002F\"\u003EDev Patel\u003C\u002Fa\u003E has been here before. The cycle of endless interviews and red-carpet appearances that has him crisscrossing oceans to promote his latest film, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4577009\u002Flion-movie-review-saroo-brierly-dev-patel\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELion\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, is much like the one that followed his first movie, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESlumdog Millionaire\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, eight years ago. But this time, it&rsquo;s different. Now 26, the British actor is a little less starry-eyed, if no less grateful for the ride. He has been to enough post-screening Q&amp;A sessions in half-empty auditoriums to know that the kinds of standing ovations that bookend his still young career are, as he tells TIME, &ldquo;an anomaly, and a very special one.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELion\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, for which Patel won a BAFTA and earned Golden Globe, SAG and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4635815\u002F2017-oscars-nominations-list\u002F\"\u003EAcademy Award\u003C\u002Fa\u003E nominations for Best Supporting Actor, tells the true story of Saroo Brierley, played in the first half of the movie by 8-year-old first-timer Sunny Pawar, and in the second half by Patel. Born in India, Brierley got separated from his family at age five and was officially declared a lost child and adopted by an Australian couple. (Nicole Kidman, who plays his adoptive mother, is also nominated for an Oscar.) Twenty years later, with limited memories of his early years, he used \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Earth to search for&mdash;and find&mdash;his birth mother in India.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe role has Patel not only physically transformed&mdash;bulked up and lusciously mop-topped&mdash;but losing himself to a wrestling match with ghosts who might hold the key to his identity, if only he could find them. And it&rsquo;s a part, he says, he&rsquo;s been waiting for since \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESlumdog \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ehad audiences around the world \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=xwwAVRyNmgQ\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Esinging &ldquo;Jai ho.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E Fresh off his BAFTA win, Patel spoke to TIME from Los Angeles about his own relationship to India, the upcoming Oscars ceremony and his next endeavor: producing.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETIME: You&rsquo;ve said you felt like since \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ESlumdog Millionaire\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E you were waiting for a role like this to come along. Why do you think it took so long to happen?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDev Patel: \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI just think the pond I was fishing from was very small. I try to be as versatile as I can in the characters that I&rsquo;m offered. Some people phrase it as a blanket term as just playing &ldquo;Indian men.&rdquo; But I think that does a great injustice to the work. You can&rsquo;t compare \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESlumdog\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E to a \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMarigold Hotel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, for instance, or a \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMarigold Hotel\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E to \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe Man Who Knew Infinity\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. When this film came along, it was a character that didn&rsquo;t require me to play into a specific box. That&rsquo;s what I&rsquo;ve been waiting for, to go on a journey where I could dig deep inside a human being and get stuck in there. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EI heard you showed up at director Garth Davis&rsquo; doorstep to try to make this happen.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI had been sent a news article about it and the themes of the piece, I really responded to, as a young man. I was completely moved by the love that the whole family had: this woman in India who never lost hope in finding her son, this amazing mother in Australia who sacrificed everything and loved her son unconditionally and these two brothers who, despite having a slightly rocky relationship, there was a real foundation of care. The character had something which I respond to a lot, which is resilience. Those are the types of films I like to watch&mdash;someone who doesn&rsquo;t give up, who achieves the impossible. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESaroo built his identity around growing up in Australia, since he had no tangible links to India. Having been born in London, with parents born in Kenya, what&rsquo;s the nature of your relationship to India?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EDespite Saroo being born in India, I&rsquo;ve been there and have a deeper connection to it than he has. He sees himself through and through as an Aussie, and the one thread that connects him to that country is his mother and his family. With me, it was different because I have been exposed to the country so much because of the projects I&rsquo;ve done. What we did relate to was the idea of suppressing a part of our culture to fit into where we were living. I&rsquo;m of Indian heritage but grew up in London, and I did suppress that so I could be like everyone else in school and not feel different, not expose myself to bullying or prejudice. It was only when I shot \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESlumdog\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E that I really started to understand and appreciate India.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYou spent the better part of a year preparing for this role. What did that entail?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EIt was a lot of physical training. Garth was trying to push me into a new physical space on camera. He wanted me to be more masculine and not like the underdog I was in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESlumdog\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. And then he sent me on an emotional journey that made me more vulnerable than I&rsquo;ve ever been able to be on camera. That entailed going to India, traveling on the trains, visiting orphanages, writing diaries. I met the real Mrs. Sood, who was the woman who first showed Saroo the picture [of the Brierleys] and took him out of his horrible orphanage. She&rsquo;s an extraordinary human being. She&rsquo;s in her 90s. It makes the words on that page more sacred.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYou share this character with Sunny Pawar, who plays Saroo as a child, but you don&rsquo;t share screen time. What was your relationship like on set?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EYou could see him growing into an actor as the weeks went on. From someone who&rsquo;s never been in front of a camera before or seen a boom mic, by the end of those three weeks, he was really aware. And kudos to the other two actors in those scenes, Priyanka [Bose] and Abhishek [Bharate], who have been really forgotten in this process but were so incredible at creating a safe atmosphere for this young boy to play freely in. A whole set of 150 people relying on this kid to perform&mdash;it&rsquo;s a lot of pressure. And he really rose to the occasion. I&rsquo;m standing on his shoulders in this film.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome people feel like this year&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4644539\u002Foscar-nominations-diversity-hollywood\u002F\"\u003EOscar nominations\u003C\u002Fa\u003E are a sign of progress after two years with no non-white acting nominees. What do you make of it?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELook, I&rsquo;m proud when I walk that red carpet and I look over and see Viola Davis, I see Octavia Spencer, I see Mahershala Ali, I see all these actors and more representing and it feels like a really inclusive, diverse season. I don&rsquo;t believe in nominating performances for diversity&rsquo;s sake. I hope performances are recognized because of talent. Where I want to focus my emphasis are not on the award ceremonies but on the birth of the stories. Where the stories are born is important, because that&rsquo;s what enables us to go and do these great films. It&rsquo;s amazing that the industry is supporting diverse voices, and that in turn ricochets into more work for everyone. I want people to focus on the art. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYou&rsquo;re an executive producer on \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EHotel Mumbai\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E, which comes out later this year\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E. \u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIs producing a direction you&rsquo;re planning to continue in?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EOne hundred percent, yes. If I can help breathe life into stories with diverse material, then that&rsquo;s great. We need different storytellers.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3730925\u002Fdev-patel-marigold-hotel-chappie\u002F"},"content":["Dev Patel"]}," has been here before. The cycle of endless interviews and red-carpet appearances that has him crisscrossing oceans to promote his latest film, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4577009\u002Flion-movie-review-saroo-brierly-dev-patel\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Lion"]}]},", is much like the one that followed his first movie, ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Slumdog Millionaire"]},", eight years ago. But this time, its different. Now 26, the British actor is a little less starry-eyed, if no less grateful for the ride. He has been to enough post-screening Q&amp;A sessions in half-empty auditoriums to know that the kinds of standing ovations that bookend his still young career are, as he tells TIME, an anomaly, and a very special one."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Lion"]},", for which Patel won a BAFTA and earned Golden Globe, SAG and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4635815\u002F2017-oscars-nominations-list\u002F"},"content":["Academy Award"]}," nominations for Best Supporting Actor, tells the true story of Saroo Brierley, played in the first half of the movie by 8-year-old first-timer Sunny Pawar, and in the second half by Patel. Born in India, Brierley got separated from his family at age five and was officially declared a lost child and adopted by an Australian couple. (Nicole Kidman, who plays his adoptive mother, is also nominated for an Oscar.) Twenty years later, with limited memories of his early years, he used ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["Google"]}," Earth to search forand findhis birth mother in India."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The role has Patel not only physically transformedbulked up and lusciously mop-toppedbut losing himself to a wrestling match with ghosts who might hold the key to his identity, if only he could find them. What we did relate to was the idea of suppressing a part of our culture to fit into where we were living. That entailed going to India, traveling on the trains, visiting orphanages, writing diaries. I met the real Mrs. Sood, who was the woman who first showed Saroo the picture [of the Brierleys] and took him out of his horrible orphanage. Shes an extraordinary human being. Shes in her 90s. It makes the words on that page more sacred."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["You share this character with Sunny Pawar, who plays Saroo as a child, but you dont share screen time. From someone whos never been in front of a camera before or seen a boom mic, by the end of those three weeks, he was really aware. And kudos to the other two actors in those scenes, Priyanka [Bose] and Abhishek [Bharate], who have been really forgotten in this process but were so incredible at creating a safe atmosphere for this young boy to play freely in. A whole set of 150 people relying on this kid to performits a lot of pressure. And he really rose to the occasion. Im standing on his shoulders in this film."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Some people feel like this years ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4644539\u002Foscar-nominations-diversity-hollywood\u002F"},"content":["Oscar nominations"]}," are a sign of progress after two years with no non-white acting nominees. What do you make of it?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Look, Im proud when I walk that red carpet and I look over and see Viola Davis, I see Octavia Spencer, I see Mahershala Ali, I see all these actors and more representing and it feels like a really inclusive, diverse season. I dont believe in nominating performances for diversitys sake. I hope performances are recognized because of talent. Where I want to focus my emphasis are not on the award ceremonies but on the birth of the stories. Where the stories are born is important, because thats what enables us to go and do these great films. Its amazing that the industry is supporting diverse voices, and that in turn ricochets into more work for everyone. I want people to focus on the art. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Youre an executive producer on "]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Hotel Mumbai"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[", which comes out later this year"]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":[". "]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Is producing a direction youre planning to continue in?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["One hundred percent, yes. If I can help breathe life into stories with diverse material, then thats great. We need different storytellers."]}],"plain":"Dev Patel has been here before. The cycle of endless interviews and red-carpet appearances that has him crisscrossing oceans to promote his latest film, Lion, is much like the one that followed his first movie, Slumdog Millionaire, eight years ago. But this time, it&rsquo;s different. Now 26, the British actor is a little less starry-eyed, if no less grateful for the ride. He has been to enough post-screening Q&amp;A sessions in half-empty auditoriums to know that the kinds of standing ovations that bookend his still young career are, as he tells TIME, &ldquo;an anomaly, and a very special one.&rdquo; Lion, for which Patel won a BAFTA and earned Golden Globe, SAG and Academy Award nominations for Best Supporting Actor, tells the true story of Saroo Brierley, played in the first half of the movie by 8-year-old first-timer Sunny Pawar, and in the second half by Patel. Born in India, Brierley got separated from his family at age five and was officially declared a lost child and adopted by an Australian couple. (Nicole Kidman, who plays his adoptive mother, is also nominated for an Oscar.) Twenty years later, with limited memories of his early years, he used Google Earth to search for&mdash;and find&mdash;his birth mother in India. The role has Patel not only physically transformed&mdash;bulked up and lusciously mop-topped&mdash;but losing himself to a wrestling match with ghosts who might hold the key to his identity, if only he could find them. And it&rsquo;s a part, he says, he&rsquo;s been waiting for since Slumdog had audiences around the world singing &ldquo;Jai ho.&rdquo; Fresh off his BAFTA win, Patel spoke to TIME from Los Angeles about his own relationship to India, the upcoming Oscars ceremony and his next endeavor: producing. TIME: You&rsquo;ve said you felt like since Slumdog Millionaire you were waiting for a role like this to come along. Why do you think it took so long to happen? Dev Patel: I just think the pond I was fishing from was very small. I try to be as versatile as I can in the characters that I&rsquo;m offered. Some people phrase it as a blanket term as just playing &ldquo;Indian men.&rdquo; But I think that does a great injustice to the work. You can&rsquo;t compare Slumdog to a Marigold Hotel, for instance, or a Marigold Hotel to The Man Who Knew Infinity. When this film came along, it was a character that didn&rsquo;t require me to play into a specific box. That&rsquo;s what I&rsquo;ve been waiting for, to go on a journey where I could dig deep inside a human being and get stuck in there. I heard you showed up at director Garth Davis&rsquo; doorstep to try to make this happen. I had been sent a news article about it and the themes of the piece, I really responded to, as a young man. I was completely moved by the love that the whole family had: this woman in India who never lost hope in finding her son, this amazing mother in Australia who sacrificed everything and loved her son unconditionally and these two brothers who, despite having a slightly rocky relationship, there was a real foundation of care. The character had something which I respond to a lot, which is resilience. Those are the types of films I like to watch&mdash;someone who doesn&rsquo;t give up, who achieves the impossible. Saroo built his identity around growing up in Australia, since he had no tangible links to India. Having been born in London, with parents born in Kenya, what&rsquo;s the nature of your relationship to India? Despite Saroo being born in India, I&rsquo;ve been there and have a deeper connection to it than he has. He sees himself through and through as an Aussie, and the one thread that connects him to that country is his mother and his family. With me, it was different because I have been exposed to the country so much because of the projects I&rsquo;ve done. What we did relate to was the idea of suppressing a part of our culture to fit into where we were living. I&rsquo;m of Indian heritage but grew up in London, and I did suppress that so I could be like everyone else in school and not feel different, not expose myself to bullying or prejudice. It was only when I shot Slumdog that I really started to understand and appreciate India. You spent the better part of a year preparing for this role. What did that entail? It was a lot of physical training. Garth was trying to push me into a new physical space on camera. He wanted me to be more masculine and not like the underdog I was in Slumdog. And then he sent me on an emotional journey that made me more vulnerable than I&rsquo;ve ever been able to be on camera. That entailed going to India, traveling on the trains, visiting orphanages, writing diaries. I met the real Mrs. Sood, who was the woman who first showed Saroo the picture [of the Brierleys] and took him out of his horrible orphanage. She&rsquo;s an extraordinary human being. She&rsquo;s in her 90s. It makes the words on that page more sacred. You share this character with Sunny Pawar, who plays Saroo as a child, but you don&rsquo;t share screen time. What was your relationship like on set? You could see him growing into an actor as the weeks went on. From someone who&rsquo;s never been in front of a camera before or seen a boom mic, by the end of those three weeks, he was really aware. And kudos to the other two actors in those scenes, Priyanka [Bose] and Abhishek [Bharate], who have been really forgotten in this process but were so incredible at creating a safe atmosphere for this young boy to play freely in. A whole set of 150 people relying on this kid to perform&mdash;it&rsquo;s a lot of pressure. And he really rose to the occasion. I&rsquo;m standing on his shoulders in this film. Some people feel like this year&rsquo;s Oscar nominations are a sign of progress after two years with no non-white acting nominees. What do you make of it? Look, I&rsquo;m proud when I walk that red carpet and I look over and see Viola Davis, I see Octavia Spencer, I see Mahershala Ali, I see all these actors and more representing and it feels like a really inclusive, diverse season. I don&rsquo;t believe in nominating performances for diversity&rsquo;s sake. I hope performances are recognized because of talent. Where I want to focus my emphasis are not on the award ceremonies but on the birth of the stories. Where the stories are born is important, because that&rsquo;s what enables us to go and do these great films. It&rsquo;s amazing that the industry is supporting diverse voices, and that in turn ricochets into more work for everyone. I want people to focus on the art. You&rsquo;re an executive producer on Hotel Mumbai, which comes out later this year. Is producing a direction you&rsquo;re planning to continue in? One hundred percent, yes. If I can help breathe life into stories with diverse material, then that&rsquo;s great. We need different storytellers."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDev Patel has been here before. The cycle of endless interviews and red-carpet appearances that has him crisscrossing oceans to promote his latest film, Lion, is much like the one that followed his first movie, Slumdog Millionaire, eight years ago. But this time, it&rsquo;s different. Now 26, the British actor is a little less Arrivals"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":190,"name":"movies","slug":"movies","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":491,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":5039,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":1098,"name":"Entertainment","slug":"entertainment","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":23,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"From esoteric art to Housewives hullaballoo, TIME Entertainment covers what's good, bad and breaking right now in music, movies, TV, tech, celebrities and style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4662871,"date":"2017-02-10T09:00:13","date_gmt":"2017-02-10T14:00:13","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4662871"},"modified":"2017-02-17T12:26:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-17T17:26:00","slug":"ava-duvernay-13th-documentary-interview","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4662871\u002Fava-duvernay-13th-documentary-interview\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Ava DuVernay on Her Oscar-Nominated Documentary \u003Ci\u003E13th\u003C\u002Fi\u003E and Resistance Through Art"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWhen the 13th amendment was ratified into law on December 6, 1865, it abolished slavery, with one key caveat: &ldquo;except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.&rdquo; More than 150 years later, that exception has proven much more than a mere footnote to history. More African-American men \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.politifact.com\u002Frhode-island\u002Fstatements\u002F2014\u002Fdec\u002F07\u002Fdiego-arene-morley\u002Fbrown-u-student-leader-more-african-american-men-p\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eare incarcerated\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, or on probation or parole, than were enslaved in 1850, and the United States, which accounts for 5% of the world&rsquo;s population, counts \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fnews\u002Ffact-checker\u002Fwp\u002F2015\u002F04\u002F30\u002Fdoes-the-united-states-really-have-five-percent-of-worlds-population-and-one-quarter-of-the-worlds-prisoners\u002F?utm_term=.05372752b982\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Enearly a quarter\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E of the world&#8217;s incarcerated people.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ETo understand how we got from there to here, look no further than Ava DuVernay&rsquo;s Oscar-nominated Netflix documentary \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E13th\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Released just a month before the presidential election last fall and nominated for an Oscar at this month&rsquo;s Academy Awards, the film draws a line from the ratification of its titular amendment to mass incarceration today, making pit stops at significant moments in history, from the depiction of black men as a threat to white women in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3729807\u002Fd-w-griffiths-the-birth-of-a-nation-10\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe Birth of a Nation\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E in 1917 to the thinly-veiled racist appeals of President Reagan&rsquo;s \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fnewrepublic.com\u002Farticle\u002F130039\u002Fsouthern-strategy-made-donald-trump-possible\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESouthern strategy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E in the early &lsquo;80s. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe subject is familiar territory for DuVernay, who has also touched upon it in her narrative work. Though she is best known for 2014&rsquo;s Best Picture-nominated Martin Luther King, Jr. drama \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESelma\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, her 2012 Sundance winner \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMiddle of Nowhere\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E concerned a young woman whose husband was serving time, and her Oprah-produced TV series \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EQueen Sugar\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E features a character recently released from prison. And as she told Oprah in an interview that accompanies \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E13th \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eon Netflix, her interest in the topic was visceral before it was intellectual. As a child growing up in Compton, California, she explained, she learned to see police officers as a symbol of fear rather than one of safety.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EDuVernay, who recently finished shooting the movie adaptation of the young adult classic \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EA Wrinkle in Time\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E&mdash;a project that makes her the first woman of color to direct a $100-million film&mdash;spoke to TIME from Los Angeles about how she made \u003Cem\u003E13th\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, how it feels to be a part of this year&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4644539\u002Foscar-nominations-diversity-hollywood\u002F\"\u003Emore inclusive\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Academy Awards and how she plans to resist President Trump&rsquo;s administration: through her art.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETIME: This documentary came out a month before the election, and it includes footage of both Donald Trump and the Clintons talking about incarceration and related subjects. Was your hope that it would influence the conversation about the candidates?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EAva DuVernay: \u003C\u002Fstrong\u003ECertainly. It was important for us to make the piece evergreen so it could live beyond the election, but also with hopes that we could contribute more information to the national conversation as people were making their decisions.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe issue of mass incarceration is so interconnected with other issues in America, from education to healthcare to employment. How did you draw the line on what to include?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI gave myself a 100-minute limit. \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fnetflix-379\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ENetflix\u003C\u002Fa\u003E was very flexible on the format. They just wanted me to tell the story in whatever form fit best. I wanted to be more rigorous than letting it be a free-for-all, told over six or eight episodes, mainly because I didn&rsquo;t think that people would watch it, and it was important to me that it be seen. It&rsquo;s hard enough to get a national conversation in America going about race in a meaningful way, that&rsquo;s not in reaction to something bad happening. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ESome viewers might be surprised by some of the people who are interviewed in the film, like famous conservatives Newt Gingrich and Grover Norquist. How did you decide on this particular group of talking heads?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EIt was important for me to make sure that we included people on both sides of the aisle, so to speak. I know what I think, but I&rsquo;m interested in knowing what everyone thinks. Everyone who I asked to be in the documentary said yes, and they were included because I wanted to hear their side of the story. I was eager to sit down with them and pick their brains. I spoke with every subject for two hours, and the most intriguing parts of those conversations are in the film.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDid it surprise you when Gingrich admitted to changing his position from what he had believed in in the past?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI knew that he had that position, so it was really just a question of whether or not he would repeat it to me on camera. What surprised me was \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3430949\u002Fsilicon-valley-alec-lobby\u002F\"\u003EALEC\u003C\u002Fa\u003E [The American Legislative Exchange Council, an organization of conservative legislators and representatives of private companies that has promoted policies that keep prison populations high]\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Having been an African-American Studies major at UCLA, a student of black liberation theory and growing up in Compton, I was very familiar with the history that I share in the film, and being a part of the Black Lives Matter movement, I understood that part of it. But I was so shaken up about discovering ALEC that I delved into that research for a good six months so that I could learn it fully enough to share it in the documentary.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYou show footage of Trump rallies next to violent footage from the Civil Rights movement. Do you feel like history is repeating itself?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EA lot has changed, and a lot has stayed the same. But when you have a divisive figure like Donald Trump instigating violence and prejudice against people at his own rallies as he pursues the presidency, then he takes power as President and continues to perpetuate misogynistic, homophobic, racist points of view, I feel that I have to, as an artist, tell that story as vigorously and passionately as I can. It was very apparent to me, as I was watching, that he was asking his supporters to be aggressive with and violent with people who were expressing dissent. I saw the alignment of what he was asking for and what had happened in the past, and I wanted to make that point in the montage that we crafted in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E13th\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EYou&rsquo;ve talked about resistance to the new administration. For you, how much of resistance is in your art versus your life outside of your work?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI feel like all art is political. As artists, we&rsquo;re sharing our point of view, asserting our identity through our work, whether you&rsquo;re making a romantic comedy or you&rsquo;re making a documentary about prison. For artists who are seeing the work as art and not as work for hire, it&rsquo;s saying something about how they feel. All of the work that I&rsquo;ve done in film and television, even the commercial work, the images that I try to craft are saying something about me. That won&rsquo;t change. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIn a \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.vulture.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fraoul-peck-i-am-not-your-negro.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Erecent interview\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cb\u003E, your fellow Oscar nominee Raoul Peck, who directed \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4657880\u002Freview-i-am-not-your-negro-shows-how-far-we-only-think-weve-come\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EI Am Not Your\u003C\u002Fi\u003E \u003Cem\u003ENegro,\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cb\u003E said that he refuses to make films that audiences come to consume; he wants them to engage. What&rsquo;s your take on that?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI don&rsquo;t make films for audiences. I make films to express myself. Through that, I have confidence that there are people out there&mdash;it might be a small audience, it might be a large audience&mdash;but there are folks out there that are interested in looking in through the window of the world of my story, in the same way that I enjoy watching films by filmmakers of all kinds, all over the world, from all generations. Raoul Peck is a legend and a master, and I&rsquo;ve had the pleasure of working with him as his publicist on his landmark film \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELulumba\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. I think his current film is a masterpiece, and I&rsquo;m proud to share this Oscar category with him. I hope that audiences engage, but I don&rsquo;t make it for that reason.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat do you make of the fact that three of the five documentary Oscar nominees are about race and civil rights?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe category has five beautiful films by five very different filmmakers. I love the fact that four of the nominees are black, from different parts of the country with different issues. There&rsquo;s a film in there that touches on themes of immigration, so I think four of the five really deal with matters of race and class, and that&rsquo;s a beautiful thing. I wish there were more women nominated. And it&rsquo;s important that when we speak of inclusion, it&rsquo;s not just black folk. We need Latino filmmakers, we need LGBT filmmakers, we need Native filmmakers, we need Asian and Asian American filmmakers and actors and people below the line, and this is an ongoing issue that needs to be addressed. But this year feels nice to be included in a year that has more inclusion than in the past.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe movie calls out the influence that Hollywood has on public perception and policy, beginning with \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EThe Birth of a Nation\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E a hundred years ago. How do you feel about the impact Hollywood is having on conversations about racism and civil rights today?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI don&rsquo;t know that Hollywood is having an effect on it. I feel like the world is having an effect on Hollywood. It would be disingenuous to say that this conversation wasn&rsquo;t happening before this film. There are people that have been working vigorously on issues of incarceration, criminalization and prison abolition for decades. Many of them are in the documentary. So this work is just to capture that and share it with a wider audience. I&rsquo;m grateful to Netflix for making it available in 190 countries, which is pretty stunning. I think that is a misconception, that Hollywood&rsquo;s leading a conversation. It&rsquo;s really not. People in the real world are doing work and have been. My job is just to reflect it.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["When the 13th amendment was ratified into law on December 6, 1865, it abolished slavery, with one key caveat: except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted. All of the work that Ive done in film and television, even the commercial work, the images that I try to craft are saying something about me. That wont change. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["In a "]},{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.vulture.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fraoul-peck-i-am-not-your-negro.html"},"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["recent interview"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[", your fellow Oscar nominee Raoul Peck, who directed "]},{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4657880\u002Freview-i-am-not-your-negro-shows-how-far-we-only-think-weve-come\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["I Am Not Your"]}," ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Negro,"]}]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[" said that he refuses to make films that audiences come to consume; he wants them to engage. Whats your take on that?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I dont make films for audiences. I make films to express myself. Through that, I have confidence that there are people out thereit might be a small audience, it might be a large audiencebut there are folks out there that are interested in looking in through the window of the world of my story, in the same way that I enjoy watching films by filmmakers of all kinds, all over the world, from all generations. Raoul Peck is a legend and a master, and Ive had the pleasure of working with him as his publicist on his landmark film ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Lulumba"]},". I think his current film is a masterpiece, and Im proud to share this Oscar category with him. I hope that audiences engage, but I dont make it for that reason."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["What do you make of the fact that three of the five documentary Oscar nominees are about race and civil rights?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The category has five beautiful films by five very different filmmakers. I love the fact that four of the nominees are black, from different parts of the country with different issues. Theres a film in there that touches on themes of immigration, so I think four of the five really deal with matters of race and class, and thats a beautiful thing. I wish there were more women nominated. And its important that when we speak of inclusion, its not just black folk. We need Latino filmmakers, we need LGBT filmmakers, we need Native filmmakers, we need Asian and Asian American filmmakers and actors and people below the line, and this is an ongoing issue that needs to be addressed. But this year feels nice to be included in a year that has more inclusion than in the past."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["The movie calls out the influence that Hollywood has on public perception and policy, beginning with "]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["The Birth of a Nation"]}]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":[" a hundred years ago. How do you feel about the impact Hollywood is having on conversations about racism and civil rights today?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I dont know that Hollywood is having an effect on it. I feel like the world is having an effect on Hollywood. It would be disingenuous to say that this conversation wasnt happening before this film. There are people that have been working vigorously on issues of incarceration, criminalization and prison abolition for decades. Many of them are in the documentary. So this work is just to capture that and share it with a wider audience. Im grateful to Netflix for making it available in 190 countries, which is pretty stunning. I think that is a misconception, that Hollywoods leading a conversation. Its really not. People in the real world are doing work and have been. My job is just to reflect it."]}],"plain":"When the 13th amendment was ratified into law on December 6, 1865, it abolished slavery, with one key caveat: &ldquo;except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.&rdquo; More than 150 years later, that exception has proven much more than a mere footnote to history. More African-American men are incarcerated, or on probation or parole, than were enslaved in 1850, and the United States, which accounts for 5% of the world&rsquo;s population, counts nearly a quarter of the world&#8217;s incarcerated people. To understand how we got from there to here, look no further than Ava DuVernay&rsquo;s Oscar-nominated Netflix documentary 13th. Released just a month before the presidential election last fall and nominated for an Oscar at this month&rsquo;s Academy Awards, the film draws a line from the ratification of its titular amendment to mass incarceration today, making pit stops at significant moments in history, from the depiction of black men as a threat to white women in The Birth of a Nation in 1917 to the thinly-veiled racist appeals of President Reagan&rsquo;s Southern strategy in the early &lsquo;80s. The subject is familiar territory for DuVernay, who has also touched upon it in her narrative work. Though she is best known for 2014&rsquo;s Best Picture-nominated Martin Luther King, Jr. drama Selma, her 2012 Sundance winner Middle of Nowhere concerned a young woman whose husband was serving time, and her Oprah-produced TV series Queen Sugar features a character recently released from prison. And as she told Oprah in an interview that accompanies 13th on Netflix, her interest in the topic was visceral before it was intellectual. As a child growing up in Compton, California, she explained, she learned to see police officers as a symbol of fear rather than one of safety. DuVernay, who recently finished shooting the movie adaptation of the young adult classic A Wrinkle in Time&mdash;a project that makes her the first woman of color to direct a $100-million film&mdash;spoke to TIME from Los Angeles about how she made 13th, how it feels to be a part of this year&rsquo;s more inclusive Academy Awards and how she plans to resist President Trump&rsquo;s administration: through her art. TIME: This documentary came out a month before the election, and it includes footage of both Donald Trump and the Clintons talking about incarceration and related subjects. Was your hope that it would influence the conversation about the candidates? Ava DuVernay: Certainly. It was important for us to make the piece evergreen so it could live beyond the election, but also with hopes that we could contribute more information to the national conversation as people were making their decisions. The issue of mass incarceration is so interconnected with other issues in America, from education to healthcare to employment. How did you draw the line on what to include? I gave myself a 100-minute limit. Netflix was very flexible on the format. They just wanted me to tell the story in whatever form fit best. I wanted to be more rigorous than letting it be a free-for-all, told over six or eight episodes, mainly because I didn&rsquo;t think that people would watch it, and it was important to me that it be seen. It&rsquo;s hard enough to get a national conversation in America going about race in a meaningful way, that&rsquo;s not in reaction to something bad happening. Some viewers might be surprised by some of the people who are interviewed in the film, like famous conservatives Newt Gingrich and Grover Norquist. How did you decide on this particular group of talking heads? It was important for me to make sure that we included people on both sides of the aisle, so to speak. I know what I think, but I&rsquo;m interested in knowing what everyone thinks. Everyone who I asked to be in the documentary said yes, and they were included because I wanted to hear their side of the story. I was eager to sit down with them and pick their brains. I spoke with every subject for two hours, and the most intriguing parts of those conversations are in the film. Did it surprise you when Gingrich admitted to changing his position from what he had believed in in the past? I knew that he had that position, so it was really just a question of whether or not he would repeat it to me on camera. What surprised me was ALEC [The American Legislative Exchange Council, an organization of conservative legislators and representatives of private companies that has promoted policies that keep prison populations high]. Having been an African-American Studies major at UCLA, a student of black liberation theory and growing up in Compton, I was very familiar with the history that I share in the film, and being a part of the Black Lives Matter movement, I understood that part of it. But I was so shaken up about discovering ALEC that I delved into that research for a good six months so that I could learn it fully enough to share it in the documentary. You show footage of Trump rallies next to violent footage from the Civil Rights movement. Do you feel like history is repeating itself? A lot has changed, and a lot has stayed the same. But when you have a divisive figure like Donald Trump instigating violence and prejudice against people at his own rallies as he pursues the presidency, then he takes power as President and continues to perpetuate misogynistic, homophobic, racist points of view, I feel that I have to, as an artist, tell that story as vigorously and passionately as I can. It was very apparent to me, as I was watching, that he was asking his supporters to be aggressive with and violent with people who were expressing dissent. I saw the alignment of what he was asking for and what had happened in the past, and I wanted to make that point in the montage that we crafted in 13th. You&rsquo;ve talked about resistance to the new administration. For you, how much of resistance is in your art versus your life outside of your work? I feel like all art is political. As artists, we&rsquo;re sharing our point of view, asserting our identity through our work, whether you&rsquo;re making a romantic comedy or you&rsquo;re making a documentary about prison. For artists who are seeing the work as art and not as work for hire, it&rsquo;s saying something about how they feel. All of the work that I&rsquo;ve done in film and television, even the commercial work, the images that I try to craft are saying something about me. That won&rsquo;t change. In a recent interview, your fellow Oscar nominee Raoul Peck, who directed I Am Not Your Negro, said that he refuses to make films that audiences come to consume; he wants them to engage. What&rsquo;s your take on that? I don&rsquo;t make films for audiences. I make films to express myself. Through that, I have confidence that there are people out there&mdash;it might be a small audience, it might be a large audience&mdash;but there are folks out there that are interested in looking in through the window of the world of my story, in the same way that I enjoy watching films by filmmakers of all kinds, all over the world, from all generations. Raoul Peck is a legend and a master, and I&rsquo;ve had the pleasure of working with him as his publicist on his landmark film Lulumba. I think his current film is a masterpiece, and I&rsquo;m proud to share this Oscar category with him. I hope that audiences engage, but I don&rsquo;t make it for that reason. What do you make of the fact that three of the five documentary Oscar nominees are about race and civil rights? The category has five beautiful films by five very different filmmakers. I love the fact that four of the nominees are black, from different parts of the country with different issues. There&rsquo;s a film in there that touches on themes of immigration, so I think four of the five really deal with matters of race and class, and that&rsquo;s a beautiful thing. I wish there were more women nominated. And it&rsquo;s important that when we speak of inclusion, it&rsquo;s not just black folk. We need Latino filmmakers, we need LGBT filmmakers, we need Native filmmakers, we need Asian and Asian American filmmakers and actors and people below the line, and this is an ongoing issue that needs to be addressed. But this year feels nice to be included in a year that has more inclusion than in the past. The movie calls out the influence that Hollywood has on public perception and policy, beginning with The Birth of a Nation a hundred years ago. How do you feel about the impact Hollywood is having on conversations about racism and civil rights today? I don&rsquo;t know that Hollywood is having an effect on it. I feel like the world is having an effect on Hollywood. It would be disingenuous to say that this conversation wasn&rsquo;t happening before this film. There are people that have been working vigorously on issues of incarceration, criminalization and prison abolition for decades. Many of them are in the documentary. So this work is just to capture that and share it with a wider audience. I&rsquo;m grateful to Netflix for making it available in 190 countries, which is pretty stunning. I think that is a misconception, that Hollywood&rsquo;s leading a conversation. It&rsquo;s really not. People in the real world are doing work and have been. My job is just to reflect it."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EWhen the 13th amendment was ratified into law on December 6, 1865, it abolished slavery, with one key caveat: &ldquo;except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.&rdquo; More than 150 years later, that exception has proven much more than a mere footnote to history. More African-American men are Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=1182"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":56926,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Foscars\u002F","name":"Oscars","slug":"oscars","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F56926"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=56926"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=56926"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No When a white person picks up a weapon and demands freedom, he says, white people are quick to applaud him. When a black person does the same, he continues, white people don't hesitate to criminalize him. Days after a national address on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4657862\u002Fdonald-trump-black-history-month\u002F"},"content":["Black History Month"]},", it wouldn't be an overstatement to call Peck's film required viewing."]}],"plain":"James Baldwin&rsquo;s words have been cropping up with growing frequency in recent days: In movie award acceptance speeches and on posters at anti-Trump protests. In discussions on TV news programs and even the prelude to Madonna&rsquo;s remarks at the Women&rsquo;s March on Washington. And in tweet after tweet after tweet punctuated with the hashtag #blacklivesmatter. It has been almost 30 years since the writer and social critic died, and though his words have never lost their potency, they have, of late, increasingly found their way into the airwaves (and twitter-waves) of mainstream popular culture. As a new generation discovers his work and older generations seek to revisit it, the timing couldn&#8217;t be more auspicious for director Raoul Peck&rsquo;s new documentary I Am Not Your Negro, which uses Baldwin&rsquo;s unfinished manuscript about the lives and assassinations of Medgar Evers, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King, Jr. as a launchpad for a conversation about race in contemporary America. The documentary, which hits theaters Feb. 3, had a qualifying run in 2016 that made it eligible for an Academy Award nomination, which it received on Jan. 24. The category this year is rich with films that explore racism from different angles: Ava DuVernay&rsquo;s 13th draws a straight line from slavery to mass incarceration and Ezra Edelman&rsquo;s O.J.: Made in America uses the life of O.J. Simpson as a lens through which to explore race, celebrity and sport. In I Am Not Your Negro, Samuel L. Jackson breathes life into the never published Remember This House, of which Baldwin had completed only 30 pages before he died. Peck places archival footage side by side with contemporary footage&mdash;Birmingham in the &lsquo;60s, Ferguson in 2015&mdash;illustrating, though it&rsquo;s already clear to so many, why the last 50 years don&rsquo;t seem to have made Baldwin&rsquo;s perspective any less necessary or relevant. In the exclusive clip above, Baldwin appears on an episode of The Dick Cavett Show in 1968 to explain a damaging double standard of perception. When a white person picks up a weapon and demands freedom, he says, white people are quick to applaud him. When a black person does the same, he continues, white people don&#8217;t hesitate to criminalize him. Days after a national address on Black History Month, it wouldn&#8217;t be an overstatement to call Peck&#8217;s film required viewing."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EBaldwin&#8217;s work feels more timely than ever\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":73875048,"featured_media":4656587,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[58298,420934628,57299,621152,190,56926],"time_section":[1098],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4656492"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4656492"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4656492"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656492\u002Fauthors"}],"fo ey_article?tags=56926"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No
