class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5307994529001\" data-video-id=\"5307994529001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E","provider":"brightcove"},"structured":[{"tag":"video","attributes":{"controls":"1","videoid":"5307994529001"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":190,"name":"movies","slug":"movies","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":491,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":5039,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":1098,"name":"Entertainment","slug":"entertainment","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":23,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"From esoteric art to Housewives hullaballoo, TIME Entertainment covers what's good, bad and breaking right now in music, movies, TV, tech, celebrities and style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4656493,"date":"2017-02-01T14:52:54","date_gmt":"2017-02-01T19:52:54","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4656493"},"modified":"2017-02-01T14:52:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-01T19:52:00","slug":"moonlight-barry-jenkins-interview","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4656493\u002Fmoonlight-barry-jenkins-interview\u002F","title":{"rendered":"\u003Cem\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fem\u003E Filmmaker Barry Jenkins on the Bittersweet Feeling of Being a First"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThere are a lot of reasons why Barry Jenkins might not have expected to be in the position he&rsquo;s in today: the first black filmmaker nominated for an Academy Award for Best Director, Best Screenplay and Best Picture and the face of the most \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4650309\u002Foscars-2017-rotten-tomatoes-critics-survey\u002F\"\u003Ecritically revered\u003C\u002Fa\u003E movie of 2016. The writer-director of \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4540116\u002Fbarry-jenkins-moonlight-enchants\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E grew up poor, in the Miami neighborhood of Liberty City, where his mother struggled with drug addiction. He&#8217;s a relatively late bloomer when it comes to filmmaking, not finding his way to the medium until his junior year at Florida State University. His projects remained mostly under the radar in the eight years between the release of his little seen but much respected first movie, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMedicine for Melancholy\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E last October. And while his new film had a lot of things going for it, obvious commercial appeal was not one of them.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EBut today, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ehas a \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4626237\u002Fgolden-globes-2017-moonlight-best-picture-drama\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EGolden Globe\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E and eight \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4635815\u002F2017-oscars-nominations-list\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EOscar nominations\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E under its belt, and its box office take is more than triple its $5 million budget. The story of a young boy growing up poor in Liberty City, with a mom addicted to crack and a repressed attraction to other boys, is remarkable not only for its subject matter but for its lush visual palate and dreamlike aesthetic. As America emerges from a year that saw frequent headlines about young black men \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4394802\u002Falton-sterling-police-shooting-baton-rouge\u002F\"\u003Ekilled by police\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, and from a month in which the shift in power has many \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4649876\u002Fdonald-trump-visa-ban-executive-order-lives\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Efearing for their rights\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, audiences have found profound urgency in \u003Cem\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EOn the heels of a trip to Europe, where he screened \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E in six different cities, Jenkins talked to TIME about the life-saving power of representation and the bittersweet feeling of awards recognition when so many who came before him never got their due.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETIME: How has the response to \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E stacked up to your expectations?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EJenkins:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E It&rsquo;s definitely exceeded my expectations. But I don&rsquo;t mean that because I had modest expectations for the film. There&rsquo;s just certain aspects of this movie that are challenging. There&rsquo;s no movie stars. Structurally, it&rsquo;s a bit adventurous, it&rsquo;s visually adventurous. So it&rsquo;s not built to be a commercial piece of art and yet people are coming to the cinema, and they&rsquo;re seeing the work for what it is and appreciating it, but also finding a way to see themselves in it, no matter who they are or where they come from.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe movie is based on Tarell Alvin McCraney&rsquo;s short play, \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EIn Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E. Have you found that many people assume it&#8217;s your story?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EYeah. I think the starting point is different than the end point. I think it has become my story. Working on a film that had to be made in the way this film was made, it&rsquo;s kind of impossible to do it without giving your full self over to it. And if you read about this film, you will read that Barry Jenkins is straight and the character in our film is gay. So if people feel like they see me in the piece, I take it as the highest compliment.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat reaction have you gotten from people in Liberty City, Miami, where the movie is set? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe community really took ownership. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe first voice you hear in the film is not one of our actors&mdash;it&rsquo;s not Mahershala Ali&mdash;it&rsquo;s the voice of a kid who came into a community center to an open casting call. I think that puts a stamp on the piece. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EPeople see the main character as any one of the hundreds of kids living in that neighborhood. Tarell and I are from that neighborhood, and they see that we have a Golden Globe, that we have eight Academy Award nominations, and they see themselves in that. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EIt seems like one of the reasons the movie has caught on so much\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E is that many people have an opportunity to see themselves in a way that maybe they&rsquo;ve never been able to walk into a movie theater or turn on a TV and see.\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI&rsquo;m on Twitter and Instagram, and I get these messages from total strangers all the time, saying just that. They never thought that they would walk into a theater and, as you said, see themselves onscreen. When you have such a lack of representation, such a lack of images, two things can happen. Either you start to feel like you&rsquo;re voiceless, or people who don&rsquo;t live in close proximity to you can conveniently start to think you don&rsquo;t exist, that you&rsquo;re invisible. When images do arise to fill that lack, they take on added importance. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDo you see the main character, Chiron, as an antidote to stereotypes about black masculinity? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI did not sit down to draw him in that way, not as a response to anything. [I was] trying to do justice to Tarell&rsquo;s work and Tarell&rsquo;s life. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EIt&rsquo;s not that characters like Chiron didn&rsquo;t exist before. It&rsquo;s just that they don&rsquo;t often get centered in narratives. There was a point where I realized there were things happening in front of the camera that I hadn&rsquo;t seen very often, or ever. Watching a black man cradle a boy in the Atlantic Ocean&mdash;I hadn&rsquo;t seen that before. That&rsquo;s a very simple image. It&rsquo;s not something you draw to counter a stereotype.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EHow did you approach the depiction of his mother, who is addicted to crack? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThis character was drawn from my mom, from Tarell&rsquo;s mom, so the idea of a stereotype never presented itself to me. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWhen you&rsquo;re drawing from inside the community, you&rsquo;re drawing on human beings and not any stereotype. T\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ehe reception of the character was something that I was concerned about. The way I work, things are very nuanced, not everything is explained. I hoped that people would see into some of the very simple gestures that Naomie [Harris] performs as a character and see both sides of her, the vice and the virtue. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI haven&rsquo;t seen that many depictions of this supposed black crackhead mom. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI remember [Spike Lee&#8217;s] \u003Cem\u003EJungle Fever\u003C\u002Fem\u003E and David Simon&rsquo;s \u003Cem\u003EThe Corner\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, which was amazing. Otherwise, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI feel like we&rsquo;re afraid of these images to the point that we stifle people from depicting things that they actually lived through. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe way the film captures light is remarkable. What were you and cinematographer James Laxton going for?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ECinema is a little over 100 years old, and a lot of what we do is built around film emulsion. Those things were calibrated for white skin. We&rsquo;ve always placed powder on skin to dull the light. But my memory of growing up in Miami is this moist, beautiful black skin. And this movie is meant to reflect the consciousness of the character&mdash;of me and Tarell, to be honest. So we used oil. I wanted everyone&rsquo;s skin to have a sheen to reflect my memory.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat do you make of people&rsquo;s tendency to politicize this film?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EArt is inherently political. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EEven trying to make a film that has nothing to do with politics is, in and of itself, a political act. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EOnce we make the work and release it into the world, it&rsquo;s beyond our control. This movie premiered under one President and is now going into the awards season under a different President. I&rsquo;ve seen the cultural currency of the film shift just over the course of those six to eight weeks.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EHow do you feel about \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E being pitted against the musical \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ELa La Land\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cb\u003E, another Oscar front-runner? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThey could not be more different films. I don&rsquo;t think a love for one has to be to the rejection of the other. I can only speak to the film I made, which was made in the service of shining a light on a character who is often marginalized. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWhere that falls in the context of the awards season, I can&rsquo;t say. But I love that regardless of where we are right now, a year and a half ago, we sat down to make this thing, and that&rsquo;s exactly how I felt and it&rsquo;s how I feel now.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EHow does it feel to be the first black writer-director to be nominated for Best Picture, Director and Screenplay? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EIt&rsquo;s bittersweet. I shouldn&rsquo;t be the first. I&rsquo;ll be happy when there&rsquo;s no longer any space for firsts because it&rsquo;ll mean those things have been done. I wouldn&rsquo;t be the first person who&rsquo;s merited this distinction. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI don&rsquo;t understand how someone like Spike Lee has never been nominated for these three awards. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe greatest thing is, I can take out my phone and look at messages from total strangers who feel a little bit less alone because of this film. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI do recognize that it&rsquo;s larger than me. That&rsquo;s why I even hesitate to speak on it, because I think it&rsquo;s larger than me. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EBut it&rsquo;s important to note that the barrier is not mine to break. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI made a piece of work. The barrier does not fall to me.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E The barrier belongs to the Academy.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EA couple months ago you tweeted the link to your very first short film, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fvimeo.com\u002F7456450\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EMy Josephine\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. How do you feel\u003C\u002Fb\u003E \u003Cb\u003Erewatching it now, 14 years later?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThere was a moment where I thought I couldn&rsquo;t be a good filmmaker because of who I was and where I was from. I grew up black and poor, and my mom went through these things depicted in the film. And making that movie proved to me that I could do the work to make myself as accomplished as anyone else. And it&rsquo;s just a reminder that even from the beginning, I was working to humanize others and to center marginalized characters. It&rsquo;s just a reminder to keep doing that. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EWhat are you into other than filmmaking? \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI love coffee. I&rsquo;ve got, like, eight different ways to make coffee at my house. That&rsquo;s about it. I&rsquo;m so damn boring. I like reading and writing and making coffee. And walking. Barry Jenkins likes long walks. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There are a lot of reasons why Barry Jenkins might not have expected to be in the position hes in today: the first black filmmaker nominated for an Academy Award for Best Director, Best Screenplay and Best Picture and the face of the most ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4650309\u002Foscars-2017-rotten-tomatoes-critics-survey\u002F"},"content":["critically revered"]}," movie of 2016. But I love that regardless of where we are right now, a year and a half ago, we sat down to make this thing, and thats exactly how I felt and its how I feel now."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["How does it feel to be the first black writer-director to be nominated for Best Picture, Director and Screenplay? I wouldnt be the first person whos merited this distinction.  I dont understand how someone like Spike Lee has never been nominated for these three awards.  The greatest thing is, I can take out my phone and look at messages from total strangers who feel a little bit less alone because of this film.  I do recognize that its larger than me. Thats why I even hesitate to speak on it, because I think its larger than me.  But its important to note that the barrier is not mine to break.  I made a piece of work. The barrier does not fall to me.  The barrier belongs to the Academy."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["A couple months ago you tweeted the link to your very first short film, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fvimeo.com\u002F7456450"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["My Josephine"]}]},". How do you feel"]}," ",{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["rewatching it now, 14 years later?"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There was a moment where I thought I couldnt be a good filmmaker because of who I was and where I was from. I grew up black and poor, and my mom went through these things depicted in the film. And making that movie proved to me that I could do the work to make myself as accomplished as anyone else. And its just a reminder that even from the beginning, I was working to humanize others and to center marginalized characters. Its just a reminder to keep doing that. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["What are you into other than filmmaking? "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["I love coffee. Ive got, like, eight different ways to make coffee at my house. Thats about it. Im so damn boring. I like reading and writing and making coffee. And walking. Barry Jenkins likes long walks. "]}],"plain":"There are a lot of reasons why Barry Jenkins might not have expected to be in the position he&rsquo;s in today: the first black filmmaker nominated for an Academy Award for Best Director, Best Screenplay and Best Picture and the face of the most critically revered movie of 2016. The writer-director of Moonlight grew up poor, in the Miami neighborhood of Liberty City, where his mother struggled with drug addiction. He&#8217;s a relatively late bloomer when it comes to filmmaking, not finding his way to the medium until his junior year at Florida State University. His projects remained mostly under the radar in the eight years between the release of his little seen but much respected first movie, Medicine for Melancholy, and Moonlight last October. And while his new film had a lot of things going for it, obvious commercial appeal was not one of them. But today, Moonlight has a Golden Globe and eight Oscar nominations under its belt, and its box office take is more than triple its $5 million budget. The story of a young boy growing up poor in Liberty City, with a mom addicted to crack and a repressed attraction to other boys, is remarkable not only for its subject matter but for its lush visual palate and dreamlike aesthetic. As America emerges from a year that saw frequent headlines about young black men killed by police, and from a month in which the shift in power has many fearing for their rights, audiences have found profound urgency in Moonlight. On the heels of a trip to Europe, where he screened Moonlight in six different cities, Jenkins talked to TIME about the life-saving power of representation and the bittersweet feeling of awards recognition when so many who came before him never got their due. TIME: How has the response to Moonlight stacked up to your expectations? Jenkins: It&rsquo;s definitely exceeded my expectations. But I don&rsquo;t mean that because I had modest expectations for the film. There&rsquo;s just certain aspects of this movie that are challenging. There&rsquo;s no movie stars. Structurally, it&rsquo;s a bit adventurous, it&rsquo;s visually adventurous. So it&rsquo;s not built to be a commercial piece of art and yet people are coming to the cinema, and they&rsquo;re seeing the work for what it is and appreciating it, but also finding a way to see themselves in it, no matter who they are or where they come from. The movie is based on Tarell Alvin McCraney&rsquo;s short play, In Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue. Have you found that many people assume it&#8217;s your story? Yeah. I think the starting point is different than the end point. I think it has become my story. Working on a film that had to be made in the way this film was made, it&rsquo;s kind of impossible to do it without giving your full self over to it. And if you read about this film, you will read that Barry Jenkins is straight and the character in our film is gay. So if people feel like they see me in the piece, I take it as the highest compliment. What reaction have you gotten from people in Liberty City, Miami, where the movie is set? The community really took ownership. The first voice you hear in the film is not one of our actors&mdash;it&rsquo;s not Mahershala Ali&mdash;it&rsquo;s the voice of a kid who came into a community center to an open casting call. I think that puts a stamp on the piece. People see the main character as any one of the hundreds of kids living in that neighborhood. Tarell and I are from that neighborhood, and they see that we have a Golden Globe, that we have eight Academy Award nominations, and they see themselves in that. It seems like one of the reasons the movie has caught on so much is that many people have an opportunity to see themselves in a way that maybe they&rsquo;ve never been able to walk into a movie theater or turn on a TV and see. I&rsquo;m on Twitter and Instagram, and I get these messages from total strangers all the time, saying just that. They never thought that they would walk into a theater and, as you said, see themselves onscreen. When you have such a lack of representation, such a lack of images, two things can happen. Either you start to feel like you&rsquo;re voiceless, or people who don&rsquo;t live in close proximity to you can conveniently start to think you don&rsquo;t exist, that you&rsquo;re invisible. When images do arise to fill that lack, they take on added importance. Do you see the main character, Chiron, as an antidote to stereotypes about black masculinity? I did not sit down to draw him in that way, not as a response to anything. [I was] trying to do justice to Tarell&rsquo;s work and Tarell&rsquo;s life. It&rsquo;s not that characters like Chiron didn&rsquo;t exist before. It&rsquo;s just that they don&rsquo;t often get centered in narratives. There was a point where I realized there were things happening in front of the camera that I hadn&rsquo;t seen very often, or ever. Watching a black man cradle a boy in the Atlantic Ocean&mdash;I hadn&rsquo;t seen that before. That&rsquo;s a very simple image. It&rsquo;s not something you draw to counter a stereotype. How did you approach the depiction of his mother, who is addicted to crack? This character was drawn from my mom, from Tarell&rsquo;s mom, so the idea of a stereotype never presented itself to me. When you&rsquo;re drawing from inside the community, you&rsquo;re drawing on human beings and not any stereotype. The reception of the character was something that I was concerned about. The way I work, things are very nuanced, not everything is explained. I hoped that people would see into some of the very simple gestures that Naomie [Harris] performs as a character and see both sides of her, the vice and the virtue. I haven&rsquo;t seen that many depictions of this supposed black crackhead mom. I remember [Spike Lee&#8217;s] Jungle Fever and David Simon&rsquo;s The Corner, which was amazing. Otherwise, I feel like we&rsquo;re afraid of these images to the point that we stifle people from depicting things that they actually lived through. The way the film captures light is remarkable. What were you and cinematographer James Laxton going for? Cinema is a little over 100 years old, and a lot of what we do is built around film emulsion. Those things were calibrated for white skin. We&rsquo;ve always placed powder on skin to dull the light. But my memory of growing up in Miami is this moist, beautiful black skin. And this movie is meant to reflect the consciousness of the character&mdash;of me and Tarell, to be honest. So we used oil. I wanted everyone&rsquo;s skin to have a sheen to reflect my memory. What do you make of people&rsquo;s tendency to politicize this film? Art is inherently political. Even trying to make a film that has nothing to do with politics is, in and of itself, a political act. Once we make the work and release it into the world, it&rsquo;s beyond our control. This movie premiered under one President and is now going into the awards season under a different President. I&rsquo;ve seen the cultural currency of the film shift just over the course of those six to eight weeks. How do you feel about Moonlight being pitted against the musical La La Land, another Oscar front-runner? They could not be more different films. I don&rsquo;t think a love for one has to be to the rejection of the other. I can only speak to the film I made, which was made in the service of shining a light on a character who is often marginalized. Where that falls in the context of the awards season, I can&rsquo;t say. But I love that regardless of where we are right now, a year and a half ago, we sat down to make this thing, and that&rsquo;s exactly how I felt and it&rsquo;s how I feel now. How does it feel to be the first black writer-director to be nominated for Best Picture, Director and Screenplay? It&rsquo;s bittersweet. I shouldn&rsquo;t be the first. I&rsquo;ll be happy when there&rsquo;s no longer any space for firsts because it&rsquo;ll mean those things have been done. I wouldn&rsquo;t be the first person who&rsquo;s merited this distinction. I don&rsquo;t understand how someone like Spike Lee has never been nominated for these three awards. The greatest thing is, I can take out my phone and look at messages from total strangers who feel a little bit less alone because of this film. I do recognize that it&rsquo;s larger than me. That&rsquo;s why I even hesitate to speak on it, because I think it&rsquo;s larger than me. But it&rsquo;s important to note that the barrier is not mine to break. I made a piece of work. The barrier does not fall to me. The barrier belongs to the Academy. A couple months ago you tweeted the link to your very first short film, My Josephine. How do you feel rewatching it now, 14 years later? There was a moment where I thought I couldn&rsquo;t be a good filmmaker because of who I was and where I was from. I grew up black and poor, and my mom went through these things depicted in the film. And making that movie proved to me that I could do the work to make myself as accomplished as anyone else. And it&rsquo;s just a reminder that even from the beginning, I was working to humanize others and to center marginalized characters. It&rsquo;s just a reminder to keep doing that. What are you into other than filmmaking? I love coffee. I&rsquo;ve got, like, eight different ways to make coffee at my house. That&rsquo;s about it. I&rsquo;m so damn boring. I like reading and writing and making coffee. And walking. Barry Jenkins likes long walks."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHe directed the most striking and critically revered movie of 2016\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":73875048,"featured_media":4656573,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[58298,420934628,430940571,190,56926],"time_section":[1098],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4656493"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4656493"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4656493"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4656493\u002Fauthors"}],"fortu style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4652888,"date":"2017-01-29T14:09:35","date_gmt":"2017-01-29T19:09:35","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4652888"},"modified":"2017-01-29T14:08:00","modified_gmt":"2017-01-29T19:08:00","slug":"asghar-farhadi-donald-trump-immigration-ban-oscars","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4652888\u002Fasghar-farhadi-donald-trump-immigration-ban-oscars\u002F","title":{"rendered":"Asghar Farhadi Will Not Attend Oscars, Condemns President Trump's Immigration Ban"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EIranian Oscar nominee Asghar Farhadi released a statement on Sunday addressing President Donald Trump&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fnews\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F28\u002Fdonald-trump-immigration-ban\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eimmigration ban\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. While \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F28\u002Ftrump-immigration-ban-oscars-asghar-farhadi\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eunconfirmed reports\u003C\u002Fa\u003E previously claimed the filmmaker would not be able to enter the U.S. to attend the Oscars in February, Farhadi states he will not be present either way.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;Over the course of the past few days and despite the unjust circumstances which have risen for the immigrants and travelers of several countries to the United States, my decision had remained the same: to attend this ceremony and to express my opinions about these circumstances in the press surrounding the event,&rdquo; Farhadi writes in a statement, via \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fmovies\u002Ftrump-immigration-oscars-iranian-director-asghar-farhadi.html\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EThe New York\u003Cem\u003E Times\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &ldquo;I neither had the intention to not attend nor did I want to boycott the event as a show of objection, for I know that many in the American film industry and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are opposed to the fanaticism and extremism which are today taking place more than ever.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFarhadi&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F26\u002Fthe-salesman-ew-review\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThe Salesman\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a nominee for Best Foreign Language Film. Despite initial plans to attend the ceremony with his cinematographer, Hossein Jafarian, he writes, &ldquo;the possibility of this presence is being accompanied by ifs and buts which are in no way acceptable to me even if exceptions were to be made for my trip.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EInstead, he included a statement he would&rsquo;ve made to press in the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;Hardliners, despite their nationalities, political arguments and wars, regard and understand the world in very much the same way. In order to understand the world, they have no choice but to regard it via an &lsquo;us and them&rsquo; mentality, which they use to create a fearful image of &lsquo;them&rsquo; and inflict fear in the people of their own countries,&rdquo; Farhadi writes. &ldquo;This is not just limited to the United States; in my country hardliners are the same. For years on both sides of the ocean, groups of hardliners have tried to present to their people unrealistic and fearful images of various nations and cultures in order to turn their differences into disagreements, their disagreements into enmities and their enmities into fears. Instilling fear in the people is an important tool used to justify extremist and fanatic behavior by narrow-minded individuals.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile he condemned &ldquo;the unjust conditions forced upon some of my compatriots and the citizens of the other six countries trying to legally enter the United States of America,&rdquo; Farhadi believes &ldquo;the similarities among the human beings on this earth and its various lands, and among its cultures and its faiths, far outweigh their differences. I believe that the root cause of many of the hostilities among nations in the world today must be searched for in their reciprocal humiliation carried out in its past and no doubt the current humiliation of other nations are the seeds of tomorrow&rsquo;s hostilities.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHe adds, &ldquo;To humiliate one nation with the pretext of guarding the security of another is not a new phenomenon in history and has always laid the groundwork for the creation of future divide and enmity.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe Academy released its own statement on the matter Saturday in light of Trump&rsquo;s executive order, which bars refugees and immigrants from several Middle Eastern countries, including Iran, from entering the U.S.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;As supporters of filmmakers &mdash; and the human rights of all people &mdash; around the globe, we find it extremely troubling that Asghar Farhadi, the director of the Oscar-winning film from Iran \u003Cem\u003EA Separation\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, along with the cast and crew of this year&rsquo;s Oscar-nominated film \u003Cem\u003EThe Salesman\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, could be barred from entering the country because of their religion or country of origin,&rdquo; it read in part.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fasghar-farhadi-oscars-statement\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Estory\u003C\u002Fa\u003E originally appeared on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.ew.com\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EEW.com \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Iranian Oscar nominee Asghar Farhadi released a statement on Sunday addressing President Donald Trumps ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fnews\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F28\u002Fdonald-trump-immigration-ban\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["immigration ban"]},". While ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F28\u002Ftrump-immigration-ban-oscars-asghar-farhadi\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":["unconfirmed reports"]}," previously claimed the filmmaker would not be able to enter the U.S. to attend the Oscars in February, Farhadi states he will not be present either way."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Over the course of the past few days and despite the unjust circumstances which have risen for the immigrants and travelers of several countries to the United States, my decision had remained the same: to attend this ceremony and to express my opinions about these circumstances in the press surrounding the event, Farhadi writes in a statement, via ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fmovies\u002Ftrump-immigration-oscars-iranian-director-asghar-farhadi.html","target":"_blank"},"content":["The New York",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" Times"]}]},". I neither had the intention to not attend nor did I want to boycott the event as a show of objection, for I know that many in the American film industry and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are opposed to the fanaticism and extremism which are today taking place more than ever."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Farhadis ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F26\u002Fthe-salesman-ew-review\u002F","target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["The Salesman"]}]}," is a nominee for Best Foreign Language Film. Despite initial plans to attend the ceremony with his cinematographer, Hossein Jafarian, he writes, the possibility of this presence is being accompanied by ifs and buts which are in no way acceptable to me even if exceptions were to be made for my trip."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Instead, he included a statement he wouldve made to press in the U.S."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Hardliners, despite their nationalities, political arguments and wars, regard and understand the world in very much the same way. In order to understand the world, they have no choice but to regard it via an us and them mentality, which they use to create a fearful image of them and inflict fear in the people of their own countries, Farhadi writes. This is not just limited to the United States; in my country hardliners are the same. For years on both sides of the ocean, groups of hardliners have tried to present to their people unrealistic and fearful images of various nations and cultures in order to turn their differences into disagreements, their disagreements into enmities and their enmities into fears. Instilling fear in the people is an important tool used to justify extremist and fanatic behavior by narrow-minded individuals."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["While he condemned the unjust conditions forced upon some of my compatriots and the citizens of the other six countries trying to legally enter the United States of America, Farhadi believes the similarities among the human beings on this earth and its various lands, and among its cultures and its faiths, far outweigh their differences. I believe that the root cause of many of the hostilities among nations in the world today must be searched for in their reciprocal humiliation carried out in its past and no doubt the current humiliation of other nations are the seeds of tomorrows hostilities."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He adds, To humiliate one nation with the pretext of guarding the security of another is not a new phenomenon in history and has always laid the groundwork for the creation of future divide and enmity."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Academy released its own statement on the matter Saturday in light of Trumps executive order, which bars refugees and immigrants from several Middle Eastern countries, including Iran, from entering the U.S."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["As supporters of filmmakers  and the human rights of all people  around the globe, we find it extremely troubling that Asghar Farhadi, the director of the Oscar-winning film from Iran ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["A Separation"]},", along with the cast and crew of this years Oscar-nominated film ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["The Salesman"]},", could be barred from entering the country because of their religion or country of origin, it read in part."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["This ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Few.com\u002Fmovies\u002F2017\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fasghar-farhadi-oscars-statement\u002F"},"content":["story"]}," originally appeared on ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.ew.com"},"content":["EW.com "]}]}]}],"plain":"Iranian Oscar nominee Asghar Farhadi released a statement on Sunday addressing President Donald Trump&rsquo;s immigration ban. While unconfirmed reports previously claimed the filmmaker would not be able to enter the U.S. to attend the Oscars in February, Farhadi states he will not be present either way. &ldquo;Over the course of the past few days and despite the unjust circumstances which have risen for the immigrants and travelers of several countries to the United States, my decision had remained the same: to attend this ceremony and to express my opinions about these circumstances in the press surrounding the event,&rdquo; Farhadi writes in a statement, via The New York Times. &ldquo;I neither had the intention to not attend nor did I want to boycott the event as a show of objection, for I know that many in the American film industry and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are opposed to the fanaticism and extremism which are today taking place more than ever.&rdquo; Farhadi&rsquo;s The Salesman is a nominee for Best Foreign Language Film. Despite initial plans to attend the ceremony with his cinematographer, Hossein Jafarian, he writes, &ldquo;the possibility of this presence is being accompanied by ifs and buts which are in no way acceptable to me even if exceptions were to be made for my trip.&rdquo; Instead, he included a statement he would&rsquo;ve made to press in the U.S. &ldquo;Hardliners, despite their nationalities, political arguments and wars, regard and understand the world in very much the same way. In order to understand the world, they have no choice but to regard it via an &lsquo;us and them&rsquo; mentality, which they use to create a fearful image of &lsquo;them&rsquo; and inflict fear in the people of their own countries,&rdquo; Farhadi writes. &ldquo;This is not just limited to the United States; in my country hardliners are the same. For years on both sides of the ocean, groups of hardliners have tried to present to their people unrealistic and fearful images of various nations and cultures in order to turn their differences into disagreements, their disagreements into enmities and their enmities into fears. Instilling fear in the people is an important tool used to justify extremist and fanatic behavior by narrow-minded individuals.&rdquo; While he condemned &ldquo;the unjust conditions forced upon some of my compatriots and the citizens of the other six countries trying to legally enter the United States of America,&rdquo; Farhadi believes &ldquo;the similarities among the human beings on this earth and its various lands, and among its cultures and its faiths, far outweigh their differences. I believe that the root cause of many of the hostilities among nations in the world today must be searched for in their reciprocal humiliation carried out in its past and no doubt the current humiliation of other nations are the seeds of tomorrow&rsquo;s hostilities.&rdquo; He adds, &ldquo;To humiliate one nation with the pretext of guarding the security of another is not a new phenomenon in history and has always laid the groundwork for the creation of future divide and enmity.&rdquo; The Academy released its own statement on the matter Saturday in light of Trump&rsquo;s executive order, which bars refugees and immigrants from several Middle Eastern countries, including Iran, from entering the U.S. &ldquo;As supporters of filmmakers &mdash; and the human rights of all people &mdash; around the globe, we find it extremely troubling that Asghar Farhadi, the director of the Oscar-winning film from Iran A Separation, along with the cast and crew of this year&rsquo;s Oscar-nominated film The Salesman, could be barred from entering the country because of their religion or country of origin,&rdquo; it read in part. This story originally appeared on EW.com"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFarhadis \u003Ci\u003EThe Salesman\u003C\u002Fi\u003E is a nominee for Best Foreign Language Film\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":90768241,"featured_media":4652894,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[430939235,56926],"time_section":[1098,204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4652888"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4652888"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4652888"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4652888\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newslet y_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":430939235,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Fonetime\u002F","name":"onetime","slug":"onetime","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F430939235"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=430939235"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=430939235"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":56926,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Foscars\u002F","name":"Oscars","slug":"oscars","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F56926"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=56926"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=56926"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No Will \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4628608\u002Fgolden-globes-2017-winners-oscar-predictions\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003ELa La Land\u003C\u002Fem\u003E&#8216;s\u003C\u002Fa\u003E deluge of accolades culminate in a Best Picture win? Will \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4626323\u002Fgolden-globes-2017-viola-davis-best-supporting-actress-fences\u002F\"\u003EViola Davis\u003C\u002Fa\u003E one-up her first Golden Globe with her first Oscar? Though the next month of campaigning could still bolster or batter any given nominee&#8217;s chances, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4607908\u002Frotten-tomatoes-certified-fresh-movies-2016\u002F\"\u003ERotten Tomatoes\u003C\u002Fa\u003E surveyed more than 150 critics to get their take on who will (and should) take home top honors as of today.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ECritics, of course don&#8217;t vote for Oscars \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E&mdash; if they did, then \u003Cem\u003EOut of Africa \u003C\u002Fem\u003E(56% on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4604580\u002Fbest-movies-franchises-rotten-tomatoes\u002F\"\u003ERotten Tomatoes\u003C\u002Fa\u003E), \u003Cem\u003EThe Greatest Show on Earth\u003C\u002Fem\u003E (44%) and \u003Cem\u003EAround the World in 80 Days \u003C\u002Fem\u003E(31%) would have to give back their little gold men. But their voices are as good an indication as any of what to expect on Feb. 26 (though as the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4649902\u002Fhow-president-trump-is-trampling-precedent\u002F\"\u003Elatest non-Hollywood news\u003C\u002Fa\u003E reminds us, anything &mdash; literally anything &mdash; could happen between now and then).\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003EHighlights of the survey include a two-thirds majority predicting that \u003Cem\u003ELa La Land \u003C\u002Fem\u003Ewill triumph, though only 20% think it deserves to. Just over half think \u003Cem\u003ELa La Land\u003C\u002Fem\u003E&#8216;s director, Damien Chazelle, will take home top honors, but the jury is hung on the case of Best Actress.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003ESee the full results of the survey below:\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E \u003Cb\u003EWhich film \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ewill\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003E win Best Picture?\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E1. \u003Ci\u003ELa La Land\u003C\u002Fi\u003E &ndash; Will La La Land&#8216;s deluge of accolades culminate in a Best Picture win? Will Viola Davis one-up her first Golden Globe with her first Oscar? Though the next month of campaigning could still bolster or batter any given nominee&#8217;s chances, Rotten Tomatoes surveyed more than 150 critics to get their take on who will (and should) take home top honors as of today. Critics, of course don&#8217;t vote for Oscars &mdash; if they did, then Out of Africa (56% on Rotten Tomatoes), The Greatest Show on Earth (44%) and Around the World in 80 Days (31%) would have to give back their little gold men. But their voices are as good an indication as any of what to expect on Feb. 26 (though as the latest non-Hollywood news reminds us, anything &mdash; literally anything &mdash; could happen between now and then). Highlights of the survey include a two-thirds majority predicting that La La Land will triumph, though only 20% think it deserves to. Just over half think La La Land&#8216;s director, Damien Chazelle, will take home top honors, but the jury is hung on the case of Best Actress. See the full results of the survey below: Which film will win Best Picture? 1. La La Land &ndash; 67% 2. Moonlight &ndash; 11% 3. Manchester by the Sea &ndash; 9% Which film should win Best Picture? 1. Moonlight &ndash; 28% 2. La La Land &ndash; 20% 3. Manchester by the Sea &ndash; 14% Who do you think will win Best Director? 1. Damien Chazelle, La La Land &ndash; 52% 2. Barry Jenkins, Moonlight &ndash; 22% 3. Kenneth Lonergan, Manchester by the Sea &ndash; 8% Who do you think will win Best Actor? 1. Casey Affleck, Manchester by the Sea &ndash; 65% 2. Denzel Washington, Fences &ndash; 18% 3. Ryan Gosling, La La Land &ndash; 5% Who do you think will win Best Actress? 1. Natalie Portman, Jackie &ndash; 39% 2. Emma Stone, La La Land &ndash; 29% 3. Isabelle Huppert, Elle &ndash; 9% Who do you think will win Best Supporting Actor? 1. Mahershala Ali, Moonlight &ndash; 55% 2. Jeff Bridges, Hell or High Water &ndash; 12% 3. Michael Shannon, Nocturnal Animals &ndash; 11% Who do you think will win Best Supporting Actress? 1. Viola Davis, Fences &ndash; 52% 2. Michelle Williams, Manchester by the Sea &ndash; 23% 3. Naomie Harris, Moonlight &ndash; 7% What do you think will win Best Animated Film? 1. Zootopia &ndash; 49% 2. Moana &ndash; 19% 3. Kubo and the Two Strings &ndash; 18% What do you think will win Best Documentary? 1. O.J. Made in America &ndash; 53% 2. 13th &ndash; 17%"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EMore than 150 critics weigh style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4644539,"date":"2017-01-24T11:15:19","date_gmt":"2017-01-24T16:15:19","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4644539"},"modified":"2017-01-27T17:11:00","modified_gmt":"2017-01-27T22:11:00","slug":"oscar-nominations-diversity-hollywood","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4644539\u002Foscar-nominations-diversity-hollywood\u002F","title":{"rendered":"This Years Oscars Arent #SoWhite. But Hollywood Still Has Work to Do."},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor the past two years, the announcement of Oscar nominations has been met with persistent protests over the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F\"\u003Elack of nonwhite nominees\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. The \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4180433\u002Foscar-nominations-white-diversity-oscarssowhite\u002F\"\u003E#OscarsSoWhite\u003C\u002Fa\u003E hashtag was beginning to feel like a regular late January trend. This year is different.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter two years without a single nonwhite acting nominee, seven of 20 \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4635815\u002F2017-oscars-nominations-list\u002F\"\u003Enominations\u003C\u002Fa\u003E in 2017 went to nonwhite actors. Three of the nine Best Picture nominees feature mostly black casts, four of the five nominated documentaries have black directors and Viola Davis becomes the first black actress to earn three Oscar nominations.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe shift wasn&rsquo;t exactly a surprise. Last year brought a comparative bounty &mdash; if still an overall dearth &mdash; of accomplished movies about the lives of people of color. There was \u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E&rsquo;s lyrical story of a young, gay black man growing up poor in Miami; \u003Ci\u003EHidden Figures\u003C\u002Fi\u003E&rsquo; celebration of the black female mathematicians who sent John Glenn (et. al.) into space; \u003Ci\u003EFences\u003C\u002Fi\u003E&rsquo; intimate depiction of the life of a black family in Pittsburgh in the 1950s. There was \u003Ci\u003ELion\u003C\u002Fi\u003E and its true story of an Indian-Australian man navigating a bifurcated identity, and \u003Ci\u003EMoana\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, Disney&rsquo;s first animated movie set in the South Pacific, whose nomination for Original Song helped \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4607907\u002Flin-manuel-miranda-donald-trump\u002F\"\u003ELin-Manuel Miranda\u003C\u002Fa\u003E get one step \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4645021\u002Flin-manuel-miranda-egot-moana\u002F\"\u003Ecloser to an EGOT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, this year&#8217;s inclusive list of nominees can&rsquo;t be entirely chalked up to the mere existence of those movies. Recall that in 2015, there were plenty of nonwhite stories for which Academy members might have cast their votes &mdash; \u003Ci\u003EStraight Outta Compton\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, \u003Ci\u003EBeasts of No Nation\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, \u003Ci\u003EChi-Raq\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, \u003Ci\u003ECreed\u003C\u002Fi\u003E &mdash; but (mostly) didn&rsquo;t.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe change might be explained by the Academy&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4191098\u002Facademy-changes-diversity-increase\u002F\"\u003Eefforts\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, under President Cheryl Boone Isaacs and in response to last year&rsquo;s uproar, to diversify its ranks. It may be explained by an increased commitment, among members, to get around to screeners they might have passed over in the past. And it may simply have something to do with the random timing of Hollywood releases; the life span of a movie, from conception to release, is a multiyear affair, and the fact that the crop released this year was released this year is as much coincidence as anything.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut even if we can&rsquo;t fully explain it, what are we to make of this year&rsquo;s retiring, at least temporarily, of #OscarsSoWhite? First, it&rsquo;s important to remember that the historic lack of diversity among Oscar nominees has less to do with the whiteness of the Academy (although that is most definitely \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4187311\u002Foscars-diversity-2\u002F\"\u003Ea thing\u003C\u002Fa\u003E) than it does with the decisions that get made behind the scenes. As of one year ago, the top six Hollywood studios counted just two African Americans and five Asian Americans among a combined 60 top executives, according to the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.hollywoodreporter.com\u002Fnews\u002Ffilm-studio-scorecard-how-diversity-859668\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EHollywood Reporter\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. And there is still a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fbusiness\u002Feconomy\u002Fhollywoods-race-problem-an-insular-industry-struggles-to-change\u002F2014\u002F12\u002F19\u002Fd870df04-8625-11e4-9534-f79a23c40e6c_story.html?utm_term=.371c32c25867\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eperception in the industry\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that movies helmed by or featuring people of color won&rsquo;t succeed at the box office, despite \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.bunchecenter.ucla.edu\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F2016-Hollywood-Diversity-Report-2-25-16.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eevidence to the contrary\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe result: Hollywood still has a long way to go. According to the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.bunchecenter.ucla.edu\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F2016-Hollywood-Diversity-Report-2-25-16.pdf\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E2016 Hollywood Diversity Report\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by the Ralph J. Bunche Center for African American Studies at University of California, Los Angeles, which studied films released from 2013 to 2014, minorities were underrepresented 3 to 1 among movie leads, 3 to 1 among directors and 5 to 1 among actors. A similar \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fthetwo-way\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F22\u002F467665890\u002Fhollywood-has-a-major-diversity-problem-usc-study-finds\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Estudy\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by the University of Southern California found that 28.3% of characters with dialogue were nonwhite, though nearly 40% of the U.S. population is nonwhite, and only 7% of films had a cast reflective, percentage-wise, of the country&#8217;s diversity.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThis year&rsquo;s nominations aren&#8217;t perfect, either. For the eighth year in a row, no women were nominated for Best Director. Representation among Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, LGBT and gender-nonconforming people and people with disabilities is paltry to nonexistent.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA more inclusive Oscars in 2017 is a sign of progress, not an indication that Hollywood&rsquo;s problems have been solved. It is a sign that perhaps the spotlight on the lack of inclusion is paying off, not an indication that that spotlight should be dimmed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For the past two years, the announcement of Oscar nominations has been met with persistent protests over the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F"},"content":["lack of nonwhite nominees"]},". And there is still a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fbusiness\u002Feconomy\u002Fhollywoods-race-problem-an-insular-industry-struggles-to-change\u002F2014\u002F12\u002F19\u002Fd870df04-8625-11e4-9534-f79a23c40e6c_story.html?utm_term=.371c32c25867","target":"_blank"},"content":["perception in the industry"]}," that movies helmed by or featuring people of color wont succeed at the box office, despite ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.bunchecenter.ucla.edu\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F2016-Hollywood-Diversity-Report-2-25-16.pdf"},"content":["evidence to the contrary"]},"."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The result: Hollywood still has a long way to go. According to the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.bunchecenter.ucla.edu\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F2016-Hollywood-Diversity-Report-2-25-16.pdf"},"content":["2016 Hollywood Diversity Report"]}," by the Ralph J. Bunche Center for African American Studies at University of California, Los Angeles, which studied films released from 2013 to 2014, minorities were underrepresented 3 to 1 among movie leads, 3 to 1 among directors and 5 to 1 among actors. A similar ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.npr.org\u002Fsections\u002Fthetwo-way\u002F2016\u002F02\u002F22\u002F467665890\u002Fhollywood-has-a-major-diversity-problem-usc-study-finds"},"content":["study"]}," by the University of Southern California found that 28.3% of characters with dialogue were nonwhite, though nearly 40% of the U.S. population is nonwhite, and only 7% of films had a cast reflective, percentage-wise, of the country's diversity."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["This years nominations aren't perfect, either. For the eighth year in a row, no women were nominated for Best Director. Representation among Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, LGBT and gender-nonconforming people and people with disabilities is paltry to nonexistent."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["A more inclusive Oscars in 2017 is a sign of progress, not an indication that Hollywoods problems have been solved. It is a sign that perhaps the spotlight on the lack of inclusion is paying off, not an indication that that spotlight should be dimmed."]}],"plain":"For the past two years, the announcement of Oscar nominations has been met with persistent protests over the lack of nonwhite nominees. The #OscarsSoWhite hashtag was beginning to feel like a regular late January trend. This year is different. After two years without a single nonwhite acting nominee, seven of 20 nominations in 2017 went to nonwhite actors. Three of the nine Best Picture nominees feature mostly black casts, four of the five nominated documentaries have black directors and Viola Davis becomes the first black actress to earn three Oscar nominations. The shift wasn&rsquo;t exactly a surprise. Last year brought a comparative bounty &mdash; if still an overall dearth &mdash; of accomplished movies about the lives of people of color. There was Moonlight&rsquo;s lyrical story of a young, gay black man growing up poor in Miami; Hidden Figures&rsquo; celebration of the black female mathematicians who sent John Glenn (et. al.) into space; Fences&rsquo; intimate depiction of the life of a black family in Pittsburgh in the 1950s. There was Lion and its true story of an Indian-Australian man navigating a bifurcated identity, and Moana, Disney&rsquo;s first animated movie set in the South Pacific, whose nomination for Original Song helped Lin-Manuel Miranda get one step closer to an EGOT. Still, this year&#8217;s inclusive list of nominees can&rsquo;t be entirely chalked up to the mere existence of those movies. Recall that in 2015, there were plenty of nonwhite stories for which Academy members might have cast their votes &mdash; Straight Outta Compton, Beasts of No Nation, Chi-Raq, Creed &mdash; but (mostly) didn&rsquo;t. The change might be explained by the Academy&rsquo;s efforts, under President Cheryl Boone Isaacs and in response to last year&rsquo;s uproar, to diversify its ranks. It may be explained by an increased commitment, among members, to get around to screeners they might have passed over in the past. And it may simply have something to do with the random timing of Hollywood releases; the life span of a movie, from conception to release, is a multiyear affair, and the fact that the crop released this year was released this year is as much coincidence as anything. But even if we can&rsquo;t fully explain it, what are we to make of this year&rsquo;s retiring, at least temporarily, of #OscarsSoWhite? First, it&rsquo;s important to remember that the historic lack of diversity among Oscar nominees has less to do with the whiteness of the Academy (although that is most definitely a thing) than it does with the decisions that get made behind the scenes. As of one year ago, the top six Hollywood studios counted just two African Americans and five Asian Americans among a combined 60 top executives, according to the Hollywood Reporter. And there is still a perception in the industry that movies helmed by or featuring people of color won&rsquo;t succeed at the box office, despite evidence to the contrary. The result: Hollywood still has a long way to go. According to the 2016 Hollywood Diversity Report by the Ralph J. Bunche Center for African American Studies at University of California, Los Angeles, which studied films released from 2013 to 2014, minorities were underrepresented 3 to 1 among movie leads, 3 to 1 among directors and 5 to 1 among actors. A similar study by the University of Southern California found that 28.3% of characters with dialogue were nonwhite, though nearly 40% of the U.S. population is nonwhite, and only 7% of films had a cast reflective, percentage-wise, of the country&#8217;s diversity. This year&rsquo;s nominations aren&#8217;t perfect, either. For the eighth year in a row, no women were nominated for Best Director. Representation among Asian Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, LGBT and gender-nonconforming people and people with disabilities is paltry to nonexistent. A more inclusive Oscars in 2017 is a sign of progress, not an indication that Hollywood&rsquo;s problems have been solved. It is a sign that perhaps the spotlight on the lack of inclusion is paying off, not an indication that that spotlight should be dimmed."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EFor the past two years, the announcement of Oscar nominations has been met with persistent protests over the lack of nonwhite nominees. The #OscarsSoWhite hashtag was beginning to feel like a regular late January trend. This year is different. After two years without a single nonwhite acting nominee, seven of 20 nominations in 2017 went&hellip;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":73875048,"featured_media":4645141,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[58298,430943221,6758,420934628,56926],"time_section":[1098],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4644539"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4644539"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4644539"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4644539\u002Fauthors"
