Your Comprehensive Guide to Oscar Season"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFebruary may seem like a long way off, but Hollywood&#8217;s annual awards season began not long after the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4577082\u002Fthanksgiving-holiday-history-origins\u002F\"\u003EThanksgiving\u003C\u002Fa\u003E dishes were returned to the hutch. The path to \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4240519\u002Foscars-2016-winners-list\u002F\"\u003EOscar Sunday\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is paved with a series of honors, some likely to influence voters and others more of a good excuse for an embarrassingly extravagant luncheon. If you&rsquo;re looking for early entries in your office Oscar pool, here&rsquo;s our handy guide to the must-see movies, the actors to watch, the schedule of events and the reason why, no matter how frivolous the pageantry can get, this year&rsquo;s golden statues still matter.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe Movies to See:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ERecent years have seen a rapid compression of the release window for prestige, which means that many of the year&rsquo;s biggest contenders won&rsquo;t open until the year&rsquo;s almost out, and many of those won&rsquo;t reach theaters nationwide until January. Still, there&#8217;s plenty to see in theaters now, and you can mark your calendar for those still to come. (And if you don&#8217;t have any plans for Christmas, we&#8217;ve got a sextuple-header for you.) \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ENote: Dates below reflect initial release, which is limited to select cities in some cases.\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ERequired Viewing:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4488759\u002Fmoonlight-tiff-toronto-international-film-festival\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Oct. 21): Ask any 10 critics which of this year&rsquo;s movies was the most beautiful, and the majority will tell you it&rsquo;s \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, a portrait of a boy grappling with his drug-addicted mother and his budding sexuality. Told in three chapters with three different actors, it will undoubtedly be a contender across the writing, directing and acting categories, and stands a serious chance of taking home Oscar&rsquo;s biggest prize.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4341168\u002Floving-movie-review-cannes\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELoving \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Nov. 4): The story of the interracial couple whose case led to the Supreme Court decision that struck down anti-miscegenation laws, Jeff Nichols&rsquo; restrained portrait focuses less on politics than on the humanity of two people in love, and it&rsquo;s all the more powerful for it.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4575255\u002Fmanchester-by-the-sea-movie-review\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EManchester by the Sea \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Nov. 18): Writer-director Kenneth Lonergan&rsquo;s portrait of a Boston custodian (Casey Affleck) helping to raise his recently orphaned teenaged son (Lucas Hedges) is at once devastatingly sad and surprisingly funny, and it&rsquo;s been one of 2016&rsquo;s most buzzed-about indies since debuting at Sundance back in January.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4474968\u002Fla-la-land-venice-film-festival\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELa La Land \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 9): Director Damien Chazelle made a name for himself with \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWhiplash \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ein 2014, and his follow-up is a musical that is both vivid and melancholy, an homage to old Hollywood that manages to still feel current. It should do big business in the acting and music categories, and it&rsquo;s a safe bet for a Best Pic, since moviemakers love movies about moviemakers (and musicians) &agrave; la 2007&#8217;s \u003Cem\u003EThe Artist\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4581099\u002Fscorsese-silence-andrew-garfield-liam-neeson\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESilence \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 23): Martin Scorsese&rsquo;s films have racked up an impressive 20 Oscar wins (and 80 nominations) over four decades, and this long-gestating passion project about 17th-century Jesuit priests in Japan will be high on award voters&rsquo; radars.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4509463\u002Fviola-davis-denzel-washington-fences-trailer\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFences \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 25): Denzel Washington and Viola Davis both won Tony Awards for the 2010 revival of August Wilson&rsquo;s 1983 play about a retired Negro League baseball player and his family in 1950s Pittsburgh. Both reprise their roles in this stirring, Washington-directed movie adaptation.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4480944\u002Finvisible-women-history\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHidden Figures\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Dec. 25): The story of the black female mathematicians and engineers who helped get Americans into space, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHidden Figures\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E is an uplifting celebration of unsung American heroes. The ensemble took home an honor from the National Board of Review and the Pharrell-produced soundtrack will likely see action in the Best Original Song category.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExtra Credit:\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4439621\u002Fflorence-foster-jenkins-reviews\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFlorence Foster Jenkins \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Aug. 12, returning to theaters Dec. 2): Meryl Streep sings very badly very well, and Hugh Grant helps maintain her delusions of grandeur.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4457123\u002Fhell-or-high-water-review-craggy-jeff-bridges\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHell or High Water \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Aug. 12): Jeff Bridges generated lots of buzz for his grizzled Texas Ranger in this gorgeous neo-western.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4566458\u002Farrival-review-amy-adams\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EArrival \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Nov. 11): Amy Adams shines, as per usual, as a linguist communicating with aliens. Eric Heisserer&rsquo;s screenplay, adapted from Ted Chiang&rsquo;s short story, is another reason to watch.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4577009\u002Flion-movie-review-saroo-brierly-dev-patel\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELion\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Nov. 25): The true story of a boy adopted from India who, as a young man, finds his birth mother using \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Falphabet-36\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EGoogle\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Earth, features a strong supporting performance from Nicole Kidman as his adoptive Australian mother.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4520022\u002Fnatalie-portman-jackie-trailer\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EJackie\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Dec. 2): Though the film is on the bubble for the Best Picture race, Natalie Portman&rsquo;s multilayered performance as a grieving Jackie Kennedy in the days after her husband&rsquo;s assassination is likely to see ample recognition throughout the season (more on that below). \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4519443\u002Fpatriots-day-trailer-mark-wahlberg-boston-marathon-bombing\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EPatriots Day \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 21): Peter Berg and Mark Wahlberg team up for a third time (after \u003Cem\u003ELone Survivor\u003C\u002Fem\u003E and \u003Cem\u003EDeepwater Horizon\u003C\u002Fem\u003E) to tell the story of the Boston Marathon bombing and the manhunt that followed, and the result is as respectful and dignified as it is compelling.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E20th Century Women \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 25): Annette Bening, Greta Gerwig and Elle Fanning make for a delightful trio in Mike Mills&rsquo; personal story about a mother (Bening) and her son (Lucas Jade Zumann) in late-1970s Santa Barbara.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003ETeacher&rsquo;s style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ESully \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Sept. 9): There&rsquo;s some buzz for Tom Hanks&rsquo; performance as &ldquo;Miracle on the Hudson&rdquo; pilot Chesley &#8220;Sully&#8221; Sullenberger, though stiff competition among Leading Actors has him on the bubble for a nomination.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4547326\u002Fhacksaw-ridge-review-mel-gibson\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan about the heroic conscientious objector Desmond Doss features a memorable performance from Andrew Garfield and some of the most harrowing war scenes since \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan thriller are the costumes, from Cotillard&rsquo;s floral silk robes to the shades she dons during target practice.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Dec. 25): There&rsquo;s not much buzz yet for this adaptation of Dennis Lehane&rsquo;s Prohibition-era gangster story, which is written, directed and produced by star Ben Affleck, but the last time Affleck directed a movie (\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan for movie awards, and it&rsquo;s currently the frontrunner in its field, having already taken home Best Documentary from the Gotham Awards and the National Board of Review. Other strong contenders include \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E13th\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ECameraperson\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EI Am Not Your Negro\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EWeiner\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMiss Sharon Jones!\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe Eagle Huntress\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EKubo and the Two Strings \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Aug. 19): This stop-motion-animated tale of a Japanese boy fighting spirits from his past is both a stunning technical accomplishment and a nuanced meditation on childhood grief. As usual, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002Ffortune500\u002Fdisney-53\u002F\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EDisney\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and Pixar are likely to stack the animation field with this year&rsquo;s offerings, which include Disney&rsquo;s first heroine without a love interest (\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4473277\u002Fmoana-disney-princess-directors-interview\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoana\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E), the cutest baby fish ever (\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4371173\u002Ffinding-dory-review\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFinding Dory\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E) and a surprisingly relevant allegory of racism and prejudice in America (\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4247121\u002Freview-zootopia-teachable-moment\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EZootopia\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E).\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4565957\u002Fpaul-verhoeven-elle\u002F\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EElle\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Nov. 11): French actress Isabelle Huppert won Best Actress at the Gotham Awards for her portrayal of a rape survivor who takes revenge. Other foreign films to check out include \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EToni Erdmann \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E(Germany), \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe Salesman\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Iran), \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ENeruda\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Chile), \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EChevalier\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Greece) and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFire at Sea\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (Italy).\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe Actresses to Watch:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ELet&rsquo;s start with the Supporting Actress race, because this one&rsquo;s got the most obvious frontrunner: \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003EViola Davis\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. But don&rsquo;t discount the competition: \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca two-time Oscar winner \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003EDenzel Washington\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, who could also see his name in the Best Director field. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003EJeff Bridges \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eplays the role he was born to play in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan Blake, and Rooster Cogburn). \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003EMahershala Ali \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ebrings complexity to a drug dealer who&rsquo;s also a benevolent father figure in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cb\u003EHugh Grant Jenkins\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, as could \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003EKevin Costner \u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. If voters are looking for a newcomer to round out the field, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cb\u003ELucas Hedges\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E had one of the year&rsquo;s most memorable breakthrough performances as a teenager dealing with his father&rsquo;s death in \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EManchester by the Sea\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. At this point, this appears to be the acting category with the most room for campaigns to wriggle new names in or out.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe Trend to Monitor:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe most visible trend in recent awards seasons has to do not with lapels or lace but with the overwhelming homogeneity of nominees. The last two year&rsquo;s Academy Awards counted \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4180433\u002Foscar-nominations-white-diversity-oscarssowhite\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Ezero nonwhite nominees\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E (out of a total of 40) for acting awards, and a look all the way \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eback to Oscar&rsquo;s beginning\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E proves this lack of inclusion to be the rule, not the exception. In response to overwhelming pressure to take steps toward change, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences President Cheryl Boone Isaacs ushered through a series of \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4191098\u002Facademy-changes-diversity-increase\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Enew measures\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, including phasing out inactive voters and inviting a \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4388726\u002Facademy-movies-diverse-class\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Enew class\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E of voters, 41% of whose members are people of color, to address the problems at the root of #oscarssowhite.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThe Academy is just one piece of the puzzle when it comes to seeing more diverse stories onscreen&mdash;many industry insiders \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4192594\u002Fhollywood-diversity-problem-oscars-academy-awards\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Eargue\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E that real change must begin with the decisionmakers who greenlight and finance projects in the first place&mdash;and it would be overly simplistic to attribute a more inclusive event solely to the Academy&rsquo;s actions. But this year&rsquo;s field of contenders includes a number of high-profile movies which tell stories about people of color&mdash;to name just a few: \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, which took home four Gotham Awards, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EHidden Figures\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, which won the National Board of Review&rsquo;s Best Ensemble, and \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ci\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EFences\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E, which looks to rival the play&#8217;s Tony count with Oscars\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cb\u003EThe Dates to Look Out For:\u003C\u002Fb\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EThough casual viewers typically start paying attention when stars start flaunting their Neil Lane diamonds on the Golden Globes&rsquo; red carpet, there&rsquo;s a long run-up to the televised glamour, beginning right after Thanksgiving. Some awards have more influence than others&mdash;the Gotham Awards, for example, have predicted the Best Picture Oscar for two years running&mdash;but in aggregate, they hold the power to sway voters and help determine who&rsquo;s exclaiming &ldquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=rl_NpdAy3WY\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003EYou like me!\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E&rdquo; from the Oscar podium and who&rsquo;s \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=SLjmshg_0Fo#t=158\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Enot even pretending\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E to be happy for her. Here&#8217;s a list of the most important dates between now and the last Sunday in February:\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ENov. 28: style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003ENov. 29: National Board of Review winners announced (See winners \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4581099\u002Fscorsese-silence-andrew-garfield-liam-neeson\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Silence "]}]},"(Dec. 23): Martin Scorseses films have racked up an impressive 20 Oscar wins (and 80 nominations) over four decades, and this long-gestating passion project about 17th-century Jesuit priests in Japan will be high on award voters radars."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4509463\u002Fviola-davis-denzel-washington-fences-trailer\u002F"},"content":[{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Fences "]}]},"(Dec. 25): Denzel Washington and Viola Davis both won Tony Awards for the 2010 revival of August Wilsons 1983 play about a retired Negro League baseball player and his family in 1950s Pittsburgh. ",{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Jeff Bridges "]},"plays the role he was born to play in ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Hell or High Water "]},"(well, aside from Starman, and Jack Baker, and The Dude, and Bad Blake, and Rooster Cogburn). ",{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Mahershala Ali "]},"brings complexity to a drug dealer whos also a benevolent father figure in ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Moonlight. "]},{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Hugh Grant "]},"could get love for his enabling partner in ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Florence Foster Jenkins"]},", as could ",{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["Kevin Costner "]},"for his NASA bigwig in ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Hidden Figures"]},". At this point, this appears to be the acting category with the most room for campaigns to wriggle new names in or out."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["The Trend to Monitor:"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The most visible trend in recent awards seasons has to do not with lapels or lace but with the overwhelming homogeneity of nominees. The last two years Academy Awards counted ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4180433\u002Foscar-nominations-white-diversity-oscarssowhite\u002F"},"content":["zero nonwhite nominees"]}," (out of a total of 40) for acting awards, and a look all the way ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F"},"content":["back to Oscars beginning"]}," proves this lack of inclusion to be the rule, not the exception. In response to overwhelming pressure to take steps toward change, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences President Cheryl Boone Isaacs ushered through a series of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4191098\u002Facademy-changes-diversity-increase\u002F"},"content":["new measures"]},", including phasing out inactive voters and inviting a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4388726\u002Facademy-movies-diverse-class\u002F"},"content":["new class"]}," of voters, 41% of whose members are people of color, to address the problems at the root of #oscarssowhite."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The Academy is just one piece of the puzzle when it comes to seeing more diverse stories onscreenmany industry insiders ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4192594\u002Fhollywood-diversity-problem-oscars-academy-awards\u002F"},"content":["argue"]}," that real change must begin with the decisionmakers who greenlight and finance projects in the first placeand it would be overly simplistic to attribute a more inclusive event solely to the Academys actions. But this years field of contenders includes a number of high-profile movies which tell stories about people of colorto name just a few: ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Moonlight"]},", which took home four Gotham Awards, ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Hidden Figures"]},", which won the National Board of Reviews Best Ensemble, and ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Fences"]},", which looks to rival the play's Tony count with Oscars ."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"b","attributes":[],"content":["The Dates to Look Out For:"]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Though casual viewers typically start paying attention when stars start flaunting their Neil Lane diamonds on the Golden Globes red carpet, theres a long run-up to the televised glamour, beginning right after Thanksgiving. Some awards have more influence than othersthe Gotham Awards, for example, have predicted the Best Picture Oscar for two years runningbut in aggregate, they hold the power to sway voters and help determine whos exclaiming ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=rl_NpdAy3WY"},"content":["You like me!"]}," from the Oscar podium and whos ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=SLjmshg_0Fo#t=158"},"content":["not even pretending"]}," to be happy for her. Here's a list of the most important dates between now and the last Sunday in February:"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nov. 28: Gotham Independent Film Awards (See winners ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4584003\u002Fgotham-awards-moonlight-best-feature-oscars\u002F"},"content":["here"]},")."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nov. 29: National Board of Review winners announced (See winners ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nationalboardofreview.org\u002Faward-years\u002F2016\u002F"},"content":["here"]},")."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Dec. 1: New York Film Critics Circle Awards announced"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Dec. 11: Critics Choice Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Dec. 12: Golden Globes nominations announced"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Dec. 14: SAG nominations announced"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jan. 8: Golden Globe Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jan. 24: Academy Award nominations announced"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jan. 28: Producers Guild of America Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Jan. 29: Screen Actors Guild Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 4: Directors Guild of America Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 4: Annie Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 12: British Academy of Film and Television Arts Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 19: Writers Guild of America Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 25: Independent Spirit Awards"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Feb. 26: 89th Annual Academy Awards"]}],"plain":"February may seem like a long way off, but Hollywood&#8217;s annual awards season began not long after the Thanksgiving dishes were returned to the hutch. The path to Oscar Sunday is paved with a series of honors, some likely to influence voters and others more of a good excuse for an embarrassingly extravagant luncheon. If you&rsquo;re looking for early entries in your office Oscar pool, here&rsquo;s our handy guide to the must-see movies, the actors to watch, the schedule of events and the reason why, no matter how frivolous the pageantry can get, this year&rsquo;s golden statues still matter. The Movies to See: Recent years have seen a rapid compression of the release window for prestige, which means that many of the year&rsquo;s biggest contenders won&rsquo;t open until the year&rsquo;s almost out, and many of those won&rsquo;t reach theaters nationwide until January. Still, there&#8217;s plenty to see in theaters now, and you can mark your calendar for those still to come. (And if you don&#8217;t have any plans for Christmas, we&#8217;ve got a sextuple-header for you.) Note: Dates below reflect initial release, which is limited to select cities in some cases. Required Viewing: Moonlight (Oct. 21): Ask any 10 critics which of this year&rsquo;s movies was the most beautiful, and the majority will tell you it&rsquo;s Moonlight, a portrait of a boy grappling with his drug-addicted mother and his budding sexuality. Told in three chapters with three different actors, it will undoubtedly be a contender across the writing, directing and acting categories, and stands a serious chance of taking home Oscar&rsquo;s biggest prize. Loving (Nov. 4): The story of the interracial couple whose case led to the Supreme Court decision that struck down anti-miscegenation laws, Jeff Nichols&rsquo; restrained portrait focuses less on politics than on the humanity of two people in love, and it&rsquo;s all the more powerful for it. Manchester by the Sea (Nov. 18): Writer-director Kenneth Lonergan&rsquo;s portrait of a Boston custodian (Casey Affleck) helping to raise his recently orphaned teenaged son (Lucas Hedges) is at once devastatingly sad and surprisingly funny, and it&rsquo;s been one of 2016&rsquo;s most buzzed-about indies since debuting at Sundance back in January. La La Land (Dec. 9): Director Damien Chazelle made a name for himself with Whiplash in 2014, and his follow-up is a musical that is both vivid and melancholy, an homage to old Hollywood that manages to still feel current. It should do big business in the acting and music categories, and it&rsquo;s a safe bet for a Best Pic, since moviemakers love movies about moviemakers (and musicians) &agrave; la 2007&#8217;s The Artist. Silence (Dec. 23): Martin Scorsese&rsquo;s films have racked up an impressive 20 Oscar wins (and 80 nominations) over four decades, and this long-gestating passion project about 17th-century Jesuit priests in Japan will be high on award voters&rsquo; radars. Fences (Dec. 25): Denzel Washington and Viola Davis both won Tony Awards for the 2010 revival of August Wilson&rsquo;s 1983 play about a retired Negro League baseball player and his family in 1950s Pittsburgh. Both reprise their roles in this stirring, Washington-directed movie adaptation. Hidden Figures (Dec. 25): The story of the black female mathematicians and engineers who helped get Americans into space, Hidden Figures is an uplifting celebration of unsung American heroes. The ensemble took home an honor from the National Board of Review and the Pharrell-produced soundtrack will likely see action in the Best Original Song category. Extra Credit: Florence Foster Jenkins (Aug. 12, returning to theaters Dec. 2): Meryl Streep sings very badly very well, and Hugh Grant helps maintain her delusions of grandeur. Hell or High Water (Aug. 12): Jeff Bridges generated lots of buzz for his grizzled Texas Ranger in this gorgeous neo-western. Arrival (Nov. 11): Amy Adams shines, as per usual, as a linguist communicating with aliens. Eric Heisserer&rsquo;s screenplay, adapted from Ted Chiang&rsquo;s short story, is another reason to watch. Lion (Nov. 25): The true story of a boy adopted from India who, as a young man, finds his birth mother using Google Earth, features a strong supporting performance from Nicole Kidman as his adoptive Australian mother. Jackie (Dec. 2): Though the film is on the bubble for the Best Picture race, Natalie Portman&rsquo;s multilayered performance as a grieving Jackie Kennedy in the days after her husband&rsquo;s assassination is likely to see ample recognition throughout the season (more on that below). Patriots Day (Dec. 21): Peter Berg and Mark Wahlberg team up for a third time (after Lone Survivor and Deepwater Horizon) to tell the story of the Boston Marathon bombing and the manhunt that followed, and the result is as respectful and dignified as it is compelling. 20th Century Women (Dec. 25): Annette Bening, Greta Gerwig and Elle Fanning make for a delightful trio in Mike Mills&rsquo; personal story about a mother (Bening) and her son (Lucas Jade Zumann) in late-1970s Santa Barbara. Teacher&rsquo;s Pet: Sully (Sept. 9): There&rsquo;s some buzz for Tom Hanks&rsquo; performance as &ldquo;Miracle on the Hudson&rdquo; pilot Chesley &#8220;Sully&#8221; Sullenberger, though stiff competition among Leading Actors has him on the bubble for a nomination. Hacksaw Ridge (Nov. 4): Mel Gibson&rsquo;s World War II movie about the heroic conscientious objector Desmond Doss features a memorable performance from Andrew Garfield and some of the most harrowing war scenes since Saving Private Ryan. Allied (Nov. 23): The most memorable part of this Marion Cotillard\u002FBrad Pitt World War II spy thriller are the costumes, from Cotillard&rsquo;s floral silk robes to the shades she dons during target practice. Live by Night (Dec. 25): There&rsquo;s not much buzz yet for this adaptation of Dennis Lehane&rsquo;s Prohibition-era gangster story, which is written, directed and produced by star Ben Affleck, but the last time Affleck directed a movie (Argo), it took home Best Picture. Docs, Animation and Foreign Films: O.J.: Made in America (May 20): Though it aired on ESPN, a brief theatrical release qualifies this 8-hour epic for movie awards, and it&rsquo;s currently the frontrunner in its field, having already taken home Best Documentary from the Gotham Awards and the National Board of Review. Other strong contenders include 13th, Cameraperson, I Am Not Your Negro, Weiner, Miss Sharon Jones! and The Eagle Huntress. Kubo and the Two Strings (Aug. 19): This stop-motion-animated tale of a Japanese boy fighting spirits from his past is both a stunning technical accomplishment and a nuanced meditation on childhood grief. As usual, Disney and Pixar are likely to stack the animation field with this year&rsquo;s offerings, which include Disney&rsquo;s first heroine without a love interest (Moana), the cutest baby fish ever (Finding Dory) and a surprisingly relevant allegory of racism and prejudice in America (Zootopia). Elle (Nov. 11): French actress Isabelle Huppert won Best Actress at the Gotham Awards for her portrayal of a rape survivor who takes revenge. Other foreign films to check out include Toni Erdmann (Germany), The Salesman (Iran), Neruda (Chile), Chevalier (Greece) and Fire at Sea (Italy). The Actresses to Watch: Let&rsquo;s start with the Supporting Actress race, because this one&rsquo;s got the most obvious frontrunner: Viola Davis. Though her portrayal of Rose Maxson in Fences is, pardon the pun, on the fence between Leading and Supporting, Paramount is campaigning her in the Supporting field due to a tighter race among female leads. But don&rsquo;t discount the competition: Michelle Williams is an emotional powerhouse as Casey Affleck&rsquo;s estranged wife in Manchester by the Sea; Naomie Harris devastatingly portrays a mother struggling with drug addiction in Moonlight; Nicole Kidman and Greta Gerwig could see play for Lion and 20th Century Women, respectively, and the supporting actresses of Hidden Figures, Janelle Mon&aacute;e and Octavia Spencer, both deliver memorable performances, as well. When it comes to Leading Actress, it looks to be a showdown between Emma Stone&rsquo;s dreaming, constantly auditioning barista in La La Land and Natalie Portman&rsquo;s complicated take on Jacqueline Kennedy in Jackie. But if they&rsquo;re frontrunners, it&rsquo;s not by much: Annette Bening, who has been nominated for an Academy Award four times but never won, could break the spell with 20th Century Women, Ruth Negga gives a sturdy breakout performance in Loving, Isabelle Huppert could see some action if enough voters get their hands on Elle, and Meryl Streep made a movie this year. The Actors to Watch: The race for Leading Actor, at this stage in the game, looks like it will come down to Casey Affleck, who won Best Actor at the Gotham Awards and the National Board of Review Awards, and two-time Oscar winner Denzel Washington, who could also see his name in the Best Director field. The category will likely be rounded out by some combination of Ryan Gosling (La La Land), Joel Edgerton (Loving), Andrew Garfield (for Silence or Hacksaw Ridge), Warren Beatty (Rules Don&rsquo;t Apply), Tom Hanks (Sully), Michael Keaton (The Founder) and&mdash;a dark horse but a deserving one&mdash;Viggo Mortensen (Captain Fantastic). Best Supporting Actor is more of a toss-up. Jeff Bridges plays the role he was born to play in Hell or High Water (well, aside from Starman, and Jack Baker, and The Dude, and Bad Blake, and Rooster Cogburn). Mahershala Ali brings complexity to a drug dealer who&rsquo;s also a benevolent father figure in Moonlight. Hugh Grant could get love for his enabling partner in Florence Foster Jenkins, as could Kevin Costner for his NASA bigwig in Hidden Figures. If voters are looking for a newcomer to round out the field, Lucas Hedges had one of the year&rsquo;s most memorable breakthrough performances as a teenager dealing with his father&rsquo;s death in Manchester by the Sea. At this point, this appears to be the acting category with the most room for campaigns to wriggle new names in or out. The Trend to Monitor: The most visible trend in recent awards seasons has to do not with lapels or lace but with the overwhelming homogeneity of nominees. The last two year&rsquo;s Academy Awards counted zero nonwhite nominees (out of a total of 40) for acting awards, and a look all the way back to Oscar&rsquo;s beginning proves this lack of inclusion to be the rule, not the exception. In response to overwhelming pressure to take steps toward change, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences President Cheryl Boone Isaacs ushered through a series of new measures, including phasing out inactive voters and inviting a new class of voters, 41% of whose members are people of color, to address the problems at the root of #oscarssowhite. The Academy is just one piece of the puzzle when it comes to seeing more diverse stories onscreen&mdash;many industry insiders argue that real change must begin with the decisionmakers who greenlight and finance projects in the first place&mdash;and it would be overly simplistic to attribute a more inclusive event solely to the Academy&rsquo;s actions. But this year&rsquo;s field of contenders includes a number of high-profile movies which tell stories about people of color&mdash;to name just a few: Moonlight, which took home four Gotham Awards, Hidden Figures, which won the National Board of Review&rsquo;s Best Ensemble, and Fences, which looks to rival the play&#8217;s Tony count with Oscars. The Dates to Look Out For: Though casual viewers typically start paying attention when stars start flaunting their Neil Lane diamonds on the Golden Globes&rsquo; red carpet, there&rsquo;s a long run-up to the televised glamour, beginning right after Thanksgiving. Some awards have more influence than others&mdash;the Gotham Awards, for example, have predicted the Best Picture Oscar for two years running&mdash;but in aggregate, they hold the power to sway voters and help determine who&rsquo;s exclaiming &ldquo;You like me!&rdquo; from the Oscar podium and who&rsquo;s not even pretending to be happy for her. Here&#8217;s a list of the most important dates between now and the last Sunday in February: Nov. 28: Gotham Independent Film Awards (See winners here). Nov. 29: National Board of Review winners announced (See winners here). Dec. 1: New York Film Critics Circle Awards announced Dec. 11: Critics Choice Awards Dec. 12: Golden Globes nominations announced Dec. 14: SAG nominations announced Jan. 8: Golden Globe Awards Jan. 24: Academy Award nominations announced Jan. 28: Producers Guild of America Awards Jan. 29: Screen Actors Guild Awards Feb. 4: Directors Guild of America Awards Feb. 4: Annie Awards Feb. 12: British Academy of Film and Television Arts Awards Feb. 19: Writers Guild of America Awards Feb. 25: Independent Spirit Awards Feb. 26: 89th Annual Academy Awards"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EActors 5\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4586185\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4586185"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002 REUTERS\u002FLucy Nicholson (UNITED STATES - Tags: ENTERTAINMENT) - RTR4QBRZ"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":190,"name":"movies","slug":"movies","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":491,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":5039,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":1098,"name":"Entertainment","slug":"entertainment","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":23,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"From esoteric art to Housewives hullaballoo, TIME Entertainment covers what's good, bad and breaking right now in music, movies, TV, tech, celebrities and style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4584003,"date":"2016-11-29T10:38:10","date_gmt":"2016-11-29T15:38:10","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4584003"},"modified":"2016-11-29T10:42:00","modified_gmt":"2016-11-29T15:42:00","slug":"gotham-awards-moonlight-best-feature-oscars","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4584003\u002Fgotham-awards-moonlight-best-feature-oscars\u002F","title":{"rendered":"This Movie Just Won the Award That Predicted the Last Two Best Picture Winners"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EThe movie awards season officially kicked off on Monday night with the Gotham Independent Film Awards in New York City, and the night was, above all, a celebration of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4488759\u002Fmoonlight-tiff-toronto-international-film-festival\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, which took home Best Feature, Best Screenplay, the Audience Award and a special jury award for Best Ensemble. Now in its 26th year, the Gotham Awards, which honor feature-length indie movies, is the first major event of awards season. Although the criteria limit nominees to smaller-budget productions, it has often served as an early indicator of the movies whose names will become familiar by the time the Oscars roll around in February.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EBut the Gotham Awards have also, in recent years, served as a valuable predictive tool for February&rsquo;s Hollywood gold rush&mdash;not that prognostication is, by any means, its \u003Ci\u003Eraison d&#8217;&ecirc;tre\u003C\u002Fi\u003E. The last two years&rsquo; Best Feature winners, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F3613240\u002Fbirdman-nyc-gotham-independent-film-awards\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EBirdman\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(2014) and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4130610\u002Fspotlight-gotham-movie-awards\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003ESpotlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(2015), both went on to win the Oscar for Best Picture three months later. So while it&rsquo;s too early yet to engrave anything in gold, the win certainly elevates the profile of an already acclaimed movie.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, which emerged victorious from a field that included \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4549389\u002Fmichelle-williams-interview-manchester-by-the-sea\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003ECertain Women\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4277525\u002Feverybody-wants-some-deserves-a-third-exclamation-mark\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EEverybody Wants Some!!\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4575255\u002Fmanchester-by-the-sea-movie-review\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EManchester by the Sea\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Ci\u003E \u003C\u002Fi\u003Eand \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4337203\u002Fcannes-toni-erdmann-paterson\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E\u003Ci\u003EPaterson\u003C\u002Fi\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, is a coming-of-age story in three chapters that takes place in Miami during the height of the War on Drugs. Adapted by writer-director Barry Jenkins from Tarell Alvin McCraney&rsquo;s play \u003Ci\u003EIn Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, it stars three actors of different ages as Chiron, a boy whose mother falls victim to the crack epidemic and whose burgeoning attraction to other boys he deals with secretly. It&rsquo;s not only a beautiful movie but one that feels urgent: a sensitive and nuanced exploration of black masculinity during a year whose first six months saw more than 100 black men \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4394802\u002Falton-sterling-police-shooting-baton-rouge\u002F\"\u003Ekilled by police\u003C\u002Fa\u003E.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIt remains to be seen whether the awards-season success of recent Gotham winners is pure coincidence or representative of some larger trend&mdash;or, at the very least, of an Academy whose tastes are trending toward those of the veteran indie actors and filmmakers that sit on Gotham&rsquo;s juries. Even for Best Feature picks that haven&rsquo;t gone on to take home the Academy&rsquo;s highest honor, a win at Gotham has almost always translated into some kind of love from the Academy. \u003Ci\u003ESideways\u003C\u002Fi\u003E (2004) received four Oscar nominations. \u003Ci\u003ECapote\u003C\u002Fi\u003E (2005) and \u003Ci\u003EBeginners \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(2012) earned acting Oscars for Philip Seymour Hoffman and Christopher Plummer, respectively. Since the Gotham Awards began handing out the Best Feature award in 2004, a movie has never won that blue ribbon without at least getting nominated for one little gold statue in February.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EOf course, the indie nature of the Gotham Awards means that more than a handful of prestige studio pictures, which will campaign heavily throughout the coming months, weren&rsquo;t present on Monday night. These include offerings from Paramount (\u003Ci\u003EFences\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, \u003Ci\u003ESilence\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, \u003Ci\u003EFlorence Foster Jenkins, Arrival\u003C\u002Fi\u003E); Fox (\u003Ci\u003EJackie\u003C\u002Fi\u003E,\u003Ci\u003E Hidden Figures\u003C\u002Fi\u003E); Lionsgate (\u003Ci\u003ELa La Land\u003C\u002Fi\u003E) and Warner Bros. (\u003Ci\u003ESully\u003C\u002Fi\u003E).\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIt&rsquo;s also worth remembering that the path to February is long and paved with many glamorous events: The \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4131668\u002Fmad-max-national-board-of-review\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003ENational Board of Review\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Awards, the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4132996\u002Fcarol-new-york-film-critics-circle-awards\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003ENew York Film Critics Circle\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Awards, the SAG Awards and the Golden Globes, among others. And for \u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E, with its steady stream of accolades since premiering at the Telluride Film Festival in September and theatrically on Oct. 21, these wins are merely confirmation of its status as an awards-season frontrunner.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EThe win also comes after 2016&rsquo;s Academy Awards ceremony had an \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4180433\u002Foscar-nominations-white-diversity-oscarssowhite\u002F\"\u003Eall-white\u003C\u002Fa\u003E crop of acting nominees, which qualified more as trend than anomaly. While there&rsquo;s no direct correlation between changes made by the Academy since then to push toward greater inclusion among its ranks and the emergence of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4543087\u002Fmovies-awards-season-diversity-inclusion\u002F\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003Eseveral contenders\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E this year that feature stories about people of color, signs seem to be pointing toward progress, however incremental, in an industry that&rsquo;s been \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F\"\u003Eslow to change\u003C\u002Fa\u003E&mdash;and it&rsquo;s hardly a surprise to see it most clearly in indie-land.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EOther winners Monday night include \u003Ci\u003EO.J.: Made in America \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(Best Documentary); Trey Edward Shults, writer-director of \u003Ci\u003EKrisha \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(Breakthrough Director); Isabelle Huppert, star of \u003Ci\u003EElle\u003C\u002Fi\u003E (Best Actress); Casey Affleck, star of \u003Ci\u003EManchester by the Sea \u003C\u002Fi\u003E(Best Actor); (",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Sully"]},")."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Its also worth remembering that the path to February is long and paved with many glamorous events: The ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4131668\u002Fmad-max-national-board-of-review\u002F"},"content":["National Board of Review"]}," Awards, the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4132996\u002Fcarol-new-york-film-critics-circle-awards\u002F"},"content":["New York Film Critics Circle"]}," Awards, the SAG Awards and the Golden Globes, among others. And for ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Moonlight"]},", with its steady stream of accolades since premiering at the Telluride Film Festival in September and theatrically on Oct. 21, these wins are merely confirmation of its status as an awards-season frontrunner."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The win also comes after 2016s Academy Awards ceremony had an ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4180433\u002Foscar-nominations-white-diversity-oscarssowhite\u002F"},"content":["all-white"]}," crop of acting nominees, which qualified more as trend than anomaly. While theres no direct correlation between changes made by the Academy since then to push toward greater inclusion among its ranks and the emergence of ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4543087\u002Fmovies-awards-season-diversity-inclusion\u002F"},"content":["several contenders"]}," this year that feature stories about people of color, signs seem to be pointing toward progress, however incremental, in an industry thats been ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Flabs.time.com\u002Fstory\u002Foscars-diversity\u002F"},"content":["slow to change"]},"and its hardly a surprise to see it most clearly in indie-land."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Other winners Monday night include ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["O.J.: Made in America "]},"(Best Documentary); Trey Edward Shults, writer-director of ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Krisha "]},"(Breakthrough Director); Isabelle Huppert, star of ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Elle"]}," (Best Actress); Casey Affleck, star of ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Manchester by the Sea "]},"(Best Actor); Anja Taylor-Joy, star of ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["The Witch "]},"(Breakthrough Actor); ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Crazy Ex-Girlfriend "]},"(Breakthrough Series - Longform); ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["Her Story "]},"(Breakthrough Series - Shortform)."]}],"plain":"The movie awards season officially kicked off on Monday night with the Gotham Independent Film Awards in New York City, and the night was, above all, a celebration of Moonlight, which took home Best Feature, Best Screenplay, the Audience Award and a special jury award for Best Ensemble. Now in its 26th year, the Gotham Awards, which honor feature-length indie movies, is the first major event of awards season. Although the criteria limit nominees to smaller-budget productions, it has often served as an early indicator of the movies whose names will become familiar by the time the Oscars roll around in February. But the Gotham Awards have also, in recent years, served as a valuable predictive tool for February&rsquo;s Hollywood gold rush&mdash;not that prognostication is, by any means, its raison d&#8217;&ecirc;tre. The last two years&rsquo; Best Feature winners, Birdman (2014) and Spotlight (2015), both went on to win the Oscar for Best Picture three months later. So while it&rsquo;s too early yet to engrave anything in gold, the win certainly elevates the profile of an already acclaimed movie. Moonlight, which emerged victorious from a field that included Certain Women, Everybody Wants Some!!, Manchester by the Sea and Paterson, is a coming-of-age story in three chapters that takes place in Miami during the height of the War on Drugs. Adapted by writer-director Barry Jenkins from Tarell Alvin McCraney&rsquo;s play In Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue, it stars three actors of different ages as Chiron, a boy whose mother falls victim to the crack epidemic and whose burgeoning attraction to other boys he deals with secretly. It&rsquo;s not only a beautiful movie but one that feels urgent: a sensitive and nuanced exploration of black masculinity during a year whose first six months saw more than 100 black men killed by police. It remains to be seen whether the awards-season success of recent Gotham winners is pure coincidence or representative of some larger trend&mdash;or, at the very least, of an Academy whose tastes are trending toward those of the veteran indie actors and filmmakers that sit on Gotham&rsquo;s juries. Even for Best Feature picks that haven&rsquo;t gone on to take home the Academy&rsquo;s highest honor, a win at Gotham has almost always translated into some kind of love from the Academy. Sideways (2004) received four Oscar nominations. Capote (2005) and Beginners (2012) earned acting Oscars for Philip Seymour Hoffman and Christopher Plummer, respectively. Since the Gotham Awards began handing out the Best Feature award in 2004, a movie has never won that blue ribbon without at least getting nominated for one little gold statue in February. Of course, the indie nature of the Gotham Awards means that more than a handful of prestige studio pictures, which will campaign heavily throughout the coming months, weren&rsquo;t present on Monday night. These include offerings from Paramount (Fences, Silence, Florence Foster Jenkins, Arrival); Fox (Jackie, Hidden Figures); Lionsgate (La La Land) and Warner Bros. (Sully). It&rsquo;s also worth remembering that the path to February is long and paved with many glamorous events: The National Board of Review Awards, the New York Film Critics Circle Awards, the SAG Awards and the Golden Globes, among others. And for Moonlight, with its steady stream of accolades since premiering at the Telluride Film Festival in September and theatrically on Oct. 21, these wins are merely confirmation of its status as an awards-season frontrunner. The win also comes after 2016&rsquo;s Academy Awards ceremony had an all-white crop of acting nominees, which qualified more as trend than anomaly. While there&rsquo;s no direct correlation between changes made by the Academy since then to push toward greater inclusion among its ranks and the emergence of several contenders this year that feature stories about people of color, signs seem to be pointing toward progress, however incremental, in an industry that&rsquo;s been slow to change&mdash;and it&rsquo;s hardly a surprise to see it most clearly in indie-land. Other winners Monday night include O.J.: Made in America (Best Documentary); Trey Edward Shults, writer-director of Krisha (Breakthrough Director); Isabelle Huppert, star of Elle (Best Actress); Casey Affleck, star of Manchester by the Sea (Best Actor); Anja Taylor-Joy, star of The Witch (Breakthrough Actor); Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (Breakthrough Series &#8211; Longform); Her Story (Breakthrough Series &#8211; Shortform)."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe Gotham Awards confirmed \u003Ci\u003EMoonlight\u003C\u002Fi\u003E as an Oscar frontrunner\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":73875048,"featured_media":4584693,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[420934628,430943130,430943131,190,56926,430943132],"time_section":[1098],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937767],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4584003"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4584003"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4584003"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4584003\u Although Farhadi&rsquo;s The Salesman is a nominee for Best Foreign Language Film, Farhadi previously stated that he will not be present at the ceremony in reaction to President Donald Trump&rsquo;s immigration ban. Iran is one of the seven majority-Muslim countries that Trump barred from traveling to the United States. In a statement released last month, Farhadi wrote: &#8220;The possibility of [my] presence is being accompanied by ifs and buts which are in no way acceptable to me even if exceptions were to be made for my trip.&rdquo; Now, Variety announced that the two prominent Iranian Americans will be attending the awards on Farhadi&#8217;s behalf, as confirmed to the site by his publicist. The Salesman follows the story of a couple whose relationship is tested as they prepare for a performance of Arthur Miller&#8217;s Death of a Salesman. In 2012, Farhadi won an Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film for the movie A Separation and was named one of TIME&#8217;s 100 Most Influential People."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EAsghar California.  ","credit":"Greg DohertyGetty Images","title":"American Cinematheque Panel Discussion With Golden Globe Nominated Foreign-Language Directors"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":6758,"name":"awards","slug":"awards","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":500,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":288,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":1098,"name":"Entertainment","slug":"entertainment","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":23,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"From esoteric art to Housewives hullaballoo, TIME Entertainment covers what's good, bad and breaking right now in music, movies, TV, tech, celebrities and style","parent":0,"count":19439,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4677394,"date":"2017-02-24T12:15:02","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:15:02","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4677394"},"modified":"2017-02-24T12:13:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:13:00","slug":"donald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4677394\u002Fdonald-trump-opioid-epidemic-and-rising-drug-costs\u002F","title":{"rendered":"President Trump Vowed to Solve the Opioid Crisis. He Needs to Fix This Problem First"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDuring a freewheeling \u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Erecent \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673878\u002Ftrump-drugs-cheaper-than-candy\u002F\"\u003Epress conference\u003C\u002Fa\u003E,\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThroughout the 2016 presidential campaign, \u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives in 2015&mdash;the most deaths in a single year in U.S. history, according to \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.cdc.gov\u002Fdrugoverdose\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003Erecent federal statistics\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E. Trump&#8217;s \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.donaldjtrump.com\u002Fpress-releases\u002Fdonald-j.-trump-addresses-the-drug-epidemic-in-the-united-states\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eplan\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to combat the epidemic included widespread access to naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose. But as the need for the drug has grown, it has become increasingly expensive and hard to get for many addicts and the front line workers who try to help them. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E &#8220;All the politicians, Obama, Trump, everyone says, &#8216;We&#8217;re going to solve it&#8217;,&#8221; says Gordon Merry, director of West Virginia&#8217;s Cabell County EMS, which serves Huntington, a city that saw 26 opioid overdoses over four hours last August. &#8220;I haven&#8217;t seen anything that has changed.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EMeanwhile, the price of naloxone is soaring. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EEvzio, a form of naloxone manufactured by Kal&eacute;o that&#8217;s administered through auto-injection, rose from $575 per package in 2014 to a whopping $4,100 in 2016. Another version of the drug, made by Hospira, has risen from \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003Efrom $9.20 for 10 vials in in 2005 to $158.30 in 2014, according to Truven Health Analytics. The price of the naloxone nasal spray Narcan has remained stable&mdash;around $125 for a two-pack&mdash;since it was approved by the FDA in 2015.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-weight:400;\"\u003E&#8220;The best word for what&#8217;s happening now,&#8221; says Paul Ginsburg, director of the Center for Health Policy at the Brookings Institution, &#8220;is profiteering.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENaloxone price hikes parallel a spike in demand for the drug that&#8217;s fueled by the opioid epidemic, stretching government budgets&mdash;the drug is often administered by first responders&mdash;while creating a robust market for the drug.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn late November, \u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EDr. Leana Wen, Baltimore City&#8217;s Health Commissioner\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E, and 10 other health officials \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fhealth.baltimorecity.gov\u002Fnews\u002Ftestimony\u002F2016-11-29-frontline-health-leaders-urge-presidential-transition-team-invest-public\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s3\"\u003Ewrote a letter to President Trump\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E asking the new administration to prioritize public health, specifically solutions to the opioid epidemic. &ldquo;In the campaign, President Trump talked about the problems of drug addiction,&rdquo; says Wen. &ldquo;We hope that this will not just be rhetoric but resources will be devoted to this issue too.&rdquo; \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003ESo far Wen and her colleagues haven&rsquo;t received a response.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EExperts attribute the rising naloxone prices\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E to a combination of soaring need, drug-industry consolidation and an onerous FDA-approval process, which can stifle competition. Critics contend that price gouging may also be at play. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EKal&eacute;o CEO Spencer Williamson says Evzio&#8217;s list price of $4,100 &#8220;is not a true net price to anyone&hellip;due to numerous discounts and rebates that are negotiated in the supply chain.&#8221; Most patients with insurance pay nothing out of pocket, says Williamson, while uninsured patients with household incomes of less than $100,000 can also access Evzio free of charge. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EKal&eacute;o says it also offers product grants to some nonprofits and government agencies that demonstrate a need for the drug. For instance, \u003C\u002Fspan\u003EKal&eacute;o has granted 2,200 kits to the Cabell-Huntington Health Department, where the overdose death rate is nearly 10 times the national average. &#8220;The more naloxone there is, the more lives will be saved,&#8221; says Dr. Michael Kilkenny, physician director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. &#8220;I have to admit, if we didn&#8217;t get the grant, we wouldn&#8217;t have the drug. We don&#8217;t have the finances.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EYet even beneficiaries of naloxone grants acknowledge that demand outstrips affordable supply. \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn Palm Beach County, Fla., for instance, the Fire and Rescue department spent nearly $205,400 on naloxone in 2016, compared with $57,500 in 2015. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"p1\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003EIn Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. &ldquo;We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to,&rdquo; says \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003EWen, the health commissioner, adding that the \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Eprice they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years.\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s2\"\u003E &#8220;It doesn&rsquo;t make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening. The county averages up to 70 overdoses a week. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s our new normal,&rdquo; he says. Synan, who serves on the Hamilton County Heroin Coalition steering committee, says his officers use the naloxone nasal spray Narcan, and the department has not been hit with major cost increases. But the overall trend is disconcerting. &ldquo;These are life and death situations,&#8221; says Synan.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003EIf his earlier promises hold true, Trump will eventually\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E train his lens on drug companies&mdash;and drug prices. A White House spokesperson says\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003E the administration is extending grant programs to help get naloxone in the hands of first responders, has encouraged Medicaid programs to include naloxone access for low-income people, and has made sure Veterans Affairs programs offer naloxone for eligible veterans. \u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EStill, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It&#8217;s hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,&#8221; says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. &#8220;The case is pretty strong for government interference.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEspecially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;A lot of people have no idea that there&#8217;s even an antidote for an opioid overdose,&#8221; says Fugitt. &#8220;Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EWith reporting by Zeke J. Miller\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["During a freewheeling  recent ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4673878\u002Ftrump-drugs-cheaper-than-candy\u002F"},"content":["press conference"]},",  President Trump declared that America was drug-infested country. "]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to, says  Wen, the health commissioner, adding that the  price they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years.  \"It doesnt make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening.
