"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Still, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"It's hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,\" says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. \"The case is pretty strong for government interference.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Especially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"A lot of people have no idea that there's even an antidote for an opioid overdose,\" says Fugitt. \"Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["With reporting by Zeke J. Miller"]}]}],"plain":"During a freewheeling recent press conference, President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo; What the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar. Throughout the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives in 2015&mdash;the most deaths in a single year in U.S. history, according to recent federal statistics. Trump&#8217;s plan to combat the epidemic included widespread access to naloxone, a drug that can reverse the effects of an opioid overdose. But as the need for the drug has grown, it has become increasingly expensive and hard to get for many addicts and the front line workers who try to help them. &#8220;All the politicians, Obama, Trump, everyone says, &#8216;We&#8217;re going to solve it&#8217;,&#8221; says Gordon Merry, director of West Virginia&#8217;s Cabell County EMS, which serves Huntington, a city that saw 26 opioid overdoses over four hours last August. &#8220;I haven&#8217;t seen anything that has changed.&#8221; Meanwhile, the price of naloxone is soaring. Evzio, a form of naloxone manufactured by Kal&eacute;o that&#8217;s administered through auto-injection, rose from $575 per package in 2014 to a whopping $4,100 in 2016. Another version of the drug, made by Hospira, has risen from from $9.20 for 10 vials in in 2005 to $158.30 in 2014, according to Truven Health Analytics. The price of the naloxone nasal spray Narcan has remained stable&mdash;around $125 for a two-pack&mdash;since it was approved by the FDA in 2015. &#8220;The best word for what&#8217;s happening now,&#8221; says Paul Ginsburg, director of the Center for Health Policy at the Brookings Institution, &#8220;is profiteering.&#8221; Naloxone price hikes parallel a spike in demand for the drug that&#8217;s fueled by the opioid epidemic, stretching government budgets&mdash;the drug is often administered by first responders&mdash;while creating a robust market for the drug. In late November, Dr. Leana Wen, Baltimore City&#8217;s Health Commissioner, and 10 other health officials wrote a letter to President Trump asking the new administration to prioritize public health, specifically solutions to the opioid epidemic. &ldquo;In the campaign, President Trump talked about the problems of drug addiction,&rdquo; says Wen. &ldquo;We hope that this will not just be rhetoric but resources will be devoted to this issue too.&rdquo; So far Wen and her colleagues haven&rsquo;t received a response. Experts attribute the rising naloxone prices to a combination of soaring need, drug-industry consolidation and an onerous FDA-approval process, which can stifle competition. Critics contend that price gouging may also be at play. Kal&eacute;o CEO Spencer Williamson says Evzio&#8217;s list price of $4,100 &#8220;is not a true net price to anyone&hellip;due to numerous discounts and rebates that are negotiated in the supply chain.&#8221; Most patients with insurance pay nothing out of pocket, says Williamson, while uninsured patients with household incomes of less than $100,000 can also access Evzio free of charge. Kal&eacute;o says it also offers product grants to some nonprofits and government agencies that demonstrate a need for the drug. For instance, Kal&eacute;o has granted 2,200 kits to the Cabell-Huntington Health Department, where the overdose death rate is nearly 10 times the national average. &#8220;The more naloxone there is, the more lives will be saved,&#8221; says Dr. Michael Kilkenny, physician director of the Cabell-Huntington Health Department. &#8220;I have to admit, if we didn&#8217;t get the grant, we wouldn&#8217;t have the drug. We don&#8217;t have the finances.&#8221; Yet even beneficiaries of naloxone grants acknowledge that demand outstrips affordable supply. In Palm Beach County, Fla., for instance, the Fire and Rescue department spent nearly $205,400 on naloxone in 2016, compared with $57,500 in 2015. In Baltimore, first responders are facing similar constraints. &ldquo;We have to decide who is the most likely to die and make a guess on which patients we distribute naloxone to,&rdquo; says Wen, the health commissioner, adding that the price they pay for naloxone more than doubled over the course of just a few years. &#8220;It doesn&rsquo;t make sense that at a time of great demand this medication is being priced out of our reach.&rdquo; In Newtown, Ohio, police chief Tom Synan says the opioid epidemic in his community is worsening. The county averages up to 70 overdoses a week. &ldquo;That&rsquo;s our new normal,&rdquo; he says. Synan, who serves on the Hamilton County Heroin Coalition steering committee, says his officers use the naloxone nasal spray Narcan, and the department has not been hit with major cost increases. But the overall trend is disconcerting. &ldquo;These are life and death situations,&#8221; says Synan. If his earlier promises hold true, Trump will eventually train his lens on drug companies&mdash;and drug prices. A White House spokesperson says the administration is extending grant programs to help get naloxone in the hands of first responders, has encouraged Medicaid programs to include naloxone access for low-income people, and has made sure Veterans Affairs programs offer naloxone for eligible veterans. Still, some say more drastic action will be necessary. Ohio has already taken action: in November the state reached an agreement with Adapt Pharma, the manufacturer of Narcan, to freeze the price of the naloxone nasal spray for Ohio law enforcement, first responders, state and local government agencies, and community-based organizations for a year. These entities can buy 48 or more Narcan units for $75 each, a 40% discount from the $125 wholesale price. &#8220;It&#8217;s hard to justify the price increases you see on purely economic grounds,&#8221; says Darius Lakdawalla, an economist and professor of pharmaceutical development and regulatory innovation at the University of Southern California. &#8220;The case is pretty strong for government interference.&#8221; Especially when lives are at stake. Laurie Fugitt, co-founder of Georgia Overdose Prevention, a volunteer group, hopscotches across the state teaching people how to administer naloxone to themselves or their loved ones. She equates naloxone to a fire extinguisher. You never want anyone to use it. But it should be there just in case. &#8220;A lot of people have no idea that there&#8217;s even an antidote for an opioid overdose,&#8221; says Fugitt. &#8220;Back in the day, a vial of naloxone cost a couple of bucks. Now, everybody is trying to get their piece of the pie.&#8221; With reporting by Zeke J. Miller"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EDuring a freewheeling recent press conference, President Trump declared that America was &ldquo;drug-infested&rdquo; country. &ldquo;Drugs,&rdquo; Trump said, &ldquo;are becoming cheaper than candy bars.&rdquo; What the President failed to mention: the price of one lifesaving medication&mdash;naloxone&mdash;is more expensive than caviar. Throughout the 2016 presidential campaign, Trump promised to solve America&rsquo;s opioid crisis, which claimed 33,000 lives&hellip;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":14074318,"featured_media":4682040,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[189091,4381760,430952899,429195055,108735],"time_section":[204777760,204777764,204777755,204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4677394"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4677394"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4677394"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4677394\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002 But in his Thursday night show, Corden decided to form up his own, joined by Get Out director Jordan Peele and comedian Nick Kroll to craft the ultimate throwback trio&mdash;although they may not be squeaky-clean teen idols like their precursors, as they explain. &#8220;Boy band music shouldn&#8217;t be about kissing you on the cheek, it should be so much more than that,&#8221; Corden insists in the spoof video, in which the three reflect on their fictional former career in pop. &#8220;We decided to form the first honest boy band. We took existing boy band songs, cut through all the innuendo, and got to the heart of what those songs are really about: hard core sex,&#8221; Kroll continues. To understand how they reworked classics like the Backstreet Boys&#8217; &#8220;That Way,&#8221; consider the name they developed for their group: &#8220;Thr33way.&#8221; Watch them re-enact a number of previously idealized songs with a new, raunchy spin&mdash;and plenty of 90s-appropriate wig and costume changes&mdash;in the video, above."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThey call themselves &#8220;Thr33way.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":105966849,"featured_media":4682078,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[1098,3876524],"time_section":[1098,236441],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937770],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681746"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681746"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681746"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fnewsletter"}],"fortune:more":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fmore"}],"fortune:popular":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fpopular"}],"fortune:listicle":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Flisticle"}],"fortune:gallery":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fgallery"}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fprimary_tag"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fprimary_section"}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fprimary_topic"}],"ng:more:brand":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681746\u002Fbrand"}],"ng:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fauthors?post=4681746"}]},"_embedded":{"wp:term":[[{"id":1,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fcategory\u002Funcategorized\u002F","name":"Uncategorized","slug":"uncategorized","taxonomy":"category","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories\u002F1"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fcategory"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?categories=1"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?categories=1"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],[{"id":1098,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Ftime-section-entertainment\u002F","name":"Entertainment","slug":"time-section-entertainment","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F1098"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=1098"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=1098"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3876524,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Flate-night-television\u002F","name":"Late Night Television","slug":"late-night-television","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F3876524"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=3876524"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=3876524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No Jordan Peele, and Nick Kroll sing in the most honest 90s boy band ever","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681746\u002Fjames-corden-boy-band\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4681746\u002Fjames-corden-boy-band\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"video","visible":false,"image":{"id":4682078,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fscreen-shot-2017-02-24-at-11-25-29-am.png","alt":"","caption":"","credit":"","title":"james-corden-screenshot"},"video":{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=XWa2wu1Is6Q","markup":"\u003Cdiv class='vimeo-embed-wrapper'\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"video-wrapper\"\u003E\u003Ciframe class='youtube-player' type='text\u002Fhtml' width='640' height='390' src='http:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FXWa2wu1Is6Q?version=3&#038;rel=1&#038;fs=1&#038;autohide=2&#038;showsearch=0&#038;showinfo=1&#038;iv_load_policy=1&#038;wmode=transparent' class=&quot;embed-youtube&quot;&gt;&lt;iframe width=&quot;500&quot; height=&quot;281&quot; src=&quot;https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FXWa2wu1Is6Q?feature=oembed&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; allowfullscreen&gt;&lt;\u002Fiframe&gt;&lt;\u002Fdiv&gt;"},"content":[]}]}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":3876524,"name":"Late Night Television","slug":"late-night-television","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":9656,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":130,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":236441,"name":"Newsfeed","slug":"newsfeed","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":15,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"What's vital and viral from around the web, covering web culture, celebrities, food, internet trends, animals, technology, humor, fashion, sex and more","parent":0,"count":11871,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment","newsfeed"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4681828,"date":"2017-02-24T12:00:27","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T17:00:27","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4681828"},"modified":"2017-02-24T11:22:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T16:22:00","slug":"intelligence-leaks-1979","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681828\u002Fintelligence-leaks-1979\u002F","title":{"rendered":"The Damage Intelligence Leaks Can Cause"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2014\u002F10\u002Funknown1.jpeg?w=150&amp;amp;amp;amp;quality=85&amp;amp;amp;amp;strip=color&amp;amp;amp;amp;h=75&quality=85\" alt=\"\" height=\"75\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThis post is in partnership with the \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fhistorynewsnetwork.org\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EHistory News Network\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, the website that puts the news into historical perspective. The article below was originally published at \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fhistorynewsnetwork.org\u002Farticle\u002F165245\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EHNN.\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDay after day the intelligence leaks splash across our front pages, splattering sensational revelations about Russia&rsquo;s perfidious election meddling or accusations about illicit contacts between Donald Trump&rsquo;s aides and Russian agents. The frenzy of recent months has been extreme, but it is not entirely unprecedented. By considering an earlier uproar fueled by intelligence leaks we can gain insights into the motives of leakers and a broader perspective on the consequences of their disclosures of bits of classified information to politicians and journalists.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn March 1979, alarmed by Soviet-Cuban cooperation in military operations in the Third World, National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski called upon U.S. intelligence agencies to assess the size, location, capabilities, and purposes of Soviet forces in Cuba by reanalyzing existing information and increasing aerial surveillance of the island. Since the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the Soviet Union had kept thousands of troops in Cuba, in part to train Cuban forces in how to use Soviet military equipment. But the United States had not continuously kept close track of the Soviet forces and Brzezinski wanted to check whether there had been any violations of U.S.-Soviet understandings about aircraft and submarines as well as ground forces.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOn June 18 in Vienna President Jimmy Carter and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev signed the SALT II treaty, which placed limits on the nuclear arsenals of the two superpowers. Around the same time, the National Security Agency (NSA) believed it had discovered evidence of a Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; in Cuba.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter CIA Director Stansfield Turner ordered the NSA to abandon what he regarded as alarmist speculation, word of the NSA&rsquo;s finding leaked on July 17 to Senator Richard Stone (D-FL). Stone was extremely sensitive to issues concerning Cuba because of the large, powerful Cuban-American population in Florida and because he faced a re-election campaign in 1980. An aide to archconservative Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC) also leaked the story to ABC News, which reported inaccurately that a Soviet brigade, &ldquo;possibly as many as 6,000 combat-ready men, has been moved into Cuba within recent weeks.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHowever, after Turner, Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, and Secretary of State Cyrus Vance offered assurances that there was no evidence of any substantial increase in the number of Soviet troops that had been in Cuba since 1963, the controversy subsided for a time. Then on August 17 U.S. reconnaissance satellites photographed Soviet troops, equipped with tanks and artillery, in a field exercise on a beach in Cuba. Before the new evidence could be fully analyzed and discussed by top officials (some of whom were on vacation), the story of a Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; of 2,000 to 3,000 men leaked to journalists on August 29.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fnewsletter\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EGet your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECollusion between leakers and foes of SALT II went even further according to Nicholas Thompson, grandson of Paul Nitze, the most prominent critic of the SALT II treaty. In \u003Ci\u003EThe Hawk and the Dove\u003C\u002Fi\u003E (2009), Thompson writes that in late August 1979 a senior CIA official confided to Nitze that the CIA had new evidence that the Soviet brigade in Cuba was not merely giving routine training to Cuban officers but was preparing for combat operations. With Nitze&rsquo;s encouragement, the CIA official spread the story around Washington. Some in the press were also told that the Soviets had constructed a military airfield and were working on a missile boat base.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWith such wild rumors swirling and fearing imminent publication of the story of the &ldquo;combat brigade,&rdquo; Under Secretary of State David Newsom decided to inform Senator Frank Church (D-ID), chair of the Foreign Relations Committee. Facing an election in 1980 and worried about being tarred as soft on the Soviet threat, Church decided to take a hard public stance: without considering how Moscow might react, he demanded the removal of the Soviet brigade, said SALT II would not be ratified until then, and postponed hearings on the arms control treaty.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EUnder pressure and thinking the USSR wanted SALT II ratification badly enough to make concessions, Secretary of State Vance declared at a news conference on September 5 that he would &ldquo;not be satisfied with maintenance of the \u003Ci\u003Estatus quo\u003C\u002Fi\u003E in Cuba.&rdquo; Two days later, while recognizing that the Soviet unit was &ldquo;not an assault force&rdquo; since it lacked airlift or sealift capability, President Carter nonetheless reiterated that &ldquo;this status quo is not acceptable.&rdquo; Brzezinski further inflamed the issue by telling a \u003Ci\u003ENew York Times\u003C\u002Fi\u003E correspondent that the Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; in Cuba was part of a larger problem of Soviet aggressive activity and disregard for U.S. interests around the world.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBelieving the &ldquo;hysteria&rdquo; and &ldquo;hullabaloo&rdquo; had been artificially manufactured by enemies of d&eacute;tente and was being used to make unjustified demands, Soviet leaders insisted (correctly) that the small training unit had been in Cuba for 17 years, posed no threat to the U.S., and would not be withdrawn or even modified. Seeing little left to gain from d&eacute;tente after hopes for SALT II ratification were dashed, Soviet leaders felt less constraint on their actions elsewhere. Although the Kremlin earlier had hesitated to intervene in Afghanistan, in December top leaders decided to invade the country, a move that put nails in the coffin of d&eacute;tente.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn mid October former National Security Adviser McGeorge Bundy confirmed that Soviet diplomats had been right all along: the Kennedy administration had agreed in 1963 that a Soviet brigade could remain in Cuba at the same location where one was &ldquo;discovered&rdquo; in 1979. But by then the damage from the leaks had been done. As David Newsom observed in his compact study, \u003Ci\u003EThe Soviet Brigade in Cuba\u003C\u002Fi\u003E (1987), &ldquo;because intelligence is often partial or fragmented, its release can mislead; the account of the full circumstances may never catch up&rdquo; to the sensational impression left by a leak.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIf the intelligence about the Soviet unit had been fully analyzed before being conveyed to members of Congress or the press, and if the National Security Council and State Department had had more time to check their records of the 1963 agreements, it is very likely that the issue could have been resolved through quiet diplomacy and it is possible that the troubled SALT II treaty would have been ratified. Thus, the leaks may have altered the course of history in a profoundly negative way.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome authors who have written about the 1979 controversy, such as Gloria Duffy and Stansfield Turner, have attributed the crisis to confusion, missteps, errors, and bureaucratic rivalry. Yet since the intelligence leakers chose to make unauthorized disclosures of information to influential figures like Helms and Nitze, who were known to be hostile to the Soviet Union and the SALT II treaty, and to Senator Stone, who could be expected to react in a highly emotional way, it seems likely that the leakers had political motives, not merely honest professional concerns.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhile leaking had become part of the Washington scene by 1979, it has become a much bigger part of the political game in the 21st century. In recent months the leaking of unconfirmed and sometimes later discredited information has been so persistent that some national security experts worry about the potentially devastating consequences of a protracted war between the intelligence bureaucracy and the White House. Whether the leaks will destroy the prospects for improved American-Russian cooperation against international terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking, and other problems remains to be seen.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003EDavid Foglesong, a professor of history at Rutgers University, is the author of\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FAmerican-Mission-Evil-Empire-Crusade\u002Fdp\u002F0521671833\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EThe American Mission and the &ldquo;Evil Empire&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cem\u003E (2007) and\u003C\u002Fem\u003E \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FAmericas-Secret-War-against-Bolshevism\u002Fdp\u002F0807822280\u002Fref=pd_sbs_14_t_1?_encoding=UTF8&amp;psc=1&amp;refRID=T024JAESEZ3W659ZJ0X5\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAmerica&rsquo;s Secret War Against Bolshevism\u003C\u002Fa\u003E \u003Cem\u003E(1995).\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2014\u002F10\u002Funknown1.jpeg?w=150&amp;amp;amp;amp;quality=85&amp;amp;amp;amp;strip=color&amp;amp;amp;amp;h=75&amp;amp;amp;amp;quality=85","alt":"","height":"75"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["This post is in partnership with the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fhistorynewsnetwork.org\u002F"},"content":["History News Network"]},", the website that puts the news into historical perspective. The article below was originally published at ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fhistorynewsnetwork.org\u002Farticle\u002F165245"},"content":["HNN."]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Day after day the intelligence leaks splash across our front pages, splattering sensational revelations about Russias perfidious election meddling or accusations about illicit contacts between Donald Trumps aides and Russian agents. The frenzy of recent months has been extreme, but it is not entirely unprecedented. By considering an earlier uproar fueled by intelligence leaks we can gain insights into the motives of leakers and a broader perspective on the consequences of their disclosures of bits of classified information to politicians and journalists."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In March 1979, alarmed by Soviet-Cuban cooperation in military operations in the Third World, National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski called upon U.S. intelligence agencies to assess the size, location, capabilities, and purposes of Soviet forces in Cuba by reanalyzing existing information and increasing aerial surveillance of the island. Since the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the Soviet Union had kept thousands of troops in Cuba, in part to train Cuban forces in how to use Soviet military equipment. But the United States had not continuously kept close track of the Soviet forces and Brzezinski wanted to check whether there had been any violations of U.S.-Soviet understandings about aircraft and submarines as well as ground forces."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["On June 18 in Vienna President Jimmy Carter and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev signed the SALT II treaty, which placed limits on the nuclear arsenals of the two superpowers. Around the same time, the National Security Agency (NSA) believed it had discovered evidence of a Soviet combat brigade in Cuba."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["After CIA Director Stansfield Turner ordered the NSA to abandon what he regarded as alarmist speculation, word of the NSAs finding leaked on July 17 to Senator Richard Stone (D-FL). Stone was extremely sensitive to issues concerning Cuba because of the large, powerful Cuban-American population in Florida and because he faced a re-election campaign in 1980. An aide to archconservative Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC) also leaked the story to ABC News, which reported inaccurately that a Soviet brigade, possibly as many as 6,000 combat-ready men, has been moved into Cuba within recent weeks."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["However, after Turner, Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, and Secretary of State Cyrus Vance offered assurances that there was no evidence of any substantial increase in the number of Soviet troops that had been in Cuba since 1963, the controversy subsided for a time. Then on August 17 U.S. reconnaissance satellites photographed Soviet troops, equipped with tanks and artillery, in a field exercise on a beach in Cuba. Before the new evidence could be fully analyzed and discussed by top officials (some of whom were on vacation), the story of a Soviet combat brigade of 2,000 to 3,000 men leaked to journalists on August 29."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fnewsletter"},"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Get your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Collusion between leakers and foes of SALT II went even further according to Nicholas Thompson, grandson of Paul Nitze, the most prominent critic of the SALT II treaty. In ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["The Hawk and the Dove"]}," (2009), Thompson writes that in late August 1979 a senior CIA official confided to Nitze that the CIA had new evidence that the Soviet brigade in Cuba was not merely giving routine training to Cuban officers but was preparing for combat operations. With Nitzes encouragement, the CIA official spread the story around Washington. Some in the press were also told that the Soviets had constructed a military airfield and were working on a missile boat base."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["With such wild rumors swirling and fearing imminent publication of the story of the combat brigade, Under Secretary of State David Newsom decided to inform Senator Frank Church (D-ID), chair of the Foreign Relations Committee. Facing an election in 1980 and worried about being tarred as soft on the Soviet threat, Church decided to take a hard public stance: without considering how Moscow might react, he demanded the removal of the Soviet brigade, said SALT II would not be ratified until then, and postponed hearings on the arms control treaty."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Under pressure and thinking the USSR wanted SALT II ratification badly enough to make concessions, Secretary of State Vance declared at a news conference on September 5 that he would not be satisfied with maintenance of the ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["status quo"]}," in Cuba. Two days later, while recognizing that the Soviet unit was not an assault force since it lacked airlift or sealift capability, President Carter nonetheless reiterated that this status quo is not acceptable. Brzezinski further inflamed the issue by telling a ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["New York Times"]}," correspondent that the Soviet combat brigade in Cuba was part of a larger problem of Soviet aggressive activity and disregard for U.S. interests around the world."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Believing the hysteria and hullabaloo had been artificially manufactured by enemies of dtente and was being used to make unjustified demands, Soviet leaders insisted (correctly) that the small training unit had been in Cuba for 17 years, posed no threat to the U.S., and would not be withdrawn or even modified. Seeing little left to gain from dtente after hopes for SALT II ratification were dashed, Soviet leaders felt less constraint on their actions elsewhere. Although the Kremlin earlier had hesitated to intervene in Afghanistan, in December top leaders decided to invade the country, a move that put nails in the coffin of dtente."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["In mid October former National Security Adviser McGeorge Bundy confirmed that Soviet diplomats had been right all along: the Kennedy administration had agreed in 1963 that a Soviet brigade could remain in Cuba at the same location where one was discovered in 1979. But by then the damage from the leaks had been done. As David Newsom observed in his compact study, ",{"tag":"i","attributes":[],"content":["The Soviet Brigade in Cuba"]}," (1987), because intelligence is often partial or fragmented, its release can mislead; the account of the full circumstances may never catch up to the sensational impression left by a leak."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["If the intelligence about the Soviet unit had been fully analyzed before being conveyed to members of Congress or the press, and if the National Security Council and State Department had had more time to check their records of the 1963 agreements, it is very likely that the issue could have been resolved through quiet diplomacy and it is possible that the troubled SALT II treaty would have been ratified. Thus, the leaks may have altered the course of history in a profoundly negative way."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Some authors who have written about the 1979 controversy, such as Gloria Duffy and Stansfield Turner, have attributed the crisis to confusion, missteps, errors, and bureaucratic rivalry. Yet since the intelligence leakers chose to make unauthorized disclosures of information to influential figures like Helms and Nitze, who were known to be hostile to the Soviet Union and the SALT II treaty, and to Senator Stone, who could be expected to react in a highly emotional way, it seems likely that the leakers had political motives, not merely honest professional concerns."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["While leaking had become part of the Washington scene by 1979, it has become a much bigger part of the political game in the 21st century. In recent months the leaking of unconfirmed and sometimes later discredited information has been so persistent that some national security experts worry about the potentially devastating consequences of a protracted war between the intelligence bureaucracy and the White House. Whether the leaks will destroy the prospects for improved American-Russian cooperation against international terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking, and other problems remains to be seen."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["David Foglesong, a professor of history at Rutgers University, is the author of"]}," ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FAmerican-Mission-Evil-Empire-Crusade\u002Fdp\u002F0521671833"},"content":["The American Mission and the Evil Empire"]},{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" (2007) and"]}," ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FAmericas-Secret-War-against-Bolshevism\u002Fdp\u002F0807822280\u002Fref=pd_sbs_14_t_1?_encoding=UTF8&amp;psc=1&amp;refRID=T024JAESEZ3W659ZJ0X5"},"content":["Americas Secret War Against Bolshevism"]}," ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["(1995)."]}]}],"plain":"This post is in partnership with the History News Network, the website that puts the news into historical perspective. The article below was originally published at HNN. Day after day the intelligence leaks splash across our front pages, splattering sensational revelations about Russia&rsquo;s perfidious election meddling or accusations about illicit contacts between Donald Trump&rsquo;s aides and Russian agents. The frenzy of recent months has been extreme, but it is not entirely unprecedented. By considering an earlier uproar fueled by intelligence leaks we can gain insights into the motives of leakers and a broader perspective on the consequences of their disclosures of bits of classified information to politicians and journalists. In March 1979, alarmed by Soviet-Cuban cooperation in military operations in the Third World, National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski called upon U.S. intelligence agencies to assess the size, location, capabilities, and purposes of Soviet forces in Cuba by reanalyzing existing information and increasing aerial surveillance of the island. Since the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the Soviet Union had kept thousands of troops in Cuba, in part to train Cuban forces in how to use Soviet military equipment. But the United States had not continuously kept close track of the Soviet forces and Brzezinski wanted to check whether there had been any violations of U.S.-Soviet understandings about aircraft and submarines as well as ground forces. On June 18 in Vienna President Jimmy Carter and Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev signed the SALT II treaty, which placed limits on the nuclear arsenals of the two superpowers. Around the same time, the National Security Agency (NSA) believed it had discovered evidence of a Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; in Cuba. After CIA Director Stansfield Turner ordered the NSA to abandon what he regarded as alarmist speculation, word of the NSA&rsquo;s finding leaked on July 17 to Senator Richard Stone (D-FL). Stone was extremely sensitive to issues concerning Cuba because of the large, powerful Cuban-American population in Florida and because he faced a re-election campaign in 1980. An aide to archconservative Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC) also leaked the story to ABC News, which reported inaccurately that a Soviet brigade, &ldquo;possibly as many as 6,000 combat-ready men, has been moved into Cuba within recent weeks.&rdquo; However, after Turner, Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, and Secretary of State Cyrus Vance offered assurances that there was no evidence of any substantial increase in the number of Soviet troops that had been in Cuba since 1963, the controversy subsided for a time. Then on August 17 U.S. reconnaissance satellites photographed Soviet troops, equipped with tanks and artillery, in a field exercise on a beach in Cuba. Before the new evidence could be fully analyzed and discussed by top officials (some of whom were on vacation), the story of a Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; of 2,000 to 3,000 men leaked to journalists on August 29. Get your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter Collusion between leakers and foes of SALT II went even further according to Nicholas Thompson, grandson of Paul Nitze, the most prominent critic of the SALT II treaty. In The Hawk and the Dove (2009), Thompson writes that in late August 1979 a senior CIA official confided to Nitze that the CIA had new evidence that the Soviet brigade in Cuba was not merely giving routine training to Cuban officers but was preparing for combat operations. With Nitze&rsquo;s encouragement, the CIA official spread the story around Washington. Some in the press were also told that the Soviets had constructed a military airfield and were working on a missile boat base. With such wild rumors swirling and fearing imminent publication of the story of the &ldquo;combat brigade,&rdquo; Under Secretary of State David Newsom decided to inform Senator Frank Church (D-ID), chair of the Foreign Relations Committee. Facing an election in 1980 and worried about being tarred as soft on the Soviet threat, Church decided to take a hard public stance: without considering how Moscow might react, he demanded the removal of the Soviet brigade, said SALT II would not be ratified until then, and postponed hearings on the arms control treaty. Under pressure and thinking the USSR wanted SALT II ratification badly enough to make concessions, Secretary of State Vance declared at a news conference on September 5 that he would &ldquo;not be satisfied with maintenance of the status quo in Cuba.&rdquo; Two days later, while recognizing that the Soviet unit was &ldquo;not an assault force&rdquo; since it lacked airlift or sealift capability, President Carter nonetheless reiterated that &ldquo;this status quo is not acceptable.&rdquo; Brzezinski further inflamed the issue by telling a New York Times correspondent that the Soviet &ldquo;combat brigade&rdquo; in Cuba was part of a larger problem of Soviet aggressive activity and disregard for U.S. interests around the world. Believing the &ldquo;hysteria&rdquo; and &ldquo;hullabaloo&rdquo; had been artificially manufactured by enemies of d&eacute;tente and was being used to make unjustified demands, Soviet leaders insisted (correctly) that the small training unit had been in Cuba for 17 years, posed no threat to the U.S., and would not be withdrawn or even modified. Seeing little left to gain from d&eacute;tente after hopes for SALT II ratification were dashed, Soviet leaders felt less constraint on their actions elsewhere. Although the Kremlin earlier had hesitated to intervene in Afghanistan, in December top leaders decided to invade the country, a move that put nails in the coffin of d&eacute;tente. In mid October former National Security Adviser McGeorge Bundy confirmed that Soviet diplomats had been right all along: the Kennedy administration had agreed in 1963 that a Soviet brigade could remain in Cuba at the same location where one was &ldquo;discovered&rdquo; in 1979. But by then the damage from the leaks had been done. As David Newsom observed in his compact study, The Soviet Brigade in Cuba (1987), &ldquo;because intelligence is often partial or fragmented, its release can mislead; the account of the full circumstances may never catch up&rdquo; to the sensational impression left by a leak. If the intelligence about the Soviet unit had been fully analyzed before being conveyed to members of Congress or the press, and if the National Security Council and State Department had had more time to check their records of the 1963 agreements, it is very likely that the issue could have been resolved through quiet diplomacy and it is possible that the troubled SALT II treaty would have been ratified. Thus, the leaks may have altered the course of history in a profoundly negative way. Some authors who have written about the 1979 controversy, such as Gloria Duffy and Stansfield Turner, have attributed the crisis to confusion, missteps, errors, and bureaucratic rivalry. Yet since the intelligence leakers chose to make unauthorized disclosures of information to influential figures like Helms and Nitze, who were known to be hostile to the Soviet Union and the SALT II treaty, and to Senator Stone, who could be expected to react in a highly emotional way, it seems likely that the leakers had political motives, not merely honest professional concerns. While leaking had become part of the Washington scene by 1979, it has become a much bigger part of the political game in the 21st century. In recent months the leaking of unconfirmed and sometimes later discredited information has been so persistent that some national security experts worry about the potentially devastating consequences of a protracted war between the intelligence bureaucracy and the White House. Whether the leaks will destroy the prospects for improved American-Russian cooperation against international terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking, and other problems remains to be seen. David Foglesong, a professor of history at Rutgers University, is the author of The American Mission and the &ldquo;Evil Empire&rdquo; (2007) and America&rsquo;s Secret War Against Bolshevism (1995)."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EA case study from 1979 shows how leaks of misleading information can damage national security\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":31116903,"featured_media":4681854,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[14066,292,430944087,398],"time_section":[262754262],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937773],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681828"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681828"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681828"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681828\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune: I wouldn&#8217;t miss a chance to talk to my friends. TRUMP: But we&#8217;re taking a firm, bold and decisive measure, we have to, to turn things around. The era of empty talk is over, it&#8217;s over. (APPLAUSE) Now is the time for action. So let me tell you about the actions that we&#8217;re taking right now to deliver on our promise to the American people and on my promise to make America great again. We&#8217;ve taken swift and strong action to secure the southern border of the United States and to begin the construction of a great, great border wall. (APPLAUSE) By doing this, and with the help of our great border police, with the help of ICE, with the help of General Kelly and all of the people that are so passionate about this &#8212; our border patrol, I&#8217;ll tell you what they do, they came and endorsed me, ICE came and endorsed me. They never endorsed a presidential candidate before, they might not even be allowed to. (LAUGHTER) But they were disgusted with what they saw and we&#8217;ll stop it. We&#8217;ll stop the drugs from pouring into our nation and poisoning our youth. Pouring in. Pouring in. (APPLAUSE) We get the drugs, they get the money. We get the problems, they get the cash. No good. No good. Going to stop. By stopping the flow of illegal immigration, we will save countless tax dollars (ph), and that&#8217;s so important because the tax &#8212; the dollars we&#8217;re losing are beyond anything that you can imagine. And the tax dollars that can be used to rebuild struggling American communities, including our inner cities. (APPLAUSE) We are also going to save countless American lives. As we speak today, immigration offers are finding the gang members, the drug dealers and the criminal aliens and throwing them the hell out of our country. (APPLAUSE) TRUMP: And we will not let them back in. They&#8217;re not coming back in, folks. They do, they&#8217;re going to have bigger problems than they ever dreamt of. (APPLAUSE) I&#8217;m also working with the Department of Justice to being reducing violent crime. I mean, can you believe what&#8217;s happening in Chicago as an example? Two days ago, seven people were shot and I believe killed. Seven people, seven people, Chicago, a great American city, seven people shot and killed. We will support the incredible men and women of law enforcement. (APPLAUSE) Thank you, and thank them. I&#8217;ve also followed through on my campaigning promise and withdrawn America from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. (APPLAUSE) So that we can protect our economic freedom. And we&#8217;re going to make trade deals, but we&#8217;re going to do one on one, one on one, and if they misbehave, we terminate the deal and then they&#8217;ll come back and we&#8217;ll make a better deal. None of these big quagmire deals that are a disaster. Just take a look &#8212; by the way, take a look at NAFTA, one of the worst deals ever made by any country, having to do with economic development. It&#8217;s economy un-development, as far as our country is concerned. We&#8217;re preparing to repeal and replace the disaster known as Obamacare. We&#8217;re going to save Americans from this crisis, and give them the access to the quality health care they need and deserve. We have authorized the construction, one day, of the Keystone and Dakota Access Pipelines. (APPLAUSE) And issued a new rule &#8212; this took place while I was getting ready to sign. I said who makes the pipes for the pipeline? Well sir, it comes from all over the world, isn&#8217;t that wonderful? I said nope, comes from the United States, or we&#8217;re not building it. (APPLAUSE) American steel. (APPLAUSE) If they want a pipeline in the United States, they&#8217;re going to use pipe that&#8217;s made in the United States. Do we agree? (APPLAUSE) But can you imagine &#8212; I told this story the other day &#8212; can you imagine the gentleman &#8212; never met him, don&#8217;t even know the name of this company. I actually sort of know it, but I want to get it exactly correct. Big, big powerful company, they spend hundreds of millions of dollars on the pipeline, same thing with the Dakota, different vice. They got their approvals, everything, in the case of Dakota, then all of a sudden they couldn&#8217;t connect it because they had people protesting that never showed up before. But with the Keystone &#8212; so they spent hundreds of millions of dollars with bloodsucker consultants &#8212; you know, sucking the blood out of the company, don&#8217;t worry, I&#8217;ve used them all my life, OK? Don&#8217;t worry, we&#8217;re going to get it approved, I&#8217;m connected, I&#8217;m a lobbyist, don&#8217;t worry. Bottom line, Obama didn&#8217;t sign it, right? Could be 42,000 jobs, somewhere around there &#8212; a lot of jobs. Didn&#8217;t sign it. But can you imagine, he gave up. A year ago, it was dead, now he&#8217;s doing anything, calling his wife, hello darling, I&#8217;m a little bored, you know that pipeline that has killed us, that has killed our company. Knock, knock. Mr. so and so, the Keystone Pipeline sir, out of nowhere has just been approved. (APPLAUSE) Now, can you imagine the expression? And you know the sad part? Those same blood sucking consultants that hit them for all the money and failed, they&#8217;re now going to go back to him and say, did we do a great job; we want more money, right? Because that&#8217;s the way the system works, a little bit off, but that&#8217;s the way the system works. We&#8217;re preparing bold action to lift the restrictions on American energy, including shale oil, natural gas and beautiful clean coal and we&#8217;re going to put our miners back to work. (APPLAUSE) TRUMP: Miners are going back to work, folks. Sorry to tell you that, but they&#8217;re going back to work. We have begun a historic program to reduce the regulations that are crushing our economy, crushing. (APPLAUSE) And not only our economy, crushing our jobs because companies can&#8217;t hire. We&#8217;re going to put the regulation industry out of work and out of business. (APPLAUSE) And by the way, I want regulation. I want to protect our environment, I want regulations for safety, I want all of the regulations that we need and I want them to be so strong and so tough, but we don&#8217;t need 75 percent of the repetitive, horrible regulations that hurt companies, hurt jobs, make us non-competitive overseas with other companies from other countries, that we don&#8217;t need. But we&#8217;re going to have regulation. It&#8217;s going to be really strong and really good and we&#8217;re going to protect our environment and we&#8217;re going to protect the safety of our people and our workers, OK? (APPLAUSE) Another major promise is tax reform. We&#8217;re going to massively lower taxes on the middle class, reduce taxes on American business and make our tax code more simple and much more fair for everyone, including the people and the business. (APPLAUSE) In anticipation of these and other changes, jobs are already starting to pour back into our country, you see that. In fact, I think I did more than any other pre-president, they say president- elect. President-elect is meeting with Ford, he&#8217;s meeting with Chrysler, he&#8217;s meeting with General Motors. I just wanted to save a little time. (LAUGHTER) Because Ford and Fiat Chrysler, General Motors, Sprint, Intel, and so many others are now, because of the election result, making major investments in the United States, expanding production and hiring more workers. And they&#8217;re going back to Michigan and they&#8217;re going back to Ohio and they&#8217;re going back to Pennsylvania and they&#8217;re going back to North Carolina and to Florida. (APPLAUSE) It&#8217;s time for all Americans to get off of welfare and get back to work, you&#8217;re going to love it, you&#8217;re going to love it, you&#8217;re going to love it. (APPLAUSE) We&#8217;re also put nothing a massive budget request for our beloved military. (APPLAUSE) And we will be substantially upgrading all of our military, all of our military, offensive, defensive, everything, bigger and better and stronger than ever before. And hopefully, we&#8217;ll never have to use it, but nobody&#8217;s gonna mess with us, folks, nobody. (APPLAUSE) It will be one of the greatest military build-ups in American history. No one will dare question as they have been because we&#8217;re very depleted, very, very depleted. Sequester. Sequester. Nobody will dare question our military might again. We believe in peace through strength and that&#8217;s what we will have. (APPLAUSE) As part of my pledge to restore safety for the American people, I have also directed the defense community to develop a plan to totally obliterate ISIS. (APPLAUSE) TRUMP: Working with our allies, we will eradicate this evil from the face of the Earth. (APPLAUSE) At the same time, we fully understand that national security begins with border security; foreign terrorists will not be able to strike America if they cannot get into our country. (APPLAUSE) By the way, take a look at what&#8217;s happening in Europe, folks, take a look at what&#8217;s happening in Europe. I took a lot of heat on Sweden. (LAUGHTER) And then a day later, I said has anybody reported what&#8217;s going on? And it turned out that they didn&#8217;t &#8212; not too many of them did. Take a look at what happened in Sweden. I love Sweden, great country, great people, I love Sweden. But they understand. The people over there understand I&#8217;m right. Take a look at what&#8217;s happening in Sweden. Take a look at what&#8217;s happening in Germany. Take a look at what&#8217;s happened in France. Take a look at Nice and Paris. I have a friend, he&#8217;s a very, very substantial guy. He loves the city of lights, he loves Paris. For years, every year during the summer, he would go to Paris, was automatic with his wife and his family. Hadn&#8217;t seen him in a while. And I said, Jim, let me ask you a question, how&#8217;s Paris doing? &#8220;Paris? I don&#8217;t go there anymore, Paris is no longer Paris.&#8221; That was four years &#8212; four or five years hasn&#8217;t gone there. He wouldn&#8217;t miss it for anything. Now he doesn&#8217;t even think in terms of going there. Take a look at what&#8217;s happening to our world, folks. And we have to be smart. We have to be smart. We can&#8217;t let it happen to us. (APPLAUSE) So let me state this as clearly as I can, we are going to keep radical Islamic terrorists the hell out of our country. (APPLAUSE) We will not be deterred from this course, and in a matter of days, we will be taking brand-new action to protect our people and keep America safe, you will see the action. I will never ever apologize for protecting the safety and security of the American people, I won&#8217;t do it. (APPLAUSE) If it means I get bad press, if it means people speak badly of me, it&#8217;s OK, doesn&#8217;t bother me. The security of our people is number one, is number one. (APPLAUSE) Our administration is running with great efficiency, even though I still don&#8217;t have my Cabinet approved, nobody mentions that. (BOOING) You know, I still have people out there waiting to be approved and everyone knows they&#8217;re gonna be approved. It&#8217;s just a delay, delay, delay, it&#8217;s really sad, it&#8217;s really sad. And these are great people, these are some great people. We still don&#8217;t have our Cabinet. I assume we&#8217;re setting records for that. That&#8217;s the only thing good about it is we&#8217;re setting records. I love setting records. (APPLAUSE) But I hate having a Cabinet meeting and I see all these empty seats. I said, Democrats, please approve our Cabinet and get smart on health care, too, if you don&#8217;t mind. (LAUGHTER) (APPLAUSE) But we&#8217;re taking meetings everyday with top leaders in business, in science and industry. Yesterday, I had 29 of the biggest business leaders in the world in my office; Caterpillar, Tractor (ph), Campbell&#8217;s Soup. We had everybody. We had everybody. I like Campbell&#8217;s Soup. (LAUGHTER) (APPLAUSE) We had everybody and we came to a lot of very good conclusions and a lot of those folks that are in that room are gonna be building big, big, massive new plants and lots of jobs. And you know what? They&#8217;re gonna be building them in this country, not in some other country. (APPLAUSE) We&#8217;re meeting with unions, meeting with law enforcement and we&#8217;re meeting with leaders from all around where the White House doors used to be totally closed. They were closed, folks. You don&#8217;t realize that, they were closed. TRUMP: They&#8217;re now wide open and they&#8217;re open for people doing business for our country and putting people to work. (APPLAUSE) And when they come into the White House, we&#8217;re translating these meetings into action. One by one, we&#8217;re checking off the promises we made to the people of the United States. One by one, a lot of promises. And we will not stop until the job is done. We will reduce your taxes, we will cut your regulations, we will support our police, we will defend our flag. (APPLAUSE) We will rebuild our military. We will take care of our great, great veterans. We&#8217;re taking care of our veterans. (APPLAUSE) We will fix our broken and embarrassing trade deals that are no good. None of them. You wonder where did the people come from that negotiated these deals. Where did they come from? Well, they came also from campaign contributions, I must be honest. They&#8217;re not as stupid as you think. (LAUGHTER) We will cut wasteful spending. We will promote our values. We will rebuild our inner cities. We will bring back our jobs and our dreams. So true. So true. (APPLAUSE) And by the way, we will protect our Second Amendment. (APPLAUSE) You know, Wayne and Chris are here from the NRA and they didn&#8217;t have that on the list. It&#8217;s lucky I thought about it. (LAUGHTER) But we will indeed, and they&#8217;re great people. And by the way, they love our country. They love our country. The NRA has been a great supporter. They love our country. (APPLAUSE) The forgotten men and women of America will be forgotten no longer. That is the heart of this new movement and the future of the Republican Party. People came to vote, and these people, the media, they said where are they coming from? What&#8217;s going on here? These are hard-working, great, great Americans. These are unbelievable people who have not been treated fairly. Hillary called them deplorable. They&#8217;re not deplorable. (BOOING) AUDIENCE: Lock her up! Lock her up! Lock her up! TRUMP: Who would have thought that a word was gonna play (ph) so badly? (LAUGHTER) That&#8217;s the problem in politics. One wrong word and it&#8217;s over. She also said irredeemable, but we won&#8217;t mention that. (LAUGHTER) The GOP will be, from now on, the party also of the American worker. (APPLAUSE) You know, we haven&#8217;t been as a group given credit for this, but if you look at how much bigger our party has gotten during this cycle, during the early days when we had 17 people running in the primaries. Millions and millions of people were joining. Now, I won&#8217;t say it was because of me, but it was. OK? (LAUGHTER) (APPLAUSE) And we have an amazing, strong, powerful party that truly does want to see America be great again, and it will see it and it&#8217;s gonna see it a lot sooner than you think, believe me, a lot sooner than you think. (APPLAUSE) TRUMP: We will not answer to donors or lobbyists, or special interests, but we will serve the citizens of the United States of America, believe me. (APPLAUSE) Global cooperation, dealing with other countries, getting along with other countries is good, it&#8217;s very important. But there is no such thing as a global anthem, a global currency or a global flag. This is the United States of America that I&#8217;m representing. (APPLAUSE) I&#8217;m not representing the globe, I&#8217;m representing your country. (APPLAUSE) AUDIENCE: USA! USA! USA! TRUMP: There&#8217;s one allegiance that unites us all, and that is to America. America, it&#8217;s the allegiance to America. (APPLAUSE) No matter our background or income, or geography, we&#8217;re all citizens of this blessed land. And no matter our color or the blood &#8212; the color of the blood we bleed, it&#8217;s the same red blood of great, great patriots. Remember, great patriots. (APPLAUSE) We all salute with pride, the same American flag, and we all are equal &#8212; totally equal in the eyes of almighty God, we&#8217;re equal. (APPLAUSE) Thank you. (APPLAUSE) And I want to thank, by the way, the Evangelical community, the Christian community. (APPLAUSE) Communities of faith, rabbis and priests and pastors, ministers, because the support for me was a record, as you know, not only in terms of numbers of people, but percentage of those numbers that voted for Trump. So I want to thank you folks, that was amazing &#8212; an amazing outpour&#8230; (APPLAUSE) &#8230; and I will not disappoint you. As long as we have faith in each other and trust in God, then there is no goal at all beyond our reach. There is no dream too large, no task too great, we are Americans and the future belongs to us. (APPLAUSE) The future belongs to all of you. And America is coming about, and it&#8217;s coming back, and it&#8217;s roaring and you can hear it. It&#8217;s going to be bigger and better. It is going to be &#8212; it is going to be &#8212; remember and it&#8217;s roaring. It&#8217;s going to be bigger and better and stronger than ever before. (APPLAUSE) I want to thank you. And Matt and Mercedes, I want to thank the two of you, and all of the supporters that I have. I see them; they&#8217;re all over the place. You are really great people. I want to thank you. (APPLAUSE) And I want to say to you, God bless you and God bless the United States of America. Thank you, folks. Thank you.
