Covering the White House, elections, primaries, Congress, domestic policy, foreign policy, the military and more","parent":0,"count":11775,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["politics"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4681072,"date":"2017-02-24T11:41:09","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T16:41:09","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4681072"},"modified":"2017-02-24T11:41:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-24T16:41:00","slug":"transgender-students-bathroom-donald-trump","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681072\u002Ftransgender-students-bathroom-donald-trump\u002F","title":{"rendered":"What the Trump Administrations Bathroom Memo Means for Transgender Kids"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681019\u002Fpresident-trump-cpac-watch-live\u002F\"\u003ETrump\u003C\u002Fa\u003E administration&#8217;s letter this week \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679063\u002Fdonald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F?xid=homepage\"\u003Erevoking protections for transgender students\u003C\u002Fa\u003E does not directly change schools&#8217; existing policies &mdash; but transgender students and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661514\u002Flgbt-asylum-seekers-face-extra-anxiety-under-president-trumps-travel-ban\u002F\"\u003ELGBT\u003C\u002Fa\u003E rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe administration&#8217;s letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ENow, states are largely left where they started &mdash; guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,&#8221; Warbelow said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThere remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump&#8217;s Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board&mdash; which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys&#8217; restroom two years ago &mdash; \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.chicagotribune.com\u002Fnews\u002Flocal\u002Fbreaking\u002Fct-gavin-grimm-transgender-ruling-trump-20170223-story.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esaid\u003C\u002Fa\u003E it was &#8220;pleased&#8221; by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELegal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration&#8217;s guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren&#8217;t already offering them.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it&#8217;s transgender youths,&#8221; said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. &#8220;It&#8217;s just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.&#8221; Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fpeople.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcaitlyn-jenner-donald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ecalled the Trump administration&#8217;s move a &#8220;disaster.&#8221; \u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhite House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHolly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration&#8217;s letter will make things worse for transgender kids.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I think it&#8217;s going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,&#8221; Montemayor said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EMontemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls&#8217; restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women&#8217;s restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EHer father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I didn&#8217;t know anything about this topic when Holly came out,&#8221; he said. &#8220;We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed &mdash; they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681019\u002Fpresident-trump-cpac-watch-live\u002F"},"content":["Trump"]}," administration's letter this week ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4679063\u002Fdonald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F?xid=homepage"},"content":["revoking protections for transgender students"]}," does not directly change schools' existing policies  but transgender students and ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4661514\u002Flgbt-asylum-seekers-face-extra-anxiety-under-president-trumps-travel-ban\u002F"},"content":["LGBT"]}," rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The administration's letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Now, states are largely left where they started  guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,\" Warbelow said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Fourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration's decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["There remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump's Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys' restroom two years ago  ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.chicagotribune.com\u002Fnews\u002Flocal\u002Fbreaking\u002Fct-gavin-grimm-transgender-ruling-trump-20170223-story.html"},"content":["said"]}," it was \"pleased\" by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Legal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration's guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren't already offering them."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it's transgender youths,\" said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. \"It's just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.\" Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fpeople.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Fcaitlyn-jenner-donald-trump-transgender-bathroom\u002F"},"content":["called the Trump administration's move a \"disaster.\" "]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration's decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Holly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration's letter will make things worse for transgender kids."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I think it's going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,\" Montemayor said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Montemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls' restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women's restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Her father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"I didn't know anything about this topic when Holly came out,\" he said. \"We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed  they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.\""]}],"plain":"The Trump administration&#8217;s letter this week revoking protections for transgender students does not directly change schools&#8217; existing policies &mdash; but transgender students and LGBT rights advocates say the action sends a message that the highest political office in the U.S. does not support transgender rights. The administration&#8217;s letter rescinds guidance that came under former President Obama instructing schools to allow transgender students access to bathrooms and other facilities that aligned with their gender identity. But any enforcement of those guidelines was already on hold even before this week, after 13 states accused the Obama administration of overstepping its bounds and a federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked it late last year. Now, states are largely left where they started &mdash; guided by state law, if there is one that addresses the rights of transgender students, and otherwise able to make up their own minds about how to treat transgender students in public schools. And that, according to advocates like Sarah Warbelow, legal director at the Human Rights Campaign, is a problem. &#8220;We worry that it encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people,&#8221; Warbelow said. Fourteen states have passed their own non-discrimination laws to protect transgender students, Warbelow said, and political leaders in many of those states publicly opposed the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, including in Washington, Connecticut, California, New Mexico, New York and Minnesota. There remains a risk of litigation, but advocates worry that the move by Trump&#8217;s Justice Department will embolden states, cities or school districts to require that transgender students use the bathrooms that align with the sex assigned to them at birth, even if enforcement of such policies is difficult. The prospect of singling out transgender students is harmful to children, advocates say, noting that they already face misunderstanding and bullying. In Virginia, the Gloucester County School Board&mdash; which was sued by 17-year-old student Gavin Grimm after he was blocked from using the boys&#8217; restroom two years ago &mdash; said it was &#8220;pleased&#8221; by the government withdrawing the guidance. The school board is set to defend its policy before the Supreme Court next month. Legal advocates say they believe that regardless of the Trump administration&#8217;s guidance, transgender kids are still protected under Title IX, which prohibits sex discrimination in education, and they plan to fight for those protections in states that aren&#8217;t already offering them. &#8220;What the administration did yesterday was just another moment where they are once again attacking a vulnerable community in this country, and this time, it&#8217;s transgender youths,&#8221; said Kris Hayashi, executive director of the Transgender Law Center. &#8220;It&#8217;s just horrendous and shameful that government officials and politicians use their power to target students, target transgender people who are just trying to go to school.&#8221; Transgender activist Caitlyn Jenner called the Trump administration&#8217;s move a &#8220;disaster.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer defended the Trump administration&#8217;s decision this week, saying the Obama-era interpretation of Title IX was flawed. Holly Montemayor, a transgender student in Minnesota who dropped out of school because of continuous bullying, is worried that the Trump administration&#8217;s letter will make things worse for transgender kids. &#8220;I think it&#8217;s going to enable more bigotry to happen to transgender students,&#8221; Montemayor said. Montemayor, who is now 18, came out in 2012 at the age of 13. The staff at her middle school said she could not use the girls&#8217; restroom, she said, leading her peers to ask invasive questions and stare at her when she went to the bathroom. Although she was allowed to use the women&#8217;s restroom in high school, Montemayor said she started receiving death threats from other students. The emotional toll caused her grades to suffer; she dropped out in 2016 and is pursuing her G.E.D. Her father, Ramon Montemayor, said the Obama-era guidance sent a powerful message of inclusion to school administrators who may not have been familiar with the challenges facing transgender kids. &#8220;I didn&#8217;t know anything about this topic when Holly came out,&#8221; he said. &#8220;We became educated and fully supportive. Those guidelines that have been reversed &mdash; they would be very helpful to have them for schools. They would go a long way.&#8221;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;It encourages states and local governments to behave badly toward transgender people&#8221; Rubio came in second with 30%. Trump came in third place with 15%"]}],"plain":"President Donald Trump boasted about doing well at a grassroots conservative conference in years past, but he actually lost a straw poll of attendees every single year. Speaking at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference outside Washington, D.C., on Friday, Trump noted that he had addressed the crowd in 2011, 2013, 2014 and 2015. (He notably skipped the 2016 event, held in the midst of the Republican primary.) &#8220;You know, my first major speech was at CPAC,&#8221; Trump said Friday. &#8220;I loved it. I loved the people. I loved the commotion. And then they did these polls where I went through the roof and I wasn&#8217;t even running.&#8221; It wasn&#8217;t clear exactly what polls Trump was referring to, but there is a good measure of how well someone did at CPAC: a straw poll of thousands of grassroots attendees held at the end of the event. By that measure, Trump did not go through the roof. In fact, he did poorly in five out of the past six contests, and reached only third place last year with just 15% of the vote. Here&#8217;s a look at who won in the straw polls held since Trump&#8217;s first appearance at CPAC. 2011: Then-Rep. Ron Paul won with 30%. Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney came in second with 23%. New Mexico Gov. Gary Johnson and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie tied for third place with 6%. Trump was not in the top 15. 2012: Romney won with 38%. Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum came in second with 31%. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich was third with 15%. 2013: Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul won with 25%. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio came in second with 23%. Former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum came in third with 8%. 2014: Rand Paul won with 31%. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz came in second with 11% and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson came in third place with 9%. Trump received just one percent in a seven-way tie for 14th place. 2015: Rand Paul won with 25.7%. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker came in second with 21.4%, Cruz came in third place with 11.5%. Trump came in eighth place with just 3.5%. 2016: Cruz won with 40% of the vote. Rubio came in second with 30%. Trump came in third place with 15%"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHis best showing was third place in 2016, with just 15% of the vote\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":74229987,"featured_media":4681970,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[2638643,785708,189091,7562571,430936281,143695,143692,430939235,3452,293742,216929,1671569],"time_section":[204777755],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937769],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681865"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681865"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681865"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681865\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Ft Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd roared back: &#8220;What are you going to do about it?&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELance was elected in 2008, but Ed Marceski said the event was the first time he felt the need to confront his representative. Wearing a T-shirt with the word &#8220;Resist,&#8221; Marceski, who voted for Hillary Clinton, said Trump&#8217;s election had energized him. &#8220;I&#8217;m 61 years old, and this is the first time we&#8217;ve done something like this,&#8221; Marceski said. &#8220;It won&#8217;t be the last.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5332620994001\" data-video-id=\"5332620994001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" autoplay controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ELance is one of a wave of Republican senators and representatives who have been met by vocal crowds at events held in their district during this week&#8217;s congressional recess, a groundswell that has led some to see a left wing echo of the outrage that propelled the Tea Party. Mobilized by their concern over the GOP&#8217;s promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act, as well as questions about Trump&#8217;s immigration policies and his ties to Russia, protesters have confronted\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fnymag.com\u002Fdaily\u002Fintelligencer\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fhundreds-confront-congressman-chaffetz-at-rowdy-town-hall.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E Rep. Jason Chaffetz in Utah,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E Rep. Mark Sanford in South Carolina, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwavy.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F20\u002Fcongressman-scott-taylor-hosts-town-hall-meeting-in-va-beach\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ERep. Scott Taylor in Virginia\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, Rep. Jim Jordan in \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cleveland.com\u002Fpolitics\u002Findex.ssf\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fjim_jordan_engages_his_protest.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EOhio,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and Sen. Tom Cotton in Arkansas. Support for the ACA has grown since the threat of repeal, with 48% of Americans saying they favor the law compared to 42% who oppose it, according to a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fkff.org\u002Fhealth-reform\u002Fpoll-finding\u002Fkaiser-health-tracking-poll-future-directions-for-the-aca-and-medicaid\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EKaiser Health Tracking Poll\u003C\u002Fa\u003E released Feb. 24. The approval level is the highest since Kaiser began the poll in 2010.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Iowa, Anna Plank drove an hour and a half to confront Senator \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4678389\u002Frepublican-congress-donald-trump-town-hall-protests\u002F\"\u003EJoni Ernst\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;People were yelling in the hallway, people were chanting &#8216;do your job,'&#8221; Plank said \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F21\u002Fpolitics\u002Fjoni-ernst-iowa-town-hall\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eafter the veterans&#8217; event in Maquoketa\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. &#8220;We don&#8217;t feel heard, we don&#8217;t feel listened to,&#8221; Plank said. &#8220;It doesn&#8217;t feel like this country this was meant to be.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EA spokesperson for Ernst says the senator &#8220;believes it&#8217;s critical that she hears from folks across the state directly,&#8221; and said that Ernst holds 99 county tours in her state every year, including three public events last month.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EPlank is an organizer of \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4649891\u002Fprotest-donald-trump\u002F\"\u003EIndivisible Iowa\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, one of hundreds of grassroots organizations that have sprung up around the country in opposition to Trump&#8217;s policies and GOP policy planks like the repeal of the ACA. Indivisible started as an \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.indivisibleguide.com\u002Fresources-2\u002F2017\u002F2\u002F16\u002Freclaim-recess\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eonline how-to guide\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for citizens to effectively pressure their representatives, written by former congressional staffers who witnessed the rise of the Tea Party in 2009. In the months since the election, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.indivisibleguide.com\u002Fgroups-nav.\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EIndivisible has morphed into an organizing engine\u003C\u002Fa\u003E for the Trump opposition, pumping energy and information into local resistance efforts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhite House officials have \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fnews\u002Fpost-politics\u002Fwp\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F06\u002Fin-echoes-of-2009-republicans-see-astroturf-in-democratic-protests\u002F?utm_term=.4c8e3066f4dd\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Edescribed \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ethe anti-Trump protests as &#8220;astro-turf,&#8221; coordinated national efforts masquerading as grassroots pushback. Trump dismissed the boisterous town halls as &#8220;so-called angry crowds&#8221; and \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftwitter.com\u002FrealDonaldTrump\u002Fstatus\u002F834181712783560705\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Esuggested on Twitter\u003C\u002Fa\u003E that they were &#8220;planned by liberal activists.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer called the protesters a &#8220;small, loud group of people&#8221; on \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fabcnews.go.com\u002FPolitics\u002Fgop-town-hall-backlash-hybrid-real-concern-manufactured\u002Fstory?id=45663842\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E Wednesday,\u003C\u002Fa\u003E adding that &#8220;just because they&#8217;re loud doesn&#8217;t mean that there are many.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s difficult to tell exactly how many people are involved with the protests, but they have been building momentum. Indivisible has more than 5,000 verified groups, and 678 registered events with more than 12,000 RSVPs. The website has been viewed more than 15.5 million times since the election, and the Indivisible Guide has been viewed 2 million times on the site, according to the group&#8217;s organizers. All of the Indivisible organizers interviewed by TIME in four states say they are first-time organizers, new to political activism, and are not being paid.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;I wish I was being paid,&#8221; says Plank, an elementary school teacher currently raising her daughters full time, adding that she was so angry with Trump and Ernst that she didn&#8217;t need a financial incentive. &#8220;They could pay me to \u003Cem\u003Enot\u003C\u002Fem\u003E show up.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIn Tennessee, local constituents confronted Republican Rep. Marsha Blackburn during a town hall meeting Tuesday, demanding answers about health care and Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia. &#8220;A lot of our questions were followed by &#8216;I&#8217;ll look into it,'&#8221; says Michelle Bewley, 36, who helped organize the Indivisible group in Blackburn&#8217;s district, a stretch of Middle Tennessee that includes some of Nashville&#8217;s wealthiest suburbs. &#8220;We didn&#8217;t get a lot of clear answers on any of our questions.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBewley is a parent, adjunct professor, volunteer and first-time political organizer. When her Indivisible group first started shortly after the election, they had a handful of members. Now, she says they have more than 400 people involved and organize multiple events a week.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;As an individual, if I&#8217;m just one person voicing my opinion, I&#8217;m not going to get heard,&#8221; she says. &#8220;But if we have 100 people voicing the same concerns, it&#8217;s gonna be heard.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EIt&#8217;s too early to know if this outrage will be sustained, let alone if it can\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4675256\u002Fdonald-trump-congress-town-hall-protests\u002F\"\u003E change outcomes in Congress\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. But it is already forcing many Republicans to recalibrate their outreach efforts.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"video-container\"\u003E\u003Cvideo id=\"brightcove-player-5334420223001\" data-video-id=\"5334420223001\" data-account=\"293884104\" data-player=\"SJa0Thl7\" data-embed=\"default\" controls preload=\"auto\" class=\"video-js responsive-video\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fvideo\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOf the 59 Republican members of Congress targeted as vulnerable by the DCCC in 2018 elections, only 19 held any sort of constituent event this week, according to a running tally compiled by the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdocs.google.com\u002Fspreadsheets\u002Fd\u002F1yq1NT9DZ2z3B8ixhid894e77u9rN5XIgOwWtTW72IYA\u002Fhtmlview?sle=true#\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ETownHallProject. \u003C\u002Fa\u003EOf those, 17 were &#8220;empty chair&#8221; town halls, tele-town halls (where constituents can call in their questions) or appearances by staff instead of the elected officials.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESome Republicans who did show up to meet their constituents said the confrontations turned into productive dialogue. In South Carolina, Sanford lingered to talk to constituents after a boisterous town hall meeting on Saturday. &#8220;Nobody drives out of their way to go to a town hall just to score points,&#8221; Sanford said. &#8220;Let&#8217;s get to the bottom of this.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESanford and Senator Rand Paul are \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fpolitics\u002Frand-paul-mark-sanford-obamacare\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eco-sponsoring a health care replacement bill \u003C\u002Fa\u003Ethat would allow insurers to sell a wider range of policies (including some with lower premiums but limited benefits), allow citizens to sock away more money in tax-free health-care savings accounts, and allow those with pre-existing conditions to keep their coverage as long as they had continuous coverage. The bill, which was \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.cnn.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F14\u002Fpolitics\u002Frand-paul-mark-sanford-obamacare\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eendorsed\u003C\u002Fa\u003E by the House Freedom Caucus earlier this month, turns up the pressure on House Republicans to repeal the ACA. But Sanford said that speaking with some of the attendees caused him to &#8220;look more deeply&#8221; at the way the bill would treat pre-existing conditions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;There&#8217;s a degree of directness that I haven&#8217;t really seen before,&#8221; he said. &#8220;I&#8217;ve seen pieces of it, but not with such energy.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EFor Republican members of Congress who rode the Tea Party wave to Washington, the local resistance movement created a sense of deja vu&#8211;but only to a point. &#8220;The energy looks familiar,&#8221; says Rep. David Brat, who toppled then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in the 2014 Virginia Republican primary. But there are differences. &#8220;Over half the energy from the Tea Party was against our own party leadership, and that&#8217;s not what&#8217;s going on here,&#8221; he said.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnti-Trump protesters have also focused some attention on Democratic representatives, \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fvideo\u002Fnational\u002Fprotesters-rally-outside-chuck-schumers-home\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F01\u002Fd0d95e50-e88f-11e6-903d-9b11ed7d8d2a_video.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ewith hundreds gathering in front of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer&#8217;s\u003C\u002Fa\u003E New York home to challenge him to stand up to Trump.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ECome Feb. 27th, Congress will be back in session and its members shielded by the relative protection of its chambers. Those who rallied at town halls say they&#8217;ll keep working, turning their attention to other forms of organizing. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup &#8220;to show our neighbors that we&#8217;re not just those people they saw on TV, we&#8217;re actually helping our community,&#8221; says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;We&#8217;re out here,&#8221; Plank says. &#8220;You may ignore us, but we&#8217;re not going away.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Nothing Rep. But Sanford said that speaking with some of the attendees caused him to \"look more deeply\" at the way the bill would treat pre-existing conditions."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"There's a degree of directness that I haven't really seen before,\" he said. \"I've seen pieces of it, but not with such energy.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["For Republican members of Congress who rode the Tea Party wave to Washington, the local resistance movement created a sense of deja vu--but only to a point. \"The energy looks familiar,\" says Rep. David Brat, who toppled then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in the 2014 Virginia Republican primary. But there are differences. \"Over half the energy from the Tea Party was against our own party leadership, and that's not what's going on here,\" he said."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Anti-Trump protesters have also focused some attention on Democratic representatives, ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.washingtonpost.com\u002Fvideo\u002Fnational\u002Fprotesters-rally-outside-chuck-schumers-home\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F01\u002Fd0d95e50-e88f-11e6-903d-9b11ed7d8d2a_video.html"},"content":["with hundreds gathering in front of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer's"]}," New York home to challenge him to stand up to Trump."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Come Feb. 27th, Congress will be back in session and its members shielded by the relative protection of its chambers. Those who rallied at town halls say they'll keep working, turning their attention to other forms of organizing. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup \"to show our neighbors that we're not just those people they saw on TV, we're actually helping our community,\" says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"We're out here,\" Plank says. \"You may ignore us, but we're not going away.\""]}],"plain":"Nothing Rep. Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd roared back: &#8220;What are you going to do about it?&#8221; Lance was elected in 2008, but Ed Marceski said the event was the first time he felt the need to confront his representative. Wearing a T-shirt with the word &#8220;Resist,&#8221; Marceski, who voted for Hillary Clinton, said Trump&#8217;s election had energized him. &#8220;I&#8217;m 61 years old, and this is the first time we&#8217;ve done something like this,&#8221; Marceski said. &#8220;It won&#8217;t be the last.&#8221; Lance is one of a wave of Republican senators and representatives who have been met by vocal crowds at events held in their district during this week&#8217;s congressional recess, a groundswell that has led some to see a left wing echo of the outrage that propelled the Tea Party. Mobilized by their concern over the GOP&#8217;s promise to repeal the Affordable Care Act, as well as questions about Trump&#8217;s immigration policies and his ties to Russia, protesters have confronted Rep. Jason Chaffetz in Utah, Rep. Mark Sanford in South Carolina, Rep. Scott Taylor in Virginia, Rep. Jim Jordan in Ohio, and Sen. Tom Cotton in Arkansas. Support for the ACA has grown since the threat of repeal, with 48% of Americans saying they favor the law compared to 42% who oppose it, according to a Kaiser Health Tracking Poll released Feb. 24. The approval level is the highest since Kaiser began the poll in 2010. In Iowa, Anna Plank drove an hour and a half to confront Senator Joni Ernst. &#8220;People were yelling in the hallway, people were chanting &#8216;do your job,'&#8221; Plank said after the veterans&#8217; event in Maquoketa. &#8220;We don&#8217;t feel heard, we don&#8217;t feel listened to,&#8221; Plank said. &#8220;It doesn&#8217;t feel like this country this was meant to be.&#8221; A spokesperson for Ernst says the senator &#8220;believes it&#8217;s critical that she hears from folks across the state directly,&#8221; and said that Ernst holds 99 county tours in her state every year, including three public events last month. Plank is an organizer of Indivisible Iowa, one of hundreds of grassroots organizations that have sprung up around the country in opposition to Trump&#8217;s policies and GOP policy planks like the repeal of the ACA. Indivisible started as an online how-to guide for citizens to effectively pressure their representatives, written by former congressional staffers who witnessed the rise of the Tea Party in 2009. In the months since the election, Indivisible has morphed into an organizing engine for the Trump opposition, pumping energy and information into local resistance efforts. White House officials have described the anti-Trump protests as &#8220;astro-turf,&#8221; coordinated national efforts masquerading as grassroots pushback. Trump dismissed the boisterous town halls as &#8220;so-called angry crowds&#8221; and suggested on Twitter that they were &#8220;planned by liberal activists.&#8221; White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer called the protesters a &#8220;small, loud group of people&#8221; on Wednesday, adding that &#8220;just because they&#8217;re loud doesn&#8217;t mean that there are many.&#8221; It&#8217;s difficult to tell exactly how many people are involved with the protests, but they have been building momentum. Indivisible has more than 5,000 verified groups, and 678 registered events with more than 12,000 RSVPs. The website has been viewed more than 15.5 million times since the election, and the Indivisible Guide has been viewed 2 million times on the site, according to the group&#8217;s organizers. All of the Indivisible organizers interviewed by TIME in four states say they are first-time organizers, new to political activism, and are not being paid. &#8220;I wish I was being paid,&#8221; says Plank, an elementary school teacher currently raising her daughters full time, adding that she was so angry with Trump and Ernst that she didn&#8217;t need a financial incentive. &#8220;They could pay me to not show up.&#8221; In Tennessee, local constituents confronted Republican Rep. Marsha Blackburn during a town hall meeting Tuesday, demanding answers about health care and Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia. &#8220;A lot of our questions were followed by &#8216;I&#8217;ll look into it,'&#8221; says Michelle Bewley, 36, who helped organize the Indivisible group in Blackburn&#8217;s district, a stretch of Middle Tennessee that includes some of Nashville&#8217;s wealthiest suburbs. &#8220;We didn&#8217;t get a lot of clear answers on any of our questions.&#8221; Bewley is a parent, adjunct professor, volunteer and first-time political organizer. When her Indivisible group first started shortly after the election, they had a handful of members. Now, she says they have more than 400 people involved and organize multiple events a week. &#8220;As an individual, if I&#8217;m just one person voicing my opinion, I&#8217;m not going to get heard,&#8221; she says. &#8220;But if we have 100 people voicing the same concerns, it&#8217;s gonna be heard.&#8221; It&#8217;s too early to know if this outrage will be sustained, let alone if it can change outcomes in Congress. But it is already forcing many Republicans to recalibrate their outreach efforts. Of the 59 Republican members of Congress targeted as vulnerable by the DCCC in 2018 elections, only 19 held any sort of constituent event this week, according to a running tally compiled by the TownHallProject. Of those, 17 were &#8220;empty chair&#8221; town halls, tele-town halls (where constituents can call in their questions) or appearances by staff instead of the elected officials. Some Republicans who did show up to meet their constituents said the confrontations turned into productive dialogue. In South Carolina, Sanford lingered to talk to constituents after a boisterous town hall meeting on Saturday. &#8220;Nobody drives out of their way to go to a town hall just to score points,&#8221; Sanford said. &#8220;Let&#8217;s get to the bottom of this.&#8221; Sanford and Senator Rand Paul are co-sponsoring a health care replacement bill that would allow insurers to sell a wider range of policies (including some with lower premiums but limited benefits), allow citizens to sock away more money in tax-free health-care savings accounts, and allow those with pre-existing conditions to keep their coverage as long as they had continuous coverage. The bill, which was endorsed by the House Freedom Caucus earlier this month, turns up the pressure on House Republicans to repeal the ACA. But Sanford said that speaking with some of the attendees caused him to &#8220;look more deeply&#8221; at the way the bill would treat pre-existing conditions. &#8220;There&#8217;s a degree of directness that I haven&#8217;t really seen before,&#8221; he said. &#8220;I&#8217;ve seen pieces of it, but not with such energy.&#8221; For Republican members of Congress who rode the Tea Party wave to Washington, the local resistance movement created a sense of deja vu&#8211;but only to a point. &#8220;The energy looks familiar,&#8221; says Rep. David Brat, who toppled then-House Majority Leader Eric Cantor in the 2014 Virginia Republican primary. But there are differences. &#8220;Over half the energy from the Tea Party was against our own party leadership, and that&#8217;s not what&#8217;s going on here,&#8221; he said. Anti-Trump protesters have also focused some attention on Democratic representatives, with hundreds gathering in front of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer&#8217;s New York home to challenge him to stand up to Trump. Come Feb. 27th, Congress will be back in session and its members shielded by the relative protection of its chambers. Those who rallied at town halls say they&#8217;ll keep working, turning their attention to other forms of organizing. The New Jersey Indivisible group convenes postcard parties to write to local representatives and hosts information sessions on immigration and gerrymandering. The Arkansas Indivisible group makes daily calls to their representatives and organizes local volunteer efforts like a trail cleanup &#8220;to show our neighbors that we&#8217;re not just those people they saw on TV, we&#8217;re actually helping our community,&#8221; says Caitlynn Moses, another first-time organizer. In Iowa, Plank and her fellow Indivisible members have been throwing fake retirement parties for Ernst. &#8220;We&#8217;re out here,&#8221; Plank says. &#8220;You may ignore us, but we&#8217;re not going away.&#8221;"},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003ENothing Rep. Leonard Lance said was going over well. Constituents gathered at a town hall in Branchburg, NJ Feb. 22 weren&#8217;t buying the Republican Congressman&#8217;s answers to questions about health care reform, or the environment, or financial regulation. Each time he acknowledged he was skeptical of President Trump&#8217;s ties to Russia, the packed crowd They were also asked about their libido, answering questions on their sexual activity, arousal, desire, attraction, fantasy, appetite, fulfilment, need for intimacy and more."]},{"tag":"video","attributes":{"controls":"1","videoid":"5225927535001"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The study's authors found that participants with the least-intense training regimes had greater odds of having a high or normal libido than those who trained at the highest intensity. The conclusion, therefore, was that regular exposure to high intensity and endurance exercise was \"significantly\" associated with a lower libido state in men."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"Clinicians who treat male patients for sexual disorders and\u002For council couples on infertility issues should consider the degree of endurance exercise training a man is performing as a potential complicating factor,\" the study's conclusion added."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The research paper, called \"Endurance Exercise Training and Male Sexual Libido,\" was published in the journal ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Medicine &amp; Science in Sports &amp; Exercise"]},"."]}],"plain":"Men who strenuously exercise on a regular basis have a significantly decreased libido than those who engage in lower-intensity exercise, a new study has found. Researchers from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill surveyed 1,100 men aged 18 and older using a questionnaire to ascertain detailed information about their exercise training habits. They were also asked about their libido, answering questions on their sexual activity, arousal, desire, attraction, fantasy, appetite, fulfilment, need for intimacy and more. The study&#8217;s authors found that participants with the least-intense training regimes had greater odds of having a high or normal libido than those who trained at the highest intensity. The conclusion, therefore, was that regular exposure to high intensity and endurance exercise was &#8220;significantly&#8221; associated with a lower libido state in men. &#8220;Clinicians who treat male patients for sexual disorders and\u002For council couples on infertility issues should consider the degree of endurance exercise training a man is performing as a potential complicating factor,&#8221; the study&#8217;s conclusion added. The research paper, called &#8220;Endurance Exercise Training and Male Sexual Libido,&#8221; was published in the journal Medicine &amp; Science in Sports &amp; And it turned out that they didn&rsquo;t, not too many of them. &#8230; The [Swedish] people understand I&rsquo;m right.&#8221; In his original remarks, Trump said an incident had occurred last Friday night in Sweden. He later clarified that he was talking about a Fox News segment that ran that night about immigration in Sweden which alleged there had been a surge in violence in the country. There is no data to suggest that refugees are responsible for more crime in Sweden than other groups and Sweden&#8217;s crime prevention council found that there was no significant increase in crimes between 2015 and 2016. Stephen Colbert gave the signs on those bathrooms a chance to speak their mind on The Late Show on Thursday. In the show&rsquo;s opening scene, The Late Show combined news footage of the announced action with an animated feature that delivered a blunt message for the president. Turns out the signs closely associated with the roll back are not too pleased about the president&rsquo;s latest news. Earlier in the episode, during his monologue, Colbert also played a clip of Matt Lauer asking Trump if Caitlyn Jenner could hypothetically use any bathroom in Trump Tower she chose, to which he said, &#8220;correct.&#8221; Colbert response: &#8220;which is good because right now I&#8217;m guessing a lot of trans people would like to take a dump in Trump&#8217;s lobby.&#8221; As for White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer&#8217;s explanation of the joint action, Colbert had a few words on that. &#8220;Is there a more cowardly phrase than this is a state&#8217;s rights issue.&#8221; Watch the Trump","slug":"donald-trump","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F189091"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=189091"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=189091"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":1342,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Feducation\u002F","name":"Education","slug":"education","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F1342"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=1342"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=1342"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":3876524,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Flate-night-television\u002F","name":"Late Night Television","slug":"late-night-television","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F3876524"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=3876524"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=3876524"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":222712626,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Flate-show-with-stephen-colbert\u002F","name":"late colbert","slug":"stephen-colbert","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F65743"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=65743"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=65743"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":459,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Ftelevision\u002F","name":"Television","slug":"television","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F459"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=459"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=459"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}},{"id":878550,"link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Ftag\u002Ftransgender-rights\u002F","name":"Transgender Rights","slug":"transgender-rights","taxonomy":"post_tag","_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags\u002F878550"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags"}],"about":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Ftaxonomies\u002Fpost_tag"}],"wp:post_type":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fposts?tags=878550"},{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fwp\u002Fv2\u002Fmoney_article?tags=878550"}],"curies":[{"name":"wp","href":"https:\u002F\u002Fapi.w.org\u002F{rel}","templated":true}]}}],{"code":"rest_no_route","message":"No route was found matching the URL and request method","data":{"status":404}}],"wp:meta":[{"bitly_url":"http:\u002F\u002Fti.me\u002F2lROMkb","mt_seo_title":"Colbert on Trump Bathroom Trans Trump","negative_coverage":false,"permalink":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681760\u002Fstephen-colbert-on-trans-bathroom\u002F","amp_link":"http:\u002F\u002Famp.timeinc.net\u002Ftime\u002F4681760\u002Fstephen-colbert-on-trans-bathroom\u002F?source=dam"}],"fortune:featured":[{"size":"landscape","type":"image","visible":false,"image":{"id":4681962,"link":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002Fbrbill.jpg?quality=85","alt":"","caption":"","credit":"","title":"brbill"},"video":[],"structured":false}],"fortune:primary_tag":[{"term_id":3876524,"name":"Late Night Television","slug":"late-night-television","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":9656,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":130,"filter":"raw"}],"fortune:primary_section":[{"term_id":236441,"name":"Newsfeed","slug":"newsfeed","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":15,"taxonomy":"time_section","description":"What's vital and viral from around the web, covering web culture, celebrities, food, internet trends, animals, technology, humor, fashion, sex and more","parent":0,"count":11871,"filter":"raw","all_sections":["entertainment","newsfeed"]}],"fortune:primary_topic":[{}]}},{"id":4680673,"date":"2017-02-24T11:00:18","date_gmt":"2017-02-24T16:00:18","guid":{"rendered":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F?p=4680673"},"modified":"2017-02-23T13:23:00","modified_gmt":"2017-02-23T18:23:00","slug":"james-baldwin-documentary-history","type":"post","link":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4680673\u002Fjames-baldwin-documentary-history\u002F","title":{"rendered":"James Baldwin Documentary \u003Ci\u003EI Am Not Your Negro\u003C\u002Fi\u003E Is the Product of a Specific Moment in History"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThough the Oscar-nominated documentary \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.iamnotyournegrofilm.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EI Am Not Your Negro\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E is a brand new movie, by filmmaker Raoul Peck, it is also a historical document: the narration, delivered in the film by Samuel L. Jackson, was written by James Baldwin, one of America&rsquo;s foremost public intellectuals of the 20th century, who died in 1987. The main source material was a 30-page packet of letters obtained by Peck from Baldwin&rsquo;s youngest sister, Gloria, that were notes for a book project called \u003Cem\u003ERemember This House\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, which Baldwin began to propose in the late 1970s but never got to write.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cem\u003ERemember This Hous\u003C\u002Fem\u003Ee was to be Baldwin&rsquo;s magnum opus, a critique of American society from the viewpoint of the assassination of his friends \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdonate.naacp.org\u002Fpages\u002Fnaacp-history-medgar-evers\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMedgar Evers\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fmalcolmx.com\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMalcolm X\u003C\u002Fa\u003E and \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.thekingcenter.org\u002Fabout-dr-king\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMartin Luther King Jr\u003C\u002Fa\u003E. As Peck aptly notes in the introduction to the film&rsquo;s \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FNot-Your-Negro-Documentary-International-ebook\u002Fdp\u002FB01MTQ1BT1\u002Fref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1486785806&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=i+am+not+your+negro\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ecompanion book\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, what these activists had in common had less to do with race and each man&rsquo;s approach to the Black Liberation Movement, but rather that all three were &ldquo;deemed dangerous&rdquo; and &ldquo;disposable.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESo, though the film provides a provocative analysis of American race relations up to the present day, as a testament to Baldwin&rsquo;s continued relevance, an understanding of the moment when Baldwin began the project can add another layer to the movie&rsquo;s meaning.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBaldwin&rsquo;s straight-no-chaser style of criticism, as captured in his essay collection \u003Cem\u003EThe Fire Next Time,\u003C\u002Fem\u003E had made him a household name more than a decade earlier. As a 1963 \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fcontent.time.com\u002Ftime\u002Fsubscriber\u002Farticle\u002F0,33009,830326-1,00.html\"\u003ETIM\u003C\u002Fa\u003EE cover story about the author and activist noted, &ldquo;in the U.S. today there is not another writer &mdash; white or black &mdash; who expresses with such poignancy and abrasiveness the dark realities of the racial ferment in North and South.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAt the heart of Baldwin&rsquo;s argument was the question of who is responsible for the problem of racism, a point the film makes with Baldwin&rsquo;s use of language. Never one to mince words, he wrote and spoke what Toni Morrison called in \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002Fbooks\u002F98\u002F03\u002F29\u002Fspecials\u002Fbaldwin-morrison.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Ea 1987 remembrance\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of her friend the &ldquo;undecorated truth&rdquo; about the American illusion, which juxtaposed whiteness as American innocence with blackness as sullying American purity hence, &#8220;the Negro Problem.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fnewsletter\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EGet your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ESuch an illusion was based on what Jabari Asim in his book \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FWord-Who-Can-Say-Shouldnt-ebook\u002Fdp\u002FB00CR6WQ7U\u002Fref=sr_1_1?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1486968071&amp;sr=1-1&amp;keywords=asim+the+n+word\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EThe N Word\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E dubbed one of America&rsquo;s &ldquo;founding fictions,&rdquo; the invention of a specific term to define blacks as subhuman and to lend credence to notions of white supremacy. As Asim notes, &ldquo;From the outset, the British and their colonial counterparts relied on language to maximize the idea of difference between themselves and their African captives.&rdquo; Yet it was far more than just a word. Asim demonstrated how over the centuries the N word became the ideological justification that codified American society and its institutions.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EOne of the most striking moments in \u003Cem\u003EI Am Not Your Negro\u003C\u002Fem\u003E comes from a 1963 \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.pbs.org\u002Fvideo\u002F2112495022\u002F\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EPBS interview\u003C\u002Fa\u003E between Baldwin and the esteemed psychologist Kenneth Clark, whose research &mdash; produced with his research partner and wife \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.apa.org\u002Fpi\u002Foema\u002Fresources\u002Fethnicity-health\u002Fpsychologists\u002Fclark.aspx\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EMamie Phipps Clark\u003C\u002Fa\u003E &mdash; had influenced the Supreme Court decision in \u003Cem\u003EBrown v. The Board of Education\u003C\u002Fem\u003E. Baldwin, rejecting America&rsquo;s founding fiction quipped, &ldquo;I am not a &lsquo;nigger,&rsquo; I am a man!&rdquo; He asserted that &ldquo;the future of the country&rdquo; depended on white peoples&rsquo; ability to ask themselves &ldquo;why it was necessary to have a &lsquo;nigger&rsquo; in the first place&rdquo; and why they would have invented that idea.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDespite his harsh criticism, Baldwin remained hopefully optimistic that American equality was achievable. The passage of the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.ourdocuments.gov\u002Fdoc.php?flash=true&amp;doc=97\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ECivil Rights Act\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of 1964 and the \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fourdocuments.gov\u002Fdoc.php?flash=true&amp;doc=100\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EVoting Rights Act\u003C\u002Fa\u003E of 1965 had brought a renewed sense of hope.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut, though Baldwin&rsquo;s message would essentially remain the same for the rest of his life, the world changed around him. The assassination of King in 1968 was the death knell of that period&rsquo;s Civil Rights Movement, and, in the decade that followed, the assassination did not spur any great movement among white Americans to reconsider. Instead, as Carol Anderson has demonstrated in her book \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002FB01D1RUOJU\u002Fref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&amp;btkr=1\" target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EWhite Rage\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, a political backlash against civil rights had ensued, and politicians like Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan would capitalize on opposition to civil rights victories in order to win elections. Meanwhile, Baldwin was being tracked by the FBI; as his FBI file, which spanned the years 1958-1974, attests, he was under continued surveillance.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe film captures Baldwin&rsquo;s sentiments during this time with Jackson narrating, &ldquo;What can I do? Well I&rsquo;m tired.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EWhen Baldwin began work on \u003Cem\u003ERemember This House\u003C\u002Fem\u003E, he had resolved, as he stated in a 1979 \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.c-span.org\u002Fvideo\u002F?170651-1\u002Fjames-baldwin-speech\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Espeech\u003C\u002Fa\u003E at Berkeley, to communicate that, despite the legislative achievements of the Civil Rights Movement, blacks remained ruled by slave codes and that his fallen companions were carrying out a &ldquo;modern day insurrection.&rdquo; In other words, though the three assassinated men at the center of \u003Cem\u003EI Am Not Your Negro\u003C\u002Fem\u003E had given their lives to their own visions of black liberation, the film comes not from a place of simple celebration of the legacy of Evers, X and King, but from a moment when Baldwin saw, as much as ever, the need to point out to white audiences that the work those men had done had \u003Cem\u003Enot\u003C\u002Fem\u003E achieved its aim, and that it was their job &mdash; white Americans &mdash; to make things better.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=OCUlE5ldPvM\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EAs he once put it\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, &ldquo;You always told me &lsquo;It takes time.&rsquo; It&rsquo;s taken my father&rsquo;s time, my mother&rsquo;s time, my uncle&rsquo;s time, my brothers&rsquo; and my sisters&rsquo; time. How much time do you want for your progress?&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EDespite his disillusionment and his view that it was not the responsibility of blacks to fix things, Baldwin continued to use his writing and his voice throughout the 1970s and much of the 1980s as a vehicle for social change &mdash; though the world to which he spoke was a new one. On Dec. 10, 1986, almost a year before his death, Baldwin, during a Q&amp;A session after a National Press Club lecture, insisted that the country institute &ldquo;a white history week; and I&rsquo;m not joking,&rdquo; focused on dispelling the illusions that kept the nation in a constant state of peril.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;History is not the past,&rdquo; stated Baldwin, &ldquo;It is the present. We carry our history with us. We are our history.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2 _10M0Ygc4\"\u003E\u003Ca target=\"_blank\"\u003E\u003Cimg class=\"alignleft\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Flong-view.png?w=150&amp;amp;amp;h=150\" alt=\"The Long View\" width=\"150\" height=\"150\" \u002F\u003E\u003C\u002Fa\u003E\u003Cstrong\u003E\u003Cem\u003EHistorians explain how the past informs the present\u003C\u002Fem\u003E\u003C\u002Fstrong\u003E\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp class=\"column small-12 medium-10 medium-offset-1 large-offset-2 end _10M0Ygc4\"\u003E\u003Cem\u003EArica L. He asserted that the future of the country depended on white peoples ability to ask themselves why it was necessary to have a nigger in the first place and why they would have invented that idea."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Despite his harsh criticism, Baldwin remained hopefully optimistic that American equality was achievable. In other words, though the three assassinated men at the center of ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["I Am Not Your Negro"]}," had given their lives to their own visions of black liberation, the film comes not from a place of simple celebration of the legacy of Evers, X and King, but from a moment when Baldwin saw, as much as ever, the need to point out to white audiences that the work those men had done had ",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["not"]}," achieved its aim, and that it was their job  white Americans  to make things better."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=OCUlE5ldPvM"},"content":["As he once put it"]},", You always told me It takes time. Its taken my fathers time, my mothers time, my uncles time, my brothers and my sisters time. How much time do you want for your progress?\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Despite his disillusionment and his view that it was not the responsibility of blacks to fix things, Baldwin continued to use his writing and his voice throughout the 1970s and much of the 1980s as a vehicle for social change  though the world to which he spoke was a new one. On Dec. 10, 1986, almost a year before his death, Baldwin, during a Q&amp;A session after a National Press Club lecture, insisted that the country institute a white history week; and Im not joking, focused on dispelling the illusions that kept the nation in a constant state of peril."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["History is not the past, stated Baldwin, It is the present. We carry our history with us. We are our history."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"target":"_blank"},"content":[{"tag":"img","attributes":{"src":"https:\u002F\u002Ftimedotcom.files.wordpress.com\u002F2015\u002F02\u002Flong-view.png?w=150&amp;amp;amp;h=150","alt":"The Long View","width":"150","height":"150"},"content":[]}]},{"tag":"strong","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Historians explain how the past informs the present"]}]}]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":["Arica L. Coleman is the author of "]},"That the Blood Stay Pure: African Americans, Native Americans and the Predicament of Race and Identity in Virginia",{"tag":"em","attributes":[],"content":[" and chair of the Committee on the Status of African American, Latino\u002Fa, Asian American, and Native American (ALANA) Historians and ALANA Histories at the Organization of American Historians."]}]}],"plain":"Though the Oscar-nominated documentary I Am Not Your Negro is a brand new movie, by filmmaker Raoul Peck, it is also a historical document: the narration, delivered in the film by Samuel L. Jackson, was written by James Baldwin, one of America&rsquo;s foremost public intellectuals of the 20th century, who died in 1987. The main source material was a 30-page packet of letters obtained by Peck from Baldwin&rsquo;s youngest sister, Gloria, that were notes for a book project called Remember This House, which Baldwin began to propose in the late 1970s but never got to write. Remember This House was to be Baldwin&rsquo;s magnum opus, a critique of American society from the viewpoint of the assassination of his friends Medgar Evers, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. As Peck aptly notes in the introduction to the film&rsquo;s companion book, what these activists had in common had less to do with race and each man&rsquo;s approach to the Black Liberation Movement, but rather that all three were &ldquo;deemed dangerous&rdquo; and &ldquo;disposable.&rdquo; So, though the film provides a provocative analysis of American race relations up to the present day, as a testament to Baldwin&rsquo;s continued relevance, an understanding of the moment when Baldwin began the project can add another layer to the movie&rsquo;s meaning. Baldwin&rsquo;s straight-no-chaser style of criticism, as captured in his essay collection The Fire Next Time, had made him a household name more than a decade earlier. As a 1963 TIME cover story about the author and activist noted, &ldquo;in the U.S. today there is not another writer &mdash; white or black &mdash; who expresses with such poignancy and abrasiveness the dark realities of the racial ferment in North and South.&rdquo; At the heart of Baldwin&rsquo;s argument was the question of who is responsible for the problem of racism, a point the film makes with Baldwin&rsquo;s use of language. Never one to mince words, he wrote and spoke what Toni Morrison called in a 1987 remembrance of her friend the &ldquo;undecorated truth&rdquo; about the American illusion, which juxtaposed whiteness as American innocence with blackness as sullying American purity hence, &#8220;the Negro Problem.&#8221; Get your history fix in one place: sign up for the weekly TIME History newsletter Such an illusion was based on what Jabari Asim in his book The N Word dubbed one of America&rsquo;s &ldquo;founding fictions,&rdquo; the invention of a specific term to define blacks as subhuman and to lend credence to notions of white supremacy. As Asim notes, &ldquo;From the outset, the British and their colonial counterparts relied on language to maximize the idea of difference between themselves and their African captives.&rdquo; Yet it was far more than just a word. Asim demonstrated how over the centuries the N word became the ideological justification that codified American society and its institutions. One of the most striking moments in I Am Not Your Negro comes from a 1963 PBS interview between Baldwin and the esteemed psychologist Kenneth Clark, whose research &mdash; produced with his research partner and wife Mamie Phipps Clark &mdash; had influenced the Supreme Court decision in Brown v. The Board of Education. Baldwin, rejecting America&rsquo;s founding fiction quipped, &ldquo;I am not a &lsquo;nigger,&rsquo; I am a man!&rdquo; He asserted that &ldquo;the future of the country&rdquo; depended on white peoples&rsquo; ability to ask themselves &ldquo;why it was necessary to have a &lsquo;nigger&rsquo; in the first place&rdquo; and why they would have invented that idea. Despite his harsh criticism, Baldwin remained hopefully optimistic that American equality was achievable. The passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 had brought a renewed sense of hope. But, though Baldwin&rsquo;s message would essentially remain the same for the rest of his life, the world changed around him. The assassination of King in 1968 was the death knell of that period&rsquo;s Civil Rights Movement, and, in the decade that followed, the assassination did not spur any great movement among white Americans to reconsider. Instead, as Carol Anderson has demonstrated in her book White Rage, a political backlash against civil rights had ensued, and politicians like Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan would capitalize on opposition to civil rights victories in order to win elections. Meanwhile, Baldwin was being tracked by the FBI; as his FBI file, which spanned the years 1958-1974, attests, he was under continued surveillance. The film captures Baldwin&rsquo;s sentiments during this time with Jackson narrating, &ldquo;What can I do? Well I&rsquo;m tired.&rdquo; When Baldwin began work on Remember This House, he had resolved, as he stated in a 1979 speech at Berkeley, to communicate that, despite the legislative achievements of the Civil Rights Movement, blacks remained ruled by slave codes and that his fallen companions were carrying out a &ldquo;modern day insurrection.&rdquo; In other words, though the three assassinated men at the center of I Am Not Your Negro had given their lives to their own visions of black liberation, the film comes not from a place of simple celebration of the legacy of Evers, X and King, but from a moment when Baldwin saw, as much as ever, the need to point out to white audiences that the work those men had done had not achieved its aim, and that it was their job &mdash; white Americans &mdash; to make things better. As he once put it, &ldquo;You always told me &lsquo;It takes time.&rsquo; It&rsquo;s taken my father&rsquo;s time, my mother&rsquo;s time, my uncle&rsquo;s time, my brothers&rsquo; and my sisters&rsquo; time. How much time do you want for your progress?&#8221; Despite his disillusionment and his view that it was not the responsibility of blacks to fix things, Baldwin continued to use his writing and his voice throughout the 1970s and much of the 1980s as a vehicle for social change &mdash; though the world to which he spoke was a new one. On Dec. 10, 1986, almost a year before his death, Baldwin, during a Q&amp;A session after a National Press Club lecture, insisted that the country institute &ldquo;a white history week; and I&rsquo;m not joking,&rdquo; focused on dispelling the illusions that kept the nation in a constant state of peril. &ldquo;History is not the past,&rdquo; stated Baldwin, &ldquo;It is the present. We carry our history with us. We are our history.&rdquo; Historians explain how the past informs the present Arica L. Coleman is the author of That the Blood Stay Pure: African Americans, Native Americans and the Predicament of Race and Identity in Virginia and chair of the Committee on the Status of African American, Latino\u002Fa, Asian American, and Native American (ALANA) Historians and ALANA Histories at the Organization of American Historians."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHow understanding the 1970s lends an extra layer of meaning to the Oscar-nominated film\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":31116903,"featured_media":4680738,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[190,430944087],"time_section":[262754262],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937773],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4680673"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4680673"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4680673"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4680673\u002Fauthors"}],"fortune:newsletter":[{
