and anonymous sources, before he turned to delivering a version of his usual stump speech.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;A few days ago I called the fake news the enemy of the people, and they are, they are the enemy of the people,&#8221; Trump said Friday morning as part of a 15-minute tirade against the press. &#8220;Because they have no sources, they just make them up when there are none.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EThe President said early in his speech that he doesn&#8217;t view honest journalism as his enemy. &#8220;I&rsquo;m not against the media, I&rsquo;m not against the press, I don&rsquo;t mind bad stories if I deserve them,&#8221; he said. &#8220;And I tell you I love good stories, but I don&rsquo;t get too may of them. But I am only against the fake news media or press.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EBut Trump proceeded to say that the press should not be allowed to use anonymous sources in their coverage of him. &#8220;Let their name be put out there,&#8221; he said. &#8220;&#8216;Donald Trump is a horrible human being.&#8217; Let them say it to my face. &#8230; You will see stories dry up like you&rsquo;ve never seen before.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAnd he criticized journalists invoking the First Amendment as a protection for their work. &#8220;They say we can&rsquo;t criticize their false stories because of the First Amendment. They always bring up the First Amendment,&#8221; Trump said in an exaggerated mocking voice, to laughter from the crowd. &#8220;I love the First Amendment, who uses it more than I do?&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EAfter Trump&#8217;s apparently off-teleprompter remarks about the press, he delivered one of his standard speeches, including references to his campaign and the Democratic primary. He referenced key Administration policies, including cracking down on immigration and repealing the Affordable Care Act. &#8220;We&#8217;re going to repeal and replace Obamacare,&#8221; Trump said. &#8220;From a purely political standpoint, the single best thing we can do is nothing. Let it implode completely&#8230; The Democrats will come to us and beg for help, and it&rsquo;s their problem. But it&rsquo;s not the right thing to do for the American people.&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump has taken the stage at CPAC before, and he credited his past appearances at the event for inspiring his political career. In 2011, he mused onstage about running for President. &#8220;[It was my] first major political speech, and I loved it,&#8221; Trump said Friday. &#8220;I loved the people, I loved the commotion, and then they did these polls where I went through the roof and I wasn&rsquo;t even running&#8230; But it gave me an idea.&#8221; (In reality, Trump \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681865\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-straw-poll\u002F?xid=homepage\"\u003Elost the CPAC straw poll\u003C\u002Fa\u003E each year for the past six years.)\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003ETrump was scheduled to speak in 2016 during his presidential run, but he \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4248043\u002Fdonald-trump-controversial-cpac-speech-cancel\u002F?iid=sr-link3\"\u003Edropped out\u003C\u002Fa\u003E to hold a campaign rally instead. &#8220;I would have come last year but I was worried that I would be, at that time, too controversial,&#8221; Trump said Friday.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["President ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4672974\u002Fdonald-trump-white-house-chaos\u002F"},"content":["Donald Trump"]},"'s speech at the ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681503\u002Fdonald-trump-cpac-conservatives-alt-right\u002F"},"content":["Conservative Political Action Conference"]}," quickly turned into a media-bashing session as he took aim at \"",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ffortune.com\u002F2017\u002F02\u002F13\u002Fapple-ceo-tim-cook-fake-news-killing-minds\u002F"},"content":["fake news"]},"\" and anonymous sources, before he turned to delivering a version of his usual stump speech."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["\"A few days ago I called the fake news the enemy of the people, and they are, they are the enemy of the people,\" Trump said Friday morning as part of a 15-minute tirade against the press. \"Because they have no sources, they just make them up when there are none.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The President said early in his speech that he doesn't view honest journalism as his enemy. \"Im not against the media, Im not against the press, I dont mind bad stories if I deserve them,\" he said. \"And I tell you I love good stories, but I dont get too may of them. But I am only against the fake news media or press.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["But Trump proceeded to say that the press should not be allowed to use anonymous sources in their coverage of him. \"Let their name be put out there,\" he said. \"'Donald Trump is a horrible human being.' They always bring up the First Amendment,\" Trump said in an exaggerated mocking voice, to laughter from the crowd. \"I love the First Amendment, who uses it more than I do?\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["After Trump's apparently off-teleprompter remarks about the press, he delivered one of his standard speeches, including references to his campaign and the Democratic primary. He referenced key Administration policies, including cracking down on immigration and repealing the Affordable Care Act. \"We're going to repeal and replace Obamacare,\" Trump said. \"From a purely political standpoint, the single best thing we can do is nothing. Let it implode completely... The Democrats will come to us and beg for help, and its their problem. But its not the right thing to do for the American people.\""]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump has taken the stage at CPAC before, and he credited his past appearances at the event for inspiring his political career. But it gave me an idea.\" (In reality, Trump ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681865\u002Fcpac-donald-trump-straw-poll\u002F?xid=homepage"},"content":["lost the CPAC straw poll"]}," each year for the past six years.)"]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Trump was scheduled to speak in 2016 during his presidential run, but he ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4248043\u002Fdonald-trump-controversial-cpac-speech-cancel\u002F?iid=sr-link3"},"content":["dropped out"]}," to hold a campaign rally instead. \"I would have come last year but I was worried that I would be, at that time, too controversial,\" Trump said Friday."]}],"plain":"President Donald Trump&#8216;s speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference quickly turned into a media-bashing session as he took aim at &#8220;fake news&#8221; and anonymous sources, before he turned to delivering a version of his usual stump speech. &#8220;A few days ago I called the fake news the enemy of the people, and they are, they are the enemy of the people,&#8221; Trump said Friday morning as part of a 15-minute tirade against the press. &#8220;Because they have no sources, they just make them up when there are none.&#8221; The President said early in his speech that he doesn&#8217;t view honest journalism as his enemy. &#8220;I&rsquo;m not against the media, I&rsquo;m not against the press, I don&rsquo;t mind bad stories if I deserve them,&#8221; he said. &#8220;And I tell you I love good stories, but I don&rsquo;t get too may of them. But I am only against the fake news media or press.&#8221; But Trump proceeded to say that the press should not be allowed to use anonymous sources in their coverage of him. &#8220;Let their name be put out there,&#8221; he said. &#8220;&#8216;Donald Trump is a horrible human being.&#8217; Let them say it to my face. &#8230; You will see stories dry up like you&rsquo;ve never seen before.&#8221; And he criticized journalists invoking the First Amendment as a protection for their work. &#8220;They say we can&rsquo;t criticize their false stories because of the First Amendment. They always bring up the First Amendment,&#8221; Trump said in an exaggerated mocking voice, to laughter from the crowd. &#8220;I love the First Amendment, who uses it more than I do?&#8221; After Trump&#8217;s apparently off-teleprompter remarks about the press, he delivered one of his standard speeches, including references to his campaign and the Democratic primary. He referenced key Administration policies, including cracking down on immigration and repealing the Affordable Care Act. &#8220;We&#8217;re going to repeal and replace Obamacare,&#8221; Trump said. &#8220;From a purely political standpoint, the single best thing we can do is nothing. Let it implode completely&#8230; The Democrats will come to us and beg for help, and it&rsquo;s their problem. But it&rsquo;s not the right thing to do for the American people.&#8221; Trump has taken the stage at CPAC before, and he credited his past appearances at the event for inspiring his political career. In 2011, he mused onstage about running for President. &#8220;[It was my] first major political speech, and I loved it,&#8221; Trump said Friday. &#8220;I loved the people, I loved the commotion, and then they did these polls where I went through the roof and I wasn&rsquo;t even running&#8230; But it gave me an idea.&#8221; (In reality, Trump lost the CPAC straw poll each year for the past six years.) Trump was scheduled to speak in 2016 during his presidential run, but he dropped out to hold a campaign rally instead. &#8220;I would have come last year but I was worried that I would be, at that time, too controversial,&#8221; Trump said Friday."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003E&#8220;They are the enemy of the The Supreme Court Has Sided with Her."},"content":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThe family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a \u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.aclumich.org\u002Farticle\u002Fscotus-rules-unanimously-behalf-michigan-girl-cerebral-palsy-who-was-prevented-bringing\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ESupreme Court ruling in their favor\u003C\u002Fa\u003E as a victory for all children with disabilities.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Ca href=\"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-court-dog-idUSKBN1611Y6\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003EEhlena Fry\u003C\u002Fa\u003E, now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights &mdash; some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl&#8217;s school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlena&rsquo;s side for most of the day.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that,&rdquo; Ehlena&#8217;s mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. &ldquo;At school, where it was really most important for her to be accepted, which was key to her development, they essentially said no. Nobody deserves to be treated this way.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cfigure class=\"inline-custom-size alignnone \"\u003E\u003Cimg data-attachment-id=\"4681826\" data-permalink=\"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002F4681179\u002Fsupreme-court-service-dog-ehlena-fry\u002Fehlena-and-wonder-on-steps\u002F\" 427px\"\u003E\n\u003Cfigcaption class=\"image-caption\" style=\"max-width:427px\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"credit\" \u003EPhoto courtesy ACLU\u003C\u002Fspan\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigcaption\u003E\u003C\u002Ffigure\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003EEhlena&rsquo;s family made the decision to homeschool her, choosing not to separate her from Wonder, and then filed a federal complaint against \u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003Ethe Napoleon School District and the Jackson County Intermediate School District. A\u003C\u002Fspan\u003Efter several legal back and forths, the case landed before the Supreme Court. The nation&rsquo;s highest court sided with Ehlena in a \u003Ca href=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.supremecourt.gov\u002Fopinions\u002F16pdf\u002F15-497_p8k0.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\"\u003Eruling\u003C\u002Fa\u003E on Wednesday that ultimately streamlines discrimination cases in federal court and allows the Fry family to sue for violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;It&rsquo;s our hope that this will set the precedent that&rsquo;s needed to tear down the barriers,&rdquo; Stacy Fry said. &ldquo;We feel that this really is a victory for our family and all the families with children of differing abilities. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"article-video\"\u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"time-embed time-embed__youtube video-wrapper\" data-provider=\"youtube\" data-url=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=PIfyHn2_lmE\" \u003E\n\u003Cdiv class=\"embed-youtube\"\u003E\u003Ciframe width=\"500\" height=\"281\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FPIfyHn2_lmE?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003C\u002Fdiv\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"s1\"\u003ENeither school district returned requests for comment. Stacy Fry said \u003C\u002Fspan\u003EEhlena no longer needs the help of Wonder, 9, who is retired from his service and spends his days as the girl&rsquo;s companion. The girl&#8217;s mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;He&rsquo;s a companion. He&rsquo;s her sidekick. He&rsquo;s that constant reassurance,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasn&rsquo;t previously able to do. He was that bridge.&rdquo;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n\u003Cp\u003E&ldquo;He was a great teacher,&rdquo; she added.\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n","structured":[{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["The family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a ",{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.aclumich.org\u002Farticle\u002Fscotus-rules-unanimously-behalf-michigan-girl-cerebral-palsy-who-was-prevented-bringing","target":"_blank"},"content":["Supreme Court ruling in their favor"]}," as a victory for all children with disabilities."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":[{"tag":"a","attributes":{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Farticle\u002Fus-usa-court-dog-idUSKBN1611Y6","target":"_blank"},"content":["Ehlena Fry"]},", now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights  some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl's school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlenas side for most of the day."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that, Ehlena's mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. We feel that this really is a victory for our family and all the families with children of differing abilities. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose."]},{"tag":"oembed","attributes":{"raw_html":"&lt;div class=&quot;embed-youtube&quot;&gt;&lt;iframe width=&quot;500&quot; height=&quot;281&quot; src=&quot;https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fembed\u002FPIfyHn2_lmE?feature=oembed&quot; frameborder=&quot;0&quot; allowfullscreen&gt;&lt;\u002Fiframe&gt;&lt;\u002Fdiv&gt;","type":"youtube","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.youtube.com\u002Fwatch?v=PIfyHn2_lmE"},"content":[]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Neither school district returned requests for comment. Stacy Fry said  Ehlena no longer needs the help of Wonder, 9, who is retired from his service and spends his days as the girls companion. The girl's mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["Hes a companion. Hes her sidekick. Hes that constant reassurance, she said. Hes given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasnt previously able to do. He was that bridge."]},{"tag":"p","attributes":[],"content":["He was a great teacher, she added."]}],"plain":"The family of a Michigan girl with cerebral palsy who was barred from bringing her service dog to school is hailing a Supreme Court ruling in their favor as a victory for all children with disabilities. Ehlena Fry, now 13, used to heavily rely on her Goldendoodle named Wonder to balance, open doors and turn off lights &mdash; some of the daily tasks she struggled with because she has a severe form of cerebral palsy which affects her legs, arms and body. But in 2009, when Ehlena was 5, the girl&#8217;s school district said her hypoallergenic and certified service dog was not allowed. While the school district slightly bowed to pressures from the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan, which advocated on her behalf, the civil rights group said Wonder was still prohibited from being by Ehlena&rsquo;s side for most of the day. &ldquo;It was devastating as a parent to see a child go through that,&rdquo; Ehlena&#8217;s mother Stacy Fry told TIME on Thursday. &ldquo;At school, where it was really most important for her to be accepted, which was key to her development, they essentially said no. Nobody deserves to be treated this way.&rdquo; Photo courtesy ACLU Ehlena&rsquo;s family made the decision to homeschool her, choosing not to separate her from Wonder, and then filed a federal complaint against the Napoleon School District and the Jackson County Intermediate School District. After several legal back and forths, the case landed before the Supreme Court. The nation&rsquo;s highest court sided with Ehlena in a ruling on Wednesday that ultimately streamlines discrimination cases in federal court and allows the Fry family to sue for violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act. &ldquo;It&rsquo;s our hope that this will set the precedent that&rsquo;s needed to tear down the barriers,&rdquo; Stacy Fry said. &ldquo;We feel that this really is a victory for our family and all the families with children of differing abilities. For us, it really means that we did the right thing. It was not in vain. We had a bigger purpose.&rdquo; Neither school district returned requests for comment. Stacy Fry said Ehlena no longer needs the help of Wonder, 9, who is retired from his service and spends his days as the girl&rsquo;s companion. The girl&#8217;s mother credits Wonder with teaching her daughter everything she needs to complete tasks on her own. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s a companion. He&rsquo;s her sidekick. He&rsquo;s that constant reassurance,&rdquo; she said. &ldquo;He&rsquo;s given her the confidence to navigate her environment more independently. Socially and emotionally, he has given her so much confidence to do the things that she wasn&rsquo;t previously able to do. He was that bridge.&rdquo; &ldquo;He was a great teacher,&rdquo; she added."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EHes a companion. Hes her sidekick. Hes that constant reassurance&#8221;\u003C\u002Fp\u003E\n"},"author":97824220,"featured_media":4681180,"comment_status":"closed","ping_status":"closed","sticky":false,"format":"standard","categories":[1],"tags":[490,11110,430939235],"time_section":[204777754],"money_section":[],"time_topic":[],"primary_time_section":[430937772],"primary_money_section":[],"primary_time_topic":[],"paid":false,"display_modified_time":false,"_links":{"self":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179"}],"collection":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts"}],"author":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fauthor"}],"wp:featuredmedia":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Ffeaturedmedia"}],"wp:term":[{"taxonomy":"category","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fcategories?post=4681179"},{"taxonomy":"post_tag","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftags?post=4681179"},{"taxonomy":"topic","embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Ftopics?post=4681179"}],"wp:meta":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fmeta"}],"wp:attachment":[{"embeddable":false,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fmedia"}],"fortune:featured":[{"embeddable":true,"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Ffeatured"}],"fortune:related":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Frelated"}],"fortune:authors":[{"href":"http:\u002F\u002Ftime.com\u002Fwp-json\u002Fti-api\u002Fv1\u002Fposts\u002F4681179\u002Fauthors"}],"fo A new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that 25% of overdose deaths are from heroin, which is three times the proportion in 1999 (8%). Overall, the age-adjusted rate of drug overdose deaths in 2015 at 16.3 per 100,000 was more than 2.5 times the rate in 1999, when it was 6.1 per 100,000. Adults between the ages of 45 and 54 had the highest rates of overdose deaths in 2015, and the rates are increasing among non-Hispanic white people, nearly 3.5 times the rate in 1999, according to the CDC. Read TIME&#8217;s cover story: Why America Can&rsquo;t Kick Its Painkiller Problem Researchers acknowledged that several factors could affect death rate measurement, including but not limited to the fact that drug overdose deaths can involve multiple drugs. Heroin, however, has been a growing concern in the U.S. The CDC noted in 2015 that heroin use has increased among both men and women across most age ages and income level."},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003Cp\u003EThree times the proportion in Streep has racked up a number of Oscar nods since 1979, when she was first nominated for her role in The Deer Hunter. Although she lost that year to Maggie Smith, Streep came back the next year and won Best Supporting Actress for her performance in Kramer vs. Kramer. By 2012, when she won the Oscar for Best Actress for playing Margaret Thatcher in The Iron Lady, Streep had been nominated 17 times. &#8220;When they called my name I had this feeling I could hear half of America going, &#8216;Oh no. Oh, come on. Why? Her. Again,&#8217; you know?&#8221; Streep said while accepting the award. &#8220;But, whatever.&#8221; If Streep wins for Florence Foster Jenkins, she will tie Katharine Hepburn for most acting awards ever, with four.
